text:
rosalvina is 52-years-old and has two children who are now adults. she is a member of the group “l. nueva luz” (the new light) which is mad. up of 8 hard-working residents of the “zona del señor d. los milagros,” or the zone of our lord of miracles in the comas district. her fellow group members elected her to be be president of the board of directors of the group. fifteen years ago, she began working as a seamstress in various businesses. she began making all kinds of curtains and blouses, especially for girls. with her work she has been able to buy her tools and help support the household expenses. she would very much like to become more independent and have her own shop in her house. the loan she is requesting will be invested in part in the purchase of materials in order to be able to advance her goal of having a small sewing shop in her house. the other part will be used for the purchase of cloth for making towels for drying.

translated from spanish by anna ruby waxham blackwell, kiva volunteer

ana is 41 years old, she has a partner and two daughters who are 4 and 10 years old. she learned her butchering skills because she she needed to earn money for her family, since her partner's income as a day laborer were not enough to cover household expenses. since her partner got at least one day off of work, they took advantage of this day and dedicated it to developing butchering skills. she has been doing this every 15 days and thanks to god she has been able to generate additional income for her family. 

they buy animals to butcher from their local community, most of the time from local producers and other times she goes to the livestock plazas in the city, but this costs her extra money because she has to pay for transportation so that she can get the animals back to her house. 

the loan she is asking for from fundacion campo is to pay the balance with another institution and the rest she will use to purchase livestock for her butcher shop because a good opportunity has presented itself to her. many of her customers are asking her for her cuts of meat and other cuts that she doesn't have as often because it is difficult to purchase a cow because it is much more expensive than a pig. 

with this investment, her business will grow, and there will surely be more work but by making smart purchases she will be able to earn higher profits and to generate a higher income that will help her to guarantee economic stability for her family. it will also guarantee the satisfaction and retention of her customers and that she is able to live in a different way.  today, their current income doesn't allow them to purchase even enough of the basic necessities for herself and her two daughters and her older daughter is going to school now and has school costs, and the younger daughter will also have school costs soon and they want her to go to school. 

in the future, they hope that their business continues to improve and they can do it more than every 15 days, but rather, once a week so that their daughters can study and continue to get ahead in life and to have a professional career, as well as make improvements to her house because they would like a house made of brick but currently it is made of laminate.

as a married parent of six children, elsa works hard to support her family.

she has a bakery business in the philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store. elsa is borrowing php 30,000 through nwtf to  purchase flour, yeast, margarine, butter, sugar, etc. for her bakery business.

elsa has been sustaining her business activities through her past 25 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

lovincer's group is comprised of three hard-working women. lovincer is 17 years old and lives in the town of kalisizo in the masaka region of uganda. for the past two years, lovincer has been working hard to manage her fresh food business. 

to help expand her business, lovincer has requested a loan of 500,000 ugandan shillings from brac uganda. the loan will be used to buy more raw fresh food such as raw bananas to sell, and will help lovincer to generate greater profits and take care of her young sisters and her mother. lovincer hopes that in the future she will be able to own a retail shop. 

lovincer is a member of brac's empowerment and livelihood for adolescents (ela) program. in addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

bernadith lives a simple life in albuera, leyte. she is 46 years old, married, and has a six-year-old child. she and her husband support their family through a buying and selling business. they have been in this business for six years. thus, they work hard to obtain an income for the family.

bernadith wants to have a good and safe toilet facility. so she is asking for a loan through kiva's field partner cevi, which offers financial assistance for safe water and good sanitation. with this loan, she will buy materials for building such as hollow blocks, cement, sand, gravel, deformed bar, coco lumber, tie wire, pvc elbow, pvc tee, adhesive, floor drain and door accessories.

with the help of this loan, bernadith and her family will have a comfortable toilet facility for their living.

gemma is a 38-year-old farmer from barangay san fernando, laur, nueva ecija. she is happily married to mr. renato and blessed with five children who are still pursuing their studies. she engaged in the farming industry where she plants rice grains for almost four years. they deliver it to rice dealers around their town.

she is a good client of alalay sa kaunlaran (aski), inc. for about two years. she has been granted a loan of php 30,000 under the agri-loan program of aski. her loan will be used to buy different vegetable seeds to plant and fertilizer for the easy growth of their crops. she believes that with the help of aski, she will have a hectare of land.

la señora  irma es socia del  banco comunal “nueva flor”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de ilave, provincia de el collao, departamento de puno, ella tiene 30 años de edad, estado civil casada y no tiene hijos, irma estudio secundaria completa, vive en el centro poblado de rosa cami.

la señora trabaja con el movimiento manuela ramos hace varios años es socia fundadora, su préstamo inicial fue de s/. 300.00 nuevos soles, la señora  se dedica a la venta de ganado menor, en la ferias semanales de la zona.

en este momento ella solicito un préstamo de s/. 500.00 nuevos soles, este dinero lo invertirá en la compra de ganado menor para engorde.

su mayor deseo continuar trabajando y así poder ampliar su negocio.

a ella le gustan los ahorros y las charlas.

everline, pictured above, is a group leader and is representing her group, formed by 12 farmers in matete district, kenya.

she joined one acre fund for the first time in 2010 and decided to represent her group because she wanted to help more farmers. she is married and has four children.

with a portion of this loan, everline will not only purchase maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming harvesting season, but also a solar light. receiving a solar light as part of her loan means that now she will be able to have light during the night and have somewhere to charge her phone.

everline plans to use the profits she gains this year to send her children to school.

in total everline’s group will use the inputs received from this loan to plant a total of 4.25 acres of land. they will also receive a total of nine solar lights.

mercideta is 60 years old and married with two children. she works very hard to provide for them.

mercideta runs a general store in the philippines and requested a 10,000 php loan through nwtf to buy items to sell like canned goods, personal care products, noodles, drinks, spices, shampoo, and other snack foods. she has been in this business for five years.

in the future, mercideta would like to save money to expand her business.

rosa is a hardworking mother and an upstanding woman, who lives in her own home along with her son franco, who is 11 years old.  rosa has a business selling shoes, and on the weekends she sells creole food from the door of her house.  both of these businesses are doing very well.  but the most important business for her is the shoe selling business; it is profitable, since she has many customers who always order her merchandise.  for this reason, she is constantly going to the wholesale market in the center of lima, where she can find a variety of shoes at affordable prices.  in the future she wants to acquire a stall in a market where she can sell her shoes, to improve her quality of life.  this is her 16th loan with mfp and she is committed to making all of her payments on time so she can avoid future problems with her communal bank, where she is well respected.  with the loan she requests she will buy a greater quantity of shoes with the goal of increasing her inventory and, in this way, having a greater variety of shoes to offer her customers. \r\n\r\n

i made has been engaged in a service business, transporting goods by truck. the usual stuff to be transported are materials to build houses, such as stone, cement, sand, and wood. he started this business around the time he got married, four years ago. in this business pursuit, i made is assisted by two workers who are paid on a daily basis, the amount depending upon the amount of work done during the day.\r\n\r\ntoday i made received contracts for the procurement of stone, cement and sand, to build a store. he needs additional funding to meet customer demand. with his 3mm idr loan, i made can provide building materials quickly, to satisfy the customers. he will use the loan to purchase stone, cement and sand. he hopes his business can thrive and succeed. the profit of this effort will be saved, for venture capital for future endeavors.

samon is the married mother of two children, living in the phnom srouch district of kampong speu province.  

she does rice-planting while her husband is a palm juice maker. with 30 years' experience in this business, she is able to earn up to usd 3 per day and keep usd 1.5 each day as savings.

samon has joined visionfund, kiva’s partner, this cycle as a first-time borrower. she is now applying for a loan to pay her son’s university tuition. 

she hopes this loan will enable her to keep her son in tertiary education until graduation and also help relieve the financial burden for her family.  thereby she can sustain and grow her business.

he was born in namaacha, maputo province. he is 25 years old and married. he is the father of an underage son and maintains her sister, who lives with him. he has been working for a water company for more than four years. with the salary he earns, he covers the home expenses.

with this loan, he plans to buy construction materials such as sand, cement, zinc sheets and gravel to continue the works. this is his fourth loan from hluvuku. he used the previous ones for the same activity.

in the future, he plans to build a pen to raise chickens and sell them, and open a commercial establishment. his biggest challenge is to finish the construction works.

mr. benoit represents the group neerwata 06 sapone. a married man, he is the father of four children. the oldest is 30 years old, and the youngest is 21. none goes to school. he has five persons to support. mr. benoit has been working in agriculture for 35 years. he gets his supplies from nearby villages. he wants to purchase a motorized pump. with his profit, he wants to raise livestock. his ambition is to ensure his children’s future. \r\n\r\n

ligia is an honest and responsible person. she is 43 years old, and has two children in her care who are 14 and 12 years old. she has worked for more than 30 years selling fruits and vegetables such as chayote, sour oranges, lemons, annatto,  onions, and sweet peppers. this is her 24th loan cycle, and this time the loan is to supply her business by buying annatto, chayote, lemons, and sour oranges so that she can grow her business and keep it on its feet, and earn more income.

tatu is a married woman with three children; two of her children are in school and one is still very young. she owns a house that has neither piped water nor electricity. 

tatu operates a charcoal business, selling at the market to her local customers. she dreams of expanding her business in the future.

with the kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

mrs. gloria marina is a 55-year-old woman from managua. she is a single mother with a child who is still in college. she has worked as a cook at one of the state universities for 20 years.

at this time, she needs a loan to buy block, cement, and labor to build an addition, since one of her dreams is to have a house with all the suitable living conditions. 

she trusts in god that kiva investors will finance her loan through ceprodel, since this is the only way she will be able to achieve her dreams for her family’s life.

modesta, from san pedro province in isabela, is  married to rogelio. she is a vendor. she explains that she has loyal customers because she always provides good service. she is a hard-working person, responsible and very honest. her dream is to have her own store. with time, sacrifice and hard work, she was able to reach her goal. she is now applying for a loan to expand her business. in this way, she expects to be able to continue to grow her business and to offer better service to her customers.

analita is 40 years old and married with four children.

she earns a living by farming sugarcane in the philippines. analita is borrowing php 26,000 through nwtf to pay for the laborers' salaries in harvesting sugarcane and for land preparation.

analita has been farming sugarcane for five years and earns additional income from her general store.

she is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

marlene, who is 40, is a single mother.  she has lived for the past three years in the house which she bought together with her 2 daughters, gabriela and yovana.  she owns 4 purebred cows and declares "my animals are my most prized possession".  she tends them with great care every morning since she obtains an average of 36 litres a day from them.  she says that if her cows become pregnant, she sells any male calves or bulls which they may have at the cattle market in the city of jauja.  this is because most of her earnings come from milk production and one of the major producers of tinned goods buys the milk from marlene\'s cows every day.  as a result, she feels happy and wants to increase her income.  she has already started to grow her own good quality alfalfa to eat and, now that her cows are pregnant and their production has fallen, she is thinking of buying an additional purebred cow so as to maintain the same level of production and produce more litres of milk, which she thinks is possible.  she belongs to the "las abejitas" (the beehives) solidarity group and this will be her second loan with mfp.  she is grateful for the opportunity to make progress which they given her, and so she will begin to use the loan to improve her business.  marlene will invest money in the purchase of a dairy cow because she does not want to reduce her level of production.\r\n\r\n

thea, 21, is single and resides with his mother in kampong cham province, cambodia. he has been employed in a rubber plantation for more than two years, earning approximately usd 4 per day. in order to improve his family’s living conditions, thea wants to run an additional business. due to lack of capital, thea is requesting a loan of usd 1000 to purchase farmland to use for cassava cultivation. this money will help him acquire the security to start the new business and generate more income to support the family. in the future, he would like to purchase more farmland to cultivate rubber and rebuild his present house to make it bigger and more comfortable for his family’s living conditions.\r\n

melanie t., from the town of sto. niño, is 29 years old, married and has two children aged six and five. to make a living, melanie owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting rice for sale.

melanie joined cevi to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. she also likes its microinsurance program. melanie is requesting a loan of 8000 php to purchase seeds, fertilizers and farming equipment. she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

tete ensemble bois dioute was created in february 2013, under the leadership of  delianne (on the right). joseph (middle) is the treasurer, and segu (on the left) is the secretary. 

last year, tete ensemble bois dioute members supported medical fees for one of its sick members. this group plays a key role in assisting its members during hard times. 

today, they are looking for a loan to allow members to sell natural medicines. the group received training  and supervision from an ngo. your contribution will improve many families’ life conditions within the group.

itaf has a home business selling blankets. she is 44 years old and has 7 children and a step son. she has a strong, hard working and striving personality. also, a good soul and well mannered interaction with customers as described by her neighbors. her business began 3 years ago with the intention of increasing the family's income. this business helped her provide her step son with an education because his mum died years ago and to support her husband. now she has a small number of blankets and is applying for a loan to purchase more to sell from home. nonetheless, she aspires to have a store where she can present her goods and deal directly with the customers.

she produces fruits and vegetables for sale in the local markets, local educational institutions and health centers. the target clients include school children, patients of the local health centers, the 5 surrounding communities at large, and 1 major urban centre.

she has received farm business skills training based on kraban support foundation\'s teach lending strategy. this methodology involves providing her the needed skills in farm business record keeping, daily sales, profits and working capital and farm produce marketing skills.

she has also acquired training in fruit processing to make fruit juices to sell to school children to help improve their dietary intakes to enable them to be in school.

i am shaheen a., and i was born and brought up in abbotabad, a small mountainous town. after my marriage i had to move to lahore with my husband. i have eight children, two daughters and six sons. all of my sons together operate an embroidered clothes business except the youngest one who studies in grade ten. they started this business with the loan i took from asasah, a microfinance institution. my sons need to expand their business so that they can take on bigger orders and earn more. they will buy an embroidery frame and a peco machine. we need a loan.

gilbert has been running a retail shop for four years. he got the initial capital after selling off his plot. price fluctuations, inflation and inadequate capital to purchase stock are his major challenges. his business goal is to expand his business into new markets. gilbert wants a loan to buy general merchandise such as rice and sugar to sell.

gilbert is a 42-year-old businessman, married with three children living in bundibugyo, uganda. his personal goals are to educate his children to university level, build a permanent house for his family, and buy a car to transport his commodities to his customers.

marietha sends you her thanks for your generosity because her previous loan has greatly enriched her business. she was able to buy products and supplies that she needed in her store. the loan also helped her provide for her family's daily needs and expenditures.

she is very positive that she can improve her business more if lenders let her take out a new loan of 30,000 philippines pesos (php). this new loan will go to additional groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products that she sells. simultaneously, she will be able to sustain the needs of her family through the help of this assistance.

marietha wants her family to always be healthy and free from any form of sickness. she aims to grow her business too. she meets every week with her *co-fellowship members to share stories of her work and to also draw strength and inspiration from the word of god she studies.

* all cct community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

wilmine is 44 years old and she has five children who all go to school. she started a small commercial activity over 10 years ago to take care of her family. she sells grocery products from her home. the revenue from this activity allows her to support her children's education.

wilmine is seeking this loan to bolster her stock of merchandise to sell. in the long term, she hopes to see a boost in her sales.

caleb was born in kisii, kenya and currently resides in nakuru town. he is now pursuing his higher education goals of achieving a general insurance diploma through the college of insurance. he is also employed as sales staff for a social enterprise which links clean energy suppliers with financial institutions. he has been working diligently for the last six months to reach over 250 kenyan households and provide them with clean energy products.

one of the main products caleb sells is the burn jikokoa cookstove, which is a life saving stove that reduces charcoal use by 50%, and creates 60% less smoke, thus helping people to save money and reduce smoke inhalation. he has been able to sell over 250 stoves to kenyan households, which has resulted in extra cash flow for many families to pay school fees, pay off loans, and invest more in their businesses.

caleb plans to use the kiva loan to purchase more jikokoa cookstoves to sell within the rift valley region, and to reach an additional 500 households before the end of the year. the loan will help caleb to raise business capital he would have been otherwise unable to raise, grow his business, and reach thousands of kenyans. not only will the loan benefit caleb’s business, but it will also improve the health of thousands of kenyans, reduce impacts on the environment, and allow families to save over $200 a year.

lucia is a widow mother of five children, 46 years old, and a vendor. she has been selling string beans and cabbage in the market for four years. it’s hard for her to sustain their daily needs because she’s the only one who provides for her children, but she’s doing her best so that she may feed them and sustain their other needs.

lucia wants to sell more vegetables, but her capital is insufficient. for this, she is requesting a loan of php 10,000 to buy a variety of vegetables to sell. the loan will be a big help for her to develop the business and get greater revenue to give enough provisions for her children.

mon’s group lives in a rural village in battambang province in cambodia. mon works as farmer to support her family. in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water.  having a water filter at home will help each of these women and men to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

analynn is 36 years old and married with three children. analynn works very hard to provide for them.

analynn runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 10,000 loan through nwtf to buy items to sell like canned goods, personal care products, and other snack foods.

analynn has been in this business for 3 years.

in the future analynn would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

mercedes is 39 years old, is in a common-law marriage, and has two children from this relationship who are 20 and 17 years old. her children are studying at the university and in high school and her husband is a driver. they live in portoviejo, the capital of manabi, known for many years as the city of the royal tamarinds.

thanks to the loans that she always receives from the group, mercedes continues with her business selling clothing, curtains, sheets, shoes and a variety of other products. she always looks for what is in season in order to have good sales. she sells door to door but also sells from her home. she sells on credit and collects payment each week. for her, this type of sales allows her to sell more since it provides her clients ease of payment.

this loan is to buy shirts, blouses, sandals, sheets, curtains and other merchandise that she sells. her dreams are to provide the best for her children.

determination, passion, and confidence have propelled lilian to where she is now. she is a dairy farmer who also grows crops and keeps poultry. in a portion of her farm, lilian grows tea. lilian enjoys farming for the increased profits she gets. she enjoys the annual bonus paid by the government to the tea planters; however lilian has remained poor since her horticultural farm has failed to produce yields. lilian lives with her family in a remote village in the nyamira region of kenya.

lilian is borrowing this loan so that she can use it to buy farming inputs (fertilizers, pesticides, and herbicides).

being a woman and accessing funds in kenya, especially around nyamira, is very challenging, but lilian feels relieved knowing there are institutions such as kiva that help enterprising women like her. she is always working to improve her family’s living conditions, but her biggest dreams are to become independent and support her family by herself, secure her children’s future, and to buy a home.

your kindness and good will touch the hearts of her family members.

josephine, age 48, raises hogs to be fattened and eventually offered for sale. she manages her business while her husband is busy in their rice field. between the two of them, they are able to support her two children in their studies. with the help and support of her husband, josephine has become confident in running her business successfully. from the profits she earns from her business, josephine is able to help provide for the family's daily necessities and strives to improve their standard of living. 

josephine has paid back her previous loan and is now requesting another loan in the amount of php 20,000, which she will use to buy hog feed and vitamins for her three hogs. she is hopeful that her requested loan funds will help her meet her life goals. in addition, she is grateful for the continuous access of financial services available to her from kiva lenders through aski so that she can continue to ensure the proper growth of her hogs. as a result, she is able to offer her hogs to buyers at higher prices.

through the generated income from her business, she intends to build savings toward ensuring a bright future of her children.

vet is a 48-year-old widowed homemaker with two children. she resides in kampong chhnang province in cambodia. she has mainly been earning income from selling porridge and khmer noodles since 2011. her two children are working in a factory and another one is working as a black blacksmith. vet and her children can earn approximately 14 usd each day. now vet would like to request loan to buy a motorcycle for her son, who works in the factory, to commute to work. this loan will help her son to reduce travelling expenses and have better travelling conditions. in the future, vet is going to expand her business, so she will be able to save money to renovate her house.

leonida d. is from the village of poblacion, iligan city. she is 42 years old. leonida is married and has two adult-aged children. to make a living, leonida owns and operates a specialized retail business, selling a variety of beauty products in the local community. leonida has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately $114 a month from this activity.

in 2008, leonida joined hspfi to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. leonida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 php from hspfi. leonida is requesting a new loan of 11,000 php which will be used to invest in expanding her business. this will be her 4th loan from hspfi. she plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

about hspfi:

hspfi is one of the accredited partners of opportunity international in the philippines. it is based in cagayan de oro city and is reaching out to the poor households of northern mindanao.

*note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva.  given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

silvina is a 60-year-old married woman with five children; one child is still in school. she is a very hard working entrepreneur.

silvina has a tailoring business in the philippines. silvina requested a php 10,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy additional materials like fabric, threads, needles, etc. for her business.

silvina has been in this business for 18 years. silvina would like to save money to expand her business to secure the future of her family.

junita is applying for a loan of $ 1000.00 to improve her business. she is married. she is running a business in front of her house by doing computer services. she is making a good income from computer services and she wants to apply for a big loan for the future. she is living in a town near by the main road; so many people come to fix their computers. she opened her business in 2002 with her own working capital.

rolanor is a married woman with four children. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur. rolanor is 39 years old and has three children who are currently in school.

rolanor has a business buying and selling ready-to-wear in the philippines. 

rolanor requested a php 13,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy more stock of ready-to-wear to sell to her customers.

rolanor has been in this business for 6 years. in the future, rolanor would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

willington is a ugandan male, aged 50 years, who needs a loan to buy sodas for resale. this retail shop owner hails from the kyenjojo district and is the father of four children between the ages of 24 and 8. having had this business for 10 years, he dreams of growing into a wholesale business and educating his children.

bebelyn is 30 years old, married with three children, who are all in school. she is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

bebelyn has a business selling dried fish in the philippines. bebelyn requested a php 10000 loan amount through nwtf in order to buy more dried fish to sell.

bebelyn has been in this business for six years. in the future, bebelyn would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

wani is a 28 year old mother and is married with one girl aged 5 years. her husband darman is a fisherman, earning about $5 in a day. to supplement her husband's income, wani makes and sells various cooked foods. from this business, she can earn about $2 in a day. wani needs a loan of $125. with this loan she can buy more materials, thus her working capital gets bigger and more or less enables her to double her income eventually. she really wants to have more income so that she can have a better life. she is willing to repay this loan within a period of one year.

badridin is an entrepreneur starting out in the city of gissar. he plans, at 54 years old, to start his own livestock business. badridin has all the things necessary to start this business. his only barrier is his lack of finances. for this reason, badridin has applied for a loan to purchase a few head of young bulls to fatten up and resell. thanks to the loan, badridin will finally be able to start his business and provide his family with a source of income. he really needs your help, and believes that you will provide him with the chance to start his business.

picoaza is a parish of the city of portoviejo where most of its inhabitants work in informal commerce. its traditional feasts of san pedro and san pablo attract many people from inside and outside of the city for their majesty and way of celebrating.
melissa lives here. she is 21 years old, has a domestic partner and a 5 year old daughter who goes to school. her partner is a merchant. she is part of this group who decided to join and apply to loans they hope will improve their businesses, which they were not able to finance after the earthquake.
melissa is a hardworking woman who helps her partner to move ahead, always thinking of her family's future. this is why she will give this loan to him to improve his business. every day, he goes around the streets and sells underwear and clothes in general. also, on weekends he goes to neighboring cantons in order to sell a little more in certain occasions. when there are fairs, melissa comes with him to spend time together and sell a little more.
this loan is to buy t-shirts, pants and underwear. this is her first loan cycle in the credit group, and she hopes to continue having the support of the loans for a long time.

dorina is a member of the "mujeres luchadoras" ("battling women") community bank. she lives in the peruvian "departamento" of san martin where she earns a living selling various bulk food items. she has a stall in the numero 3 ("number 3") market in tarapoto. she started her business 8 years ago, with help from her niece. because of her dedication and perseverance, the business has grown. when she started, she only had certain types of maize, but now she sells a variety of products including beans of various kinds, lentils, peas, ground coffee, etc.

with the s/.900 (900 peruvian soles), to be repaid in 6 months, dorina will buy wholesale supplies of maize, beans, lentils and peas that she will then sell in smaller lots. she will also buy unprocessed coffee beans that she'll then toast and grind for sale to her regular customers.

dorina, 67, is thoroughly committed to her business, despite her age, because she enjoys operating it and being with her customers. she says that she's always described herself as strong, determined, serene and up for a fight. she wants to have a business at home so that she can enjoy a quiet retirement.

translated from spanish by jere wiseman, kiva volunteer

la señora dorina t. g. es socia del banco comunal “mujeres luchadoras”, vive en el departamento y provincia de san martín y distrito de tarapoto, se dedica a la venta de granos de todas las variedades, en su puesto de venta ubicado en el mercado nº 3 barrio- huayco tarapoto. se inició en el negocio desde hace 8 años, contó con el apoyo de su sobrina. con dedicación y perseverancia ha logrado que el negocio se incremente, ya que cuando se inició solo tenia maíz en grano y maíz chancado, ahora oferta variedad de productos como fríjol, de distintas variedades, lentejas, alverjas, maíz canchita, café molido.

con el préstamo de s/. 900.00, que será devuelto en 6 meses comprará maíz en sacos, fríjol de distintas variedades en sacos, lentejas y alverjas en grandes cantidades, para ser vendidos estos productos por kilos al por menor, además ella compró café en granos que después de ser tostados y molidos oferta a sus clientes que diariamente la visitan.

tiene 67 años, que a pesar de su edad, ella se dedica a este negocio porque le gusta y así se distrae con su clientela. siempre se caracterizó por ser fuerte, perseverante, tranquila y luchadora. ella anhela tener un negocio en su propia casa para así tener una vejez tranquila.

roseline o. is 34 years old, married with three children. her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports the home. roseline sells groceries to make a living. she has been in this business for six years. roseline hopes to own a supermarket in the future. 

her challenge in her business is inadequate funds. she is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 nigerian naira (ngn) to purchase more groceries to sell. this is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profits. she says thanks to kiva lenders.

roseline is a client of lapo (lift above poverty organization). lapo is committed to improving lives in nigeria and africa.

a loan of idr 10,000,000  helps yeni to introduce simple, life-saving technologies such as solar lamps, water filters, and clean cookstoves to the community.
 
yeni was born and raised in the village called soe in west timor, indonesia where the majority of people are farmers. yeni and her husband,  an evangelist, visit remote villages in soe on a weekly basis. during their visit to the villages without electricity, yeni demonstrates a solar lamp to help people stop using dangerous and toxic kerosene lamps.
 
to increase her income, yeni joined kopernik’s tech kiosk network to sell simple life-changing technologies. she will use the loan to buy stock  items and grow her business. one of her dreams is to provide better education for her children. the income from selling technologies will help her increase savings for their future education.

sorn y., 62, is married and lives with one of her children in the kampong chhnang province. she sells desserts and works as a farmer, making us $3 each day, while her husband also does some farming and works as soldier, making about us $3 each day as well. sorn y. is asking for a loan of us $200 to purchase another farmland to grow more rice. she sees this new rice field as a good economic investment and will use it to increase her income and improve her standard of living.\r\n

lilian is the mother of four children and someone who is eager to get into the horticultural market. she is a smallholder dairy and poultry farmer and has been crop farming, too, but for subsistence purposes. she also grows vegetables on a small scale plus fodder for her cows.

the demand in kenya for horticultural products such as fruits and vegetables has grown steadily in recent years. although this produce has become one of the top-traded agricultural products, there is still plenty of room for the market to expand.

lilian has applied for a 80,000 kes loan through kiva's field partner juhudi kilimo to begin growing vegetables on a larger scale so as to enter the commercial market for them. she will rely on other sources of income to make the initial installments on the loan, but in a short time the farm should start yielding greater returns. her profits will be plowed back into it to fuel its growth.

most importantly, lilian’s increased income will raise the living standards of her family.

mr. p. pov is married and has 6 children: 4 sons and 2 daughters. he has been in the fishing business for almost 20 years. he began fishing by learning from the older generation in his family. when not fishing, he raises vegetables, and his wife sells the fish and vegetables in the local market or in other villages.\r\n\r\nhe has received three loans from maxima, which has helped him improve his business. he is requesting another loan in the amount of $400 so he can purchase one fishing boat and fishing net, which will enable him to further improve his business and his income.

emily is 47 years old, married with three children, two of whom in school.

she works hard to provide for her family. she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 13000 loan through nwtf to buy additional items to sell like soap, shampoo, egg, noodles, can goods, etc.

emily has borrowed and paid 5 loans from nwtf before this loan. she has been running the general store for 2 years and also earns an income from pig fattening.

she aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

as a married mother of two children, sylvia works hard to support her family. she has a general store business in the philippines and earns additional income from food vending and clothing sales businesses. 

sylvia is borrowing php 10,000 through nwtf to purchase additional groceries to sell in her general store.

sylvia has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from nwtf and, more recently, through kiva. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream, which is to save enough money to expand her business.

hello kiva community! meet serah, who is a crop and animal farmer, and a mother eager to provide the very best for her family. she states that with her small income, she hasn’t been able to provide sufficient lighting through the electricity in her home. her family has been using kerosene lamps, despite the toxic fumes that put the family at risk of contracting respiratory diseases.

serah is kindly appealing for a loan to buy a solar lantern to provide adequate lighting, enabling her children to read well while at home. with the lantern’s dual charging capability, her husband will also be able to efficiently charge his phone. kindly consider lending to her.

paulo is a married man. he and his wife have three children.

he operates a retail business, where he sells fish. he has been involved in this business for four years. his primary customers are locals.

he is seeking this loan in the amount of 25,000 kes to buy additional fish. his business goal is to have a large-scale business within five years. he hopes that, in the future, he will have a better life. this is his second loan with smep microfinance bank. his previous loan was repaid successfully.

amelia is a married woman who lives a simple life with her family in leyte, philippines. she is a mother four children. out of these four, she has three children to support. her husband raised them through their farm. her husband is of a farmer while amelia makes a living through buying and selling harvested rice. she has been doing this for more than 10 years and is hoping to have more successful years to come to enhance their livelihood. 

amelia uses their profit to provide for their daily expenses such as food, children’s school payments, and other basic needs. with this, she is asking for loans for additional capital to buy more harvested rice from the farmers and sell to the merchants. in this way, amelia’s profit will increase, as well as their livelihood will improve. in the future, she wants to invest other business for their sustainability.

leidy is a very enterprising and creative young woman of just 19 years of age who is bold and smiley. she has a corner shop which she set up out of financial need. she did not want to elaborate why as she doesn't want to incite pity, she just wants a hand to improve her business and move forward with her family. 

leidy is applying for a loan to use for the purchase of products such as cosmetics, snacks, lotions and stationery items, all of which will be new products for her business. she hopes to attract many customers, increase her store's usefulness and make her business sustainable so that in the future she can buy her own home, which is her biggest dream.

alima  is a single mother of three children and none of her children goes to school.   she takes care of additional family members (her grandchildren). she has a business selling charcoal and has been in this business for 10 years. she has applied for a loan of 1,500,000 uganda shillings from mcdt-sacco to buy more bags of charcoal. she generates additional income through rental rooms and selling piped water. \n\nalima works from home seven days out of every week and sells retail.  her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves, and she aspires to become a wholesaler and also to   build more rental rooms.  she decided to join mcdt-sacco because of lower interest charged.  she resides in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. her monthly expenses include school fees for the grandchildren and paying utility bills.

ayesha is 25 years old and resides in rawalpindi, pakistan. her husband owns a printing shop, and he is the guardian of the family and responsible for fulfilling the family's needs. ayesha has started a new beauty salon from which she is also able to contribute income, with her husband's, to their household.

ayesha needs to buy different types of cosmetics supplies such as creams, hair brushes, and other accessories for her beauty salon, but due to financial constraints, she is not able to buy these items for her business. therefore, ayesha has applied for a kiva loan. this loan will help her to buy the necessary items for her business so that she can provide better services to her customers. it will also help her to earn maximum income so she can fulfill the needs of her business and family. ayesha is very grateful to kiva and brac pakistan for this financial assistance.

ky, 42, is a married mother of three school-aged children; she lives in a village in the takeo province of cambodia. she is a rice farmer and has been cultivating rice since 1995 to earn income to support the family’s living. her family income is aided by her husband who is a construction worker.

ky appears in the photo and would like to ask for a loan to purchase a sugar cane juice machine. she believes this loan will allow her to have a new source of income and better support her family.

h. hosiat has her own stall in the big market of ”farovon”, in gafurov, khujand.  she is a widow and a mother of 5 children.

she and her two sons sell different goods in this market.  they have three places of trade.  her elder son travels to istaravshan, khujand to purchase goods for them.  hosiat became a client of microinvest in 2005.  her first loan was for $100.

today, she has a wide assortment of goods.  she sells children’s and men’s shoes and t-shirts, and other kinds of clothes for girls, boys and so on.  her turnover of goods is good.  her trade place is small, but very profitable because it is situated in the passage of the market.

for the coming autumn season she is going to purchase seasonal goods such as warm boots, jackets and warm sport clothes for teenagers.

as a married parent of five children, luz mary works hard to support her family.

she has a business buying and selling rice in the philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening. luz mary is borrowing 18,000 php through nwtf to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell for her business buying and selling rice.

luz mary has been sustaining her business activities through her past 17 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

the 6 members of the gnesouma group are principally married women with an average age of 37 and, on average, 5 children. they mainly live in monogamous families in hamdallaye, one of the popular districts of sikasso town (3rd administrative region of mali). this is their 4th loan from the soro yiriwaso microfinance institution, which they have requested in order to satisfy their customers' needs.

fatoumata is the group member who sells fruit and vegetables. she is standing in the middle of the picture. she plans to use her loan buy baskets of bananas, avocados and fresh tomatoes which she will resell for cash or credit at the hamdallaye market, to a diverse and varied retail clientèle. she expects to make an average monthly profit of 40 000 francs, part of which will be used to pay off the loan and its interest and part of which will be used to build up her savings.

kong’s group lives in a rural village in kompong thom province in cambodia. kong makes a living cultivating rice and he also does extra work as a farmer to support his family.

in his village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help kong safeguard the health of his family, save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

elsa is 42 years old and married. she lives in guipos, zds. for the past ten years, elsa has been a farmer. she earns 50,000 php each month.

elsa is requesting a 30,000 php loan to purchase fertilizer. in the future, she hopes to expand and improve her business.

abida is a 44-year-old married lady and mother of three children. her husband is a government employee with a low salary income. it was very tough for abida to manage her household needs with the small income of her husband. therefore, she decided to help her husband in earning. for this purpose, she started her business of clothing sales, as she buys clothes of different verities from the wholesale market and sells them in her area. 

now she is playing a very important role for her family. currently, she requested a loan of pkr 30,000 from kashf foundation to buy a wide variety of clothes in different colors and designs to attract more customers and expand her inventory. she expects a boost in her earnings with her loan, and plans to spend part of her profits on the betterment of her family members.

esmelida p. is 38 years old. she lives in the suburban zone of fortín d. guayaquil. her dwelling only has light and water, she is a single mother with 2 children, 16 and 12 years old.

it has been difficult being a single mother so 6 years ago, because of her children, she decided to get a loan from her sister who lives abroad. esmelida invested the money in a small stationery store in a place called bahia (place in guayaquil where many informal merchants have small businesses).

she moved the stationery store to her house and started selling clothes and toys. she works from 6:00am to 8:00pm with the help of her mother. criminality in fortín is unstoppable so therefore she closes her business early.

with the loan she will buy a showcase, notebooks, and clothes for her business. in the future she wishes to set up telephone booths at her business.

translated from spanish by lene struck christensen, kiva volunteer

william, who is a goat trader, is a parent with two children living in kyenjojo, uganda. he also does farming to supplement his income. he ventured into business after obtaining working capital from milk hawking, so as to support his children, since he is their only hope for their education. william hopes to engage himself in commercial farming despite the complaints of traveling long distances looking for animals, as well as the poor weather conditions, especially the rainy season where his sales are low. william will use the loan to buy goats to sell.

pictured in the above picture is gladys. she is a farmer who has always tried to empower herself, break barriers, conquer fears, and create pathways to success. she resides with her husband and children in a remote village in kitale. here, she has invested for ten years in dairy farming and poultry and she loves this being her only source of generating an income.

in the modern world, agriculture has become exceedingly dynamic. therefore, making the kind of inputs that are being used in the sector today have been upgraded. on this note, there is a need to use improved farming inputs for effective production. these inputs include high quality seeds, fertilizers, pesticides and herbicides. gladys has borrowed this loan to buy farming inputs such as fertilizers, pesticides and herbicides.

this loan is an opportunity that she has never gotten before. her irregular income and lack of collateral security were the main drawbacks limiting her from accessing a loan in commercial banks. thanks to juhudi kilimo and kiva, the life of gladys and her family will be changed through this loan.

amparo is 69 year old, married woman with five children. she is a very hard working entrepreneur.

amparo has a food vending business in the philippines. she has been in this business for 15 years. amparo requested a php 29,000 loan amount through nwtf in order to buy ingredients for her food production business.

in the future, amparo would like to build and expand her business.

pablo is 54 years old and lives in the municipality of sahagun. he’s the father of two children, a son and a daughter, who think the best of him because he’s a loving and kind father who has worked hard to give them the best. he’s been running his business for five years raising pigs, something that allows him provide for his family.

the economy in colombia is not in the best state so it’s been hard for many people, especially people like pablo who are humble and live in hard areas, but he’s a strong man who never quits, so he wants to increase his clients, sales, and profits. he’s asking for a loan so he can buy pigs and food for them.

he dreams that his children will study at a great college and become professionals.

if you want to know more about the entrepreneurs and the loans from interactuar, you can join the lending team called: “friends of interactuar colombia”: http://www.kiva.org/team/interactuar_colombia

domingo lives with his wife in the city of santa cruz de yojoa. he is a retired teacher having provided his services for over 30 years. he receives a monthly pension and he also provides his services as a transport driver and has his own vehicle.

domingo is requesting the loan to improve the front and roof of the porch of his house. he has lived there for over 30 years with his family and with the passing of the years it has deteriorated. he wants to make improvements to his house to give it a nicer appearance. plus his family will have a place in better shape to live in. domingo will buy cement, gravel, sand and cinder blocks.

domingo hopes that with this loan he can make improvements to the house that he sacrificed so much to buy and slowly improve it with the help of his family. he has the great blessing that his children are very close and carry out projects together to benefit their loved ones.
\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
his dream is to improve his house and that his family remains united.
\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
santa cruz de yojoa, honduras. december 2016

editha is 61 years old and married with seven children.

editha works hard to provide for her family. she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a 5,000 php (philippines pesos) loan through nwtf in order to purchase more items like soap, snack foods, sardines and other groceries.

editha has borrowed and repaid three loans from nwtf before this loan. she has been running the general store for 25 years and also earns an income from pig fattening.

editha aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

regina is 68 years old and has 8 children. she is a group leader and is representing her group formed by 7 farmers in kakamega north district, kenya. 

regina has been with one acre fund for years and joined the program  in 2010. this decision was largely a result of her desire to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods.  she described her last harvest as very good but believes she could have a better one this year by continuing to work with one acre fund. regina also decided to purchase a solar light as part of her loan, which she is very excited about, as it will allow her to have light during dark hours for her children to be able to study.

obtaining this loan means that regina's group will be able to receive a total of 4 solar lights, as well as farming supplies to plant a total of 4.5 acres.

greetings from sierra leone! this is 27-year-old josephine from kandeh town in the southern area bo district. she is a single mother of one child, age 8 years, and her child is currently attending school. 

josephine runs a retail store at her house. she sells cigarettes, soap, toothpaste and sugar. she has been running this business for over four years. she works at the business from 7 am until 6 pm, seven days per week. her business is the only income she has. josephine says that the main challenges to her business are insufficient capital to improve her business and the low purchasing power of customers. 

josephine has requested a loan in order to buy more cigarettes, soap, toothpaste and sugar. the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and educate her child. in the future, she wants to expand her business. she thanks lenders for their support!

mavjuda is a young, goal-oriented woman from the rudaki district. she is 20 years old. she is not yet married and she devotes all of her free time to her work. mavjuda is a seamstress by profession. she sews women's traditional dresses by order. she has been doing this work in her home for 3 years.  mavjuda not only takes orders, but teaches her talent to other young women. now she is asking for a loan in order to buy another sewing machine so that she can hire an employee. in this way, she will increase the profitability of her work. mavjuda has big plans for the future. she is planning to open her own workshop in the future where they will take individual orders. she can achieve her goal with the support of kiva lenders.

the krowor ladies group is made up of two women who live in the same neighborhood in ghana. they sell underwear and charcoal. 

adiza is the group representative. she is 41 years old, single and has one daughter. adiza and her child live together and provide for the expenses of the household. adiza left school at the secondary level and has been selling charcoal for 10 years now. she is very successful with her business, which allows her to provide for her child's needs. she buys charcoal from the distributors and sells to customers. 

she would like to be able to respond better to the demands of her customers, so she has requested this forth loan, with the other member of krowor ladies, from the field partner. this loan will enable them to fulfill their customers' needs and make more profit. the previous loans were fully and correctly repaid.

mary joy is a married woman, 34 years old, with 5 children. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur. mary joy has a buy-and-sell charcoal business in the philippines.

she requested a php 11,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

mary joy has been in this business for three years. she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

berinadeta is a married woman with one kid, who attends school. she rents a house that has electricity and piped water. her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

berinadeta operates a grocery stall selling vegetables. she sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. she faces a challenge of high costs of transportation to her place of operation. she dreams of expanding and establishing a motorcycle transport business in the future.

with the kes 20,000 she wants to purchase green vegetables, 2 crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business

ravshan r. lives in mastchoh; he is married and has 5 children. he has been a client of microinvest since 2005. he is a serious and strongly motivated borrower. he is eligible for an increased loan amount because of the stability of his business and its increasing profits. he breeds and sells livestock and operates a dairy. he would like to purchase a pedigreed bull for breeding purposes and a cow for the dairy.  he plans to expand the assortment of products he sells: pasteurized milk, buttermilk, sour cream, cottage cheese, and so on. he is asking for a loan of $725 to buy this livestock, which will allow him to expand his product line and increase the family's income.

as a married parent of two children, aneta works hard to support her family. she has a motorcycle transportation business in the philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store, rice retailing and pig fattening. aneta is borrowing 25,000 php through nwtf to buy spare parts, gasoline and pay for maintenance for her business.

she successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

aneta has been sustaining her business activities through her past 4 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

grace is 28 years old and married with two children, one of whom is in school. she works very hard to provide for them.

grace runs a cellphone and cellphone accessories store in the philippines and requested a php 29,500 loan through nwtf to purchase additional units of cellphones and accessories.

grace has been in this business for three years.

in the future, grace would like to save money to expand her business.

kousar parveen is a 50-year-old widowed woman living in the area of multan, pakistan. she is a mother of nine children, one of whom attends school. she has seven daughters and two sons. all of them are unmarried. she started running an embroidery business eight years ago in order to meet her household expenses. her embroidery business is very famous in the colony, and that is the reason her business runs well. due to good relations, her business has increased. she is a brave woman.

kousar parveen buys raw materials such as hand-embroidery kits, ribbon, needles and an embroidery machine from the market. another person handles her transactions with her customers. she has decided that she would like to sell her embroidery items directly in the market so that she can earn a better profit for her family. she has become an expert in the embroidery business. so, kousar parveen requested a loan so that she will be able to buy raw materials from the market.

she wants to meet the demand for bridal dresses. that is why she wants to buy thread, fancy cloths, sequins, and pearls of various colors in advance, to have in stock. she requires some capital to buy the desired items but does not have sufficient cash on hand.

therefore, kousar parveen humbly requested a loan from brac pakistan. through this loan, she will be able to buy the threads, fancy cloths, sequins, and pearls of various colors that she needs.

kousar parveen and her family will be thankful to kiva's lenders and field partner brac pakistan for helping them by funding this loan to improve their standard of living.

wilfred is a thirty-six year old komaza tree farmer. he has three children and his wife is also a farmer. wilfred joined the komaza microforestry program because he enjoys the beauty the trees provide to his homestead and he will use the profits from his tree farm to educate his children, buy more land and plant more trees. his favorite part about working with komaza is that he receives training and is provided seedlings on credit to develop himself and the community. wilfred is the farmer with his hand raised in the picture.

elisabete jacinto n. is 38 years old and was born in inhambane, lives with his wife and they have 4 children, a new born baby girl who is one month old and the oldest ones are in primary school. elisabete left with her uncle from inhmbane to namaacha a village at the frontier with swazilandia because of the intensity of war there. after they arrived he is able to finish 10th garde. years later she was able to get a job with otm (mozambique workers organization) as a servant where she worked for 2 years, her monthly salary was 150mt which didn't satisfy her necessities at home as she was living alone and paying her rent. she found a job with the center of education for teachers of primary school (cfppn), where she works from 6:30am to 2:30pm with a salary of 1.800mt a month. her husband works in education too and was able to benefit from the distribution of land but they don't have money to start building, this is why they came to hluvuku to request a loan to start the construction that stopped because of the high cost of construction materials, thanks to hluvuku and kiva she wants to use the loan to continue with the construction. besides her two children, elisabete supports her mom who lives in inhambane, she sends her 1,000mt a month. this is her third loan with hluvuku and second with kiva, this third loan for 25,000mt will be used to continue building her house. she is confident she will pay on time and will request another loan for energy and paint for the house

translated from portuguese by nina delgado, kiva volunteer

as a married parent of 4 children, violeta works hard to support her family.

she has a vegetables and spices vending business in the philippines, and she also earns additional income from meat vending. violeta is borrowing php 20,000 through nwtf to purchase additional items to sell for her vegetables and spices vending business.

violeta has been sustaining her business activities through her past 26 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

mwanaidi is a married woman who lives in the village of tiribe in the region of kenya. she has four children; all are currently in school. for the past five years, she has been working hard to manage her retail shop, selling paraffin.

to help expand her business, mwanaidi has requested a loan of 10,000 kes (kenyan shillings) from yehu microfinance trust. the loan will be used to buy more paraffin at a wholesale price and to resell at a low price to attract more customers. this will help mwanaidi to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children and their medical bills. she hopes that in the future, she will be able to improve her family's standard of living.

joel, 33, is married, with 5 children whose ages range between 1 and 11 years. three of the children are currently attending school. he has been in the farming business for four years now and sells his beans, maize and tea to the local market. he is also employed in a local school and earns about 4000kes monthly. \r\n\r\nhe has requested a loan of 45,000kes through juhudi kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. the extra income from the sale of milk will enable him to pay school fees for his children and improve the livelihood of his family. in future, he would like to save some money to enable him to start a hotel business. price fluctuations and lack of enough market for his products have been his major setbacks.
berthanie, a widow, lives with her children in savanne, in palle, hinche. she has been selling fruit for ten years at nearby markets. the loan is enabling her to diversify her products.

mirian paola is 26 years old. she is single, does not yet have children, and lives with her parents in agua clara in the canton of chillanes.

there are 14 members in the virgen del huayco communal bank, which is located in loma de guacalgoto, 20 minutes from the office in chillanes. this communal bank farms rice and beans, and some of them sell things like flour or animals.

mirian sows rice and beans. she makes her purchases in chillanes and san pablo and sells them in the sunday market in chillanes.

the loan will help her buy supplies for the crops; the loan has helped her increase the production of crops. her dream is to have her own house.

she likes being a responsible person.

valérie, age 29, is married to a police officer. the couple has two children attending a private school. valérie has a hair salon. before her marriage, she worked in a hair salon and, with experience, she was able to open her own place. she is making gradual investments to expand her business. developing this type of business depends on the quality of services and, therefore, it is important to have quality products and reliable equipment, hence this loan application. the couple's goal is to buy their own house.

menchie, 42, is married to a farmer and blessed with six children. for the past four years she has grown and sold vegetables and earns a net income of php 100 a day.\nmenchie is applying for a loan of 5,000 php through aski to buy seedlings of eggplants, string beans, red peppers, and squash to grow and sell. she's hoping that her business will continue to be ever more profitable.\n

laarni is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a tailoring business in the philippines. 

she is borrowing php 17000 through nwtf to buy materials needed for her tailoring business.

laarni successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further improve her business.

nwtf is relisting laarni's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

joseph y. is a professional barber who owns a salon. he is married and has 2 children. business is doing very well, and customers are increasing considerably. he wishes to improve his services to his clients to attract more customers.

\r\n\r\nhe is asking for $525 as additional funds to expand his business.

mwanapili is a resident of kisauni, kenya and is a clothes seller, a business she has been running for 2 years. she is a married mother of 2 children. she started the business from her husband’s income. he is a mason.

on learning about yehu from her friends, mwanapili joined the group members to access loans. she is therefore applying for a loan of 20,000 kenya shillings to buy a new stock of dresses, hair clips and trousers. she believes the additional income from this loan will help her pay her children’s school fees. her ambition is to be an established boutique owner in the region, despite the challenges of seasonal business climate and inflation.

evangeline is 35 years old, married and lives in bagakay, ozamiz city. to make a living, evangeline owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different home use products in their village.

evangeline has been engaged in her business for many years and earns well every month from these activities. in 2007, evangeline joined gdmpc to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. evangeline has successfully repaid a previous loan from gdmpc.

evangeline is requesting a new loan of 5,000 php, which will be used to purchase additional grocery items for sale. she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

marcial is 37 years old. he is a very responsible man, and thanks to his work he has managed to buy his own house, which is made of simple materials. he lives there alone, as he is single. 

his work is farming. he has cacao, coffee and coca leaf plants. he has been doing this work on his own for 15 years, but has the help of laborers for weeding and harvesting.

what he likes best is growing cacao, as it is the crop that gives him most income and is harvested monthly.

on the other hand, he considers that the most difficult part is transporting his products from the field to the community, as the trip involves an hour's walk. in the future, he hopes to buy his own cargo motorcycle for transporting his crops. 

this is his second loan with mfp, and he is very pleased to know that he will have financial help, as this way he will feel confident of moving forward with his projects. he is also grateful to the members of his communal bank for allowing him to work with them.

with these 1,000 nuevos soles, along with the money he has saved, he will buy a piece of farmland in order to increase his output.

patience is 66 years old and married, and she has two children. her husband is a businessman and he also supports their home. she is a friendly and hard-working woman. 

patience sells baby things, such as clothes, flasks, bathing bowls, etc. she loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. she hopes to expand her business. she sells her goods in the market. 

patience is hoping for a loan of ngn 150,000 to purchase more baby things to sell. she has been in this business for a long time.she says "thanks" to all kiva lenders.

priscila is 37 years old, is married, has four children, and they live in ventanas, in los rios province. she asks for the loan to purchase agricultural supplies to plant and improve her production. her dream is to purchase a plot of land to increase her crop and have earnings to pay off the family debts. in her free time, she likes to watch tv.

caroline is a beautiful and humble woman who is honest and hard-working. she adores her lovely family and will do anything to keep them from going to bed hungry. caroline is from the kapsowar area of kenya. she did not have the opportunity to advance her education enough to get a white-collar job, but she plans to succeed in life and has been a farmer for six years.

caroline is experienced and has many farming techniques at her fingertips. she raises animals and crops to take care of her family's needs and provide a good education to her children. she believes that education is 'the key' to success for them. it is for this reason that she is seeking a loan that she will use to pay the school fees for her children.

through the loan, caroline's children will learn comfortably and they will never be sent away because of lack of tuition fees. she wants her children to have a bright future and with this loan, she will be able to achieve this. lend to her now so that her children can have a brighter future.

as a widowed parent of four children, sarah works hard to support her family. she has a butcher shop business in the philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening. sarah is borrowing php 29,500 through nwtf to purchase pigs for her butcher shop business. she successfully paid back her previous loan and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business. sarah has been sustaining her business activities through her past 14 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to buy more farmlands.\r\n

good day lenders! meet one of kspps bmi’s clients, umyati. she is 63 years old, widowed, and has one daughter and two sons.

umyati has been selling food such as snacks, bread, cake, drinks, and so on in the serang district for twenty years. she works very hard. she would like to improve her living conditions and create a happy and healthy life for her kids.

today her family has no access to water sources in their home and must rely on the river for bathing. she has asked for a loan of idr 5,000,000 from kspps bmi. this loan will be used to build a facility to provide clean water sources in her home and thus improve access to clean water for her family.

her family income is insufficient to provide water sources, but umyati will be able to repay the loan received.

she and her family want to live a healthy life with clean water. she is very grateful for the opportunity and wants to thank all lenders.

eveling janet is 25 years old and is studying accounting. she chose this career because she saw the demand there was for accounting staff and saw it was much easier to find work in this area.

eveling already finished her five years of study, but has to take a refresher course to be able to start the process of getting her professional degree.

she will invest the loan to pay for the refresher course, which will allow her to relax without worrying about monthly payments. eveling janet is very grateful for the investors, as thanks to their support she will achieve her goals and her parents' goals by becoming a professional.

sanita manages a mini grocery store, which is located in front of her house.her husband is a farmer as well as, at the same time, a manufacturer of hallows blocks. sanita started her business with minimal capital and strong determination  which makes her proud and grateful.

sanita has three children. profits she gained were used to educate two of her children. sanita’s goal is to keep her business profitable and supply all of her costumers' demands. she decided to ask for a loan of 30,000 php to increase the stock of merchandise she offers. this loan will allow her to buy breads, seasoning, coffee, sugar, and cooking oil. she knows that this loan amount has a lot to do with her business growth. she just hope that lenders will continue to provide her financial assistance so she can let her youngest child finish her studies.

the las viviendas urban credit group meets every 2 weeks in the canton of jaramijó. this area is known for its beautiful beaches. the majority of the inhabitants here are workers employed in labor related to the sea.

mariela lives in this place. she is 19 years old and is in a common law relationship. she doesn't have children yet. her husband is a driver.

mariela is a very hard-working woman who does what's needed to earn money on her own to contribute towards the household expenses. she works in trade, selling clothes and shoes from a catalog. her method of sale is door to door. she goes out three or four times a week, offering her merchandise. she then leaves them on credit and collects once a week. she has been in this business for more than 3 years and earns these resources in the hope of improving her financial situation little by little, for when she has her children.

she will use this loan to buy clothing and shoes. she has had 2 cycles in the credit group, and she likes it because of the assistance the loans provide. her dream is to have her own home.

winfred is a single mother of 2 children and she is 37 years old. she is a shopkeeper and enjoys her business very much.

winfred likes serving people and meeting their daily needs as she interacts with them. she is requesting for a loan of kes.35,000 to add stock of cooking oil to sell. she will boost her business and use her profit to pay her loan in a short period of time.

winfred's dream is to grow her shop to a wholesale.

dolores c. is from the village of manticao, misamis oriental. she is 55 years old, is married, and has four adult children.

dolores owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling specialty food products in the local community. dolores is just starting this business.

in 2009, dolores joined hspfi to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. she is requesting a loan of 10,000 php which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. this loan will be her first from hspfi. she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

about hspfi:

hspfi is one of accredited partners of opportunity international in the philippines. it is based in cagayan de oro city and is reaching out to the poor households of northern mindanao.
