carmen's greatest wish is to get ahead with her sewing shop, and to have at home better economic opportunities to progress together with her husband and four children.

its mirtha is a member of the con fe y alegria (with hope and happiness) lending group, which is made up of six members who, together, share their business experiences in order to support one another in achieving their goals. she lives with her spouse, and she has four children, ages 19, 16, 14 and 12, who are her primary motivation for getting ahead.

its mirtha works selling shoes. she has almost 14 years of experience in this field and it makes her very happy because it allows her to interact with customers and get to know more people.

she will use this loan to purchase shoes for women, men and children in

lilia is 48 years old, married, and has 10 children. she operates a sari-sari store in leyte, which she has been doing for four years. 

lilia requested a loan, which she will use to buy more groceries such as canned goods, noodles, soda, beverages, soap, toiletries, bread, biscuits, candies, snack foods, and condiments. this loan will help lilia to improve her stocks thus attracting more buyers to hers store. she hopes to expand her store in the future.

as a married parent of one child, lilian works hard to support her family.

she has a buy and sell banana business in the philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending.  lilian is borrowing php 19500 through nwtf to  buy additional banana to sell in her stall.

lilian has been sustaining her business activities through her past 6 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

vit was born in 1986. he has been working as a construction worker for 10 years. his wife has been selling groceries for 10 years. they live in tramkok district, takeo province, cambodia.

he has 2 sons and 2 daughters and they are still studying. his grocery store is small so he wants to renovate it and make it bigger. but he doesn't have have enough money for renovations so he decided to apply for a loan from maxima to renovate his grocery store.

he hopes that his family's future is better than today and he can support his children to continue to study at university.

elsa belongs to the “nueva victoria (new victory) – chinchero” communal bank, located in chinchero district, urubamba province, cusco department.

elsa is 43 years old, married, and has 4 children, all of whom still depend on her.  she is an artisan by profession and makes beautiful embroidered purses, alpaca sweaters, ponchos, decorations, wool runners embroidered with flowers, and other things like coin purses, and much more.  she belongs to the virgen de las nieves (virgin of the snows) artisan association and has worked in their office for more than 15 years.  elsa makes her textiles with natural dies and decorates wool cloth with natural plants of diverse colors.

elsa wants to expand her business and buy materials and, also, part of this loan will be invested in her children's studies, paying fees little by little with the money she earns from sales of her artisan work. she is requesting the loan to buy materials and to pay school bills.

she appreciates the loan and promises to make her payments on the established schedule.

friendship bridge clients, participating in the “microcredit plus” program (education + loans), are experiencing great positive change in their economic well-being and personal development. kiva lenders are an integral part of their success!

juana is a good example. she is a married, 23-year-old mother of two children (2 and 5) who has an animal husbandry business, raising and selling chickens, goats, and pigs. she is requesting a loan to buy more chickens and goats that she will sell both inside and outside of her town. she wants her children to enjoy a complete education. she was only able to stay in school until the 6th grade.

juana belongs to the trust bank “cruzche iii” in a rural area in the department/state of santa cruz el quiché, guatemala. there are eight other women in the group who meet monthly to make repayments on their loans and participate in educational training sessions. the women have various businesses including the sales of vegetables, fruits, and straw bottle holders, as well as animal husbandry (chickens, goats, pigs, cattle), and traditional textile fabrication. they are beginning their 4th loan cycle with kiva.

thank you, kiva lenders, for creating opportunities that empower women to raise their standard of living and build better lives!

gina is 48 years old, widowed and has four children of adult age. she lives in pagadian city, zamboanga del sur. she is a pensioner, member of paglaum mpc and a microfinance member for almost five years. she maintains her membership in good standing because she knows she can always turn to the cooperative whenever she needs financial assistance. recently, gina requested a loan of 30,000 php to pay for a medical check-up and to purchase maintenance medicines.

gulbahor is 49 years old. she is a motivated and successful woman. her husband bakhtier is proud of her. they have one child who is not yet an adult. gulbahor lives together with her family happily, but poorly. 

their income does not allow them to buy all the necessary things for a living, and therefore gulbahor decided to organize her own business buying and selling men's clothing. to that end, she took a course "bring it on" organized by the association of business women and received a certificate. from this course, she learned a lot, and now she is ready to organize her own business. she will trade in the local market, and her husband will help her in running the business.

she is requesting a loan of 15,000 somoni to buy goods, in order to establish a new business.

elizabeth is a married mother of one child who is still too young to attend school. she owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. her greatest monthly expenses are household consumables.

for over three years, she has operated an open air food selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. she faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of business. 

with the 20,000 kes she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and cooking fat. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

merylou is a married woman who lives in danao city, cebu. she earns her living by operating a fruits & vegetables business.  her husband petronito, who is 45 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living.  they have two children who are 12 and 23 years old.  merylou joined nwtf-project dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family.  with the help of her past four loans from nwtf-project dungganon, merylou has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. her previous loan of php 13,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of php 13,600, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  this time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing php 18,000 to buy additional bananas for resale so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business.  merylou is a dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.  

about nwtf:  in a world full of challenges, negros women for tomorrow foundation (nwtf) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through project dungganon (a hiligaynon word that means honorable). through the alleviation program, nwtf is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. they have taken a life path that will ultimately make them dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

haruna, a babban gona maize farmer from alhaji village, is a babban gona farmer. he has one child who aspires to be a fashion designer in the future.

previously, haruna and his family were only able to eat two meals a day despite toiling for several hours on the farm. however, as a babban gona member, this loan will provide higher yielding seeds that are locally adapted and are widely accepted in his local community. he will also have the recommended pesticides and fertilizers based on the results of his field assessment.

this will enable him to optimize his yield so he can attain yields of up to 3.8 metric tonnes per hectare, two times the national average in nigeria

this season, haruna will use the income generated from his maize sales to buy a tractor. haruna’s greatest memory as a babban gona farmer was buying a car as a result of the loan he got in the past. haruna is confident that with babban gona, his future is secured and that he will have many more great memories and amazing accomplishments together with his family.

fatuma is a married woman with three kids, all of whom attend school. she owns a house that has neither
electricity nor piped water. her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

salama operates a grocery stall, selling vegetables. she sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. she faces a challenge of high cost of transportation to her place of operation. she dreams of expanding and establishing a motorcycle transport business in the future.

with the loan, she wants to purchase green vegetables, 2 crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

jose is 42 years old. he is married and has 8 children and lives with his family in the city of choloma, cortes.

six years ago, jose established a small grocery store business. this has been his source of income to support his family. he started this business with his own money and with the help of his wife. he says that sales are stable because the products he puts out every day sell and are indispensable for homes.  he has asked for his fourth loan, which is for 21,000 lempiras. he needs it to stock up on products such as flour, beans, rice, lard, sugar, eggs, bread, dairy products, chicken, beverages, etc. he thinks that making this investment will help him to earn more income and help his family financially.

the goal is to keep investing in his business to keep it stable.

sarah operates a poultry selling business, and that is where she gets her income. she mentioned a disease outbreak causing losses as a challenge in the business. sarah dreams of becoming a wholesaler of poultry in the future. 

with the kes 40,000, she wants to purchase chicks and poultry feed. she joined yehu to access loans to boost her business.

musaya is 54 years old and married to musyoki, who contributes to the family's income. she owns a retail shop where she sells assorted cereals, flour, soaps, and detergent. she has been in this business for about eleven years and earns an income of about 4,400 kes per month.\r\n\r\nshe has a very good history with kadet. this is her third loan. she has successfully repaid the previous two loans. with this loan, she intends to buy more inventory such as mung beans, maize, and beans. she hopes to own a wholesale store in the future.

mohammad karim lives in district 13 of kabul, afghanistan. he is educated and married. he is a shopkeeper, and he has a shop for making sweets. he has a lot of experience in his job. he did this business for a long time in iran and pakistan. he has lots of workers in his shop. now he wants to open another shop in another part of kabul, so he wants to take an individual loan to purchase all of his supplies and expand his business. he is happy with this loan.

loeonardo is a hard working 50 year old man. he lives with his three children and his partner in yuracchuasi, which is located in ayacucho.

he makes his living farming and raising organic cattle. he always pays careful attention to the care and the feed he gives them which is from farm crops he grows. he is requesting this microloan to buy cattle which he will raise as feeder cattle to sell later.

leonardo hopes that in the future he will be able to give his family a better quality of life. he will also work hard so his children can get a good education and become people of many principles.

this is khayri. she is 51 years old and a native of the rudaki district, where she lives and works. she buys and sells cattle and this helps her earn a living. she buys calves and bullocks and sells them for profit after fattening them. this is her main source of income. her husband, who works at the "korvon" market, helps her with the business. khayri wants to get a loan in order to purchase more cattle and expand her business.

taher is 29 years old and lives in taiz, yemen. he is a hardworking man who works hard to achieve a better life. he works for the general authority for roads, on a low income. taher built a small house from hard-earned money, but he is suffering from a lack of money to furnish his house. he asked his friends and relatives to lend him money, but no one helped him. so, he has applied for a youth loan of 150,000 yer from amb to buy furniture for his house. he wishes to improve his living standards.

marie louise is a 31 year-old married woman and mother of 3 children ranging in age between 5 and 10 years old. all of them go to school. she has sold donuts in her neighborhood for 2 years. her clients have increased over time  and she has not been able to satisfy demand. this is why she has requested a loan to buy merchandise (food products). this will increase her sales and also her profits. she plans to reinvest a part of her profits in her business and the rest will help her support the needs of her family.

faustina is a 32-year-old trader who is single and has a three year old boy. she sells sweets, soft drinks, biscuits, and provisions in her shop which is by the roadside. she has been in this business for the past three years. 

faustina dreams of sell different varieties of provisions in the next five years to meet the needs of her customers, but lacks the capital to expand the business. she will use this loan to buy more soft drinks, sugar, biscuits, milk and milo to sell. with the extra income from this loan, she hopes to pay her son's school fees and manage her home.

thank you to kiva lenders for supporting faustina’s business!

muniratu is 30 years old and has five children. she is a member of a shea nut processing women group from bagurugu in the northern region of ghana. muniratu is wearing a white veil and is in 6th place as you count squatting group members from your right as you face their photo. their group is called ‘kpangmanga-bagurugu’ women association.
 muniratu has been in this business with 31 others in the group for the past three years. a new loan of ghȼ 9,300 will support her and hert colleagues to buy 80 bags of shea nuts and pay for fuel to power stoves for the processing of premium shea butter. there are organisations and individuals who will buy the shea butter kubura processes.
she intends to expand the business venture and thereby increase her income and sustainability. with increased income she will be able to repay the loan, stay in business and also support her children to have a better education and better food to eat.

lona rose is a married woman with two children. she is a very hard working entrepreneur. lona rose is 30 years old and both of her children are in school.

she has a frozen foods business in the philippines. lona rose requested a php 50,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy more stock of frozen foods to sell.

lona rose has been in this business for five years. in the future, she would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

dina is 20 years old and lives in the town of jucuapa, within the usulutan department. she is married and lives with her husband and eight month old son. she has a store where she sells basic need products. she started the business by selling milk products five years ago. now she has a variety of products to offer her customers. the business is located within her home and she works from 6:00am to 8:00pm. she is a very enterprising woman with lots of experience. she is asking for this loan so that she can buy products such as cheese, cream, and milk curd. this will help her increase her inventory so that she can have more to offer her customers and also increase her sales. she dreams of being able to manage a strong business, attract customers, and be a good entrepreneur in order to improve her family's life.

translated from spanish by hugo reyes, kiva volunteer

delmis marina f. a. is 39 years old.  she is married and has three children.  her children are studying and one of them is graduating as a policeman.

delmis' husband supports her with deliveries in her bakery as they have a vehicle for transporting their products to different places.  delmis has been in the bread-making business for 10 years and this activity has helped her to support her household.

she will use this loan to buy materials for making bread.  she doesn't have much capital right now and would like to inject capital into her business.

delmis' greatest wish this christmas is for the peace and love of the lord to visit us all in our homes.  she requests health and strength to face life's adversities.

eugenia is married and has three children. she has never been to school. eugenia is a petty trader who sells smoked fish and vegetables at wegbe, hohoe, ghana, as she has done to make a living for 16 years. her husband is a driver. eugenia uses her income to help her husband raise their three children. eugenia will use the loan proceeds to buy more fish for her business, in order to increase her profits. eugenia intends to save the new profits from her expanded business and to start smoking her own fish.

maría sells tortillas and pork, and now she also sells clothes.  she plans to make more income which will help her with her basic household food expenses and also help her cover her water and electricity bills.

maría has the support of her husband who is a gardener by profession.  through afodenic, she has managed to make improvements.  over four loan cycles, she has increased her sales inventory and also improved her home.

maría will use this loan to build a sewage drain so that she can install a toilet and achieve better hygiene.  this will mean that sewage no longer passes through the neighborhood.  she will pay some people to build her a sewage drain and will buy blocks, iron and cement.  she will also buy a toilet.

rogers is 29 years old and married with three children living in kagadi, uganda. with the loan, rogers wants to buy maize and beans produce for his produce store and beer for his bar.

in the future he hopes to start up a wholesale shop and educate his children to university level. he also plans to put to use 2 acres of land that he owns for poultry farming and a piggery.

he is challenged by limited capital, which he feels will be solved by this funding.

samon appears the first on the right in the photo, leading this group of two members asking for a loan from kredit.

she is a 36-year-old widowed mother of two children who are students. she resides in the village in prey veng province of cambodia. to support their living expenses, she works as a garment factory worker and cultivates rice after work. she typically makes around 7 usd per day.


due to the shortage of finances, she is going to use her share of the loan to purchase more seeds, fertilizer, grass pesticide, and fuel for her tractor. all of these purchases will help her to expand her farming this season and raise her family’s living standard.

n. theara is a 52-year-old married woman whose currently living in kompong chnang province. she works as a driving teacher with a daily income of $18. her husband, a militia officer since 1979 has a daily income of $1.14, and is working hard together with her to support their three children two of whom are university students and another one is a driving teacher of his mother’s car. their monthly expenses are over $200 including the school fees, food, electricity and water supplies, and rent. changing the job from a grocery seller (she used to sell grocery at home) to a teacher of driving car, she earns more income to support her family, so she decided to make a second loan to buy another car and to enlarge her business to the other provinces.\r\n

rosalinda b. owns and operates a general store selling a variety of different products in her community. she is 44 years old, widowed and has four school-aged children. they are from the village of cabaruan. rosalinda has been in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 philippine pesos (php) a month. in 2009, rosalinda joined aski to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. rosalinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 php from aski which was used to purchase products to sell. rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 11,000 php which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. this will be her fourth loan from aski. she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. about aski: aski is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the philippines. it has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva. given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

yolanda was born in the valle sagrado de los incas in the city of pisaq. she is 30 years old and has a son (nil who is 10 years old). yolanda lives in the city of calca which is where she works. she sells white corn, dry beans, quinoa and wheat. she has been doing this work since she was very young and is doing very well. this time, she is asking for a loan to buy corn, yolanda's dream is to open a shop where she can sell her products.

the communal bank “milenium iii” meets every thirty days in the city of calca in the department of cusco (peru). cusco is known as a tourist destination and commercial centre and for its festival inti raymi. it is also close to one of the seven wonders of the world “machupicchu”.

"my name is ayesha and i’m 26 years old and a married lady, a citizen of an area of lahore called ismail nagar for the past 7 years. my husband's name is z. a. and he is a vegetable seller by profession and has been selling vegetables for the past 10 years. i’m the mother of two children: one son and one daughter. both of my kids are in kindergarten. i and my husband have a dream to see our kids in a very good position. to achieve this, i prepare decorative embroidered dresses on order. i charge $3 per dress. i have successfully repaid my three loans from asasah (a micro-finance institute in pakistan). now i am applying again for a loan to buy more seasonal vegetables to expand my husband’s vegetable selling business. "i am the group leader for some more women from my locality. sajida baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business. rashidan baji wants a loan to buy wood to re-sell. naseem k. baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics to sell. rashidan baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop."

this is a group loan. the loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. the members mutually guarantee one another's loans. if one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

virgilio is 22 years old. he is kind, honest and persistent. he lives with his parent in the community of san andrés semetabaj. he's worked since he was very young to improve his quality of life as well as his family's. for this reasons he's worked in construction for the past 8 years. this is a very profitable activity thanks to which he was been able to help his family a great deal. he's been thinking about remodeling his home for a while, but he didn't have enough money, so he decided to ask for a loan to buy cement, blocks, sand and paint to do all the necessary fixes and be able to have a more comfortable space.

this is damaris, a 40-year-old woman who is the mother of four young children. she and her husband reside in the town of san juan de nepomuceno. with the intent of improving her family’s living conditions, damaris started her own business two years ago. she began selling cell phone minutes and rechargeable phone cards, but also considered offering candy and snacks that her husband distributes since those products would be an excellent complement to her business. later on, she bought a case of soft drinks and expanded her offerings even more.

damaris is very pleased with the results she has achieved and is applying for a kiva loan, her first form of financing through fundación mario domingo. she will restock her inventory of snack foods and will also invest in clothes and shoes, a new business opportunity that she has identified.

please support damaris, a woman who wishes to formalize her business by setting up a shop so that she can improve her earnings that will benefit her family.

in the department/state of quiché, 10 maya k’iche ladies who are in the friendship bridge trust bank “naranjas de cucabaj” participate in the “microcredit plus” program that combines loans, education, and healthcare services. they live in a rural area and have set goals of creating pathways out of poverty and new opportunities for prosperity. they have traditional textile businesses and raise turkeys. the women are beginning their very first loan cycle with kiva and are most excited!

rosa, a 27-year-old married mother of three children (ages two to nine), is a member of the group and has a fifth grade education. two of her children are enrolled in school. rosa has a traditional textile business and also raises turkeys. she is requesting a loan to buy more colorful textiles like elaborate blouses or “huipiles,” wraparound woven skirts or “cortes,” fabric, and some turkeys.

she is certain that with her abundant energy and the loans/education, she will reach her goals and be successful! the monthly educational training programs are of great value to these women. they cover an aspect of four main areas that include basic business practices, nutrition, hygiene and health, and empowerment. the loans, provided by kiva investors, give rosa and her friends the capital that they need to invest in their businesses. thank you, kiva investors!

teresita is a hard-working mother of four who is engaged in the farming business. she is enjoying doing farming activities to earn profits. 

teresita is 62 years of age and is married. teresita wants to maintain the business while she can manage it. she gets a financial shortage because her expenditures in farming have increased. cost of farm inputs now is increasing. thus, teresita is requesting a loan of p50,000 to buy farm inputs like seeds, fertilizers and herbicides to use in her farm. she believes that the loan will have a positive impact for the growth of her farming business.

elena is 41 and is in a civil partnership. she has 5 children, 2 are grown up. the young ones aged between 11 to 9 and 5 years old, are at school. her husband works as a day labourer. they live in the parish of porto viejo; a place known for beautiful scenery and lush vegetation where the local people make a living from agriculture and livestock.
she is a very tenacious woman who makes a living by selling avon products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfume, and women's accessories)to provide for her family. she sells door to door and works virtually every day. she offers credit and collects every eight days. she has been in this business for more than ten years and she has been able to get ahead thanks to the loans. this loan is to buy clothing, perfumes, creams, cosmetics. she dreams of having a shop.

as a single parent of four children, leni is a very hard working entrepreneur. leni is 56 years old. leni has one kid who is in school.

leni has a general store business in the philippines. leni requested a php 10,000 loan through nwtf to purchase more stock to sell.

leni has been in this business for six years.  in the future, leni would like to send her kids to school and expand her business.

lourdes works hard to support her family. lourdes is married and has a general store business in the philippines.

lourdes requested a php 21,000 loan through nwtf to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

lourdes has been in this business for four years now.

in the future, lourdes would like to save money to expand her business.

carmelita earns a living by weaving amakan (bamboo matting, commonly used to make walls for the native houses in the philippines). she has sold amakan for three years now.

she is widow woman with six children. four of her children are still attending school. they are 12-18 years old. she lives in the town of batuan, bohol.

she  is asking for a loan  to buy materials like bamboo. with these, she could weave more amakan, which would enable her to improve her earnings.

slowly, her finances will become stable. she could continue send her children to school and could try to expand her livelihood to become more productive, and it could help uplift the family's living condition.

rosina is 41 years old and she is married with three children. all her children attend school. she is a businesswoman and she has a grocery store in her neighborhood. she has been in this business for five years now and she learned about milango through friends, and now she seeks a loan to buy tomatoes, potatoes and cabbages for her business. in five years time she wants to be running two more stores that will increase her income. the challenge that she faces is the cost of goods which at times is so high. the extra income that she raises will improve her living standards.

clement a. is single and has no children. he has attended school through senior high. clement melts metals and uses them to manufacture coal pots and locally made ovens. coal pot is a of stove that burns charcoal as a fuel. he has done this work in elmina, since 2004. clement uses his income to pay for rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. clement will use the loan to increase his purchase of scrap metal and tools which will enable him to expand production. with the new profits from his expanded business, clement plans to reinvest back into his business to improve his profit and enable him meet his financial responsibilities.

beatrice is a 44 year old married woman. she has 4 children, with ages ranging from 5 years to 18 years. she describes herself to be a visionary woman. \r\n\r\nbeatrice operates a retail store where she sells items such sugar, salt, rice etc. she has been involved in this business for 3 years. her business is located within a viable business area and her primary customers are local residents. she describes her biggest business challenge to be poor infrastructure of roads and insecurity within the business environment. she will use the kes 30,000 loan to buy maize and beans to resell. her business goal is to improve her retail store within 5 years. she hopes that in the future, she will have expanded her business.

anjeanith b. is from the village of duka, medina, misamis oriental. she is 35 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. to make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. she has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $223 a month for these activities.

in 2009, anjeanith joined hspfi to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. she has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 php from hspfi. this previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

anjeanith is requesting a new loan of 17,000 php which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. this will be her 6th loan from hspfi. she plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

about hspfi:

hspfi is one of the accredited partners of opportunity international in the philippines. it is based in cagayan de oro city and is reaching out to the poor households of northern mindanao.

*note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva.  given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

miriane is a young 34-year-old merchant, who lives with her partner. she has three children, of whom two are in school.

miriane has a bar where she sells alcoholic drinks, juice, as well as mineral water. she also sells eggs and broth.

this loan will allow her to increase her stock so that she can earn more and contribute to her family's development.

zena is a married woman with three kids, all of whom attend school. she owns a house that has neither electricity or piped water. her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

zena operates a stall selling vegetables; she sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. she faces the challenge of expensive transportation to her place of operation.

with the 35,000 kes she wants to purchase green vegetables, 2 crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

gerard is the coordinator of his group les anges de ouanaminthe. he is married and has four children. he lives in northern haiti where electricity is rare and water is very limited. 

he has managed his business for the last six years. gerard would like to use this loan to invest in selling sports shoes. 

gerard hopes that this loan will help him to have a larger business. some other members of his group have need of a loan for such businesses as charcoal, general merchandise, and cosmetology. 

gerard says his main challenges are a lack of purchasing and too many people having asked him for credit. gerard says that his main goal is to have a larger business with god's help.

vivencia is 57 years old and has four children. vivencia is married and has one child who is still in school.

vivencia is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the philippines. vivencia requested a php 30,000 loan through nwtf to buy feed, vitamins and other supplies for her pigs.

vivencia has been in pig fattening for 15 years now, and has borrowed 16 times in the past from nwtf to sustain this.

vivencia would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

rosa is a 29 year old widow. she lives with her two children in her own house in the district of tambogrande. this is a farming zone in the piura region, four hours away from the city of chiclayo, capital of the lambayeque region.

she has raised sheep in her property for three years. she currently has 15 sheep and poultry. when the animals have matured enough she sells them to her costumers at the local market. she learned this trade from her mother that is to say she has thorough knowledge regarding it.

rosa wishes to use the loan to buy balanced foods, grasses for her animals and to fix the pen. because of this she is requesting a loan of 500 nuevos soles from edpyme alternativa.

mary lives in the eldoret area of kenya, which is home to the main campus of moi university. she has five children and has been doing this work for nine years. her primary income sources are milk, eggs, and crops.

she stated what is most enjoyable about farming is "selling milk".  her biggest challenge is "disease outbreaks". animals on the farm have been given the names of 'lelmet with white spot on head".  she will use the loan to buy a milk cow.

mary was asked why she chose juhudi kilimo for this loan, to which she replied, "my fellow group members advised me to join them". this client was also asked what was learned during juhudi's required micro finance training session, and she replied, "credit management".

her highest monthly expense is school fees. when asked 'how will this loan benefit her family', mary replied, "more dairy animals will increase milk production and she will pay school fees for her children with ease".

as part of juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. mary owns the following: 'a cow, and poultry' but does not own 'a pig, a pump, a bicycle, a motorcycle, or an automobile'.  juhudi kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. this borrower has in the household 'a mosquito net, and running water' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, a sewing machine, a tv, or a dvd'.

note: to create this loan profile, juhudi kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down."

sa is 55 years old, married and the mother of six children – four of them single and two married. this photo was taken in front of her house, which is situated in the baray district, where she operates farm which is the main source of her income. sa and her spouse work hard as a team to ensure an abundant harvest each season. together, they can earn about $6 a day and have been doing this business for more than 20 years. 

sa is requesting a loan for $600 to buy potato plants to grow. she will also use a portion of this loan to pay laborers who will help her transport her rice. in the future, she would like to keep growing as a successful entrepreneur and improve the overall welfare of her family.

asiya is a 42-year old married woman; who is living along her six children and spouse in lahore, pakistan. pictured with her husband. he is a hawker by profession and offer fish in winter which is much demanded these days. fe, days ago bought fish on credit and wants to pay credit amount. he will utilize the remaining loan for purchasing more fish to cope with the increasing demand.

therefore; asiya has requested a kiva loan for her husband so he can pay debt and can buy additional fish to cope with the demand.

asiya is very happy after receiving this loan because her husband can generate maximum money in winter and profits can be utilized in summer as well.

asiya gives thanks to kiva and field partner for this honorable support.

alice is 40 years old and married with three children, all of whom are in school. alice works very hard to provide for them. she runs a general store in the philippines and has requested a php 14,000 loan through nwtf to purchase more groceries to sell. alice has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items, such as rice, noodles, sugar and other groceries. in the future, alice would like to save enough money to expand her business and to continue to send her children to school.\r\n

teing is 35 years old and married. she lives in a village located in the phnom proek district of cambodia. she has three children, one of whom is still in school and another one is too young for school. her primary source of income is from the rice and corn plantation of a six-hectare farmland. she has been in this business for several years. \r\n\r\nshe is applying for a loan of 2,000,000khr to buy fertilizer, insecticide and seeds for her farmland. this is the third loan for teing with kiva’s partner, visionfund, and she has completely paid back the previous loans. with this loan, she will be able to buy decent food for her family. she hopes to increase her crop yields and make a better life and keep her children in school until tertiary level.

the communal bank "los girasoles" consists of 8 members who have been improving their lives over time through their businesses.

this is the story of vilma, 50 years old, who is separated and has 2 grown-up children. more than 20 years ago, vilma started selling tamales and also chicken broth. as a result of her efforts, she could improve her business and provide a better education for her children. 

she asks for a loan to invest it in the purchase of corn, oil, chicken and noodles. the group "los girasoles" are thankful for the loans and promise to continue their hard work. vilma is in the front of the picture, she is the third from the right and is wearing a brown vest and a blue polo.

béatrice a. is 56 years old and an enterprising woman who struggles for the success of her children. married, she cares for nine people by selling yogurt and small condiments during the last 30 years. her meager earnings do not allow her to take care of the needs of her large family. her aging husband does not have the necessary strength to practice his job of farmer. a. therefore finds herself facing large responsibilities alone. she needs support by means of a loan to promote her activities.

translated from french by chloe tuot, kiva volunteer

hello, my name is reina f.. for several years i have made and sold tortillas. i am a hardworking, honest, and responsible person. this is a great business because tortillas are an essential and nutritious food in our country, eaten throughout the year. right now, what i can produce cannot keep up with the high demand. for this reason, i am asking for a loan to buy an electric grinder. that way i can grind more corn to make more dough and be able to produce more tortillas. this will save me time and effort, since i currently grind the corn by hand.\r\n

translated from spanish by kris vickery, kiva volunteer

arlita is 43 years old and married with four children who are in school. arlita works very hard to provide for them.

she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 30,000 loan through nwtf to buy items to sell like canned goods, personal care products, etc.

arlita has been in this business for seven years.

in the future, arlita would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

baterdene is 31 years old and lives alone in ulaanbaatar city, mongolia. he started his taxi service business in 2006 with his own car. since then, he has renewed his car and bought a yard with the profit. also, he runs a meat retailing business. he is a sharp and hardworking man who says "the cab business is pretty much the same everyday so i rented a counter at the market and hired somebody to run the business. it is going surprisingly well so i need to increase my supply in order to run my new business successfully". he is requesting a 3,000,000 mnt loan to purchase more meat.

andrés is a humble farmer, 66 years old, originally from the region called la laguna, in the outskirts of boaco.  he has 8 adult children and is married.  he plants corn and beans, an activity which he has been doing for more than 20 years on land that he has acquired bit by bit through his own effort and hard work.  he also has cows that he has purchased with income from his crops and money from his children.  andres does his work with help from his children, and with labor that he contracts for the season.  he takes his crops to managua to sell where he receives a good price for basic grains.  he is requesting a loan to pay for labor and to purchase two cows and all supplies he needs for planting, such as fertilizers for the next crop cycle.. \r\n\r\n

beverly works hard to support her family. she is married and has a sewing business in the philippines.

beverly requested a php 5,000 loan through nwtf to purchase additional materials like thread, fabric, zippers, etc. for her business. 

beverly has been in this business for 15 years now. she would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

margarita is running a variety store selling of variety of grocery items. she is 63 years old and married. they are blessed with five children where four of them are settled for marriage. her age not become a hindrance in managing this business. margarita wants to purchase more groceries to increase her sales and now she's requesting a loan of php 30,000. she will buy bread, canned goods, detergent powder, soap and other groceries to sell. she's hoping for more business improvement this coming years.

japhet  is a 30-year-old married man. he has 1 child. he describes himself to be an independent, determined and humble man. 

he operates a motorcycle, which he uses to provide transportation services. he has been involved in this business for 7 years. his business is located near a busy market, and his primary customers are the general public. he describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving his business. he will use the kes 15,000 loan to buy spare motorcycle parts. 

his business goal is to run a garage for motorcycle spare parts within 5 years. this is his first loan with smep dtm.

lilianita, 62, is known in talinga in the leon b. postigo, zamboanga del norte area for her sari-sari (variety) store. she actively participates in the services that kiva's field partner pmpc offers and hopes to retain her membership in good standing with a good repayment record. this matters in that she has been given priority for a loan as a microfinance member of pmpc.

lilianita has applied for a 12,000 php loan to buy plywood, nails, and lumber to build a decent house. she is thankful when all the financing needs of her retail business are supported by pmpc.

in the future lilianita hopes to be living comfortably.

estrella is 51 years old and married with two children. she works very hard to provide for them.

she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 14,000 loan through nwtf to purchase additional stocks like soap, sardines, noodles, etc. to sell.

estrella has been in this business for 10 years.

she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

mrs. yon l., age 31, is a garment worker who has lived in siem reap province since 2005. she earns $2.50 a day.\r\nher husband is a construction worker who builds houses and makes $6 a day. they have three children, all of whom are in school. this couple has applied for a loan from kiva to buy a motorbike that they will use to commute to work and to buy some land. they will hold on to the land until the price goes up, and then sell it for a profit.

aurelyn is a married woman with two children. she is 38 years old and has two children who are in school. she is a very hard working entrepreneur.

aurelyn has a food vending business in the philippines. she requested a php 11,000 loan amount through nwtf in ordeer to buy ingredients for her food vending business. aurelyn has been in this business for two years.

in the future, aurelyn would like to repair and renovate her family home.

heladeria nieves is a small ice cream shop owned by nieves a. (appropriately, nieves means snow in spanish). at her shop she also sells snacks and candies. she has a good amount of business because her ice cream shop is conveniently located by a school and a children’s park. therefore most of her clients are kids and young adults. she started this business with only $30 about four years ago. she would like to take out this loan in order to buy ice cream at larger quantities and also to continue to invest in other products that may be attractive to her young clients. she also wants to finish paying off the last $100 she owes for the freezer she stores the ice cream in.

\r\n\r\n

mifex offers its clients microinsurance and access to business training and educational programs. for more information about microfinance, ecuador, and our services, please visit www.mifex.org.

m. saleem is a 38-year-old married father of three children. he is living happily with his family in the area of sahiwal, pakistan. 

m. saleem owns a clothing shop in the market where he sells fancy and high quality clothes. some customers prove very poor and they do not purchase after asking the rates. he does not compromise on his quality and rates. he does not sell below his purchasing power but he does not like to refuse his worthy customers either. to win their confidence and to avoid the disappointment of his worthy customers; he wants to start a low rate clothing stall in front of his shop. this way, poor customers who do not have enough purchasing power can buy clothing easily.
 
m. saleem invests his savings and profit in his current business but does not have enough cash in hand to start the new stall. for this reason, he wants financial support from kiva. he contacted the field partner brac pakistan who is the middleman between kiva and the borrowers. 

m. saleem is very delighted and thankful to kiva and its field partner brac pakistan.

janet a. is married to a pastor and has 4 children.  janet sells second hand clothing in a small fishing village just outside of cape coast called elmina.  she is requesting a loan of $475 to buy additional clothing so she can expand her business.  she hopes this loan will increase her profits and she’ll be able to provide additional income to her family.\r\n\r\njanet is also a member of a lending group called “nkor ma ahoto traders”, which consists of 11 members in cape coast, ghana.

loreta r. is a pig grower. she engages in this business because she enjoys doing the work and she finds it profitable enough to support the needs of her  family. she has four children who are all in school. she wants to send all of them to college because she believes that when they graduate, they will be able to find better jobs. her husband is a rice grower. they use part of the harvest for the family consumption and they sell the rest to  traders. loreta thinks that growing pigs is a better way for her to contribute to the family income. she is happy about how her business is going.

in 2000, loreta started her pig business with only one sow. she wants to grow her business, so that is why she is asking for a loan from cevi to purchase feed for her pigs and to to increase the size of her pig pen. in this way, she hopes to earn enough money to pay for their food, clothing, and other needs.
 
cevi supports hard working entrepreneur like loreta. because of the credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage that cevi provides to its clients, many people are able to build their own businesses.

graça lives with her husband and son who goes to high school. she is a businesswoman.\r\n\r\nwith this loan graça intends to buy different products such as bags, blankets and bain-maries to resell. her dream is to expand her business and have her own store. her main challenge is to keep working more and more so that she can benefit from more loans from hluvuku.

sophone is 50 years old and is a widowed woman with four children. she sells at a cafe. her children work as a factory worker, vegetables seller, motor repairer, and buyer and seller of recycled materials respectively.

she will use this loan to purchase more chairs for her cafe shop. her goals are to expand her current business to get more income and change her family's living standard in the future.

insufficient working capital to buy more stock and customers' immigration are her major challenges.

tanti is a 44-year-old woman living in adidogomé. married with three children, she sells maize and millet flours which are traditionally used to make porridge. 

tanti buys stock twice per month at the local market, then resells her products in the surrounding districts and from her home. she is requesting this credit to finance the purchase of bags of maize and millet. she hopes to increase her sales and income so that she can better contribute to her family’s expenses.

mary is a married woman. she describes herself to be honest. she operates a farm where she grows vegetables and other crops. she has been involved in this business for 10 years. her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. she will use the kes 80,000 loan to buy farm inputs to boost production. this is her fourth loan with smep microfinance bank. her previous loans were repaid successfully.

dora is a member of the communal bank "winay", in the district and province of puno. she is 58 years old and married with 2 children whom she helps support financially. with her first loan, dora purchased merchandise to sell in her small general store. she has been working with the communal bank for almost 3 years now. with the new loan, which she will repay in 4 payments, she will purchase more merchandise for her business so that she can continue to support her family.


translated from spanish by emily charnes, kiva volunteer

mohira is in the photograph. she is 32. she lives together with her family in the town of tursunzoda. she is married and has one child. her child is still small and goes to kindergarten. her husband works in animal husbandry and farming.

for three years, mohira has worked in cattle breeding. she wants to expand this work, so as to increase the number of livestock. mohira buys cattle at the cattle market, fattens them for 40 to 60 days, then resells them at the cattle market. her husband helps her. she does not have enough funds to buy livestock, so she applied for a loan. this loan will help her get ahead, and it will expand this small business.

born around 1960, elisabethe lives with her 7 children and her husband in mana, in the rural commune of ouelessebougou.  she lives in a nuclear family.

she got involved in income-generating activities at a young age, learning from an aunt who was selling grains.  after many years of experience working with her aunt, she decided to start buying and selling grains: millet, fonio, maize, black-eyed peas, groundnut, bissap etc.

having duly repaid three previous loans, elisabethe is taking her fourth loan with soro yiriwaso.  she will use her loan to buy 40 bags of millet from rural producers in ouelessebougou, mana and moridjambougou and very occasionally from local wholesalers.  she sells for cash or on credit to a retail customer base mainly consisting of consumers.  she sells from home, at the ouelessebougou market and other surrounding markets.

she is hoping to make a monthly profit of 30,000 cfa francs which will be used in part to help her husband take care of the family's needs and repay her loan, while the rest will be reinvested in her business.

catalina is 32 years old and lives in the municipality of medellín. she’s a happy married woman and loves her husband more than anybody, and he has become in a big motivation for her. in 2002 she started her own business, a selling place where she commercializes different kinds of products like food, accessories, clothes and others.

she wants to improve her business so that she can improve her sales and get more profits. she also wants to be more competitive in the market because there are a lot of other stores like hers, but she knows she can offer better service and products with high quality. she’s asking for a loan so that she can buy inputs, toys especially, for this christmas season.

catalina has big expectations for the future of her business; she wants to see it as a successful and recognized business. she also wants to improve the condition of her house. help catalina with the loan she needs.

leah is a married woman with one child. her child attends school. she lives in her own house, which has electricity and piped water. her greatest monthly expense is food .

she has operated a retail shop for the past four years, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. she faces a major challenge of creditors taking too long to repay her for goods taken on credit.

with the loan she is requesting she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

jenny elizabeth alegría r. is 39 years old and married. she has 4 children. her business is the sale of general merchandise, which she has done for more than 12 years. doña jenny began in the business through her aunt, who taught her the trade. it was through her aunt that she learned to enjoy the business, and through it to help maintain her family. jenny intends to continue growing her business to strongly compete in the market. the loan she is requesting is for working capital, for the purchase of perfumes, creams and undergarments, among other things. jenny's dream is to continue improving her business in order to someday establish a restaurant.

translated from spanish by elizabeth novesky, kiva volunteer

nazeer is a 46-year-old married woman. she has been running a business of animal sales and purchase for the past three years. she buys animals (baby goats and baby cows) at low prices, brings them up and then her husband sells them out in the market at higher prices. now she has 5 goats and 1 cow.  \r\n\r\nshe has gradually improved her business with the support of kashf foundation.  currently she requested a loan of 35,000 pkr to purchase two more goats. she is in her 3rd loan cycle with a good repayment history.  she hopes to grow her business and dreams of giving a good and quality education to her children through all her hard work in her business.

evangelina is 52 years old and married with five children. with one child in school, evangelina works very hard to provide for them.

evangelina runs a general store in the philippines and requested a 25,000 php loan through nwtf to buy items to sell like beverages, canned goods, junk food, and other groceries.

evangelina has been in this business for eight years and sells a variety of items such as biscuits, soft drinks, hopia, junk food, candy, cigarettes, etc.

in the future, evangelina would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

nida is 31 years old and has four children. nida is married and has two children who are currently in school.

nida is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the philippines. nida requested a php 10000 loan through nwtf to purchase additional piglets, feeds and other supplies for her business.

nida has been in pig fattening for 10 years now, and has borrowed 5 times in the past from nwtf to sustain it.

nida would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

the communal bank mi dios es mi fortaleza [my god is my strength] comprises 10 members: nine women and one man. they are all responsible parents who, between them, have 20 children in their care. they are from malpaisillo, in the north of the region. the members of the group are characterised by responsible and hardworking outlook, and their desire to do well personally. unfortunately they have few resources, which has meant they have all had to work from a young age. 

the coordinator of the communal bank is matilde. her economic activity is the sale of curds on a mobile basis and from her home. her objective for getting the loan is to invest it in working capital and to stock her business, which involves buying and selling curds, in order to supply her customers. 

as part of her work routine, matilde works 8 hours a day, with a basket on her head, selling her curds. the communal bank mi dios es mi fortaleza is grateful to the kiva investors for the assistance they give to people with scarce resources and in poor counties like nicaragua so that they may have a means to obtaining a decent job.

isagani is a father to two young children ages two and four from badian, cebu. he supports their needs by selling home-cooked meals. his business is situated just outside his house where people can buy food at an affordable price. he is asking for a loan to buy fish, seasoning, meat, condiments and vegetables.

isagani works hard in order to send his children to school someday. he plans to expand his business in the future.

subira, 35, is a married mother; she has four children, all of whom attend school which is her reason to strive. she’s from msambweni district. from her savings she has managed to open her own business where she sells all types and brands of clothes. she currently has a well-established clientele in the area and her clothes orders increase accordingly. thanks to her effort and dedication she has been able to build a little house for herself. 

she’s asking for the loan to buy shirts, t-shirts, shorts and other clothes that are in season and that her customers ask her for a lot. she is grateful for the support she’s receiving because everything she does is in order to provide her children with the best.

victoria is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her.  her business has been running for three years now and it is continuously growing. her loan also helped with the education of her children while her income is supporting their everyday household expenses. she and her husband are working hard to provide for their everyday expenses.
 
she would like to apply for another 8,000 php loan for additional processed meat and frozen food needed in her business.  her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and educational expenses of her children. she looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

victoria dreams to be more successful in her business and hopes that her children will finish their studies. she meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the word of god she studies.

* all cct community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

meet shomaila, a young farmer from multan region. only 26 years old, shomaila has been in farming for 10 years. as one can conclude, she is a very experienced farmer. shomaila is married and has two kids who are one year old. together with her husband, she takes care of her mother-in-law.

shomaila’s farm is mixed and consists of livestock (with cows, calves, oxen, sheep, and hens) and gardens. in the gardens, she grows barley, wheat, and potatoes. shomaila also grows grass to use as forage for her livestock.

she applied for this loan to pay for fertilizer and pesticides. this will improve her daily living and give her a chance to provide better conditions for her children. shomaila thanks you and hopes for this kiva support.

jamilu is a babban gona farmer from magami village. he joined babban gona so that he could realize better yields on his farm. since joining babban gona, jamilu no longer has to worry about having inadequate income to feed his family and children. through babban gona’s input loan he will have access to top of the range farm inputs such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average in nigeria.  this will see him increase his income considerably. this season jamilu has ambitious plans to harvest 80 bags of maize. thanks to babban gona’s support, jamilu now has the opportunity to ensure that all his children get a postsecondary education.

chhai’s group live in a rural village in kompong cham province in cambodia. chhai makes a living cultivating rice and he also does extra work as construction worker to support his family. in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these men to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.\n\t\n

safargul is a resident of the yavan region. safargul is married and has three daughters and two sons. the children help her to advance her activities. on her land, safargul raises vegetables. safargul has been engaged in this kind of work for about 15 years. safargul always puts her heart into her crop. she wants to receive a rich crop and for this safargul tries to work hard.

with the arrival of spring, safargul will prepare to plant the crop. she needs money from a loan to buy seeds and fuel mixture for a tractor. safargul has financial problems and that is why she applied for a loan. safargul believes that with the help of kiva lenders she will preserve her activities and complete the spring planting.

florencia is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school.  she is 33 years old and is a very hard working entrepreneur.

for 4 years florencia has operated a general store business in the philippines.  she requested a 15,000 php loan through nwtf to buy additional stock to sell in her general store.  she successfully repaid her previous loans and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

in the future, florencia would like to save enough money to be able to afford to send her children to college.

doña consuelo is 33 years old. she is a farmer and a housewife. she went to primary school through her fifth year, and she is the mother of three children who attend the community primary school. along with her husband, she raises and produces coffee, having approximately 15 years of experience in this business, since it was her father who taught her to work and who also gave her the land that she works today along with her husband. her coffee plantings are located approximately half an hour from her home, a distance that she walks, doing her part for everyone as a family for their development and well being.\r\n\r\nher plans for the future are to help her children so that they can finish primary school as the first step of their education and later secondary school, each one trying to make a reality of his dreams until she sees them become successful professionals, putting into practice what they have learned and being able to take charge of the land that they are working on today. as a producer of coffee, she has as a goal to continue expanding her plantings of coffee through the purchase of land and continue producing greater quantities with each harvest. she is applying for economic support for the purchase of compost, fertilizers, and new young coffee plants to plant, to clean the weeds from one part of her plantings, among other items, giving this excellent maintenance for this new season.

liza is 49 years old and single. 

she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 13000 loan through nwtf to purchase groceries like diapers, sanitary pads, bath soap, noodles, cereals, etc. to sell.

liza has been in business for 20 years and sells a variety of items such as diapers, sanitary pads, bath soap, noodles, cereals, etc. 

in the future, liza would like to save money to expand her business.

khim hak is 32 years old. she is married and resides with two children in kampot province, cambodia. she has been involved in growing rice for more than ten years, earning approximately $3 daily. her husband is a photographer who makes an income of $10 each day. in order to improve her family’s livelihood, khim hak is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a camera to use in the business. this purchase will help her generate more income for the family. in the future, she would like to run a photographry shop and send her children to a good school. moreover, she hopes to build a new house as soon as possible.\r\n

anabelle is a married woman with two children. she is a very hard -working entrepreneur. anabelle is 47 years old and has one child who is in school.

anabelle has a buy-and-sell feed business in the philippines. she requested a php 6,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy additional sacks of feed to sell.

anabelle has been in this business for three years. in the future, anabelle would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

joshua is 67 years old and comes from nakuru. he has four children of whom two are in school.

joshua hasbeen in the tailoring business for the past twenty-eight years.he has applied for his second loan from  kadet ltd after repaying his previous loan successfully. 


he intends to use the loan amount to buy fabric and materials for making clothes. he hopes to buy a plot of land in the near future.

regina is a 44-year-old single woman. she has two children between 22 and 24 years old. she describes herself as calm and kind. she operates a grocery store where she sells groceries to the local people. she has been involved in this business for three years. her business is located in a shopping centre. she describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient capital. she will use the kes 40,000 loan to add to her stock of groceries. her business goal is to grow into wholesale within five years. she hopes that in the future, she will be financially stable, educate her children at the university and buy a plot of land for herself.

maría lives in guaranda, ecuador. she is 58 years old, married, and with no children. she works as a farmer, growing corn and potatoes.

with this loan, maría wants to purchase farming supplies that she needs for planting potatoes. she hopes that this will improve her quality of life. she will purchase the supplies in guaranda.

her personal dream is to have land of her own one day. one of her current challenges is the lack of attention received by the community where she lives. in her free time, maría helps in the community's cooperative work.

hannatu remembers feeling depressed  during a particularly bad harvest. this was before she became a babban gona member. now,  hannatu, like all babban gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the nigerian farmer’s annual income. the average babban gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. however, hannatu  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “in 5 years, i want to become the most profitable farmer in my community” expressed hannatu.  with this loan, hannatu is well on her way to achieving  this dream. \n

kennedy is very hard working, shrewd and vigilant in business. he has a stone quarrying business located in the kikuba,rubirizi district. he is married and has three children. this is his first loan from ugafode microfinance ltd (mdi). he is also a farmer who grows tea and bananas. he started business in 2007 and he wanted to stabilize his life and family. he has borrowed 1,100,000 ugx to buy stones, for this is the season when many people plan to construct residential and commercial buildings ahead of the rainy season’s disturbance. his clients include schools, factories, organizations and all categories of people. he is affected by bad weather, both heavy rainfall and excessive heat, and price fluctuations on the market and high labor costs. he thanks ugafode microfinance for always being there for him and other local people in his area to help them develop their businesses, support their families and keep in service.

nelvis is 44 years old and lives in barranquilla with her spouse and three children, ages 8 to 17 years old. she works as a domestic worker. she lives in housing subsidized by the state. she obtained this housing through a micro project from a foundation that provides sustainable housing called san pablo villas. nevis has received two loans from the mario santo domingo foundation in the past four years. these loans have helped her reach her dream of having a roof on her home. she continues to remodel her home and also would like to provide her children with a good education. she is applying to kiva for a loan to buy construction materials such as tile, cement for plastering and paint. with these improvements she and her family will feel more comfortable in their home.\r\n\r\n

this loan helps claudette get connected to her local prepay microgrid.

claudette is a 58-year-old single mother of four children, three in school. she is a farmer and lives in a small house in les anglais, in southern haiti. she is seeking a loan from kiva lenders to be able to connect to the local solar-powered microgrid, and to have her business finally independent of her noisy and costly diesel generator. she is looking forward to being connected to the microgrid as it will allow her to save money and secure reliable and clean electricity.

after running pilots since 2012 that have proved the benefits of prepay electricity to people in les anglais (first with 14 households, and then with 54), earthspark international is developing a full-scale, sun powered microgrid. this microgrid is expected to meet the needs of up to 500 households.\xa0kiva loans allow earthspark to increase the number of beneficiaries by reducing the upfront costs for customers, and will be repaid over time by electricity sales.

to see a video of les anglais and the hybrid solar grid, please click here.

john is a small trader, married with 6 children. life was very difficult for john after the war. with some small savings, he started selling a few packets of cigarettes. when smt expanded its activities in makeni town of sierra leone, john obtained loans and diversified his business.  his children have school fees now, so he also needs to expand his business to be able to generate more income for future high school requirements. he is therefore requesting a $300 loan for the purpose. john is 52 years old.

alejandra is single, and she is a woman with a great entrepreneurial mentality, dreams, and clear goals.

two years ago she began to work in a business that was a combination of an internet café and a store selling sweets and other food items. the idea for this business arose from the need to obtain employment that would give her the opportunity to work independently, and furthermore, because no similar business existed in the community.

little by little her business strengthened, and now she sells stationery items and offers internet service.

she is applying for financial encouragement to make the purchase of display cases and a stock of stationery items with which she will boost her business in an effective manner.

in this way her business will advance and she will be able to offer her household good income to improve their quality of life.

mwanatumu is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. she rents a house that has electricity, but no piped water. her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

for the past three years, she has operated a cereals shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. she mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges.

with the kes 50,000, she wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, cooking fat and oil. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

julia is 62 years old and has 10 children. she is a group leader and is representing her group formed by 12 farmers in matete district, kenya.

julia has been farming with one acre fund for years now, having joined the program for the first time in 2011. this decision was largely a result of her desire to earn enough to send her children to school. and although she described her last harvest as very good, she believes she could have a better one this year by continuing to work alongside one acre fund. julia also decided to purchase two solar lights as part of her loan, which she is very excited about, as it will allow her to have light during dark hours for her children to be able to study.

obtaining this loan means that julia 's group will be able to receive a total of 13 solar lights, as well as farming inputs to plant a total of 4 acres.

flor is a happily married woman and has a 12 year old son.

she started her own business three years ago, selling liqueurs, fried food, drinks and offering a billiard service. she works with her husband who is also independent and they employ a lady on a daily basis, mainly on the weekends.

she wants to stock her business with more products such as liqueurs and fried food, as well as buy some implements for her billiards table to replace the ones that are in bad condition.

taking advantage of the great reception that her business has and the good services they offer, she wants to increase their sales. the problem is she doesn't have sufficient capital to do this, so they are turning to a loan to reach their objective.

her greatest dream is to be able to have her own house and to see her son grow into a good person.

oun is a married woman who has been farming and working as a paid laborer for five years. she lives in a small house located in the thala barivat district of steung treng province with her husband. on average oun and her husband can earn only a little income per day, which is just enough to cover the family’s expenses and save some for future needs.

to keep supporting her farming, oun is now leading a group of three members to apply for a loan via visionfund. this will be her second loan cycle. her income has increased due to her previous loan. with this new loan, she will buy fertilizer and seeds for her farmland, which she expects will increase her crop yields. she hopes this supportive loan will help provide her a better income and improve her living conditions.

godfrey is 45 years old and has seven children. he has been a farmer for more than 20 years and is always said to be a very experienced farmer. even though godfrey is the only one featured in the above picture, he is actually representing his group formed by 12 farmers in chwele district, kenya.

godfrey started working alongside one acre fund a few years ago, in 2012, and decided to do so because he wanted to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods. since then, he has seen his life improve; especially in the sense that he has been able to consistently feed his family ever since. this year he decided to represent his group because he wanted to be more active in his community.

godfrey’s group will receive farming inputs to plant a total of 11 acres of land. additionally, some of the farmers in the group will be purchasing a solar light, so with this loan the group will also receive a total of five solar lights.

kaneez has been living in sahiwal for the past 15 years with her family in a single-room brick house. sahiwal is a small city in pakistan known for its agriculture and cattle farming. she is 42 years of age and has given birth to two sons and two daughters. all of them are enrolled in a local school getting their education. her husband’s name is a. h. and he is a blacksmith by profession. he makes iron boxes (used to keep clothes, quilts and blankets and usually used in houses) and sells through his shop. he is an expert and has a good name in this industry in his area. kaneez herself is a housewife who stays at home and does her household responsibilities. she is a very supportive lady and tries her best to provide relief to her family with her work.
