juana is a 49-year-old mother of 2 children, neither of whom live with her. she has had a small grocery store in her home for 3 years, where she offers essential products such as basic grains. she attends to her business personally and has always had the support of her family. juana has had several loans, and all of them have been used to improve her business. currently she is requesting this loan for working capital, which will be used to purchase rice, sugar, detergents, coffee, oil, and some toys for the christmas season. her desire is to maintain this economic activity, since these are difficult times, due to a lot of competition.

translated from spanish by mark broscoe, kiva volunteer

although she has received no prior formal education, margaret is an entrepreneur. she works as a petty trader in apewosika (near cape coast). she has been involved in this enterprise for 1 year. margaret is married and has 3 children. her husband works as a teacher. the proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees. margaret wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of biscuits, groundnuts, and gari. in the long term, margaret plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

sikinan is a hardworking farmer who paid off her loan and is now preparing for the upcoming planting season. she has leased an extra piece of land where she plans to grow more wheat.

she has acquired a loan of kes 80,000 which will facilitate land preparation as well as the purchase of seedlings and fertilizers.

she will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her children. she hopes to acquire a large piece of land in the future.

pola lives in the kongowea area of coast province, kenya. she is married and has eight children; four of whom attend school. she owns a firewood store that she has been operating for three years. apart from which, she earns a salary from fish mongering.

she learned about milango through a friend with an aim of accessing credit to improve the business operations. the challenge she faces is scarcity of firewood. pola is applying for a loan of 5,500 kenyan shillings to buy logs to get the firewood. the extra income from the loan will be added to her savings to improve the living standards of her family.

a citizen of the rural village of banteay meanchey province’s mongkul borey district, samet is 33 years old and married with two dependent children who are still in school.

to make a living and support their family, samet and her husband have been farming rice on four hectares of farmland as their primary business for ten years. her family’s daily income is about 30,000 khr but she can only manage to save about 15,000 khr each day after deducting daily expenses.

samet has been with visionfund for one cycle and has successfully paid back the past loan. the other member of the group has been with visionfund for three cycles. samet wisely used her previous loan to support her children’s education.

now, she is leading her group of two to apply for another loan of 500,000 khr each. samet, who is the leader, will use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland and will use part of it to buy household supplies for the family. she hopes to cultivate her rice to earn more income in order to improve her lifestyle.

m. mobibi is 53 years old. she is married with 4 adorable children. mobibi has been able to combine her love of children with a successful business selling kid’s clothing at a busy market in dushanbe. mobibi currently has one sales place at the market. eventually, she would like to open a store in a permanent facility. she has requested a loan of 5400 somoni to help purchase new clothing inventory.  


more about tajikistan and imon international

tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the silk road and the end of alexander the great's rule. it has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including rudaki, avicenna, ferdowsi, omar khayyam, jomi, and rumi. the country is home to communities that still speak the ancient sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium bc. and, even today, it is a complex mixture of the islamic faith, soviet culture, new west culture and central asian traditions.

but tajikistan is also the poorest of the former soviet republics. the civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the u.s.s.r., further damaged the already weak economy. in addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. these conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly russia. while the people of tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

imon's history

since december 2007, imon international has worked closely with kiva and kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. funds raised through kiva have already been distributed to thousands of imon international's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. to learn more about imon international's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

juan josé is a 42-year-old man. he's married with a beautiful family and four children between five and 14 years old. this family lives in the community of san antonio suchitepéquez.

to earn income and support his family, he buys and sells milk. he's been doing this work for 10 years and also works as a guard on a farm to increase his income.

juan josé lives in a community very far from his work and transportation to travel in this community is not very frequent. as a result of this need, he's seeking a loan to buy a motorcycle which he will use to transport himself to his business and work. his biggest desire is to improve his family's location.

elizabeth is a married woman. she has four children. she describes herself to be polite. she operates a retail business where she sells vegetables. she has been involved in this business for eight years. her primary customers are locals. she describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital.

she will use the kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of vegetables. she hopes that in the future she will educate her children to university level. this is her third loan with smep microfinance bank. she will use the anticipated profits to expand the business.

khadija is a married woman with four children. she sells seasonal fruits and vegetables such as pears, oranges, apples, bananas, onions, potatoes, and cabbages. khadija has ten years of experience in this field and has gained the necessary skills and knowledge required for her business.

fruits are very popular among the people of mombasa and, they are in high demand throughout the year. people like to eat fresh fruit, and it is one of the main desserts given to guests. her shop is located in a bazaar. people always pass her shop and come to buy some fresh fruit. 

khadija wants to expand her business. she does not have enough products to cover the high demand. she would like to purchase more fruits and vegetables and increase her turnover as well as improve the lives of her family members.

from dipolog, zamboanga del norte, lily earns a living through her car wash business. she seeks to have enough inventory to continuously provide for her family. for her capital needs, pmpc has stood by her since the start of her business. she is happy that she is able to survive the odds of business with determination and her family as her inspiration. to earn more, she applied for a loan to buy car wash supplies and maintenance. lily hopes to live comfortably with her children until they finish their studies.

demetria, 43, lives in her own home with her husband and her daughter margot, 7. since she was very young, she has worked hard for the well-being of her family and has had a variety of jobs. currently she sells condiments. this business generates the necessary economic income for her to provide a high quality of life to her family. she offers these condiments in a market that is near the area where she lives. she prepares various sauces and spices like ocopa (a spicy sauce made of peanuts, chili peppers, and herbs), chili sauces, ground garlic, and others. the housewives in the area prefer her and frequently acquire their sauces from her to prepare their food quickly.\r\n\r\nshe also sells various beauty products by catalog to her friends and people she knows. in the future, she wants to establish a more stable business and to administer it from her home. she feels at peace with her jobs because she wants to get ahead little by little. this is her second loan that she has had with microfinanzas prisma, and she promises to be very punctual with her repayments. she plans to invest the money from her credit in the purchase of a larger quantity of ingredients that she needs to make her condiments. she will also invest part of it in the purchase of beauty products that are on sale right now.

translated from spanish by tanya harper, kiva volunteer

lyra is a married woman with six children. she is a very hard  working entrepreneur. lyra is 39 years old and has five children who are currently in school.

lyra has a food vending business in the philippines. lyra requested a php 6000 loan amount through nwtf to purchase ingredients like flour, fish, beans, sugar, etc. for her food production business.

lyra has been in this business for 10 years.  in the future, lyra would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

as a parent of four children, lutgarda works hard to support her family. she has a business culturing seaweed in the philippines, and also earns additional income from fishing.

lutgarda is borrowing php 10,000 through nwtf to purchase seaweed seedlings and other materials for her business culturing seaweed.

lutgarda has been sustaining her business activities through her past 12 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

sheedan is a 48-year-old married woman and a mother of six. she has been running a business selling clothes for many years. she purchases a variety of clothes from the main city and then sells them to the people of her vicinity. she has become famous for selling good quality clothes in her community. sheedan requested a loan of pkr 30,000 from kashf foundation to buy a stock of different clothes for the winter season by taking into account the choices and tastes of her customers. in this way, she will be able to earn more income through more sales. she hopes to have a good experience with this new loan and wants to grow her business. she expects a boost in her earnings and wishes to spend part of her profits on the betterment of her family members. \r\n\r\n

lolita has been running a sari-sari store for two years. she is from getafe, bohol. she is a 38-year-old, married woman, and she has three children, ages 11, 14 and 17 years. her husband is a farmer and works in the government.

lolita is requesting a loan, for additional capital with which to buy canned goods and soft drinks. in the future, she plans to reinvest her profits and continue to expand her business, so she can send her children to school

as a married parent of four children, maria luzviminda works hard to support her family.

she has a general store business in the philippines and earns additional income from raising pigs. maria luzviminda is borrowing php 20,000 through nwtf to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

maria luzviminda has been sustaining her business activities through her past 27 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

gladys vanesa g. is a secondary school teacher in a community called isidrillo, which is 6 kilometers from esteli. she draws up her lesson plan and then imparts it during a 5-hour period from monday until friday. gladys will use her loan to buy a double bed. she wants a new bed because the one she has has given all it had to give. gladys is a single mother of two, school-age children; she lives with her sister. this is her 6th loan with ceprodel over the four years she has collaborated with ceprodel. she states that ceprodel's loans have been much help to her because they have covered some expenses and have paid for some home appliances she needed.

translated from spanish by michael bujazan, kiva volunteer

jennifer is 26 years old and married. she has two children.

jennifer runs a general store in the philippines. she has been in this business for three years.

jennifer requested a php 11,000 loan through nwtf to buy additional items to sell like soap, sugar, soft drinks, cooking oil, personal care products, and snack foods.

jennifer would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

danis says, "many thanks for the efforts of kiva to provide me with assistance. as a result, i was able to acquire new equipment." she has been very happy since receiving her kiva loan because she was able to buy a photocopier. now she has more customers, which translates into revenue. \r\n

\r\nfor this reason, danis is applying for a new kiva loan so that she can buy a cpu and upgrade her equipment, thus enabling her to serve her customers better and provide them with faster responses in terms of technology. her customers are the reason for her to be in business.

marife is a married woman with five children. she is a very hard-working entrepreneur. marife is 42 years old and has three children who are in school.

marife has a fish-vending business in the philippines. marife requested a php 10,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy a variety of fish and other supplies needed in her business.

marife has been in this business for 20 years. in the future, marife would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

marcos is a very hardworking man.  every day he works on his plot of land cultivating cassava. he works in agriculture because it is the only source of income to be able to get his family ahead, above all because he is the father of four children, ages 13, 13, 9 and 1.\r\n\r\nmarcos is grateful for the support that has been given to him.  he will be able to buy soil amendments and fertilizers, among other things.  in this way, he will be able to maintain his crop and can get a better harvest.  he can make his biggest dream a reality: to give his children a profession.

martin is a married man with four children, all of whom attend school. he owns a house that has electricity and piped water. his greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

for the past ten years, he has operated a retail shop business, selling to his neighbours and passersby. he faces a major challenge of seasonality in his place of operation. he dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

with the kes 20,000 he wants to purchase bales of wheat flour, maize flour, and rice for sale. he decided to join yehu to access loans to boost his business.

touch is a 40-year-old, married woman. she and her husband reside with their five children in takeo province, cambodia.

to earn a living, she has been involved in the agricultural business for more than twenty years. specifically, she cultivates rice and raises pigs. she explains that she has extensive experience and has been successful throughout her career. she typically earns approximately $5 per day from her work. her husband helps her run the business. two of her children are employed in a garment factory, and they earn approximately $4 per day.

due to difficulties relating to her family’s transportation needs, touch is requesting a loan in the amount of $1,200 to purchase a motorbike for her family's commuting needs to better support their family. in the future, she would like to expand her pig farm and to help her children earn bachelor’s degrees. moreover, she hopes to build a new house as soon as possible.

virginia del carmen rodriguez, ayda read mirna g. and maria lopez m. are the ones that promote the “rey de reyes“ group. they live in the camilo ortega area in managua.

virginia del carmen rodriguez is 40 years old and the coordinator of the group. she sells milk, gas and coal, and what she wants the most is to grow her business.

ayda lea g. is 33 years old and sells ice cream, ice and soft drinks.

mirna maría l. m. is 28 years old and has a fried food business at home. the fry food restaurants are very popular in nicaragua. the fried meals are precooked and only need to be on the grill, so people usually buy them for dinner. salgado is the coordinator of the group and what she wants the most is to improve her business and continue working for her family.

translated from spanish by adriana pierce, kiva volunteer

margarita is married and mother of two dependents. she is 41 years old and lives in san vicente, tambulig. for the past two years, margarita has owned and operated a motorcycle transport business. she established her business as a way of generating an extra 4,600 php income each month. margarita is a new gdmpc member. 

margarita is requesting a 10,000 php loan from gdmpc to purchase motorcycle spare parts and accessories. in the future, margarita wants to purchase more motorcycles for her business.

odilia is a single, hard-working 46-year-old woman. (she is the one pictured on the left in a green blouse with white figures.)  she lives in the department of suchitepéquez  and her main work is doing typical embroideries, mainly skirts and blouses. she has been doing this for two years and sells her products in the regional markets in her community.  it is a profitable activity and the majority of her earnings go to help her family. \r\n\r\nthis is why they formed a group to support each other from production to the sale of the final product.  odilia is asking for a loan so she can buy materials to make these typical pieces of clothing. her goal is to increase her sales and have her own stand.  currently she rents space to sell her products.

mariam appreciates  her previous loan that improved her living standards.  her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.\r\n \r\nshe would like to apply for a loan of 20,000 kes to buy more goats for her business. she thanks yehu for their financial support.

sabiu is a hardworking babban gona maize farmer from dokan itu village. sabiu is grateful to be a member of babban gona, his partner in the fight against poverty. building on his previous input loan, sabiu expects to reap up to 35 bags/hectare of maize, double the national average of 18 bags/hectare.

as a babban gona member, sabiu does not have to forfeit making a profit by selling his maize at low harvest prices to cater for basic provisions for his family. through this loan, known as a harvest advance loan, sabiu will receive a cash advance, equal to the price of maize at harvest that allows him to meet pressing household needs such as food and clothing.

with babban gona’s support, sabiu will store his maize at harvest and sell it for up to 40% higher than the market price. with his maize stored, sabiu can generate earnings of up to $1,000/hectare, more than four times the average nigerian farmer’s annual income.

with this cash advance and increased income, sabiu hopes to attain his personal goal: to purchase more farmland.

sreihiep’s group live in a rural village in siem reap province in cambodia. sreihiep makes a living cultivating rice to support her family. in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

adela belongs to the village bank “santa ana” in the moyobamba district, province of moyobamba, department of san martin. she lives with her partner, is 44 years old, and is a mother to 1 child that depends on her. with the security of having a great seasoning mix to prepare different types of foods, and with her own initiative, she used her first loan of 300 pen to launch her business in the sale of food; she sells meals daily in her business which is located in her home. currently, though time has passed she continues in the same business, relying on a loyal client base that seeks her food stall daily, where she attends to them with the charisma that she is known for. with this loan of 2,000 pen, she will purchase supplies to prepare her daily meals such as a sack of rice, sugar, oil in packages, chicken, and also utensils to use in her business that will allow her to give her clients a better service. she is ready for anything and still feels strong enough to continue working and continue moving forward. adela thanks the manuela ramos movement for contributing to the fulfillment of her dreams and goals.

translated from spanish by mariela cedeno, kiva volunteer

this good, nice woman in the photo is badal. she is 64 years old; she is a wonderful, caring wife and mother of six children. badal's husband rears animals, and her son is a builder. badal is a hard-working woman; she has been cultivating plants for 15 years, and despite her age, she continues to work in the field. she has 2.5 hectares of land. now she is preparing for the autumn sowing. she prepared the land, and now asks for your help to buy onion and garlic seeds, and to purchase mineral fertilizers. she plans to plant onions on 1 hectare of land, and garlic on 0.20 hectares of land. badal hopes for your support and expresses her gratitude to you in advance.

ny (pictured here) is 33 years old and her husband, soy, is 42 years old. they live in a suburb of phnom penh, about 15 kilometres away. they have been married since 1995 and have four children - three sons and one daughter. one is a garment worker, two attend school, and another one is still too young. 

ny has been operating a business, renting out a space of her house to garment workers for five years. her husband is a garment worker. she is asking for a loan of $1,000 to buy a motorcycle for commuting.

hary is thirty-eight years old and married to a man who works in a bus depot. the couple have three children (twenty-one, twenty and eleven years old). the eldest already works as a trader and the other two are still studying.

hary used to work in a ftz company but, when it closed, she opened a general store. her first dealings with the field partner, cefor, were in 2012. her previous loans have increased her working capital, expanded the range of products that she sells and helped her create a profitable business. this loan will buy rice, sugar, oil, soap, candles and salt for sale in the shop. this is important as the shop provides most of the income for the family.

hary lives with her family in their own house. her aim is to expand her business, be able to educate her children and greatly improve their living conditions.

joseph is a 52-year-old man living in fort portal, uganda. he is married to a businesswoman and together they have five children, ages 23, 19, 17, 15 and 13 years old. he lives in a family of ten people. he has a produce business, purchasing cereals like maize, rice and beans for reselling at a profit. he has been at it for the last 20 years. joseph says the biggest challenge he faces is the fluctuating prices of his produce. sometimes the prices hit a low, meaning his profit is low for that period. however, he says it is a profitable venture and he would like to develop it further. joseph intends to use this loan to purchase beans, rice and maize for reselling at a profit.

teresa a. is from the village of poblacion1, clarin,misamis occidental. she is 30 years old. teresa is married and has 4 school-aged children. to make a living, teresa owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. while not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling kitchen supplies and products in the local community. teresa has been engaged in her business for over 1 years and earns approximately 2,500.00 php a month for these activities.

in 2009, teresa joined pmpc to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. teresa is requesting a new loan of 4000 php which will be used to purchase new equipment & tools to expand the business. this loan will be the 1st loan taken out by teresa from pmpc. she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of the borrower's family. 

about pmpc:

paglaum multi-purpose cooperative (pmpc is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern mindanao. it reaches out to the rural poor using the grameen model.

*note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva.  given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

senora rosa emilia is 31 years old. she is married and has a 14-year-old in high school. an enterprising businesswoman, rosa emilia sells clothes during the day and at night she sells meals from a food stand. for the past two years, rosa has managed these businesses. her food stand is located in the central park in the city of somotillo. she is well known for her banana chips, tacos and enchiladas. her clothing she sells on foot. she hopes to be able to afford a cart to transport and better display her items. this loan of c$ 7,000 will go towards the purchase of supplies for her food cart and items to increase her inventory of clothing.

ivy is a very ambitious, enterprising, and go-getting woman who hails from the litein area of kenya. she is a proud mother and has been doing mixed farming for the past ten years. her primary source of income is crop selling. 

ivy loves farming and she really takes good care of her dairy cows. the litein area has conditions that favour horticultural farming: good soil, good climate, a good transport system, and a ready market for horticultural products. ivy wants to take advantage and start horticultural farming. 

ivy is seeking a loan to buy seeds and start horticultural farming, and through improved income, she will be able to improve her living conditions and secure the future of her family. the financial benefits that ivy will reap are almost immediate, and hence she will be assured of a secure future. she plans to start exporting her produce to international markets.
ivy is grateful to the kiva lenders who make up part of this dream. she pledges to fully repay the loan.

señora ana julia is 37 years of age, lives with her life companion and has 4 children, all of which go to grade and secondary school. she lives in the villa reconciliación settlement, a marginalized, very poor, rural neighborhood. the dwellings of the settlers are built of zinc, plastic and/or wood. the area does not have a sewer system. there is a shortage of water and the streets are not paved. the housing conditions of the lady are very humble. she has many limitations due to the fact that she can not rely on having the necessary resources to improve the infrastructure of her dwelling.

ana julia’s life companion works in the duty-free zone of operative. the pay that he receives is very little and does not cover even half of the basic food needs of the children. being in this difficult situation, the lady has decided to rent rooms at low prices to people from other areas, with the objective of having a monthly income and in this way she can meet all the family expenses. with this activity the lady assures that her children will have food. this is how her family will subsist and move forward, despite the difficult economic situation in the country. at this time ana julia needs a loan to improve the condition of the rooms that she rents. she wants to refinish the walls, to cover certain holes that they have and to paint them, to give a better appearance to the rooms so that she can come to receive a better income from them.

translated from spanish by b, kiva volunteer.

la señora ana julia tiene 37 años de edad, vive con su compañero de vida, tiene 4 hijos, los cuales todos se encuentran estudiando en primaria y secundaria, habita en el asentamiento villa reconciliación, un barrio rural, muy pobre, marginado, las viviendas de los pobladores son construidas de zinc, plástico y/o madera, no tiene alcantarillado, existe escasez de agua, las calles no están pavimentadas. las condiciones habitacionales de la señora es muy humilde, tienen muchas limitaciones debido a que no cuenta con los recursos necesarios para mejor la infraestructura de la vivienda.

el compañero de vida de la señora trabaja en la zona franca de operario, el pago que obtiene es muy bajo y alcanza a cubrir ni la mitad de la canasta básica de los alimentos de los niños, viéndose en esta difícil situación, la señora decide alquilar cuartos a personas ajenas a la localidad a precios bajos, con el objetivo de tener ingresos fijos mensualmente y de esta manera pueda asumir todos los gastos familiares. con esta actividad la señora asegura la alimentación de sus hijos, es así como esta familia subsiste y sale adelante, pese a la dura situación económica en la que se encuentra el país. en estos momentos la señora requiere un préstamo para acondicionar mejor los cuartos que alquila, desea darle un fino a las paredes, tapar ciertos agujeros que poseen y pintarlos, para darle una mejor presentación a los cuartos y pueda llegar a tener una mejor renta de los mismos.

josephine has been running a retail shop for six years – an idea she got to meet the needs of her school-going children. she also supplies fresh fruit to hotels for additional income. she is married and has three children, ages 18, 16, 10 years old. all attend school; the elder two in high schools and the last in primary school. she lives in malindi town of the coastal province, kenya. 

josephine joined milango in april, 2011, after an invitation from a friend. her major challenge comes from her supply business where payments are made on a monthly basis. a loan of 60,000 kenyan shillings will help josephine restock her business with retail stock like soap, sugar, flour, oil, etc. josephine intends to faithfully repay her upcoming loan, so she can obtain higher credit and establish a salon and a boutique. this loan will also help her obtain additional income to carry out farming on the piece of land she bought using her first loan. she hopes milango partners, especially kiva, will support her with credit for her upcoming businesses.

hermenia is a hardworking businesswoman from tudela.

she has been into selling dried fish for more than 5 years, and that gives her an approximate monthly income of 10,000 php that enables her to support her family's needs.

she is able to support the education of her children.

hermenia is supported financially by paglaum mpc, and that makes her business survive the odds. now that she wants to expand her business, she ask for a loan of 50,000 php to purchase additional supplies of dried fish to sell.

the six women of the yiriwaso group are all married and on average 34 years old with 3 children. they live in monogamous households in médine, one of the areas of the city of sikasso, 3rd administrative region of the republic of mali. they are on their fourth collaboration with the microfinance institution soro yiriwaso in order to meet the needs of their constantly increasing clientele and to increase their sales. they run a range of businesses, which include among others the sale of shoes, oranges, potatoes, and children's clothing. with this loan, they intend to buy 50 pairs of shoes, 25 100-kg sacks of oranges, 10 100-kg bags of potatoes, and 18 children's outfits. they supply themselves at the grand market in the city of sikasso and in burkina faso. their merchandise is sold on-the-spot at the sikasso grand market and often door-to-door to a clientele composed of women and men, in cash at retail and on credit. they foresee realizing an average monthly profit of 18,000 fcfa each, of which one portion will be used to pay for their children's education and health, and the remaining portion will be invested in their businesses.

translated from french by vilas menon, kiva volunteer

ma. rovelyn hails from the town of sagbayan. she is 37 years of age. she is married with five children. her eldest is 14, while the youngest is 4. she earns a living by means of buying and selling piglets and goats respectively. her husband has an income that could help defray the family's daily expenses.

she would like to boost her earnings by acquiring additional funds. ma. rovelyn decided to avail herself of a loan to buy additional piglets and livestock like goats. in this way, her financial income will be augmented, and thus increase her profitability and enable her to roll out her capital. with these, she would be able to support the needs of her family and slowly improve their livelihood as well.

she dreams of having a truck, which would be very useful in transporting her livestock in the years to come.

lorenza is married and has five children who attend school. she and her husband are both teachers in the local school, where her children are able to receive an education. in addition to her teaching and motherly duties, lorenza has been running a business that distributes various textiles for 15 years and has slowly expanded it to include five employees. \r\n\r\nlorenza requested a loan, which she will use to expand her textile business to other areas around lake atitlán, increase the wages for her employees, and possibly hire additional employees. lorenza is the president of the santa isabel trust bank in the town of santa maría. the group has been together for five years and currently includes eight members. the women in the group have varying levels of education. the businesses of the santa isabel members are diverse, from raising chicken to selling corn and beans to running daily consumption stores.

faustine is 45-years-old and lives in the town of nateete in the kampala region of uganda. she is married and has 5 children with 4 of them currently in school. for the past 8 years, faustine has been working hard to manage her clothing business, which sells clothes. 

to help expand her business, faustine has requested a loan of 4,000,000 ugandan shillings from brac uganda. the loan will be used to buy more clothes, and will help faustine to generate greater profits and pay school fees. faustine hopes that in the future she will be able to increase her business.

cecilia, 56 years old and married, works very hard to provide for her family. for 30 years she has run a general store in the philippines that sells a variety of items.


cecilia has requested a php 5000 loan through nwtf to buy more goods to sell such as groceries, canned goods, milk, sugar, coffee, etc. in the future she would like to save enough money to expand her enterprise.

elizabeth is a 58-year-old married woman from polo, dapitan city, who has one child. she has been a member of the paglaum-mpc for almost seven years. \r\n\r\nelizabeth owns and manages a small eatery in front of their house, which is on a national road that many people pass through looking for places to eat. due to the improvements to their city, many people travel in and out of the vicinity, so she has decided to expand her business to cook more dishes and also to repair the site in order to draw more people to visit her eatery. to fund this project, she needs additional capital, so she has requested a loan from paglaum-mpc.

55-year old maría auxiliadora has owned a corner store for four years. she is a very happy woman and grateful to kiva and micrédito for her previous loan. thanks to the loan she was able to invest in her business.

using the profits from her business, maría auxiliadora was able to buy a used vehicle to use to make purchases and transport merchandise. now she is seeking a new loan to buy soap, coffee, matches, sugar, eggs and other products to sell. one of her next goals is to make improvements to her home.

ernestina is 48 years old, did not have the opportunity to study due to financial difficulties, is a single mother, and her 3 children work.

ernestina works at the household tasks, and in addition sells clothing house to house, and also to some customers who come to her house to purchase.

she needs the loan to purchase clothing for children and adults to continue selling.

ernestina plans to establish a boutique to work only from her house.

sakina is a 41-year-old married woman and works from home as a tailor. she has been in this line of work for ten years now and is proud to be contributing to her household income. when sakina was not earning her family was going through a severe financial crisis that compelled her to use her stitching skills in a productive manner, as her husband was the sole breadwinner of the family. sakina felt it obligatory to change her family’s living standards. her hard work helped her establish a good clientele but she is having difficulty in fulfilling large orders so she applied for a loan of pkr 50,000 to purchase a new stitching machine with some spools of threads in various colors. she is in her sixth loan cycle with good repayment behavior. she expects a boost in her earnings and wishes to spend it on the betterment of her family members.

juana lucia is a hard-working and entrepreneurial woman of 31 years. she has been a primary school teacher at nicarao de diria for 4 years, a job that she loves.

teacher juana is married and has two children, one who's 12 and a 1 year old girl. she wants the loan to repair her house because water can get in when it rains. she also wants to put down tile.

her dream is to have a motorbike that will allow her to get around to the schools where she works.

saima is a 32-year-old woman who lives in gujranwala, pakistan, a large agricultural city. she has been involved in a livestock business with her husband for the last 10 years. she and her husband take care of the buffaloes and sell milk in their community to handle their family expenses.

at the moment, they are facing a problem due to low milk production because of the poor quality of their fodder. therefore, saima has asked for a loan from jws pakistan to purchase a new buffalo and good-quality fodder for their buffaloes. this will be helpful in raising milk production. she is hopeful that this loan will help their business be more productive.

saima and her husband are very thankful to kiva and jws pakistan.

agnes a. is 32, married, and has two children, aged 7 and 5. she owns and operates a little grocery shop selling items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, frozen beef, chicken, and fish. she wants to use the loan to buy more rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, etc. to expand her business. she believes that with increased income, she would be better able to provide a decent accommodation for her family.

agnes belongs to the community group called determination trust group. in this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access a loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

morena manages a store in the village of villa corazon, mallig, isabela. she is married and blessed with two children who are currently studying. she wishes that her children will finish their studies and this is the reason why she and her husband keep on working hard for them to provide their educational needs. since their income from farming is not enough, she decided to venture in another business as an alternative source of income. 

“through sacrifices and patience you can achieve success,” said morena. she is a vegetable vendor in their village. she would like to buy additional vegetables to further minimize her fare in going to the market. but her capital is insufficient and that’s the reason why she is asking for additional financial support from kiva lenders to gain a bigger income for her family needs. she is requesting a loan of php 5,000 that she can use to buy more vegetables.

amidst flowers and trees lives freddy, a forty-five year old man who is the owner of his own nursery. he began this business when he was ten years old. in his garden he has fruit plants and ornamental plants. currently he has another income as well; he works as a security guard. day after day, freddy works hard to give a better quality of life to his four children and his wife. he is asking for a loan to invest in his business. with the money he is asking for he is going to buy manure, plastic bags, and female plants. in the nursery he has the help of his family.

when she was a child, one of heydi’s favourite games was playing school. she always used to keep her little friends in order and taught them their lessons. now she wishes to be a real teacher. she is 25 years old, a single mother, and studying year five of biology and chemistry on saturdays. as well as studying, two years ago heydi started teaching biology on weekdays. 

careful and dedicated are two words that define this wonderful woman who works hard every day to provide the best she can for her two daughters. she has managed to bring them up with the help of her parents.

heydi is seeking a loan to pay for courses and graduation. she is confident that the loan will be a great help. once she has her teaching qualifications, she will get better offers of employment and be paid fairly. she longs to be a help in society and put into practice the knowledge she now has. she wishes to be the kind of teacher that helps her students find the road to success.

ana is a member of the communal bank “azucenas” (lilies). she is 22 years old, single, and lives with her father. ana rents a vending post at the april 12th market where she sells various types of clothing. she works every day in the mornings, and in the afternoons, she studies history at the university.\r\n

\r\nana is requesting a loan of 2000 pen in order to buy trousers, polo shirts, and jackets. she dreams of having her own vending location and pursuing her career.

translated from spanish by ronan reodica, kiva volunteer

fatuma is a married woman and has been blessed with one child who attends school. together with her husband, they live at their own house that has electricity but no piped water.

she has operated a fish selling business for over seven years, selling from home to restaurant operators and passersby. she faces the major challenge of competition in her business.

with the kshs 30,000 loan she wants to purchase bundles of fish for resale. she dreams of expanding her business and establishing another business in the near future.

lolita m., 54 years old, lives in barangay lapogan tumauini, isabela. she is married to claro who operates their passenger tricycle (three-wheeled vehicle) and sometimes hires out as a carpenter in their village and other villages if there is available carpentry work or if someone asks him to do carpentry. they have six children, mario – 31 years old elementary undegraduate, same as allan –who is now 30 years old; danilo – 26 years old, unfortunately did not enter any grades; clarita – 21 years old, high school graduate, catherine – 19 years old high school graduate; and clary – 14 years old, grade six student.

lolita is looking forward to receiving a loan amounting to php 5, 000 as assistance for their passenger "tricycle" business. the amount will be utilized to maintain the operation of their motorcycle daily. some will also be used by lolita to start up a new business: buying and selling vegetables, provided they still have enough funds to start up said business.

according to lolita, she will work with her husband for their family's welfare because they really want to improve their life and ultimately overcome poverty. part of her goal in life is to finally finish their house for her family's safety and comfort because until now, it is still unfinished.

lerma makes good earnings from her farming activities in lerma. this is how she supports her family and is able to send her children to school.

she wants to increase her farm yield, especially since she had a higher cost of living when her children entered college. lerma approached paglaum to borrow an amount to purchase rice seeds that will have good results with healthier, heavier, and potentially higher-yielding seedlings. she has high hopes that she will have good produce this cropping season.

meet 49-year-old yeanoh from waterloo2 eastern area in freetown. she is married and blessed with eight children. 

she began her business because she wants to take care of her family. in 2001, yeanoh established her general stock business. she works at the business nine hours per day, seven days per week. she says that the main challenges to her business are price inflation and transportation difficulties.

yeanoh requires a loan in order to purchase more items like cigarettes, biscuits, drinks and pure water. she hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her family's welfare. in the future, yeanoh plans to own the biggest shop in the community. she thanks you for your support.

dalerjon is a happy and hardworking man of the age of 26 years. he is married and has a child. he turned to arvand for the first time because he learnt that there was a possibility to get financial support. 

dalerjon lives with his family in a village. he has higher education. dalerjon's wife does not have any education and is a housewife. she manages the household chores and raises their child. 

in order to have an income for food, dalerjon has his own business. he works with fattening and selling cattle. his wife helps him with the business. she sells the milk they get from the cattle. 

currently dalerjon would like to increase the number of cattle to expand his business. therefore he turned to arvand and would like to get a loan to purchase cattle. dalerjon hopes very much for a positive result and thanks arvand in advance for the support.

sabina is 63 years old. she doesn’t have any dependent children and she lives with her family in the small town of huaca quemada, a rural area where most of the economic activity is related to agriculture. she is from the district of mochumí, which is located 45 minutes from the city of chiclayo. 

she raises and sells small animals in several places near her home. she usually raises turkeys, ducks, sheep, and pigs, feeding them natural grasses and commercial feed so that they grow well. when they have reached a good point, she sells them in the moshoqueque market (the wholesale market for the region). with this she supports her household, and it always goes well enough to support her and her family.

sabina would like to buy feed to provide to her animals so that they will grow quickly. her goal is for them to grow as much as possible for the christmas holidays, which is when her business is in its highest demand. in order to achieve her goal, she has decided for the first time to request a loan with edpyme alternativa for pen 1000.00.

sabina is a very responsible woman, and very hardworking. the business she has makes her feel active and useful. those who know her consider her to be even-keeled and trustworthy.

these ladies are part of the group called otinkorang and are three women who are all merchants and live in the same neighborhood. they sell tomatoes, onion, pepper, garden eggs, rice, salted fish, charcoal, cloth, and materials. \r\n\r\njoyce, age 45, is the group's representative. she's married and the mother of two children. she's a merchant with more than eight years of experience in the field. she displays her products at her residence and sells quality products, which is her strength. with this loan, she intends to buy more tomatoes, onions, peppers, garden eggs, rice, and salted fish and sell them to customers. her profits enable her to save money with id-ghana, pay her children school fees, and also take care of her household expenses. she and the other members will need a total amount of ghs 5,000 in their eight loan cycle to expand their businesses. they will hold each other responsible for the repayment of the loan.

angelica del carmen c. resides in the municipality of san juan opico located in the state of la libertad. angelica is 41 years old and lives with her husband and their two daughters veronica and gabriela, who are 15 and 12 years old. both girls are studying in a school. \r\n\r\nrigoberto angelica's husband works and makes an average of $ 250 a month. angelica has a small grocery shop to help her husband with the family expenses, and with her daily earnings she helps to pay suppliers’ expenses as well. angelica is asking for a loan that will be invested in the purchase of some other products that are often requested by her customers.

translated from spanish by adriana pierce, kiva volunteer

maria, who is 44 years old, only completed two years of primary school because her parents were financially dependent on the coffee they grew. coffee is harvested yearly and school expenses were monthly, weekly, and even daily. she is married and has a family of four children. the two oldest are the ones most involved in working in the fields alongside their father, while the two youngest are in school.

her current financial situation also depends on coffee, which is sold in the area through middlemen, neighbors, relatives, and others. she learned the trade when she was very young, since she learned from her parents how to work. they taught her the different farming techniques. in order to increase her household income, she also works selling tamales on the weekends. her customers are her neighbors, relatives, and other local residents. they own the land they are farming as a family. it is located 330 yards from their home, so they get there walking. 

her plans and goals for the future include expanding her coffee plantation and purchasing more land in order to build a stronger estate for her children and future generations. as a mother, she wants to continue supporting her children as much as possibly needed because they deserve all the best. 

maria is requesting financial support in order to be able to buy farming supplies to help care for and protect her coffee crops. it is necessary to get help during this time of the year to avoid pest invasions and coffee rust.

khady lives in a suburb of the town of mbour. she began her little business selling fried dough with an initial loan of 50000 f cfa (about us$ 120). two further loans of about us$ 360 and $600 allowed her to purchase a refrigerator so as to sell ice and then to begin to sell breakfast (coffee and sandwiches).

translated from french by teresa kramer, kiva volunteer

khady habite dans un quartier périphérique de la ville de mbour .elle débute ses activités par la vente de beignets avec un premier pret de 50000 f cfa.deux autres prets successifs de 150000 f cfa et 250.000f cfa lui ont permis d'acheter un réfrigirateur pour vendre de la glace et de commencer aussi la vente petit déjeuner (café, sandwich).

inom is 40 years old and the father of four children. his wife is a homemaker. inom has his own herd of forty goats, which he grazes in a distant pasture far from home. the goats spend their days eating various beneficial grasses. inom has been able to make enough profit trading in livestock to earn a living. his wife sells the wool and yarn. inom would like to increase the size of his herd, and would like to take out a loan for that purpose.

translated from russian by joyce ., kiva volunteer

señora rosa maría is 36 years of age and a member of the community bank mujeres del mañana ("women of tomorrow"). she lives on the street antenor orrego of the district of agallpampa, province of otuzco, department of la libertad, perú. she studied through secondary school completely but did not continue studying because she got married to señor carlos alfaro guzmán. she has two sons and two daughters who are still students. she and her husband together are dedicated to buying and selling animals. she works independently sewing and making craftworks and she also makes cheeses and sells milk, but lately she couldn't work because she found herself in a delicate state of health. her business is located in her home. with her first loan of 300 soles, repaid in four months, she made herself independent of her husband's business and created another economic source for their household. she bought curd and made cheeses; she also bought young animals and some materials for sewing. with this loan for 100 soles, which will be repaid in four months, she will buy a pig for 25 soles and the rest of it will be spent on material for craftworks to sell during christmas. her great dream is to have her own capital so she won't have pending debts anymore.

translated from spanish by jay osborne, kiva volunteer

kobena e. is married and has four children. he has no educational background. kobena sells gari, which he gets from processed cassava at kormantse near cape coast. he has done this since 1990. his wife is a trader. kobena uses his income to feed his family and pay his children’s school fees. kobena will use the loan to increase his capital to buy more cassava to process for sale. with the new profits from his expanded business, kobena plans to save towards building a new house.

washinton lives in the city of paucartambo and works in agriculture. paucartambo is known for its beautiful countryside and for being the department of cusco's city of folklore. the majority of the residents earn their livings in farming and livestock production. in the month of july, the festival of the virgin of carmen is celebrated, and people come from all over peru for this three-day party.

washinton works throughout the year in farming; he has several fields of crops where he grows potatoes, wheat, barley, oats, broad beans, and other things. he is one of the borrowers of the "nuevo amanecer" [new dawn] communal bank and has been for several years. in this city, there are no permanent financial entities like asociación arariwa, so he has borrowed money for several years. at this time, he needs the loan to purchase fertilizer. 

washinton is grateful for the support provided, and he promises to make his loan payments responsibly and punctually.
manal is a 21-year-old woman from madaba, jordan. she is requesting a loan of 800 jod to do maintenance for her home.\r\ndue to cultural issues, the man in the photo is manal's brother.

faith is a hardworking smallholder woman from the thika area of kenya. the main source of her income is milk and crops.

faith enjoys dairying above any other income-generating activity she is involved in. she owns 2 high-breed frisian cows that produce enough milk for her family's consumption and surplus for sale.

faith has one problem that she wishes to tackle with the help of your loan. there is nothing like a tap water system in her village where she comes from. she relies on pails to fetch and store water for domestic and agricultural use.

faith is seeking a loan to buy a water tank. the tank will hold the same volume of water as at least 50 buckets. this investment will ensure a continuous supply of water on faith's farm. rain water will be harvested to fill the tank. the impact of this loan is not only to faith's family but also a step forward for the community in her village to start adopting best water management practices.

santos del pilar has been a general merchandise retailer for over 20 years; a nephew gave her the idea for this business. she has four children to support so this is very important to her. she goes out to sell her products to various customers in an itinerant manner. she is asking for funding to buy shoes, perfumes, shirts, pants and suits. she dreams with setting up a store so that her customers will have more comfort.

translated from spanish by michael bujazan, kiva volunteer

bernadita is 40 years old and married with five children. she works hard to provide for her family. she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a loan of 13,000 philippines pesos (php) through nwtf to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

bernadita has borrowed and paid six loans from nwtf before this loan. she has been running the general store for 2 years and also earns an income from farming vegetables.

bernadita aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

alona s. is 37 years old and is married to mr. jun s.. she has five children and lives in brgy. canroma, pontevedra, negros occidental. she is a dedicated wife who is determined to help her husband improve their life situation. mrs. s. has been engaged in food production for the past fifteen years. she and her husband, with the help of their older children, sell snack food, corn, vinegar and other food products to the neighboring towns, especially where there is a fiesta going on (and there is always a fiesta going on somewhere in the island of negros). this is not easy work because they need to wake up early to travel and set up their station, stay up late selling their product, and when the crowds are gone, pack up and go home. however, it earns a good income of about php 9,800 per month, so they persevere because it sustains the education of some of their children, and the needs of the family. hard work, patience and discipline are the key elements to mrs. s.'s continuing success. mrs. s. joined nwtf-project dungganon in 1999 and the unsecured loans she has borrowed over the last ten years have enabled her to make her business a sustainable endeavor which is a great help to their family. at present, mrs. s. needs to purchase a transport vehicle to facilitate the delivery of her products and transport them from town to town as they transfer selling locations. this is why, for her 17th loan, mrs. s. is borrowing php 19,500 so that, with her own transportation, she will be able to reach farther and stay longer in the towns and not be dependent on the availability of public transportation. about nwtf: in a world full of challenges, negros women for tomorrow foundation, inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. they have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. this is project dungganon.

maricel is 31 years old, married and has one child in school.

she is in the agricultural business of pig fattening in the philippines. maricel requested a php 13,000 loan through nwtf to purchase additional sacks of feeds.

maricel has been pig fattening for 2 years now, and has borrowed 4 times in the past from nwtf to sustain it.

in the future, maricel would like to save money to expand her business.

haruna is a babban gona farmer from tashar nabai. haruna expressed that he is driven by one goal; to “make more money for myself and my family.” it is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led haruna to join babban gona. now, as a babban gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. like all babban gona members, haruna can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the nigerian farmer’s average annual income. the average babban gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. however, haruna, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. by doing so, haruna will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. when asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “i plan to use the money i make to build a better home”. with this loan, haruna will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

32-year-old jenalyn is from the town of banga. she is married and has a 5-year-old child. jenalyn owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. she is just starting this business.

jenalyn joined cevi to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. she has successfully repaid a previous loan from cevi. jenalyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 php which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. this will be her third loan from cevi. she plans to use the additional revenue generated to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

elizabeth is 56 years old and lives in baybay, liloy, zamboanga del norte. she is married, with six children.

elizabeth works in the fish industry and sells fish for a living. she has been doing this for 30 years. she has requested a loan for additional capital. she wants to purchase more kilos/boxes of fish to sell/retail.

elizabeth has been a member of paglaum multi-purpose cooperative (pmpc) for two years. in the future, she hopes to improve her business.

marlyn is 53 years old and married with two children. marlyn works very hard to provide for them.

marlyn runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 15000 loan through nwtf to buy items to sell like canned goods, personal care products, eggs, spices, noodles, bread and other snack foods.

marlyn has been in this business for 10 years. 

in the future marlyn would like to save money to expand her business.

agnes is 31 years old and married with one child. she works hard to provide for her family.

she has a general store in the philippines and requested a php 14,000 loan through nwtf in order to buy more groceries to sell.

agnes has borrowed and paid 3 loans from nwtf before this loan. she has been running the general store for three years.

she aspires to save enough money to build and expand her business.

faithfulness is a group led by theresah who is 52 years old. theresah is married with two children. she sells clothes and has been doing this clothes sales business for the past 7 year. the faithfulness group members sell different items and they have same objective of obtaining a better future.  with this loan, theresah would like to buy more clothes so she can re-sell them at a profit. the profits from the business will be used to increase her savings, repay loan and reinvest into her business.

appolonie is a young cameroonian who is 24 years old, married, without children but she has two dependents. she has been selling fresh food supplies in a neighborhood of her town for one year. with this loan she would like to buy tomatoes, green condiments, gumbo, etc. to increase her stock of merchandise in order to satisfy the demand of her clientèle. with the profits generated, she would like to increasingly help her husband to take care of their domestic responsibilities.

a. charlotte constance est née le 12/12/1959 à porto-novo, capitale administrative et politique de la république du benin. charlotte constance est mariée à kiki lambert. le couple a deux enfants. la famille vit à porto-novo. grâce au revenu de son activité, charlotte constance vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. c’est des tissus, chaussures et ustensiles de cuisine que charlotte constance vend. charlotte constance achète ses tissus à cotonou,  capitale economique  de la république du bénin et les vend au marché ouando de porto-novo. charlotte constance est une cliente d’alidé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. pour  augmenter le volume de son activité, charlotte constance demande de crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.

the mujer y fortaleza loan group is made up of 15 members who, despite their daily problems, never abandon their good humor and charisma because it's what allows them to move forward happily every day.  they make a living in a variety of economic activities that have given them the opportunity to be financially independent and give their children a better future.

the members live in the area of turi parish in cuenca.  this area enjoys a spectacular view, so it's known as the viewpoint of the city.  the architecture is a mix of old and new, and the residents work in agriculture, raise animals, and perform various jobs in the city.

one of the members of this group is rosa florinda, who has been in mujer y fortaleza for two years.  this group is made up of determined, friendly, and kind women who support each other mutually.

rosa florinda, 45, lives in a common-law relationship and has three children, ages 12, 11, and 4.  her two oldest children attend school in the town and her youngest one is in pre-school.  her husband's a sawyer by trade.  the house they live in is their own.

rosa florinda makes a living in agriculture.  she sells her harvests and raises and sells guinea pigs and chickens.  she also has had a store for four years.  she's going to invest the money from her loan in provisions because her goal is to expand her store.

the small photos are of three members who weren't able to be there when the group photo was taken.

aged 39, mika is married to a mason. the couple has two children in school.

mika started raising broiler chickens in 2014. she learned this trade from her friends. she is already selling her chickens, but she lacks capital to buy feed, which will ensure a high laying rate. this is why she seeks this loan.

her dream is to have a large farm in the future.

edgar is 36 years old. he is a mason who works doing construction jobs in the municipality of cota. he is the father of a 10-year-old child, and his partner offers child care services. edgar learned his art working as a construction helper, and he specialized in finishes, such as veneers and floors. he has 10 years of experience in this art with which he supports his household. as an alternative, he adds to his income by reselling construction materials.

he currently needs additional capital to purchase cement, ceramic floor tiles, and glue, among other materials with a high rate of turnover. for that reason, he requested his first kiva loan, from fundación mario santo domingo, to carry out his investment. support this hard-working man with his microloan.

ritchel is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with three children.

she has a general store in the philippines and requested a php 19,000 loan through nwtf in order to buy additional stock of groceries to sell.

she industriously earns additional income through other business ventures like raising livestock.

ritchel dreams that one day she will be able to save enough money so she can continue to send her children to school.

work in education requires much sacrifice and follow-through in teaching/learning. aware of this, dirafruz works hard as a teacher at a school teaching youngsters of various ages. her main concern is educating these children since they are future of the nation and will improve standards of living. the investment would guarantee her level of development since she will also be improving her standard of living. \r\n\r\ndirafruz lives on her salary. she requested a loan for 2,000 somoni, which she will use to replace doors and windows of her house.

socorro is s responsible, hard- working and enterprising woman. she is 45 years old, married and the mother of a son. she works selling steel jewellery, clothing and shoes. she gives part of her merchandise to her sister who helps her sell in a store. she is requesting her 10th loan from adim as she wants to invest in buying bracelets, rings, chains and omega necklaces. she is a micro-entrepreneur with vision and one of her projects is to open her own store in the country's airport.

rosalinda is 35 years old and married with seven children.

she earns a living by pig fattening in the philippines. rosalinda is borrowing 11,000 php through nwtf to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

rosalinda has been pig fattening for six years and also earns additional income from food vending.

she successfully paid back her previous loan and now requests a new loan to further build her business.

she is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

laura is 42 years and married to david.  they have five children who range in age form one to twenty years old.  laura and her family live under their own roof in the indigenous community of inchatingari, district of perené, province of chanchamayo. 

laura begins a variety of activities the moment the first rays of sun shine over her community.  she takes care of her home and family so that they can also begin their daily activities.  after she finishes her household chores, she takes care of her farmland.

currently, she has three plots of fertile land, in which she plants achiote (a spice made from the red seed of the annatto tree), coffee, and citrus fruits such as tangelos (hybrid fruit that is a cross between a grapefruit and a tangerine) and oranges.  “i grow it all, but coffee and achiote are best for me as there is demand throughout the year”, she says.  

production of achiote is common in her region.  each harvest yields 2500 kilos and each kilo sells for between 5 and 7 soles. these days, the price is low reaching 4 soles and 50 céntimos.   however, she is certain that, beginning in april, the price will be profitable for her.  

thanks to her hard work, her children are assured food, clothing, and an education.  her immediate goals are to expand her farmland and improve production, and in order to achieve them, she must invest in the purchase of land and fertilizer.  

this will be her third loan with mfp, and she is committed to making her monthly payments on time, as she has done in the past. “los productores inchatingari” is the name of her communal bank and she feels happy to be a part of such a solid and hard-working group.  when she obtains the loan, she will be able to buy bags of fertilizer.  in addition, she will pay for the services of laborers who will clear her land of weeds and other shrubs.

this is julieta, aged 54, a long time member of cct. she is thankful that she learned of kiva and cct whose mission is to help small businessmen like her. her "sari-sari"(retail general store) of eight years has really helped provide for her family\'s daily needs.

a "sari-sari" (tagalog word meaning variety) store is small neighborhood retail shop run by women-micro entrepreneurs from their homes. she buys packaged food items, beverages, and toiletries from wholesalers and malls, and then sells them at retail price. to help her sustain her store she is requesting a loan to add more food items such as canned goods, instant noodles, biscuits, bread and eggs to sell in her small store. she values her business because it is a good source of income to provide for three square meals and other household needs.

julieta hopes for her family to always be intact and for the success of her business. she faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and it is there where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of god she studies.

* all cct community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

sarah is 39 years old and lives in logan town, one of the early communities in liberia that is well known. she is married and has three children between the ages of 6 and 17. all three of them are presently in school and live at home. 

for the past 6 years sarah has been running a table where she sells biscuits, candy, etc. she started this business with a little money which she saved over the years and learned this way of selling from her friends. she likes her business because she makes a lot of profit and it keeps her busy. 

sarah is requesting a loan to buy more biscuits, candy, etc., for her business. her plans are to build a house and educate her children.

maría apolonia is originally from the town of tecpan, guatemala. she is 58 years old. she is responsible for two children, one who is 13 and the other is 10 years old. she works making traditional handwoven fabrics and raising chickens.

she used the loan she received to buy raw materials for her weavings as without the resources she would not be able to work, and she also bought more chickens to breed.

her husband works as a farmer and thanks to the support of him and her children she can continue forward with her work.

she dreams of expanding her business thus getting better profits and of being able to send her children to school to study for a better future.

she already had a kiva loan and thanks to her punctuality in her payments she did not fall into arrears. she hopes that she can be supported again with the requested loan.

aisha is a married mother of four children, all of whom attend school. she lives in her own house that has electricity but not piped water. her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and transport.

for the past three years, she has operated a clothes selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. she faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation. 

with the loan that she is requesting of kes 50,000 she wants to purchase four bales of clothes for resale. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

a young energetic man, komi-kuma is a retailer of motor oil out of his home. he operates this business by himself and gets his supplies in lomé. confronted with a lack of inventory, he is requesting an initial loan from wages to purchase some. he wants to reinvest in his business and get married later on. \r\n\r\n

natividad is a resident of san dionisio, iloilo. she is 56 years old, married and has two children; one adult and one dependent.  to earn an income, her husband does fishing while natividad operates a rice retailing business. aside from this, she also buys and sells gasoline.\n\nnow, she asks for a loan of php 1,500 through kiva’s field cevi-philippines. she will use this loan to buy plastic water drum. this water drum will help her store more water for household used. this is very important for her because water is every day’s necessity.

patricia is a member of inti pakareq, an asociacion arariwa community bank in cusco.  she operates a business making and selling traditional jewelry.  she has owned the business for several years and is satisfied with the progress she's made.

patricia will use this loan to buy supplies--copper wire, for example, but other supplies too--for her business.  

patricial is grateful for the opportunity that this type of lending provides and she is committed to repaying the loan in the agreed-upon time.

ekua sells foodstuffs in adum banso, near takoradi. she is married and has four children. her husband is a farmer. \r\n\r\nekua has been selling foodstuffs for 12 years now. she is responsible for paying her children’s school fees. her loan will be used to buy more food in bulk. she hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

fatima base is an all-female group of outstanding farmers located in koidu, eastern sierra leone. eastern sierra leone was one of the areas hardest-hit by the ebola crisis. while international coverage of the crisis and acute danger have faded, the stark economic damage done is still creating enormous challenges for survivors. 

the members of fatima base were hit especially hard by the ebola crisis and remain trapped in a cycle of subsistence where they have no option but to take extremely high-interest loans for poor quality inputs during planting time. a low interest loan can make all the difference to these farmers, who will also benefit from group leader and featured borrower mahawa's experience (pictured on her own and second from right in the group photo).

in addition to any kiva loan disbursed to the fatima base group, field partner mountain lion agriculture (mlbr.org) will also support these farmers with technical advice, equipment rental and market access. with this powerful mix of capital and support, each farmer’s annual net income should grow – sustainably – by at least 250%. your loan will therefore enable an entire community to lift itself out of poverty, while increasing the production a much needed staple food (rice) during a time of great food insecurity in sierra leone.

mehreen is a 34-year-old single woman, shown in the photo with her brother. she is been involved in the cloth-trading business. she purchases a variety of cloth at low prices from the city market and sells them in her own town. she has a strong customer base. mehreen has requested a murabaha loan of 50,000 pkr. she wants to buy a greater variety of cloths in different colors for her business so that she can get a boost in her earnings with her loan

christine is 30 years old. she is single and blessed with four children. her business is selling clothes, which she has operated for five years. \r\n\r\nthis is her first loan from visionfund kenya and she will use it to buy stock of clothes for sale. she will use profits from her expanded business to build rental houses. her hopes and dreams are to have a financially stable business.

luz maria is very creative and has a good eye for combining colors, which make her resulting works of embroidery both pleasing and beautiful. she has been developing her skills since she was eight, when she was taught by her mother and grandmother. today she teaches other people who help her cover her orders. each job requires considerable labor, which is why the cost corresponds to the width of the embroidery requested. for her part, luz maria is very pleased and content with her job because it allows her to care for her children, making sure they are prepared for life and acting as their only unconditional supporter. she has plans to improve her embroidery shop and get it running with the necessary materials; she is requesting a loan to solidify these dreams. let’s support this diligent mother so she can get ahead in her self-sacrificing and generous role.

translated from spanish by shannon skoglund, kiva volunteer.
