luz maria, es muy creativa y tiene muy buenos criterios para combinar los colores haciendo que sus trabajos tengan resultados muy bellos y armoniosos en cada bordado de fustanes que realiza; viene desarrollando este oficio desde que tenía ocho años, su madre y su abuela le enseñaron y hoy enseña a otras personas que la apoyan a cubrir los pedidos que tiene.cada trabajo posee un considerable esfuerzo y es por esta razón que el pago es deacuerdo al ancho del bordado que se solicita.por su parte luz maria se siente satisfecha y muy contenta de desarrollar este oficio porque le permite cuidar de sus dos hijos porque quiere que ellos se preparen para afrontar la vida y más aún porque en ella tienen el único apoyo incondicional.tiene planes de mejorar su taller de bordados e implementarla de los materiales necesarios y solicita un préstamo para poder concretar estos anhelos. apoya a diligente madre para que pueda seguir adelante con su abnegado rol.

gerardo is a member of the communal bank “siempre juntos” (always together). he is 63 years old, married, and has three children. gerardo divides his time between his daily activities and managing his business of manufacturing mattresses. he is a responsible and industrious individual who has been at this business for quite some time so that he can support his family. gerardo wants to keep working at his business so that he can continue to support his family.

he is requesting a loan in order to buy foam and other supplies. gerardo is grateful for the loan that has been issued and promises to complete his payments according to the established terms.

gerald is a single man. he operates a transport business, where he transports customers using his motorcycle. he has been involved in this business for 4 years now. his business is located in a busy area and his primary customers are locals. he will use the kes 20,000 loan to repair his motorcycle. this is his first loan with smep microfinance bank. \t\t\t

mrs. nalda is a partner from the community bank “las fronterizas”, located in the district of desaguadero of the chucuito province in the puno department. originally from the city of huacho, she is 37 years old and mother of two sons. she attended college until the 4th level. \r\nshe has worked with the manuela ramos movement for the past two years and she has launched her juice business with a loan in the amount of 300 soles. thanks to increasing demands, she now wishes to obtain a loan in the amount of 2300 soles that will be used to purchase additional assorted producer goods and a better suited place of business to improve customer service. this will allow her to optimize her business potential and benefit her children's upbringing. she is very appreciative of the trust and support given to women that belong to the manuela ramos movement.\r\n

translated from spanish by bertolt cantalice, kiva volunteer

alexandra, 43, is a widow with four children; she lives with her children and parents in pueblo viejo canton, los ríos province.  she’s a member of the “anchoveta” communal bank located in puerto pechinche parish, recinto anchoveta, belonging to pueblo viejo canton; it does agricultural work.

alexandra works in agriculture growing corn, rice and soy and also raises chickens.  her purchases and sales take place in ventanas.  she requests the loan to buy seeds, fertilizer, insecticide and herbicide.

the loan has helped her buy fertilizer.  her dream is to have her own irrigation system for the crops.  the challenges she faces are bad weather and competition.  she likes to go on excursions and to read books on agriculture in her free time.

the communal bank “encantos de la selva” consists of seven hardworking and responsible members. one of them is sra. lucy. she is 39 years old, separated from her spouse, and the mother of two children. for the past 10 years, she has been making clothes. sportswear is what she produces the most.

one of lucy’s goals is to expand her business so that she can produce a larger volume of clothes. she also wants to do screen printing and embroidered clothes. the loan she is requesting will be invested in the purchase of fabrics and supplies for making sportswear.

in the photo, lucy is wearing a pullover shirt and black trousers. she is grateful to the kiva lenders for the support she has received.

gladys loves her family more than anything and works hard to give them a good quality life. she is very focused on her goals and dreams.

there are many challenges facing smallholder women trying to enter agriculture today, especially with accessing funds to expand their enterprise. women farmers play an important role in supplying food for the country at large.

gladys is seeking a loan to stock her cereals business. she plans to use the money to purchase and transport cereals in bulk to faraway markets where she will sell at prices high enough to cover all the expenses incurred plus profit. gladys is confident that she will be able to repay the loan on time because she is hardworking and financially disciplined.

returns from the investment will change gladys' life as she will use the additional income to raise her family's living standards and pay for her children's education. her positive attitude and hopes of getting ahead show gladys' immense desire to better herself and, of course, receive a favorable response to her loan request.

gladys really hopes for your help and understanding. she expresses her thankfulness in advance.

michael amadu is a maize farmer from kyasge village in kaduna state. before he became a babban gona member, michael amadu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. with this loan and babban gona’s support, michael amadu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. michael amadu, like other members of babban gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to ensure other members of his community are lifted out of poverty.

celia pilar is 49 years old and is married with one son. she is an accountant and she has an office where she works independently from 8:00am to 7:00pm. she is asking for this loan to implement her accounting firm by purchasing office supplies. celia pilar is happy for this loan and promises to comply with all loan repayments. \r\n\r\ncelia belongs to the communal banking group "santo domingo," which meets every 30 days in the district of cusco, which belongs to the province of cusco and department of cusco.

cristina did not have the opportunity to attend school. she is married and her husband works in agriculture. their children are grown and live independently.
cristina works in agriculture and raises cattle and small animals.
she needs a loan to purchase a heifer and vitamins for it.
she dreams of having more livestock and improving her economic situation.

loeup is an elderly villager of ek phnom district, battambang province. she has eleven children. her husband has already passed away, and now she is living with one of her children.

she has been selling vegetables at the market for 25 years. her daughter also helps with the family budget by being a teacher at a local public school.

loeup has been with visionfund, kiva’s partner, for seven times, including now. the previous loans have helped their living condition considerably. as the leader of her group, loeup is seeking a loan of 1,000,000 khr to buy vegetables to sell. she hopes that the new loan will further help improve their financial status.

jesusa is a proud mother who lives in amulung with her spouse and children. she is operating a small business in the front of her house and sells grocery items to the people in their village. she earns approximately p5, 000 each month. it is used for meals and allowance of her children who are in high school. she is asking for a loan of p21, 000 to buy more goods to sell. she will buy canned goods, soft drinks, sugar, and bottles of vinegar and cooking oil. this will help increase sales and income as well. 

she hopes to keep giving good service to her costumers and that she will grow as a successful retail store owner.

hello kiva community. meet jennifer, who is a crop and animal farmer and a mother eager to provide the very best for her family. she states that with her small income, she hasn’t been able to provide sufficient electric lighting in her home. her family has been using kerosene lamps, despite the toxic fumes that put the family at risk of contracting respiratory diseases. jennifer is kindly appealing for a loan to buy a solar lantern to provide adequate lighting, enabling her children to read comfortably while at home. with the lantern’s dual charging capability, her husband will also be able to efficiently charge his phone. kindly consider lending to her.

grace a hard-working woman representing the freedom group. she is married with two children.

grace sells food such as rice, sugar, beans, and cooking oil. grace has been in business for the past seven years.

the group members are working hard to improve their standards of living with regards to their children's education. with the loan, grace would like to buy more food such as rice, sugar, beans, and cooking oil to sell. with the profits from the business, she would like to reinvest into business to improve her living standard.

hello kiva lenders! meet joan, who lives in her own home that is made out of rustic materials. she has lovely children. she has very good personal and work references in her community, and she is located in a remote village in litein kenya. joan is a farmer with 10 years of experience, specifically in practicing dairy farming. she passionately loves dairy farming. milking and feeding her own cow is the most enjoyable part about farming. she is very appreciative that dairy farming has been able to sustain farmers in her village. profits from milk sales have enabled her to take care of her family, and she has always yearned to have more dairy cows.

accordingly, she is seeking a loan to buy a good breed of dairy cow. she has already identified the breed of cow that she will buy. the cow will produce between 15-20 liters of milk daily. this breed of cow will be producing milk referred to as the ideal drinking milk, because it contains an adequate amount of fat and the desirable quantities of protein. this cow will certainly boost milk production on her farm which will translate to more sales volume and better income for her and her family. because of this high milk production potential, she will save more money to fully repay the loan. she believes that through careful selection and the application of the strict standard of excellence in keeping her dairy cow, she will have more income which will improve her living standards.

kiloja is 29-years old, married and has two children. he has been a wheat farmer for the past three years. he applied for his third loan with kadet ltd, which he will use to buy farm inputs (wheat seeds and also land preparation). 

with the profits generated he plans to pay school fees for his children. 

he dreams to be prominent farmer. 

he is an assiduous man who works with effort to attain more notwithstanding limited resources.

orbesa is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a dried fish making business in the philippines. she is borrowing php 10,000 through nwtf to buy more fish for making dried fish. orbesa has been in this business for five years. orbesa  also earns income from a general store. she has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from nwtf. she dreams of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to school in the future.\r\n

joyce, who has her hand raised in this photo, is 33 years old, married and blessed with five children. she is a member of the maseno self help group, which joined hand in hand eastern africa in 2014 to benefit from enterprise development and financial management training. she earns a living by growing tomatoes and is requesting this kiva loan to buy pesticides and fertilizer to improve her farm's output. she hopes this will increase her sales and income, and she will earn enough money to pay school fees for her children and provide better health care to her family.  she is grateful to kiva and its lenders for their financial support and promises to repay promptly.

as a married parent of four children, shiela may works hard to support her family.

she has a fish vending business in the philippines. shiela may is borrowing php 17,000 through nwtf in order to buy more fresh seafood to sell.

shiela may has been sustaining her business activities through her past 19 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

antonio is 43 years old and lives in the city of medellin. he’s happily married and he has two children who are his biggest motivation.

he has a pulps business and he’s managing it well, but he has some problems with the administrative part of his business because he lacks of this kind of knowledge. in order to improve his business and start doing better, he feels he needs to learn how to manage it better. this is the reason why he’s asking for a loan: to pay for his studies in finance to improve his business management skills.

support this amazing entrepreneur and loan now.

if you want to know more about the entrepreneurs and the loans from interactuar, you can join the lending team called: “friends of interactuar colombia”: http://www.kiva.org/team/interactuar_colombia

lovely o. sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. she is 31 years old and married with 4 children. she buys her goods from the market in her community and the drinks from a distributor. she is happy with her business. she needs the loan amount of n100,000 to purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell.

rustam is a vendor at the gafurova market, where he rents a small stall and sells spare parts for cars and bicycles. the goods come from suppliers who import them from china. his sales have been stable, and to sustain business he would like to take out a new loan. in the photograph rustam is pictured the day he applied for the loan. rustam has met all the fund's conditions and he is grateful for all of the investors' support and financing. \r\n

translated from russian by anna brown, kiva volunteer

this is angelina, she previously accessed an 18,000 php loan that she used to purchase fish of different kinds needed for her business. her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and for their personal, house hold and business expenditures. 

she would like to apply for another 25,000 php loan for her to buy additional fish needed for her business. her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. she looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

angelina dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. she faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week; there she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of god she studies.

* all cct community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

zaragul is a responsible woman. she was born in southern part of tajikistan in 1964. she is living in small city with her family.  she has no husband or children. she is a teacher at a secondary school. her previous work was in kindergarten as a tutor. she is an honest and strong person. \r\n\r\nshe wants to enter the teacher’s institute to study and get a higher degree for teaching at prestigious institutions. she is striving and working on her self-development and hopes to be a specialist of her major. she requested a loan from kiva and imon to pay her higher education costs. she awaits your kindness.

sanini is 35 years old, married to neema and they have four children. he has been farming for the last three years, with an income of kes 15,000. 

he has never borrowed from any other mfi. he is applying for his first loan, which he will use to buy pesticides and seedlings for the farm.

with the anticipated profits, he plans to buy a dairy cow. he desires to grow his business and be financially stable in the future.

richard is a 25-year-old married man with two children. he lives in fort portal, uganda. he is charged with the responsibility of looking after his family. his desire is to build a permanent house, as he currently lives in a semi-permanent house. \r\n\r\nfor six years he has been involved in a butcher business, which has helped him to provide for the basic needs of his family. his business challenge is employees who do not remit their daily sales promptly. he plans to buy land and start raising animals. richard needs this loan to buy land.

dennis is a married man. he has two children. he describes himself to be honest. he operates a carpentry business where he makes furniture. he has been involved in this business for five years. his business is located in a busy place and his primary customers are of all types. he describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of funds. he will use the kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of carpentry materials. his business goal is to expand within five years. this is his first loan with smep microfinance bank.\t\t\t\r\n

asha, aged 56, is from kitale county, where she lives with her husband. all her children are adults and are between the ages of 21 and 41. she has been in farming for 15 years, doing mixed farming producing maize, beans, eggs and fruits, which she sells locally. she also runs a grocery store as an additional source of income.

she is requesting a 30,000 kenyan shilling (kes) loan form juhudi kilimo to buy poultry and start a poultry project, which will help her in getting more income and uplift her standards of living.

airborne poultry diseases are her major challenge in farming.

sandra is a humble woman who has dark skin and is the head of her family. she is looking to initiate a beauty salon, for which she is requesting a modest amount of money. she is very conscious of the obligation she will have to make her loan payments, and she prefers only to commit herself to a small amount. this amount will give her the opportunity to purchase a modest haircut chair and a few supplies to initiate her business. 

sandra's greatest inspiration for her work is her five year old son and the needs of her home. she runs her business out of her home but hopes to move it to another place. her dream is to have a beauty salon, to generate work and to have the strength to turn her business into a successful one. with the requested loan, sandra will purchase a haircut chair, a hair iron, a dryer and other hair styling supplies.

justus is a 28-year-old married man living in kamwenge, uganda. he has a personal goal of educating his children and building a permanent home. he has been running a beer and soda depot for the last two years after starting with capital of 500,000 ugx. now his business is worth 3,000,000 ugx. his major hardship is inadequate capital to purchase stock. he has a vision of diversifying his business to include farming and expanding his business to new markets. justus wants a loan to buy beer and soda for resale.

erlinda works hard to support her family. she is widow and has a food vending business in the philippines. erlinda has been in this business for 10 years.

erlinda requested a 12,000 php loan through nwtf to buy ingredients for her food production business. she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

juvie is 39 years old and married with three children in school. juvie works very hard to provide for them. she runs a general store in the philippines and has requested a php 10,000 loan through nwtf to buy items to sell like beverages, canned goods, snack foods, home care products, and other groceries.

juvie has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items. in the future, juvie would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

then, who is 28 years old and goes by the name of rose, is a trader living in teshie province. she is married with one dependent child, who is in school, while she works so hard for the well-being of her household. selling saucepans and ice chests is her main business.

rose is now leading the 'ekomefeemo 6' group of five members to apply for loans from kiva through id-ghana. this is the second-cycle loan for her. her past loan has helped her meet her family’s needs in a timely way. for this cycle, she will use her loan portion to buy a lot of ice chests and saucepans to boost her capital.

she hopes she will earn more income to uplift her lifestyle and keep sending her child to school.

wahida is a married woman who has been blessed with three children, all of whom attend school. together with her husband, they live at their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

she has operated a fish selling business for over ten years, selling from home to restaurant operators and passersby. she faces a major challenge of seasonality and perishability which leads to losses. in addition, she also operates a goat-meat selling business.

with the 50,000 kes she wants to purchase bundles of fish for resale. she dreams of expanding her business and establishing another business in the near future.

julieta owns and operates a talipapa (a fruit and vegetable stall) in her village. she sells a variety of fruits and vegetables. her business runs from as early as five o'clock in the morning and finishes at seven o'clock in the evening. 

income from the business is just enough to sustain all their needs, such as meals and the daily allowance for her children. her income is not stable.

she is now asking for a loan of php 10,000 to have an additional revolving capital to buy tomatoes, cabbages, eggs, potatoes and bananas to sell. 

someday, she is aspiring to diversify her business into selling meat and fish too. this will help improve her earnings.

in rural quiche, in the western highlands of guatemala, we find the area of san antonio ilotenango, home to the 10 ladies of “estrellas de xejíp”, or “stars of xejíp” trust bank. living among forests full of fresh pine trees and mountains of rich soil, most of these women grow corn and raise animals such as pigs and hens on their rural properties. others sell clothing and other products in the quiché market, or run convenience stores in their community.

agustina is 22 years old, and studied through to sixth grade. four years ago, her husband left to work in the united states but she stayed in xejíp, taking care of their little boy, who is now five years old, on her own. agustina runs a small convenience store, selling basic, everyday products such as rice, beans, sugar, fruit juices, sodas and snacks. with the loan that she is requesting, she will invest in product sfor her store, including soda, sugar, and all the different foods and items she needs to replenish her inventory. 

in her first cycle with friendship bridge, this strong, intelligent, and determined woman is excited to see the growth that will come with her investment in micro-loans.

with a wide age range, from 22 to 70 years old, all of these ladies are in different walks of life, but what unites them is their shared motivation to improve their lives through investment in and expansion of their businesses. the majority move forward with the support of their spouses, providing education to their children (which number between one and 11). the value of education is important for each of these ladies, as many of them did not receive an education themselves.

beth is a married woman. she has seven children. she describes herself as determined. she operates a farm, where she keeps cows and also grows onions, maize, cabbages and other crops. she has been involved in this business for 10 years. her business is located in a fertile area and her primary customers are locals. she describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital.

beth will use this 30,000 kenyan shilling loan to buy farm inputs to boost production. her business goal is to be successful in farming within five years.

virginia is 61 years old, married and the mother of eight children. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur who earns a living by buying and selling tomatoes in the philippines. virginia has requested a php 5,000 loan from nwtf to buy more tomatoes to sell. she has been in this line of work for ten years, and her goal for the future is to build up and expand her business.\r\n

kedwin roger a. vásque, 28, lives in the department of san miguel. he lives with his 21-year-old brother, his 8 and 4-year-old nephews whom are in school, and with his 80-year-old grandmother. for the past three years kedwin has worked selling medicine and vitamins. he has been able to obtain many customers because his is the only business that sells these products in the area. people come to his house to buy the medicines and they trust him as he is a very responsible person who sells high quality products. he is asking for a loan to invest in his business by buying more medicines so that he can meet his customers' demands. kedwin is requesting this loan from integral (kiva field partner) with the hope of increasing his sales and improving the lives of his nephews and grandmother. he is a very enterprising and visionary young man who hopes to get ahead and lead a better a life.\r\n

translated from spanish by erin sindewald, kiva volunteer

christopher is 42 years old. he is a farmer by nature, and he has worked as a manager on different farms.  today, thanks to the coming of kiva lenders and juhudi kilimo to his territory, he can dream and aspire to better things for his wife and their children. christopher is an accomplished farmer from the litein area of kenya and commands a lot of respect. he loves and cherishes his family. christopher and his wife work as a team, supporting each other, and have practiced mixed farming for the past five years. christopher often says, “i have always had an affinity for farming, and it runs in my blood.” because of the liking that he has for farming, he has even nicknamed one of his cows, which makes him a very proud farmer, especially when he is milking his cows. from his dairy cow, he is able to get between 10 and 20 liters of milk a day, and this helps him support his family. christopher also practices crop farming, but he has not been making good profits because of poor farming inputs; that is why he is kindly seeking a loan to buy farm inputs. through the loan, he will be able to buy high quality seeds, good fertilizer and pesticides that he will use to greatly improve his crop production. modern farming requires the use of modern techniques and therefore, using high-quality seeds will assure him of a bumper harvest and increased profit levels. christopher is very visionary, and his goal for the season is to boost his crop production and be able to get more crop output than the previous year. all this can be achieved through the lenders’ help and goodwill. christopher believes that through the loan, he will turn around his family life and be able to give his children a solid education background. this loan will be christopher’s way out of poverty.\r\n\r\n

teopista lives in kampala, uganda. she is widowed with four children, all of whom attend school. she is looking after her siblings. 

teopista lives in her own house without access to either electricity or piped water. her major monthly expenses include school fees and food. she works six days a week. 

teopista has been selling second-hand clothes from home, at retail, for the last 11 years. she also sews and repairs clothes to earn extra income. 

teopista has requested a loan of ugx 500,000 from micro credit for development and transformation sacco (mcdt sacco) to buy a bale of used clothes to sell. 

her challenges include seasonality. her dream is to see her business expand to selling different kinds of used clothes.

vilma is a member of the communal bank “los puntualitos”. she is 31 years old, in a common-law relationship, and has one child. vilma divides her time between her daily activities and working for a private company in the collections department. she is grateful for the loan that has been issued and promises to complete her payments according to the established terms. vilma is a responsible person who hopes to continue working so that she can support her family. by working in this manner, she is able to help her family move forward.

vilma is requesting a loan in order to buy provisions for her home such as rice, oil, milk, sugar, and other products.

mahmadsharif lives in the city of sarband. he is a 29-year-old married young man, and has two small children.\r\n\r\nmahmadsharif is a service provider. he rents a small office space, where he has opened a photo studio. he has been active in this sector for six years, and also does video editing. mahmadsharif has requested this loan to buy new equipment and a good camera.

mr. ravdanbat, 31 years old, lives with his wife and three children in ulaanbaatar, capital city of mongolia. the family resides in their own house on a fenced in land. he and his wife have been doing building decoration work through contracts with building companies since 2003. his three children all go to high school. he is requesting a loan of 6,800,000 mnt to cover the costs of purchasing building materials such as bricks, cement and metals as well as installing a heating system. during this period of time, the prices of building materials have reached their lowest rate and purchasing them now will save him a lot of money. more importantly, installing a heating system into the house will enable the family to live in a comfortable and warm place. as a direct consequence of a warm house the family will burn less coal thus contributing to the efforts against air pollution by emitting less smoke. the borrower is very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

vanny’s group lives in a rural village in the battambang province of cambodia. vanny works as a teacher and officer to support her family. her village has no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water.

having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of her family, save money on medical expenses, and save the time spent collecting fuel and boiling water.

mrs. maria is 36 years old. she has been selling fish now for quite a long time. she sells her products outside her domicile and she offers a good service to all of her clients. perhaps for this reason she doesn’t worry about having to sell on the market since all of her main clients are those who live in her own area. maria is a mother of 5 children, 2 of them are already independent, and the remaining three children are in elementary school. her dear husband supports her very much. he is a fisherman so he is in charge of bringing the fish to maria. she really likes this business, so she decided to refit the small space where she sells her products, for this reason she needs a bigger working capital to fulfill her wishes as soon as possible.

translated from spanish by ana gabriela clark, kiva volunteer.

la señora maria de 36 años de edad, se dedica a la venta de pescado desde hace ya mucho tiempo, oferta sus productos fuera de su domicilio y brinda a todos sus clientes una buena atención quizá por esa razón no se preocupa por ir a vender en el mercado ya que todos sus clientes principales son los de su propia zona. maria es madre de 5 hijos siendo 2 de ellos ya independientes, quedando sus tres últimos niños que cursan el nivel primario. su querido esposo la apoya mucho, pues él es pescador y el encargado de traer a maria el pescado que degustan muchas personas. a ella le gusta mucho este negocio es por eso que decidió implementar más su pequeño espacio de ventas y requiere de un capital de inversión lo más pronto posible para cumplir su propósito.

marivic is 38 years old.  she is married and has three children attending school. marivic's spouse works as a local farmer. to increase the family's income, marivic buys and sells plastics and used bottles to the people in the village where they live. she usually earns a daily profit of p200.  that is used for daily meals and the needs of her children.

she is now asking for a loan of p4,000 to have additional capital to buy more used bottles, magazines, plastics and cans and sell them to the junk shop. 
in the future, marivic would like to earn consistent profits for the college education of her children.

mr. ibrahim represents the group called les etoiles. a married man, he is the father of four children. the oldest is 17, and the youngest is 1. none of them goes to school. he has eight children to support.

he has been raising livestock for over twenty years. he gets his supplies from his village. he wants to purchase 2 sheep and 100 kg of feed for them. with the profits, he wants to expand his business. his ambition is to develop a herd and to purchase a parcel of land.
fooza is a 63-year-old widow who lives in mababa, jordan.\r\nshe is requesting a loan of 400 jod in order to improve her housing and living conditions and to make them more healthy.

ruth lives in mombasa, kenya. she is 43 years old, married and blessed with three children. all her three children attend school. she sells secondhand clothes at the local market. she has done this business for the last ten years. she also owns a pool business which earns her extra income. she found out about milango through friends and she now seeks a loan to buy bales of secondhand clothes to sell. she has had previous loans from milango which were not listed on kiva and she paid them back without challenges. the challenge she faces in this business is price changes. inflation also affects her income from the business and these are the challenges that she has to deal with. the extra income that she will raise from the loan use will help her pay school fees for her children. her living standard will also improve. she has a vision of selling clothes as a wholesaler.

veronica  is a 47 years old and a married mother of six children. she works very hard to support her family. she loves her husband very much. although the family works very hard, it can be difficult for them to afford the cost of her husband's education. so this loan of 1,000 usd will allow veronica  to send her husband, paulo da costa, to university. she will use the loan to pay for tuition, textbooks, school supplies and others materials. veronica loves her husband very much and hopes that further education will help them to have a brighter future. in the picture is the women is veronica and the men is extra person.

darwin is 24 years old.  he is a very kind and hard-working young man who lives in his parents' home, together with his beloved daughter, 2 year-old yuni, who is the main motivation behind all his efforts.

darwin's business is growing coffee, avocado and bananas.  after he harvests his crops he takes them to the town of pichanaki to sell as this is where he receives the best prices for them.

what darwin most enjoys about his work is cultivating his land.  he has been in this business for 5 years and he considers the most difficult part of his work to be transporting his products since the route is very rugged.  over time, he hopes to buy more land in order to increase the quantity of crops that he produces.

this is darwin's fourth loan with mfp.  he was very punctual in paying back his previous loans and he hopes to continue being punctual.  darwin is a very well-liked member of his community bank because his happiness is contagious.  he will use the 2,500 peruvian soles he has requested to buy manure so that he can better fertilize his land.

qurbonshoh is 34 years old. he, his wife, and three children reside in the town of dangara. 

qurbonshoh is an enterprising and industrious person. for ten years already, he has been engaged in raising livestock. he buys cows and calves, fattens them, and then sells them at a premium. 

qurbonshoh is requesting a loan to purchase cattle in order to expand his business.

maría is 55 years old, takes care of the household tasks since she didn't have any kind of schooling, and is a single mother of two children who live with her and the older one who lives abroad and helps her and his siblings economically.

since she was very young, maría has had to work very hard to help her family since the family's economic situation wasn't very satisfactory.  previously, she worked for a woman selling food in the market, for which she had to get up very early to wash the dishes and prepare the food, among other tasks. in addition, her husband who died left them some land which she cultivates with the help of her children. 

she needs the loan to purchase bean seeds to plant a hectare and to purchase the supplies to care for the crop.

her dream is to have a good harvest and sell it at a good price, pay off her debt, and, with the profits that she will have, be able to build a better house to be in better conditions.

chimaltenango, a busy town in the central highlands of guatemala, is where 25 year old lidia, a member of the friendship bridge trust bank “mujeres de la pila roja” lives. she received her teaching certificate & currently has a traditional textile business. lidia & the other 6 maya kakchiquel members of her group are soliciting a loan to bolster their small businesses (convenience stores, tortilla shops, & traditional textile fabrication/sales).

lidia has a traditional textile business. she weaves & embroiders blouses called “huipiles” that are both colorful & ornate. because of the high demand at the end of the year (holidays, graduations, parties), lidia is requesting a loan to purchase a large amount of high quality thread in lots of different colors. she has happily seen her business increase & is pleased to employ 4 other women to fill orders who, in turn, are able to support their own families. lidia’s motivation is to work hard, along with her husband, to construct a more prosperous future for their little son who is 19 months old.

the women of “mujeres de la pila roja” are in their 3rd loan cycle with kiva. they meet monthly with a facilitator to participate in the “microcredit plus” program of friendship bridge (loans + education). the educational trainings are about 1 aspect of 4 important pillars: health, family, women, business.

in funding these loans for lidia & her friends in the group, kiva investors are key players. thank you!

khei’s group live in a rural village in kompong thom province in cambodia. khei makes a living cultivating rice and she also does extra work as farm laborer to support her family. in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women and man to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

balbina is 48 years old and is married with four children. she works very hard to provide for them.

balbina runs a general store in the philippines and has requested a 10,000 php loan through negros women for tomorrow foundation to purchase additional inventory of groceries like canned goods, noodles, drinks, spices, shampoo, and other snack foods.

balbina has been in this business for 6 years. in the future she would like to save money to expand her business.

susan has cleared her previous loan and is now preparing her land for the next planting season. she has applied for an agriculture loan for her forth loan. she will use the funds to pay for ploughing the land and purchasing fertilizers and wheat seedlings. she now plans to cultivate a bigger portion of her land and, with increased gain, diversify into livestock trading. susan is a hardworking woman who is determined to succeed in life.

encarnación is 50 years old. she is a widow with three children. she is an older woman who works hard every day to get ahead and reach her life goals. she grew up with her parents, who taught her to work in agriculture and on the coffee farms in the area. her parents owned a small store where she learned the business. encarnación got married at the age of 18 and had three children who are now grown. her husband died 28 years ago, and her children emigrated to the united states. she now lives with her five grandchildren in her home. she used to work selling vegetables in the city market. she would have to walk 45 minutes from the mountains where she lives, and then take the bus to the city. she now has a small store in her community which provides an income for her family.
she buys her merchandise in the city. to get there, she has to walk. it often takes 45 minutes to get to the village where she catches the bus for the city. she then brings her products back to her community to sell them. she sells basic staples such as beans, corn, rice, and oil. she also sells medicine and other household products.
this loan, which she is requesting from fundacion campo, is for the purchase of bricks, cement, and sand, and to pay labourers to install a floor in her home. they currently have a dirt floor and she wants to install brick. with this investment, she will have a more dignified home. she has built her home through great hard work, and now she needs bricks so that she and her grandchildren can live a better life. they currently run the risk of getting infections in their feet from the humidity.
she plans to buy a larger display case to display her products, and to help her grandchildren with their studies.

the credit group “vida nueva” (“new life”) meets every 15 days in the canton of jaramijo, a place is known for its beautiful beaches. here the majority of the inhabitants are hard-working and make a living working at sea. this is where mary, 26, lives. she is in a common-law marriage and has two children ages 6 and 2, the oldest of which studies in school. her husband works in a factory.

doña maria is a homemaker who sells shoes and jewelry to make her own living and thereby help her husband with household expenses. she sells door to door and works three days a week, two to three hours a day. she sells her products on credit and charges every eight days. she has been working in this business for a year. it began with the first loan she received from the group and has enabled her to earn money for her children’s well-being.

this loan is to buy shoes and jewelry. this is her third cycle in the credit group, and she likes it because payments are easy to make. her dream is to own a boutique.

marie is a 46-year-old cameroonian lady.  she is single and the mother of three children who are between 21 and 30 years of age, which is to say that all of her children are now adults.  marie has two other people in her care.

marie's business is a restaurant where she sells grilled fish and drinks.  she has had this restaurant for 12 years.  she has good experience in her field and so has a large number of loyal customers.  she manages to get through a box of fish a day.  marie would like to use this loan to buy seven boxes of fish and 20 crates of soda for her business so that she can avoid experiencing a break in her stock.  

marie's ambitions for her family are to build a house from permanent materials so that she can guarantee their security.

miguela previously accessed a 10,000 php loan that she utilized to buy gardening materials and supplies needed in her business. her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

she would like to apply for another 15,000 php loan. she will be utilizing the loan to buy fertilizers and other materials needed in her business. the profits from her business will definitely help sustain their daily needs and the children's education. she looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

miguela dreams to be able to buy another lot to expand her farm. she meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of god she studies.

* all cct community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners gathering each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

jaki works for the kenya tea development authority (ktda) foundation. ktda aims to bring a range of high-quality and affordable barefoot power solar lighting products to address a critical need for lighting and other basic energy uses among small-holder tea farmers in kenya.

ktda foundation will accomplish this by leveraging the existing ktda infrastructure to ensure that the solar lamps reach the farmers and that periodic payments are collected and accumulated for repayment of the loan.

company background

kenya tea development authority foundation is a non- profit charity of the kenya tea development agency (holdings) limited. its key objective is to raise funds to initiate and support programs that improve the welfare of 560,000 small-holder tea farmers in kenya. ktda foundation is the vehicle through which ktda, its subsidiary companies and factory companies carry out corporate social responsibility activities.

there are eleven (11) counties that dominate in tea growing in kenya and where ktda operates most of its tea factories. these are murang’a, meru, kisii, nyeri, kiambu, kirinyaga, kericho, bomet,
nandi, nyamira and embu. the common denominator in all the counties is low penetration of electricity. while the national penetration is estimated at 23%, these 11 counties have an average electricity penetration of only 16%. kerosene is used by 80% of the households in these counties as the only source of lighting. 

kerosene is expensive in use: a typical off-grid household spends over ksh.18,000 (usd 200) per year on kerosene for lighting and mobile phone charging. kerosene also has numerous adverse health effects on lungs and eyes, as well as fire related burns.


a kiva loan will enable us reach over 1500 farmers with solar lighting and facilitate scale up of the program to other counties. the farmers will be able to get the solar lamps and repay the loan in installments after selling their tea to ktda.

partnering with barefoot power (www.barefootpower.com), a kiva field partner in africa, will enable us access quality solar lamps and allow us to utilize the expertise that barefoot power has gained since its inception and put those learnings into practice.

leonila is a married woman with three children. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

leonila has a fish vending business in the philippines. she requested a php 11,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy more fish to sell.

leonila has been in this business for six years. in the future, she would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

lubna sells powdered hot drinks. this is her small business and she is looking to give it more of her time and energy. she is a teacher and is in need of extra income.

lubna's plans are that her business will pick up and she will not need to work a day job. she needs a loan to buy packaging for her powdered hot drinks.

delfina is a member of the kusiky community bank. “kusiky” means “be happy” in quechua. delifina is married and 60 years old with three children. she has a shop in her house where she sells general groceries, vegetables and fruits. delfina’s husband carries out short term jobs, and delfina is in charge of sales.

delfina needs a loan of 1800 soles, money that will be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar and oil. delfina’s dreams are to have a wholesale shop and to improve her welfare.

translated from spanish by richard brown, kiva volunteer

mrs. otilia is a member of the communal bank “palomas de oro (doves of gold)” in the district of puno, province of puno, region of puno. she is 66 years old, widowed, and has six children. she does not have an education.

she has worked with the manuela ramos movement for 4 years. she has a business selling groceries (rice, sugar, pasta, oil). her first loan was for 300 pen.

she currently desires a loan of an additional 700 pen which will serve her to buy more groceries (rice, milk, oil). she would like to have a larger, better stocked store.

mrs. otilia tells us that she enjoys the meetings and the ease of paying that manuela ramos offers.

translated from spanish by william gray, kiva volunteer

greetings from zimbabwe! this is 32-year-old yollander e from harare. she is married with two children, one attending school. she also cares for two dependents. yollander e runs a clothing business selling kidswear, handbags and cosmetics. the business has been in operation for seven years. she says the main challenge she faces is the high rental fees for shops in the central business district. \r\n\r\nyollander e has requested a loan of 750 zwl to purchase kids' clothing and comestics to sell during the festive (christmas) season. she says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve the general welfare of her family. in the future, yollander e plans to own her own boutique shop.

lilia is 41 years old and married with three children, two of whom are in school.

she earns a living by pig fattening in the philippines. lilia is borrowing php 13,000 through nwtf to buy feed and other supplies to raise her pigs.

lilia has been pig fattening for six years and also earns additional income from farming rice.

she is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

edwin is a young man who is 31 years of age. he is single and lives with his family in ica. edwin currently works as a municipal security guard in his town. he believes that he is doing well because of his excellent achievements and dedication. edwin is a hardworking, friendly, and respectful individual.

he is extremely grateful to the kiva lenders. as a result, he will be able to cover the expenses related to obtaining his driver’s license since he owns a motorcycle. he wants to generate more income by providing transportation services. in addition, he will be able to have the motorcycle repaired. edwin continues to put forth the effort and save money so that later on he can finish the construction of his house.

turakul is a hardworking man. he was born in the southern part of a country in 1964. he is living in a rural area. he is married and has five children. his wife is a teacher. in the area where he lives, it is common for a man rather than a woman to take a loan, because it is most common for a woman to be a housekeeper. \r\n\r\nturakul is a teacher at secondary school. he needs to work hard in order to feed his big family. he is planning to buy livestock and get additional income for family expenditures. he is asking for financial support from kiva and imon to buy livestock. he wishes his children will be fed and have everything that they need to live.

mamie is a 31-year-old business woman. she lives with her partner and has three children, ages 10 through 18. all of her children are currently in school and they live at home.

mamie runs a business which sells fresh fish, chicken feet, pig feet and meat. she established this business 6 years ago. she has had no problem with her business. she likes her business because she has achieved greatly. to remain in business she requested a loan with brac liberia. the loan will be used to buy more fresh fish, chicken feet, pig feet and meat to sell and generate more profit that will help her achieve her goals.

her partner gave her the money to start the business and she learned the trade from her mother. she used a car to carry her goods to her business site. she sells 15 hours each day. in the future she would like to make deals as a big business woman. she says thanks for your support.

agrippine, age 51, is a member of the unguke group and she lives in gitega. she is married to a mason named protais and they have 9 children, 4 of whom go to school.

agrippine has been selling beer and lemonade for 20 years. this is her 3rd loan cycle with turame, and this credit will help to bolster her capital. she plans to buy a large supply of beer and lemonade to increase her sales and revenue.

hon, 40, is married, resides with her husband and four children in kampot province, cambodia. she has been involved in agricultural business for over twenty years, earning approximately usd 2 per day. her husband runs public transportation service (motor taxi). he earns about usd 4 per day. two of her children are employed in garment factory. approximately, they earn usd 6 per day. 

due to the difficulty in the family’s transportation, hon is requesting a loan of usd 1500 to purchase a motorbike to commute. this purchase will help her reduce the transportation expenses. in the future, she would like to expand her business and help her children get bachelor’s degree. moreover, she plans to rebuild her present house to make it bigger to provide enough space for her family’s living.

marcos lives with his wife and two children, an 8 year old daughter and a 14 year old son. his wife helps around the house and care for their daughter. their son helps him take care of livestock.

marcos works in agriculture and livestock. he sells or butchers at home. his wife and his son help cut and weigh the meat. they also help attend to customers.

he requests a loan to buy a bull and a cow for subsequent sales or butcher.

marcos plans to continue working hard for the welfare of his family. he wants to put a butcher shop in the community as the demand is increasing and he wants to expand his services.

mihary is married. her husband works as a driver. after two years of marriage, the couple have a 12-month-old child. the income made from previous work has enabled the couple to produce bricks. mihary’s work involves the farming of rice and vegetables (tomatoes) and the fattening of hogs. her farm work is seasonal.

fattening hogs requires significant funds for feeding the herd over the 6-month cycle, and the pig pen needs to be improved, thus this request for a second loan. the goal is to build up savings for the construction of the house and for being autonomous, since the couple still live with parents.

rochan is 31 years old and married with two children who are in school. she works very hard to provide for them.

she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 10,000 loan through nwtf to buy more stock to sell like soap, shampoo, chips, bread, canned goods, eggs, etc.

rochan has been in this business for three years.

in the future rochan would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

augustin needs to take out another loan in order to carry out his business. he wants to add dairy products such as yogurt, butter and cheese to his offerings. he wants to purchase quality items for his customers. he also wants to purchase different packs of biscuits in order to revitalize his shop display. he wants to earn enough profits in order to generate more savings.

flora d. is from the village of lumbayao, tampilisan, zamboanga del norte. she is 47 years old, married and has one adult-aged child. to make a living, flora owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. flora has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 php per month from these activities.
in 2009, flora joined kiva partner, pmpc, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. she has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 php from pmpc. this loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. flora is requesting a new loan of 14,900 php, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. this loan will be her sixth from pmpc. she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

about pmpc
paglaum multi-purpose cooperative (pmpc) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern mindanao. it reaches out to the rural poor using the grameen model.

*note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva. given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

even at her age of 63, linda doesn’t want to stop working yet. she feels productive when she earns money by herself. she doesn’t want to depend on her grown-up children because they have their own families to raise and support. 

she enjoys selling ready-to-wear clothes such as school uniforms, skirts, blouses, and other items. the income derived from her business sustains her and her husband’s daily needs. her 65-year-old husband, alejandro, is already retired. he takes a turn in watching over her store located at barotac viejo public market in iloilo. 

linda normally experiences stiff competition in business, but she focuses on her goal to be productive and continue earning a living. it fuels her to expand her business by making it more enticing to customers. she plans to buy more up-to-date clothes and add sweaters or jackets in time for the rainy season. she needs additional capital of php 20,000 to buy these items so she can gain extra profit and savings in case of emergencies. she meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the word of god. *all cct community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

felipa is married with 5 children. she is 50 years old and lives in lower bagong silang pagadian city zamboanga del sur. 

to earn a living, felipa has a junk shop. she has had this business for 10 years. each month, she earns approximately php 6,000. she applied for a loan to support the expansion of her business into the nearby municipalities. she needs capital to purchase junk items and empty bottles and re-sell it for recycle.

felipa has been a member of pmpc for 5 years. 

in the future, she hopes to build a big shop to store the junk.

many years ago greziel opened a sari-sari (variety) store, selling various commodities including noodles, canned goods, soft drinks, sugar, eggs, soap, and beverages. this is the source of her income.

she is married woman with four dependents, ages 9-20 years old. her husband caters motor boat transportation services for a living.

she wants to continue improve her quality of life and support the needs of her family. this is why she applied for a loan from kiva's field partner in the philippines, cevi, to buy rice, beverages, soft drinks, and canned goods for her business.

greziel is hoping that she will continue to improve her current livelihood and better the welfare of her family as well.

innocent is a positive minded and hardworking married man with three children living in kamwenge, uganda. he has a retail shop business alongside crop production where he grows crops like beans, coffee, maize and so many others. he also has a piggery project which earns him income to support his family and pay school fees for his children.

he dreams of expanding his business so much so as to become a prosperous businessman though his main challenge is the high rental costs of operating a business.

he needs the loan so as to buy more high demand stock like soap, cooking oil, classic clothes, bags, designer ladies' clothes and other items to sell.

emeline works hard to support three children. she is married and has a pig fattening business in the philippines.

emeline requested a 10,000 php loan through nwtf to pay for materials and labor in order to build a sanitary toilet for her family. she is aware that by using the sanitary toilet, she is reducing health hazard risks to her family and neighbors, as well as promoting protection of the environment.

the members of than’s group live in a rural village in kampong speu province, cambodia. than makes a living cultivating rice, and she also does extra work as a farmer to support her family.

in her village, there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help than to safeguard the health of her family, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

daniel, 52 years old, is a micro-entrepreneur in the city of barranquilla who works selling fruits and natural juices. his sales point is traditional and is located at the front of a school with a large number of students. he has been operating there for over 20 years. he lives with his wife and two children in an apartment which they just acquired.

daniel asked for his first kiva loan with the end of doing repairs on his food cart and to improve some of his utensils with the end of giving a cleaner and more hygienic appearance. support him in his loan.

maría, 47, is a single mother who lives in her home with her children.  she has a business making and selling pottery: pitchers, jewelry boxes, clay roosters, plates, jugs, and a wide variety of decorations.  she's known as a persevering person with a desire to get ahead.

maría needs the loan to buy brushes, paint, clay, etc.  she hopes this investment will allow her to get ahead in her business and earn the money she needs to get ahead with her family in her household.

one of her dreams is to finish building a space for her business.

san lorenzo, honduras, may 2015

to make a living, ricardo d. s. plants and harvests rice for sale. he is 42 years old, married and has three school-aged children. they are from the village of esperanza west. ricardo has been in his business for over 12 years and earns approximately 15,000 philippine pesos (php) per harvest. in 2010, ricardo joined aski to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. ricardo is requesting a loan of 6,000 php which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. this will be his first loan from aski. he plans to use additional income to improve and expand his business. about aski: aski is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the philippines. it has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva. given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

chhim is 30 years old, a factory worker who comes from ang snoul district. 

his work schedule starts at 7 a.m. and finishes at 5 p.m.. this type of work is extremely related to his physical state. anyway, he has to do it for his living. from this business, he is able to generate an income $8 per day. chhim has a life partner in his wife, who is on a sewing staff, and he is blessed with two children. both of his children are attending a local school. 

with the sum of $1,200, he will build a small brick house and cover the roof with zinc. this house will provide a comfortable living for his family. he would like to say thanks to all lenders who lend him money to build this shelter.

jenny works hard to support four children. she is married and has a general store business in the philippines.

jenny requested a php 7,000 loan through nwtf in order to build a sanitary toilet for her family.

jenny is aware that by using the sanitary toilet, she is reducing health and hazard risks to her family and neighbors as well as promoting environment protection.

this is arline, 31, a resident of taguig, manila, philippines. her husband is eduard and together they manage their household while operating the business. at this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

arline operates a buy and sell business. what she basically does is buy products from wholesalers and sell them per item with a profit. her products are bags, blankets, clothing and other similar products. customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many products that she offers. her regular customers are neighbors and the local community.  she earns a minimum of 500 philippine pesos (php) in sales every day.

to help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a php 8,000 loan. she will be using the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. she expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

arline dreams of succeeding in her business and in life. she faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of god she studies.

* all cct community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

afsha is the age of 31, living with her single child and husband in the area of lahore, pakistan. 
afsha adores her family, and her husband works very hard so that his family can have a good and respectable life. 

her husband provides canopies for the wedding ceremonies of people. afsha is requesting a loan from kiva's partner, brac pakistan, with the goal of improving her husband's business. her husband requires additional capital for the growth of his business. he would use the kiva loan to purchase wooden planks and bamboo to offer more variety to his clients. 

afsha hopes that the loan will be helpful for her husband's business.

cruz is a rural woman and the mother of 2 children. she has had to endure many hardships in her life but she has always had the strength to progress forward and continue to get ahead with her family.

for a long time, she has wanted to start a business raising and selling pigs. that’s why she is asking for a great economic encouragement to buy some pigs for breeding and materials to build a corral. 

with this new business, she can generate income for her family. family is everything to her. she can improve their quality of life for her husband and children. she will work everyday to promote her business and make it a sustainable and profitable activity. 

support a working woman with this loan!

njira is a woman of integrity and a great merchant. she has been managing a retail shop for over five years. she also has a motorcycle where she has hired someone to operate it. njira has been a member of yehu since 2010 and has been one of the beneficiaries of yehu loans, this being her second loan. thanks to her hardwork she has been able to cater for the needs of her family. her business goal is to open a wholesale in future. njira has been in this line of business for the last seven years, previously busy in farming. she has requested a loan in the amount of ksh 40,000 to add stock of flour, beverages such as juice and sodas, and other fast selling products.

alex is a 56-year-old proud father of 10 children. he is a group leader, often described as a very hardworking individual, and is representing his group of 10 farmers in kimilili district. since joining one acre fund in 2014, alex has noticed that he has been able to consistently feed his family.

alex described his harvest as very good last year, but believes he can have a better one this year by continuing to work with one acre fund. he is very excited to also be purchasing two solar lights, apart from fertilizer and maize, because he will now be able to have light during dark hours for his children to be able to study. with the profits from this season’s harvest, he plans to send his children to school.

with this loan, alex’s group will be able to plant a total of 5.75 acres of land and purchase a total of 8 solar lights.

as a married mother of two children, amy works hard to support her family.

she has a tailoring business in the philippines. amy is borrowing php 15,000 through nwtf in order to buy new supplies for her tailoring business.

amy has been sustaining her business activities through her past 2 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business.

josé, 46 years old, is a farmer. he studied through the first grade of primary school and did not continue due to the difficult economic situation or lack of will. he notes that when he started to study some people came and kidnapped the teachers and the teachers never came again to that school. they had to flee since it was wartime and afterward when they arrived they had to work in order to start again. now he works in agriculture as he has always done. \r\n\r\nhe is married and his wife works on the household duties. the loan he is requesting is to buy manure, although he has the land prepared with the hope that once more he will be given the opportunity to work in order to move his family ahead. his children study in the fourth and fifth grade. he would like for at least one of his two children to be a professional, although they like to do the work their father is teaching them.

hello kiva community!

irene is a smallholder farmer who lives in a small village called kapsoit in the south rift region of kenya. in this area, dairy and maize farming are the main economic activities practiced by the constituents. irene, a mixed-farmer, practices both. she has been doing this work for six good years. her primary income sources are milk, maize, and a small personal business.

the mother of four stated that milking is the most enjoyable of her activities on the farm. she is very connected with her dairy animals and has assigned a name to each of them. she has dreams of growing her dairy farm by herding more animals and buying more land.

irene is seeking a loan of 65,000 kes to purchase a dairy cow. business-related expenses keep rising by the day, forcing farmers and business people alike to reduce costs and/or increase sales. the additional cow will help in the utilization of pasture and will increase milk production and the availability of more byproducts. irene will be able to save a bit on expenses such as fertilizer.

she hopes that she will be able to use this loan investment wisely to raise her family's standard of living.

kann s. is 46 years old and a mother of three school-aged children. they all live in prey veng, cambodia. she and her husband are grocery vendors, working from their home, earning about $4 each day. she plans to invest in additional grocery products so that she can meet her customers' needs.\r\n

lomina is 37 and lives with her husband and children. she has been selling food products for the last two years. she has requested a loan with the objective of buying more food products, to optimise her business and to earn as much income as possible.

merlinda is 65 years old and married with two children.  she works very hard to provide for them.

she runs a buy and sell nipa roofing in the philippines and requested a php 11,000 loan through nwtf to purchase additional bundle of nipa roofing to sell.

merlinda has been in this business for 19 years.

in the future, merlinda would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

coronacion g. is 26 and has three children. her husband, joey, is a driver. she sells fish - such as milk fish, tilapia, shrimps, and prawns - in the town market of hamtic, to help support the needs of the family. 

she started her business when she joined ashi (ahon sa hirap, inc.) in 2000. her membership has really helped her because she was able to provide a tricycle (a bicycle with a sidecar) for her husband from her income. she also purchased furniture and utensils for the house and has been able to save money toward the education of her children.

she applied for this loan to buy more stock so as to increase her income. she dreams of selling to the vendors in the market from her own stall someday.

virginia offers bananas and charcoal for sale for ten years. she is 50 years of age, a widow blessed with two children. virginia would like to improve her vending activity; that’s the reason why she’s requesting a loan of php 8,000 to buy 300 sacks of charcoal and 2,000 kilograms of bananas to sell. \r\n\r\nvirginia hopes that her loan will enable her to improve her sales and income. in this way, she could sustain her family's basic needs and improve her living conditions.

in portoviejo, also known as the city of the royal tamarind trees since colonial times, the "mujeres de ríobamba" communal bank meets every fortnight.

forty-three-year-old ramona lives here.  she is now divorced but good came out of her marriage in the form of two daughters, aged 26 and 21 years, both of whom are now studying at university.

in order to prosper, ramona makes a living selling all types of clothing, such as shoes and women's accessories.  she sells door-to-door and from her home, where her better known customers come.  she works four days a week and her customers pay in installments, with ramona making collections every two weeks.  she mostly sells women's clothes.  she buys her merchandise in guayaquil once every two weeks or once a month, according to what she needs.  it is through this work that ramona has managed to move forward in life since her divorce with her husband.

ramona will use this loan to buy trousers, t-shirts and blouses, but especially women's clothes.  she has been with the communal bank for four years and is grateful for the payment system.

ramona's dream is to have her own house as she currently only rents.

lopur has been selling fruits and vegetables in naivasha town for the last 10 years.  he is 60 years old and married to catherine nabwaga. they have three children.

he was introduced to kadet ltd by his friend and this will be his second loan.  he plans to use the loan to buy carrots, peas and tomatoes in bulk to sell.

in the future, lopur hopes to open a big green grocer shop in naivasha town.

finda is 34 years old with school age children. she personally sells the catch from their fishing boat in nearby municipalities. she has been a member of paglaum mpc in good standing for almost 4 years. finda has improved their living condition with a house of good roofing. she also makes good savings from their profits.

finda wants to obtain financial assistance from paglaum mpc amounting to php 5,000 for the purchase of new nets. as much as possible, they have to have all the needed fishing accessories to minimize chances of a low or zero catch. she already has floats to help guard their fish cages. she also wants to buy the fish catch of her neighbors so she can sell more fish to the nearby fish market, where they will fetch higher prices. in the future, she dreams of purchasing a new fishing boat by setting aside some savings from the daily sales. she wishes to see her children have stable jobs as well.

good day lenders! meet one of kspps bmi’s clients, icih, who is 42 years old, married, and has one daughter. icih has had a small shop selling basic foods, snacks, bread, cake, drinks, etc. for one year. her husband works very hard and he has been building houses in the tangerang district for one year. their income is barely enough for their basic needs. they would like to improve their living conditions and create a happy and healthy life for their kid.

she has asked for a loan of idr 800,000 from kspps bmi. this loan will be used to build a clean water source facility at their home to improve access to water sources for her family. today her family has no access to a water source in their home and must rely on the river for bathing. her family income is insufficient to build water sources but icih will be able to repay the loan received.

she and her family want to live a healthy life with clean water. she is very grateful for the opportunity and wants to thank all lenders.

junilyn c. is a 37-year-old married woman from alburquerque municipality, a part of the island province of bohol in western visayas. she has two children that she sends to school and makes banana-cue, rice cakes and other delicacies to sell.

junilyn is a member of cevi and is requesting a loan of 6,000 php. she will use it to buy sugar, bananas and other ingredients she needs for her food vending enterprise. junilyn hopes to prosper in her business so she can give her children a bright future.

gina is 37 years old and has two children. she is married and her two children are presently in school.

gina is in an agricultural business fattening pigs in the philippines. she requested a 10,000 php loan through nwtf to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pig.

gina has been in this business for 1 year now, and has borrowed 2 times in the past from nwtf to sustain it.

in the future, gina would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

to help her husband raise her child, arlene (of malibay, manila, philippines) runs a seafood restaurant. she is 36 years old. her husband, bartolome, is 44 years old and works abroad. she started her seafood restaurant in february this year.

arlene is glad to know that there are organizations like cct and kiva who are willing to help micro-entrepreneurs like her to expand their small businesses. she is in need of additional capital for her business and she is hoping to borrow 20,000 php. she will use the loan to pay the restaurant rent and for ingredients for her seafood restaurant.

arlene’s dream is to have a home she can call her own. as of now, she is renting. it is also her desire for her child to finish his studies.
