arlene is a member of the center for community transformation and meets weekly with her fellowship partners to share her life’s testimony and business experience with her fellowship members. she also draws strength and inspiration from the fellowship and listening to the word of god. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 20 members. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social relationships among partners, and pay micro-finance loans.

yolanda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business selling young coconut juice in the philippines. she has been in this business for five years. yolanda earns additional income from food vending.

yolanda has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from negros women for tomorrow foundation (nwtf). she is borrowing 29,500 philippine pesos (php) through nwft to buy additional young coconuts, plastic cups, sugar, etc., for her business. she dreams of saving enough money so she can buy land in the future.

bashiran, 38 years old, is married and she works from home as a tailor. she has been in this business for two years now and is proud to be contributing to her household income. when bashiran was not earning an income, her family was going through a severe financial crisis that compelled her to use her stitching skills in a productive manner. her husband was the sole breadwinner of the family, so bashiran felt it obligatory to change her family’s living standards and started working from home. 

bashiran's hard work helped her establish a good clientele but she was having difficulty in fulfilling large orders. she contacted kashf foundation and applied a loan of pkr 40,000 to buy stocks of threads in different colors, packs of buttons, needles and laces in order to meet the demands of her customers without fail.  she hopes to grow her business and dreams of giving a good and quality education to her three children through all her hard work in her business.

guadioso has been operating a service-based business for many years to support his family. he earns well and has successfully repaid his previous loan for buying tires. gaudioso wants to make sure of the success of his business and it helps to improve the business.  currently, he is taking a new loan to buy a new set of tires, and to pay for repair and maintenance. he hopes to expand his business to gain more income in the near future.

phy is a 41-year-old farmer who lives in steung treng province. she is the married mother of five children, four of whom depend on her and need her to support their studies. she has been growing rice as her main source of income for twenty years. additionally, she has been working for others for a fee to earn additional income. her farming business earns her only about $6 usd per day on average, as the crop didn’t grow well and she had to sell it at a lower price in the market.

with her first loan from visionfund, she is going to buy seed to expand her rice-farming business. she hopes this loan will help her get high yields and earn more income so that she can keep her children in school until they graduate and find good jobs.

“try and try until you succeed” is the principle in life of maria rosario b.. the young mother is a resident of sta. barbara ilagan, isabela, she is a single mother and works as a manicurist/pedicurist to gain income and be able to give her children their daily needs and save funds for their future education. her two children are not yet in school but are consuming a lot of expenses because of drinking milk every day.

maria rosario is humbly asking assistance from kiva to lend some amount of capital to be used for her service business. she wanted to buy new sets of beauty products for her pedicure/manicure activity, and even start doing hairdressing somehow if given the chance to have a capital of 6,000 philippine pesos. she always believes that the customer’s satisfaction is what makes a business successful, which is why she would like to provide them with a good and complete service. she also believes that through her hard work and by doing the right services for her customers she will benefit her family.

this is mira, 45. she is a resident of dasmariñas, cavite, philippines. she is married to benjamin, a jeepney (transport) operator, and is a mother to her two children. she, together with her husband and children, manages their household while operating the business.  at this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

mira operates a variety store. in the philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. it is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5-pesos worth of cooking oil or an egg. she earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. aside from this, they have a jeep (public utility vehicle) that her husband manages. her store is located adjacent to her house. her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. she earns a minimum of 1,300 philippines pesos (php) in sales every day. 
    
to help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a php 12,000 loan. she will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. she expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

mira hopes her business grows in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. she faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of god she studies.

* all cct community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

joseph is a smallholder farmer from a rural home in central kenya. he is married and he and his wife were blessed with twins. joseph's family relies on dairy and poultry farming to make a living. joseph's biggest problem is the ever increasing household expenses and education costs. to keep providing a decent life for his family, joseph needs to figure a way of increasing his income.\r\n \r\njoseph is seeking a loan to buy a dairy cow. he plans to spend a small part of the loan on the cow’s insurance as a risk-mitigating measure to protect his family from slipping further into debt or poverty in the event the cow dies. from the cow, he expects to produce more milk, hence gain a wider customer base. this investment will generate more income for him to repay the loan, and in time, raise the living standards of his family.

meet isatu. she is 37 years old and from jui, western rural area in freetown. she is married with four children. after the war, isatu established her food container business. she began her business because she wanted to improve herself. she works at the business throughout the day, seven days per week. she says sometimes the bowls break, and she really finds it difficult to move from one environment to another to introduce her stock.

isatu requires a loan in order to purchase more food containers, cups, and knives to expand her business. she hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her condition of living and increase her business. in the future, isatu plans to open a big pharmacy. she thanks you for your support.

chek’s group lives in a rural village in takeo province in cambodia. chek makes a living cultivating rice to support her family.

in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

teofila is 55 years old and married with four children.

teofila is in the agricultural business raising livestock in the philippines. teofila requested a php 12,000 loan through nwtf to buy feed and other supplies to raise her livestock.

teofila has been raising livestock for five years now, and has borrowed eight times in the past from nwtf to sustain it.

teofila would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

lolita is 60 years old married woman with six children. she is a very hard working entrepreneur.

she has a buy and sell rice business in the philippines. lolita requested a php 10000 loan amount through nwtf to buy additional sacks of rice to sell.

lolita has been in this business for five years. in the future, lolita would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

milly is married and has one child, who goes to school. she also takes care of additional family members (sister). milly has operated a clinic for 5 years. she works from her home seven days every week on a retail basis only. milly's major business challenges are defaulters, seasonality, thieves and the ever increasing prices of medicines in uganda.\r\n\r\n

milly has applied for a loan of 1,000,000 uganda shillings from mcdt-sacco to buy more boxes of drugs, syringes and syrups. she hopes to own a fully stocked clinic or drug shop and to upgrade her clinic to a hospital. milly resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. her monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

norma, 41, is a friendly and hard-working woman. she lives in her own house alongside her husband, javier, who is 53, and their three dear children who are 15, 11, and 5 years old, to whom she wishes to provide a better quality of life. norma's work consists of selling basic necessity products. her work starts when she wakes up very early in order to open her grocery store. she starts with her daily sales at about 6 in the morning since the people who live in her neighborhood leave for work very early. she is a happy and persuasive seller, which has caused her to have more customers than her competition. at first, she had difficulty with her business since she didn't know a lot about how to do this work. but, over time, she gained experience and now she is an excellent seller. what she likes most about her work is to converse with her customers since this way she can find out about the things that happen in her neighborhood. she has been doing this work for seven years and what she considers to be most difficult is getting up so early since, generally, she attends until late hours at night. this will be the third loan with the mfp institution so she hopes, from this collaboration, to continue with her objectives. she is trusted by the group members of the community bank to which she belongs. additionally, she is convinced that they will be good, punctual and responsible clients. with the loan requested of 1000 soles, she will be products to be able to offer greater variety of things to her customers who visit her daily.

eusebio máximo, 48, is married and has one child. he works independently as a bricklayer but also farms his small plot of land. he grows potatoes, corn and vegetables. he wants to improve his farmland and is asking for funds to buy seed, manure and fertilizers to do so. he is a member of the “josé carlos mariátegui” communal bank located in urubamba district, urubamba province, cusco department. he avails himself of this platform to express his gratitude to all those who share his dream and commits to repay in a timely fashion.

translated from spanish by michael bujazan, kiva volunteer

the “damas de agua fría” (agua fría ladies) meets every two weeks in ayacucho parish in santa ana canton, a place known for its beautiful fresh-water resorts that are a great tourist attraction in the canton and province.  luis, 24, lives here.  he’s married but does not have children yet.  his wife is actually six-months pregnant with their first baby; she’s a housewife.

luis works in agriculture and doing work in the fields but also has a small store in the house where he lives.  he sells all types of products like rice, sugar, oil, detergent, etc. there.  he started with very little but as days passed and with help from the loans he’s been gradually enlarging the business and he currently has a well-stocked store.  he works there with help from his wife who is the one that spends most of her time there since he has to work in agriculture.  his parcel is currently ready for the arrival of winter and he will be planting corn and peanuts.  he’s been in business more than two years and it makes it possible for him to get ahead.

he will use this loan to better stock his store.  he will buy basic staples as well as seeds and insecticides for the crops.  he’s been in the communal bank for two cycles and likes it for the help the institution provides.  his dream is to have his own house and a larger, better-stocked store.

romelin is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with five children.

she has a fish vending business in the philippines and requested a php 27,000 loan through nwtf in order to buy more seafood to sell in her nearest market.

she successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business. romelin dreams that one day she will be able to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

these are teachers of the r.e.c primary school, waterloo. r.e.c. primary school waterloo was founded in 1926 by the government. r.e.c waterloo has a total number of 546 pupils and a total number of fourteen staff. since 2006, when nafisatu a. t. took over the administration of the school, r.e.c primary school waterloo has been producing good results at the national primary school exams (npse). however, like many schools in sierra leone, rec waterloo lacks adequate classrooms, seating accommodations and adequate learning and teaching materials. this will be the first loan for teachers of the r.e.c primary school from smt/kiva. government salaries are usually quite small for teachers, thus making teaching an unattractive profession for many whose primary motivator is money. many choose other jobs over teaching because of the small salary, thus starving the field of qualified personnel to teach the children. the few who remain in the classrooms have to find other ways of making ends meet. the vast majority of them engage in either businesses or agriculture or they provide extra tutorial classes for the children (although this is a practice the government is trying to stop).

needless to say, loans from smt are a great help to the teachers in order to boost their businesses or investing it in something productive. many want to go to school but could not afford the cost. some will want to buy pieces of furniture, but their monthly salary is not enough to let them do so. with a loan, they will be able to meet some of these needs. and with their monthly salaries, they can repay easily via a payroll deduction type of system. nafisatu a. t. (left) is the head teacher of r.e.c primary school waterloo. she was born in matotoka village, tonkolili district, northern sierra leone. she is fifty-four years of age and married with four children. one is already an adult and three are still attending schools. she has been a teacher for thirty-six years now. nafisatu will use this loan to buy bundles of corrugated iron zinc to roof her house. she does not expect to complete the roofing of her house with this loan, but with subsequent loans, however, she will certainly complete the roofing of her house. this will bring happiness and joy to nafisatu as it will relieve her of the burden of paying exorbitant rents.

virginia hails from the town of talibon. she owns and operates a tricycle (rickshaw), transportation service. she is a 51-year old married woman and has five children. her eldest child is 18 while the youngest is 7. she also engages in farming. she grows and sells rice. she has been engaged in farming for many years now. she faces challenges in handling both her sources of income.

she requested a loan to purchase fertilizers, insecticides and tires and pay for her motorcycle franchise. these are very vital and enable her to manage her resources efficiently. she could be able to improve the yield of her farm and continue operating her transportation services, too.

virginia hopes that she can continue to support the schooling of her children and be able to handle her livelihood successfully.

epiphanie is 41 years old and married. she has seven children aged 3 to 20 years old, and all the children go to school. epiphanie has been in business for 3 years doing tailoring. she is taking out a loan to buy a new sewing machine, and hopes that as a result of this loan, she’ll be able to increase business profits to pay school fees and medical insurance for her children, as well as save for her future. this is epiphanies’s first loan cycle with visionfund rwanda, and with this loan she hopes her family’s life will improve by building her own house.

mr. heng p., 41, and his wife, mrs. sophy norng, 36, live along national road number one about 17 kilometers from phnom penh. they were married in 1993 and have two children: one son and one daughter. both children study at a local school.

mr. heng has been a remoque (motorbike with a trailer at the back) motor taxi driver along national road number two for two years, while mrs. sophy has been farming for five years. now heng’s trailer is very old and broken. therefore, he is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a new trailer to replace the old one.

clarisa is 51 years old and lives in poblacion, siquijor.  she is married and has five children.  clarisa sells kitchenware products everyday.  her business is located along the highway of poblacion. she has had this business for eleven years. \r\n\r\nclarisa requested a loan amounting to php 15,000 to purchase more kitchenware products to sell.  she has been a member of paglaum multi purpose cooperative for one year.  in the future, clarisa hopes to improve her family's living condition.

aboubakar is a young man, aged 31, who is the father of one child.  he has been selling honey and vegetable oil for a very long time.  due to the fact that his customer base has increased over time and also because of his small stock of merchandise, he is requesting a loan to buy a large quantity of honey and vegetable oil.  this will allow him to increase his sales, which will in turn help him to take good care of his family and expand this activity.

kelly is 32 years old and lives in the municipality of san antonio de palmito. she has 3 children. her family is the most important thing in her life. she’s a talented entrepreneur who works making beautiful hand crafts in caña flecha, which it’s a very traditional element in colombia. she wants to improve her business, because she wants to send her children to a good university. to accomplish that she needs to start making more money. she’s asking for a loan to buy more caña flecha to increase her beautiful handcrafts production and to buy pigs to raise.



support this creative mother, and loan now.



if you want to know more about the entrepreneurs and the loans from interactuar, you can join the lending team called: “friends of interactuar colombia”: http://www.kiva.org/team/interactuar_colombia

for 10 years, juana del socorro has had her own grocery store. she and her husband have done their best so that their business is successful.
she is grateful to kiva and micredito for the loans they received previously. she has three children who have their own family. at 64, juana del socorro has a lot of strength to continue working. this is why she is requesting a new loan to invest in her business. with the money she will be able to buy rice, sugar, beverages and other products that she will sell. in the future, she wants to have her own work capital.

jeannette is a 49-year-old woman, married and the mother of four children, ages 11 to 25.  three of her children attend school.

jeannette is a retailer; for the past 22 years, she has been selling fresh produce in one of the neighborhoods of the capital city.  thanks to her expertise, social skills, and to the high quality of her products and reasonable prices, she has managed to attract a large group of customers, whose needs she can no longer satisfy.

she is requesting a loan to boost her stocks of merchandise (particularly tomato crates).  this, in turn, will help her to meet the needs of her large customer base and to increase her sales.

she will use her profits to reinvest in her business and provide for her family.

ngaya s. is a 48-year-old married woman who is the mother of five children. she has been a member of banc villageois for two years and has had four loan experiences. she would like to buy a pair of cattle for milk production in order to generate profits that will enable her to support her family and to increase her savings.

translated from french by dan kuey, kiva volunteer

emilio has a farm where he cultivates rice. he has lived in baba, ecuador for his entire life working in agriculture. his education is very limited, but he has been able to raise two children through his rice cultivation. he has over 35 years of experience with this crop and he now has the help of his two sons who work with him. he is planning to use the loan to invest in pesticides and fertilizer for his land.

communal banking in baba

this borrower is part of the newest and largest communal bank in the recently developed mifex rural finance program. all of the members of the centro agricola de baba communal bank are part of an association of rice farmers in the county of baba in rural ecuador. their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. as an association, centro agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. the farmers from centro agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

the members of centro agricola de baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. this means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the centro agricola de baba association are responsible for the amount in default. the members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

below is more information about santa lucia compiled by luis crespo and robert edgar of the mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the rural finance program.

economy of baba

the people of baba have been organized since the days of gran colombia when ecuador was yet to be a country. the area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. now baba is a county in the province of los rios in the coastal region of ecuador. for most of the latter part of the 20th century it was a cacao and banana-producing sector. most of the surrounding areas of baba in los rios are owned by large multinational companies such as dole, but baba is a sector characterized by small and informal farms.

rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. the lands in baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soybeans as secondary sources of income. many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

rice farming in baba

most of the people in the baba area are small farmers. they produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. in order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. this is the most difficult part for the farmers in baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. after appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water-intensive crop. the rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in spanish) or hand sowed. once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

access to credit

one of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. they have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

risks

the largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. although baba is in the province “los rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. the lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. if the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. on the other hand, if there is too much rain, there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. generally speaking though, baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soybeans.

loan use

the loans in this sector will mostly be used to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. the loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. the rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

hean c., 52, is married and resides in kampong cham province, cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. c. and her husband are farmers that earn an income of about usd 5 per day. each month, the family has to spend usd 58 on food and usd 30 on the other necessary expenses. c. is requesting a loan of usd 1200 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a business as motor-taxi driver. this will be her first loan from credit, a long-standing kiva partner.

the san josé credit group meets every 15 days in the district of jaramijo. this place is known for its beautiful beaches. here the majority of the people are very hard-working and have jobs that involve the sea.

valeria, who lives in this region, is 21 years old and is married. from this relationship she has two children, 4 and 3 years old, who attend kindergarten. her husband works as a fisherman. 

valeria intends to earn some money of her own to help her husband with the expenses involving their home and children. she therefore sells clothing of all types and makeup. her way of sales is door-to-door. she goes out during the less busy times and also sells her products in her home where her clients come to see her. she leaves her merchandise on credit and then collects money every 2 weeks. 
 
she has been doing this for more than 2 years, which helps her earn something on her own. she sometimes even gives part of her loan to her husband so that he can use it for fishing. 

she will use this loan to buy clothing and makeup. she has been with the credit group through 4 cycles, and she enjoys it because the loans help her greatly. her dream is to provide the best for her little ones.

fatmeh is a 56-year-old widow, and all of her children are married. 

fatmeh works in embroidery to keep on making a productive person of herself and make a living. she is seeking a loan to buy more thread and fabric to do some embroidery work on it and turn it into table and pillow covers.

klubo, 46 years old, lives in jacob town, one of the cheapest places to live in montserrado county. she’s married and has six children aged between 19 and 32; only three of them live with her and attend school. klubo has been involved in the sales of charcoal for 25 years. she started this business with her mother's help and she is proud to earn her own money. klubo is requesting this loan to purchase more charcoal. in the future, she plans to build her children a house.

linet moraa is a thirty-two-year-old lady who is married with two children. she runs a wholesale and retail shop in manyatta, a low-cost residential area in the outskirts of kisumu city. linet has been running this business for seven years. she sells mainly foodstuffs and household goods. linet had been accessing small loans from an informal women's group, which disintegrated during the post-election violence in early 2008 and she was left with no other source of capital. she learned about kadet through a friend. she hopes to use the money from this loan to purchase more stock and include cereals in her shop to serve her customers better. in the long run, linet hopes to build a permanent house on a plot of land which she has purchased and to move the business there, so that she would not have to pay rent and other related charges. about kadet: the kenya agency for the development of enterprise and technology (kadet) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

lilibeth is 44 years old and married with three children. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

lilibeth has a furniture making business in the philippines. she requested a php 29000 loan amount through nwtf to buy raw materials for her furniture making.  lilibeth has been in this business for 20 years.
 
in the future, lilibeth would like to save money to expand her business.

haidee, 31 years old, is single. she resides in san vicente, tambulig, zamboanga del sur, philippines. for the past 7 years, haidee has owned and operated a farm, planting and harvesting rice for sale. she earns php 7,000 monthly from this business. haidee has requested a loan of php 18,000 to purchase fertilizers and seedlings for the next cropping. in 2009, haidee joined gdmpc. in the future, she wants to make improvements to her house and to the family's general living conditions.\r\n

maría hilda del transito p. is 55 years old and a cheerful hardworking woman. she sells delicious tamales which are made of ground corn, contain small pieces of chicken, and wrapped and cooked in banana leaves. maría lives with her daughter, who is a teacher, and cares for her 11 year old grandson. she is in charge of producing and selling tamales as a traveling vendor in the different villages throughout the department of san miguel. maría and her family live in this same area. due to the great taste of her tamales, she has been able to attract a large customer base and maintain stable sales. this allows her to earn sufficient income to have a decent life.\r\n

\r\nfor this reason, she is applying for a loan from apoyo integral so that she can by corn in bulk, banana leaves, firewood, chicken, and some vegetables for making more tamales. this will enable her to improve her sales and achieve financial stability. since this is her only source of income, maría wants to do everything necessary to improve her business.

translated from spanish by ronan reodica, kiva volunteer

hoeun’s group live in a rural village in kompong thom province in cambodia. hoeun does work as farmer to support her family. 

in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families, save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

miranda, aged 30, is a married woman living in the adidogomé district with her two dependent children. she is very energetic and sells cosmetic products. her business brings in a profit for helping out her husband to meet family needs. she gets her supplies twice a month at the market. miranda is asking for this loan to order hair straighteners and hair extensions in order to sell and earn more income. \r\n

salma, a resident of borewala (famous for its shrines), pakistan, is the wife of m. a. and the mother of five children. they all live together in a small house of two rooms where they have lived for the past thirty years. her first two sons are involved in a vegetable selling business. her daughters are enrolled in a school and are getting an education.  
her husband operates a grocery shop in the community. he selected this business because of his four years of sales experience. he opens his shop in the morning at 8 o’clock and closes it at 9pm. salma also helps him by spending time in his grocery shop with him. in this way they handle the clients and increase the income. the income helps them to manage the financial expenses and to pay the education fees of their kids. 
salma is applying for a loan for the second time from asasah. the funds will be used to invest in capital for the grocery shop so they can purchase the groceries in bulk and increase the profit.

panka is the one holding a goat by the cord. he is 54 years old. his wife is a homemaker. panka has seven children, four of whom are in school—one girl and three boys. panka has been raising livestock and growing vegetables for over 11 years. he stocks up at the local markets, where he also sells. he makes a decent revenue in this way.

his dream for the future is to become a major import-export vendor in his district and help his four children who are in school succeed in their studies. thanks to his loan, panka plans to increase his revenues by purchasing more goats. his challenge is availability of animal feed.

noeun, 58, is living in a rural area of the kampong cham province and is the mother of five children. because of her living conditions, she can earn income via cucumber growing and has been a construction worker for ages. her daily family income earns about 41,100 khr per day.  noeun has been with visionfund (kiva’s partner) for two cycles already and completely repaid the loans. now she wants to create a new business, feeding pigs to sell. to fulfill her needs, she is now leading a group of five members to get this new loan. as the group leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy piglet feed and build a pig cage to support her new business. she hopes that she will have enough household supplies to use and get more income than before.

helina is a married woman. she has three children with ages ranging from 4 to 13 years old. she describes herself to be ambitious. she operates a retail business where she sells clothes. she has been involved in this business for six years. her business is located in an area with potential and her primary customers are mostly ladies. she describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances. she will use the kes 50,000 loan to buy more clothes. her business goal is to excel in business within five years. this is her second loan with smep microfinance bank. her previous loan was repaid successfully.\t\t\t\r\n

ma. victoria is 45 years old and married with four children. she earns a living by raising pigs in the philippines. ma. victoria has been raising pigs for 20 years and also earns additional income from food vending.\r\n\r\nma. victoria is borrowing 19500 php through nwtf to purchase additional feed and vitamins for her pigs. she is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

virginia works hard to support her family. virginia is married and has a general store business in the philippines.

virginia requested a php 12000 loan through nwtf to buy more stock to sell in her general store.

virginia has been in this business for 20 years now.

in the future, virginia would like to save money to expand her business.

lilia is 50 yeas old and lives in inasagan, aurora, zamboanga del sur with her husband and six children. to make a living, she owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of products. she has been in this line of work for 11 years and earns php 8,000 a month. lilia joined gdmpc in 2007 and is requesting a loan of php 10,000 to buy more items to sell to her customers. she plans to use the additional revenue generated by her business to improve her family's living conditions.

alhaji ishaq a. is a 30-year-old farmer from gwanki. as a babban gona member, alhaji ishaq a. is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. like all babban gona members, alhaji ishaq a. can earn up to $2,000/ha this season from growing maize -- more than three times the average nigerian farmer’s annual income. 

the average babban gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. however, alhaji ishaq a. is ambitious and is aiming to reap 120 bags per hectare this season. when asked, alhaji ishaq a. said, “i plan to use the money i make to build a better home,” and in five years, he wants to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” 

with this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

herlinda is 41 years old, married, and has two children.  she lives with her family in the cayalti district about one hour from the city of chiclayo.  

she has worked raising and selling small animals for five years.  she feeds them so they grow and fatten, and when they are at the ideal weight and size, she sells them to merchants and at the market in her area.  herlinda works hard every day together with her husband so that their income can give the best to their family.

herlinda wants to continue growing, so she has decided to request a loan of 1500 nuevos soles from edpyme alternativa.  this money will allow her to purchase more animals for later sale.  

herlinda has good personal references from her community.

adlea is a pleasant woman. she lives in the town of waspam. she is married with five children. the eldest, 16 years old, is in secondary school, and the four younger ones are in primary school. she and her husband work as teachers.

because their income would not cover the replacement of the wood in her stilt house, which is somewhat deteriorated, she requests her first loan to improve her home - buying wood and nails, and covering the cost of labor. this would give her a home that is pretty and secure.

mary ann c. is 32 years old, separated from her spouse and has two school-aged children. she is from the village of sampagar within the municipality of damulog, a part of bukidnon province on the mindanao islands. mary ann runs a specialized retail store from which she sells lotions and perfumes from a supplier in the local community. mary ann has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 php a month.

in 2010, mary ann joined hspfi to gain access to its financial services. she is requesting a new loan, her first from hspfi, of 5000 php that will be used to purchase additional products to sell. she plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

about hspfi:

hspfi is an accredited partner of opportunity international in the philippines. it is based in cagayan de oro city and is reaching out to the poor households of northern mindanao.

*note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva. given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, kiva created this template for our field partner to allow it to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

hadjah is the leader of a 4-member group. she is 55 years old and divorced with 6 children aged between 30 and 18 years. two of her children go to school, and the rest are working. she stays with her brother who owns the home where she is staying with her school-going children. there are four people at home.

the family gets two meals a day. she resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of kampala. hadjah works in kibuye market in one of the city suburbs and deals in bananas. hadjah doesn't incur any extra transport costs because she gets them from her place of work. she works seven days a week.

hadjah sells to an average of 20 customers a day and sells both small and large quantities depending on the customers' wishes. her main expenses include school fees and medication plus daily market dues.

she has been with mcdt for four years and is servicing her twelfth loan with the same group mates. she wants to use this loan to increase the stock of her business. she aspires to educate her children up to university. .

soutoura (meaning "taking care of oneself") is a group of women from the madina koura neighborhood in the city of koutiala. they live in large traditional families with their husbands, children and co-spouses. they average 34 years of age, are married and have at least four children.

the group trades in firewood, clothing, and transformation of néré nuts into food condiments. to bolster their business, the members of the group decided to join the loan program of kiva's partner, soro yiriwaso, one year ago. they are now seeking their second loan, and the previous one was repaid without problem.

djeneba o. is one of the members of the group. she buys néré nuts and transform them into sounbala (a food condiment very much appreciated by malian women, and in the subregion). she's very much in demand since she travels with her sounbala to bamako (the capital of mali) and gao.

she intends to use her part of the loan to buy sacks of néré nuts in sikasso, in dogonasso, and in zangasso. she sells her sounbala wholesale, retail and for cash, to a clientele comprising mostly women, in bamako and gao.

while the other members of the group intend to turn and average profit of xof 85'000 (ca us$ 170) each during this loan cycle, djeneba o. intends to reach xof 100'000 (ca us$ 200).

in addition to repaying the loan, the women will use part of the profits to support the daily expenses of their families. they also wish to diversify their business.

loise is an ambitious woman from litein, a region known for its favorable rainfall patterns and fertile soils that favor maize farming. she is very passionate, hardworking, and eager to learn and take on new challenges. these qualities have propelled her to become one of the most respected farmers in her village. she sells milk, poultry, and vegetables produced on her farm.

of all the activities in which she involves herself, dairy farming is closest to her heart. she enjoys waking up every morning to go and milk her cows and feed them with fodder that has a high nutritional value. she is so keen and close with her cows that she has named them. they make her feel very proud and fulfilled.

loise is seeking a loan through kiva's field partner juhudi kilimo to pay school fees for her children. she believes that the knowledge and skills her children will get through school will help them have a brighter future.

ricky is married with 1 child.  he is 31 years old and lives in ibabao, siquijor.  
to earn his living, ricky owns a small retail business.  he has had this business for four years.  each month, he earns approximately php 3,600.00. he has requested a loan of p10,000. ricky has been a member of paglaum multi purpose cooperative for seven months.

in the future, ricky hopes to be more productive with his business.

carolyne is 35 years old, has 4 children, and lives in kodaa village in in ndhiwa, kenya. carolyne works as a subsistence farmer for a living. her community of kodaa village does not have access to clean water. the water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. carolyne is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by her village to help them obtain safe drinking water.

as a volunteer promoter, carolyne represents the community on kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using the chlorine dispenser. carolyne and other promoters in her community need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. carolyne wants to be a promoter because she believes that the chlorine will help them treat there water making it safe for drinking.

the kiva loan will be repaid by evidence action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay kiva lenders and also to make sure that carolyne’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

rustam lives in the town of kulob. he is 30 years old, married and has five children. he has higher education and is a teacher by profession. he does not work in this field. rustam has opened a grocery store where he works as a salesperson. he has been selling for sixteen years. he is taking out the loan to increase commodity circulation.\r\n

day by day increasing expenditures compelled sumaira to start her own business selling animals. she is 27 years old, married, and doing business with the help of her husband (also shown in the photo) for many years. \r\n\r\nher business has provided her family with a decent life. she is a mother of 2 children. she is working very hard, providing her family with the basic necessities of life.\xa0she has requested a murabaha loan of 25,000 pkr. she intends to utilize this loan amount to purchase more baby goats and calves to cater to more customers. she is confident that she can further expand her business with the help of future loans.

in the central market of the city of chinandega, clarial p. dedicates herself to the sale of clothing and sandals sold every day in her stand that is visited by clients that buy her products. at present she is hoping to again take advantage of the loans offered by ceprodel to purchase products that she will offer to continue improving her and her family’s economic situation.

translated from spanish by mariela cedeno, kiva volunteer

the para el futuro de la mujer communal bank gets together every two weeks in la pila, montecristi. this place is well-known both in the province and in the country for its rich traditional culture; one can find a great variety of handicrafts that are made by the locals using the traditional customs. 

this is where luisa lives. she is a 39-year-old married mother of three, ages 16, 14, and 8. the two eldest are in secondary school while the youngest is in elementary school. luisa's husband is a teacher. 

in order to get ahead and make her own money without having to depend on her husband, she is a small business owner. she runs a small general store from home, where she sells all types of provisions and candies that the local tourists crave. she works every day from 6:00 a.m. until 8:00 p.m., and sometimes even later. her children her with the business whenever they can, and she has been quite prosperous because thanks to these loans, she is able to stock up her business more and more. 

she will use this loan to stock up on all types of provisions. she has been with the bank for 15 years, and she likes it because she started her business with a loan. 

her goals are to expand her business and to provide her children with a good education.

josé, age 41, is a tenacious and enterprising farmer.  he went to school through the fifth grade.  he lives with his life partner and his son.  his son is in his first year of high school.  josé works on a farm, and he has been doing this work for over two years.  he learned this work from his father.  when josé was little, his father taught him agricultural work.  now, he is teaching his son how to cultivate the land.

he will use part of the loan to prepare (threshing, chopped grass) and to gather the harvest.  he will use the rest of the loan to repair the house.

in the future he wants his house to be in better condition for his family so that they will be protected.  he wants his son to complete high school so that he can then attend the university.  he wants him to get his degree, and he wants to see him become a complete academic professional.

adan, age 66, was only able to study until the second grade.  he is accompanied by his life companion, who sells shrimp.  he has two children, but they are already living with their companions, in their own homes.  

adan has been raising and selling shrimp for 20 years.  he learned from his father, who taught him this work, and he says that before this, he worked in agriculture.  his work is about 4 blocks' distance from his house, and his work schedule is from 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.

adan is requesting the loan in order to purchase cement, iron, sand, and planks.  this will help him to have a better quality of life for his family.

adan dreams of being able to purchase 7500 meters of land [1.85 acres], in order to leave it to his children as an inheritance, and of being able to improve his house in order to be more secure.

agustina is a married woman with four children. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur. agustina is 52 years old and two of her children are in school.

agustina has a scrap vending business in the philippines. she requested a 9,000 php loan through nwtf to buy more scrap to sell.

agustina has been in this business for 11 years. in the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

heng’s group lives in a rural village in battambang province in cambodia. heng works as a farmer and makes a living cultivating rice to support her family. in her village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help heng safeguard the health of her family, save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

deona ann m. is from barangay salamague, lamut, ifugao. she is 31 years old and is married with two school-aged children. deona ann owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. she has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 4,000 php when she sells a raised animal. in 2008, deona ann joined aski to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. she has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 php from aski. this previous loan was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. deona ann is requesting a new loan of 15,000 php which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. this loan will be her 6th from aski. she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. about aski: aski is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the philippines. it has twenty-one branches covering the central and northeastern areas. its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva. given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

in the city of duran we meet jose, who is a 47 year-old carpenter.  twelve years ago, he decided to put his knowledge to work by opening up his own shop where he could work independently.  carpentry is a family business, because his father was the one who taught him to work with wood and make final products such as beds, dressers, living room sets, and other items.  now it's his turn, and he is working in his shop with his children.  his wife flor has a business selling clothing.  jose tells us that he enjoys the work that he does and he is well known for it.  he says that he is currently having some problems with his vision, and one of the main reasons is the lint that comes out when he is brushing the wood, because he doesn't have the tools he needs for this process.  but he continues ahead in the same way, and he will use this loan to buy wood to process.  his dream is to have a bigger shop with all of the tools that he needs to make his work easier.

renee is 20 years old, married, and has one son. she helps her husband with the family income and would like to start a cattle-fattening business. she has taken a training course from tade on feeding, proper fattening methods, and marketing.

renee is requesting a loan to buy a head of cattle to start her project and sell to butchers and local markets. renee believes the project will help her create a stable source of income for her family.

joel is a happily married man and a father of two children. he lives in eldoret with his family and his wife is a shopkeeper.

joel has a shop which sells general wares. he sells polythene bags, handkerchiefs, sweets and other accessories. he uses his motorbike to transport other goods to his clients, as his wife manages the shop. he is a very hardworking man who fends for his family.

his business has been gaining fame each passing day, and he has been getting many clients seeking his goods and services. he has had a challenge meeting their needs, and this loan will enable him buy more handkerchiefs and polythene bags, among other things, to serve his clients with.

he is a very industrious man who took two loans to start his shop, buy goods, as well as build a home in his village. this is his third loan.

his dream is to educate his children and give them a bright future.

fifty six year old dora is a hardworking woman, devoted to her family, and a great dreamer. since she was very young, her greatest wish was to become a small businesswoman. with effort and discipline she has been able to accomplish it. nowadays, she works in her cafeteria, which she opens every day from seven in the morning to eight in the evening. she works selling all types of deep fried snacks, snacks and beverages. she hopes to make her business be known in her hometown and to establish it as one of the best ones. in order to achieve her dreams, dora is requesting a loan to invest in buying an assortment of foods and ingredients to prepare "empanadas" and pastries in order to broaden her product assortment and be able to satisfy the level of current demand. she hopes to be able to improve her financial situation and her family\'s quality of life.

unice is a married mother of one child who attends school. she lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. school fees are her greatest monthly expense.
\t
for the past three years, unice has operated a clothing business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. she faces the major challenge of stiff competition, but dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future.

with the kes 30,000 loan she is requesting, unice wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

the client lives in guayaquil.  he started his business selling clothes years ago when he became unemployed.  he continued with his sales and gradually attained a regular clientele.  he currently works from 9am until 9pm every day selling pants, blouses, t-shirts, etc.

he has many hopes for his business because he wants to continue working and selling clothes since he now buys clothes at reduced price and resells it at a reasonable price to his customers.  the difficulty he has with his business is his health since he’s pvvs (person living with hiv/aids).  he wants his business to grow which is why he wants to buy more women’s and men’s clothes to sell so that he can have enough capital to have a store of his own.

the person in the photo is juliana. she is 34 years old, married, and blessed with two children. she joined hand in hand eastern africa to benefit from the training in enterprise development and financial management.

she started her own shop from the mobilized resources she had. juliana is borrowing a kiva loan to buy more stock for her shop in order to boost her income.

she is grateful to kiva and their lenders for the support and promises to repay her loan promptly.

cecilia cooks banku to sell, at asebu, near cape coast. she serves her banku with sauce of fried fish and vegetables. cecelia is married and has two children. she uses her income to assist her husband in the general upkeep of their household. cecilia will use her loan to purchase maize for her banku, and fish and vegetables for her sauce. with the new profit, she wishes to establish a stall for the sale of her banku.

mario alberto is 56 years old and has 3 children who are all working adults. he sells food. for more than 16 years he has done this humble work. mario used to sell electrical appliances, but he had many problems because the rent on the shop was very high, and he wasn't earning money, so he decided to establish another type of business, which is what he now has. and this is the reason he is asking for this loan--for working capital to buy basic grains, meat, chicken, vegetables, and fruits for making natural drinks. mario wants to establish a restaurant in his home.

translated from spanish by danielle maxson, kiva volunteer

joel is a married man and has 3 children. he describes himself as honest. he operates a transport business where he transports customers using his motorcycle.

he has been involved in this business for 5 years. his business is located in a good area, and his primary customers are locals.

joel says that his biggest business challenge is inadequate working capital. he will use this kes 100,000 loan to service and maintain his motorcycle.

this is his third loan with smep microfinance bank. previous loans were repaid successfully.

ramita is 34 years old. she is married and has one child, aged 7. many years ago she established her grocery store business. working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she supports her family. she has already received and successfully repaid 4 loans from patan bpw and used her most recent loan to buy grocery goods for her business. in the future, ramita plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. she thanks you for your support. 

in the kathmandu valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy. fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. owners of small grocery stores use kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. by keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. while a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

monique did well in her sales. with the loan she obtained, she added to her inventory of beverages. this enabled her to double her sales. she is again applying for a loan to invest in purchasing new supplies of candies, milk, and rice.

pinnie works hard to support her family. pinnie is married and has a fish vending business in the philippines.

pinnie requested a php 12,000 loan through nwtf to buy more fish to sell on her fish stall.
pinnie has been in this business for 4 years now.

she successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

pinnie would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

rosa is 36 years old and is a resident of the community of el bramadero, teustepe.  she works in agriculture and has a basic level of elementary education.  she is the mother of two children who are 18 and 11 years old. 

she began as a child helping her parents in their work planting.  upon marrying she and her husband dedicated themselves to cultivating basic grains.  with the income obtained she put up merchandise for sale such as clothing.  currently she plants corn and beans and she sells clothing. 

she is requesting the loan to pay for labor and to buy supplies to plant corn and also to buy clothing to sell.  this will allow her to give good maintenance to her crops and stock up for her clothing sales.  her expectation is to give her children a decent roof and to have land to plant and produce more.

vibiana is 63 years old and married with six children. she works very hard to provide for them.

she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 16,000 loan through nwtf to buy items to sell like canned goods, personal care products, etc. to sell.

vibiana has been in this business for six years.

in the future, vibiana would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

sharifaan’s age is 48. she is married and living with her husband and five children in the area of lahore, pakistan. her husband is a welder and provides welding services in his community.

sharifaan owns a small, home business of clothing. she purchases clothes from the market for a low price and sells them at a higher price in her community. the ladies of her town like her garments collection and selection a lot. her family members appreciate her for her efforts.

now that the winter season is going to start, she wants to buy clothes for the winter season to sell. however, she does not have the amount, due to household expenses. she requested a loan so she can buy clothes for the winter season to fulfill the demand.

she wishes for a bright future for her children. her dream is to provide better education to her children.

she is very thankful to kiva and its field partner brac pakistan.

kision is a 32-year-old married man with four children living in kasese, uganda. he has been running a retail shop for four years. his hardships are not having enough money to purchase inventory and encountering price fluctuations and inflation. his personal goal is educating his children, and his business goal is expanding his business into new markets. kision wants money to buy sugar and salt to sell.

marina is a member of the communal bank "las brisas del rio blanco" located in the chipana community, pilcuyo district, del collao province, puno department. she is single, 26 years old and has a son. marina finished grammar school. she has been working with movimiento manuela ramos for three years. she has a business buying and selling cheeses, dried potatoes, corn and other products. her first loan was in the amount of $100 which she used to purchase and sell cheeses in the markets of tacna. marina wants to improve her business and wants to take her cheeses to other markets (cuzco and arequipa). with this loan of $950 she will be able to purchase a greater quantity of cheeses as well as dried potatoes. this will allow her to obtain more income so that she can improve the quality of life in her home. finally, she promises to pay her loan in five monthly payments.

translated from spanish by cindy manzo, kiva volunteer

aurora, 52 and widowed, supports her three children through her bakery business. 

having grown up in a family whose main source of income generation is baking, aurora has sufficient knowledge and experience in managing a bakery. this has been their family's bread and butter, especially when aurora's husband died and left her to take care of the family's needs and their children's education all by herself.

in 2012, aurora became a partner of seed through her sister who invited her to join an orientation seminar. at that time, aurora was in need of additional capital to buy flour for the increased demand on her baked products. she was granted a first loan in seed and was a good paying partner all through out. with her good repayment record, aurora was able to get further loans which has helped her increase also her produce of various bread and baked products. to date, aurora has hired three helpers from her neighborhood for her business. 

today, aurora is taking up another loan to buy materials and pay the labor expense for the repairs of her bakery space. aurora wants to expand her bakery space and make it more presentable for her customers to have a better look on her products. with this, aurora hopes to increase her income more and be able to continuously support her children's needs.

thoy is a 43-year-old woman living in prey chor district, kompong cham province. she is married with three single children, one of whom works for tela company as a driver. thoy devotes her time to her rice farming business, earning an income accordingly and tries hard to support her family. besides rice, she also plants potatoes to sell on her own farmland of about three or four hectares. she has been in the farming business for six years and she enjoys doing this type of business.\r\n\r\nto improve her business, thoy would like to take out a loan of usd 1,000 to pay for the process of planting potatoes this coming season. she hopes that she will obtain a good outcome from her investment and better her living conditions. in the future, she plans to purchase extra land to further expand her business.

evangielyn, 38, is married and has two school-age children. she manages a rice farming business in her village. her husband is also a farmer; he is her partner in growing their rice crops in their field. evangielyn usually earns 15,000 php from her crops.

evangielyn earnings from the business usually cover her children's school fees. at present, evangielyn does not have enough capital to provide farm inputs needed in their field. thus, evangielyn is asking for a loan of 27,000 php to buy seeds and herbicides for plant care. she hopes to gain profits that will financially sustain her children's needs in school.

corazon  is 57 years old and married. she has a tailoring business repairing items and making made-to-order curtains and pillow cases with the help of her husband. she sells assorted homemade cloths to generate additional income. she had a lot of designs and ideas that make her finished products fast-selling.  \r\n\r\ncorazon requested a loan, which she will use to buy fabrics and thread. she is aiming to develop her business and increase her profits.

agustina is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a rice retailing business in the philippines. 

she is borrowing php 10,000 through nwtf to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell. she has been in this business for 4 years, and also earns more income from food vending.

she successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business. agustina has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from nwtf. 

she dreams of building and expanding her business to secure her family's future.

robert is a fifty-six-year-old hardworking man with eight children living in fort portal, uganda. he has been a farmer for the last twenty years, after using savings from his monthly salary. his main hardships are price fluctuations, inflation, seasonal weather, and high fuel and transportation costs. besides that, he has a vision of buying land to grow crops and hiring employees to help expand his business. robert needs a loan to buy maize and pay workers who are weeding the banana plantation.

ghafooran has been making savings for many days to buy a new auto rickshaw for her son, but most of the savings are spent over household expenses. now she wants to buy a new auto rickshaw for him but she does not have enough money to buy it.
 
therefore, ghafooran has requested a loan so that she can buy a new rickshaw for her son with the contribution of savings. she hopes that her son will drive the auto rickshaw with full devotion and earn sufficient income.

ghafooran is a 57-year-old woman, living with her nine children and spouse in the area of lahore, pakistan. she thanks kiva and it's field partner, brac pakistan.

nenita is 59 years old and widowed with two children.

nenita works hard to provide for her family. she has a general store in the philippines and requested a php 18,000 loan through nwtf in order to purchase more stocks of groceries to sell.

nenita has borrowed and paid 11 loans from nwtf before this loan. she has been running the general store for four years.

nenita aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

amina is a divorced woman with one school-going child. she has a house with electricity and piped water. her greatest monthly expenses are food for her family and school fees for her child. 

amina has operated a cafe for the past four years; her potential clients are lorry drivers and her neighbors. she faces a major challenge of competition from other cafe operators. she dreams of establishing a hotel.

amina plans to use this kes 20,000 loan to purchase foodstuffs such as wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking oil and to renovate her cafe. she decided to join yehu because of the easy accessibility of loan facilities and affordable repayment rates.

sikukuu is married with six children who go to school. she owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. 

she operates an open air food business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. she faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.  her dream is to establish a restaurant business in the near future. 

with the loan, she wants to purchase stock of beans,wheat flour, maize flour, charcoal, cooking oil, sugar and rice for her business. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

akouvi d. is 32 years-old. she is married and does not have children. she lives and works in the adidogomé district of lomé, togo selling cell phones and mobile phone accessories. she began this business in 2006 and is requesting her third loan from kiva partner wages. she will use this loan to resupply her stock in order to better serve her customers. by working to keep togo connected, mrs. d.’s business will continue to grow.

rowena is 38 years old and married with three children. with three children in school, rowena works very hard to provide for them.

rowena runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 10000 loan through nwtf to buy additional items to sell like condiments, home product care, personal product care, and other groceries.

rowena has been in this business for 2 years and sells a variety of items such as can goods, coffee, vinegar, soy sauce, condiments and other groceries. 

in the future, rowena would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

maqboolan is 50 years old, married, and blessed with 5 children. her husband drives a rickshaw. now that her children have grown up, one of her sons drives a van. together they contribute to the family income. as their family is big, so are their needs. therefore, they have to work really hard.

her son has been driving this van for many years now. that is why it needs to be repaired. also, his income is affected if his van does not drive smoothly. therefore, maqboolan has requested a loan to help her son pay for the repair expenses. her son will pay off this loan in weekly instalments through his daily income. they are thankful to brac pakistan and to kiva.

maqboolan's son wants to save money to buy another vehicle to rent out and generate more income.

maria is a 57-year-old, independent businesswoman from the capital of the country. she is the mother of four adult children. she started her business after a difficult family situation, the death of her spouse. in the midst of these circumstances, she had to find business opportunities in order to generate income. upon receiving the pension for the death of her spouse, she made some renovations to her home with the goal of offering rental services. she has had success with this initiative, and with the profits, she acquired a drugstore in the town of bosa.

maria hopes to continue progressing in her businesses. for that reason, she is applying for her first loan with fundación mario santo domingo that she will invest in construction materials, such as paint, ceramics, cement, and others, with the goal of improving living conditions for her tenants. support her with her loan.

violet is a 58-year-old woman, residing in rawalpindi, pakistan. she is a mother of four children. one of her sons has been running a general store for the past three years; her son is the only one responsible for fulfilling the needs of his entire family. violet's son wants to purchase different kinds of goods, e.g., rice, sugar, tea bags, milk, and other consumer items for his business purposes. but due to financial constraints he is not in a suitable position to buy all the above products for resale.

therefore violet has applied for a kiva loan from its field partner brac pakistan. this loan will enable her son to buy all these goods and also be helpful for him to earn the maximum profitable income to manage his household and business.

violet is very thankful to kiva and brac pakistan.

these are members of the “hope to god ii” group. they are small-scale business people in the eastern town of kono. with the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and gain better profit.

susan is the leader of this group. susan was born in sowa, a town in easthern sierra leone. she is 31 years old and is married to a business man. they have three children, two in primary school and one in secondary school. susan sells candles, biscuits, sardines, cream and butter and has been in this business for 2 years now.

with the help of this loan, she will buy more supplies in large quantities to add to her inventory.

included on the right of the photo is loan officer edward, posing with the borrowers

vathana is a 22-year-old single student who is pursuing a bachelor’s degree, majoring in civil engineering in his second year at a university in the city. he is from the tbong khmum province in cambodia. his father is a taxi driver and his mother is a rice farmer.

now, vathana is lacking the money to cover his university fees from the second to his fifth years, so he has decided to take out a loan. with this loan, he will have enough money for earning a bachelor’s degree and graduate successfully. after graduation, he is going to find a good job with a decent salary, so he will be able to save money to build his own house.

ana is 41 years old and a hardworking and understanding woman. she lives with her husband eduardo and her four children in playa hermosa, san ramón, in the central peruvian jungle. this hardworking woman sells cheese in the central market of san ramón. a regular vendor, her customers wait anxiously for her arrival at the end of every month because they know how delicious her cheeses are. ana also travels constantly from market to market to sell the various items of clothing that she acquires in the capital at a very low price. due to the success that she has experienced with the sale of her cheese she would now like to enter the market with more dairy products since these are in high demand in the jungle. \r\n\r\nana is an active and responsible member of the community bank “los claveles” (the carnations) and this is her second loan with mfp. ana would like to use her loan to purchase dairy products such as yoghurt. she plans to purchase a variety of yoghurts in different flavours to resell.

cyrose is ambitious, admirable, and a hard worker who wants to triumph. she wants to leave her mark on the world. at 20 years old, she is independent and runs her own mixed farming business. she is very pragmatic and considers herself more hardworking than others. 

cyrose owns a small parcel of land that she uses to grow maize and keep dairy animals. she has also planted trees on it for aesthetic appearance and environmental health. the land provides her with not only capital for her business but also a home for her family. she is blessed with a lovely family! 

cyrose is seeking a loan to purchase cereals. the cereals she is seeking serve to replenish stock for her food and her business. the demand for cereals in the market, only a few kilometers from cyrose's home, is up. farmers in the area are rushing to grow more cereal crops. by placing herself in a position to supply cereal seeds and still be a cereal farmer, she gets to enjoy profits from selling inputs and crop harvests. 

your loan will directly elevate cyrose’s livelihood. she strives to give her family a better life than the tough upbringing she grew up in. kindly loan to her!

khikmatulo is a young and energetic man. he and his family live in the qurgan-tube region. he is just 20 year old but, despite his young years, he has been repairing homes for two years. his cousin taught him this craft.

now khhikmatulo has a decent income from this work. however, he lacks a certain amount to pay for his university tuition. khikmatulo has turned to you for help. he very much hopes that you will support him, and that he will thus be able to continue his education.

gladys is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. she owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. her monthly expenses are food and school fees.

she has operated a retail shop business for the past year, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. she faces a major challenge of competition in her business.

with the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour, and wheat flour. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

kouy, 37, lives in a rural village of kampong cham province's ponhea krek district, cambodia. she is married and has four children. for the last several years, kouy has been farming rice and planting cassava to make a living. to complement that income, she works for others for a fee.
