kouy has already taken out and repaid three loans from kiva's partner visionfund. she has used the past loans wisely and successfully to improve her family's livelihood. after the three loans with visionfund, she now can earn about 20,000 riels (khr) per day to respond to her family's needs and manages to save about 10,000 khr each day for the future needs. 

now she is leading her group of three to ask for a loan. she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizer and pay for plowing the field. she hopes this loan will enable her to get a high yield from her rice paddy and cassava so as to sell it for a good price to make a better living.

meet this energetic, visionary, and enthusiastic woman who resides on the outskirts of nyamira county, in a small village occupied by farmers. her name is cicilia.

cicilia is married and lives with her husband and cute children. she is one of the passionate, small-scale farmers in her region. she loves her family and has embraced farming as a means of satisfying her family’s basic needs. her main focus is on maize and vegetable farming, dairy, and poultry-keeping.

cicilia is not a first-time borrower. you have been supporting her and she has successfully repaid her loans. cicilia is thankful for the continued support you have given her and she feels she’s been making big strides ahead.

this time, cicilia is appealing for a loan to buy a chuff-cutter. she has found it quite tedious to cut fodder for her cows using her machete and she is seeking your support, so that she can purchase a chuff-cutter. this will save her time and effort and, consequently, improve her work. she will use the extra time she saves to attend to other farm chores.

cicilia has promised to continue being faithful to her lenders. help her, so that she’ll keep moving forward.

sabiu is a maize farmer from badamasi village in kaduna state. before he became a babban gona member, sabiu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. with this loan and babban gona’s support, sabiu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. sabiu, like other members of babban gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.\r\n

eng k., 40, is married and resides with her husband and four children in kompong chnang province, cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. k. and her husband sell groceries for an income of usd 12 per day. k. is requesting a loan of usd 1000 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. in the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  this is her first loan from credit, a long-standing kiva partner in cambodia. k. appears in the photograph while she is sitting and selling at her shop.

evaline is a married lady aged 44 years old and blessed with 6 children. she is a tea farmer, and she likes meeting people as she buys and sell to them. she is hardworking and diligent in her work, and she is respected in the tea industry and a prudent business lady. she grows tea and buys more from farmers that she later sells to the tea factory on a good profit margin.

to grow her lucrative business, she is requesting a loan to buy more tea from farmers and increase her supply. she will make good returns and use her profit to repay her loan. her desire is to give good education to her children and see that they get good employment.

mrs. nelly is a member of the la gran amistad communal bank. she lives in the cumbe parish. this area has a cold climate and a beautiful view of nature. the residents are very kind and maintain the culture and traditions of their forefathers. they work in trade, raise animals, or in agriculture. many go to the city of cuenca to work every day.

mrs. nelly is 34, married, and she and her husband have 3 children ages 13, 12 and 8. her two oldest daughters are in high school and the youngest, a son, attends a local elementary school. her husband is a baker. they do not have their own home as they rent.

mrs. nelly works in a store and bakery which is her own property. she has had this business for nine years and works every day of the week from 6:00 am to 10:00 pm.

she has been a member of the communal bank for 7 years and she will invest this new loan in the purchase of flour, butter, eggs, yeast, sugar, salt, etc., for her bakery.

her dream is to have her own house.

jona d. c. is a rice grower. she is 26 years old and has 2 children. she also maintains a vegetable and flower garden in her backyard. she has been a farmer since she married her husband, helbert d. c.. she owns a 9-hectare farm in bunawan, agusan del sur. she uses her harvest to support her family's needs.

she is asking for a loan of php 11,000 from cevi. she will use the loan to buy fertilizer and herbicides. she has been a cevi client for 2 years now. she believes that her loan will bring her a good harvest. the loan will truly help her increase her yield. this also will help her start a new business.

cevi is a non-profit organization that helps people start up and run a business on their own. they teach people to earn a living for their family. they provide credit assistance, training and insurance coverage to help their clients sustain and grow their businesses.

chum s. is 30 years of age and currently lives in the siem reap province of cambodia. chum s. is a local professor who teaches classes for pupils, while her husband is a civil service officer who works in the ministry of interior. this couple has two young children. chum s. finds it hard commuting to work because she has no vehicle for her traveling needs. therefore, she asks for a loan to add to her saving to buy a used motor for riding to her workplace. \r\n\r\n

salvacion is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with nine children.

she runs a charcoal retailing in the philippines and requested a php 14,000 loan through nwtf to buy more stocks of charcoal to sell.

she industriously earns additional income through other business ventures like food vending business.

salvacion dreams that one day, she will be able to save money to expand her business.

francisco s. is a 74 years old man from the village of kinangay sur,clarin,misamis occidental, philippines. francisco is married and has four adult children. to make a living,francisco owns and operates a business venture in the services sector operating transportation services. while not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating passenger motor services in the local community.francisco has been engaged in this business for over 12 years and earns approximately  10,000 php a month for these activities.

francisco joined gdmpc in 2004 to access financial services and engage in business activities, which helps to improve his living situation.francisco has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 from gdmpc. francisco is requesting a new loan of  24,000.00 php, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide his motor services. this will be franciso 13th loan from gdmpc, and he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's living conditions. 

about gdmpc:

gdmpc is one of the most progressive cooperatives in mindanao, philippines. it has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of zamboanga del sur, lanao del norte and misamis occidental. its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva.  given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

greetings from zimbabwe! this is 36-year-old susan from masvingo. she is single with four children, and three are attending school.  susan runs a business selling clothes and shoes. the business has been in operation for eight years. she says her main challenge is the stiff competition. susan has requested a loan of 750 usd to buy clothes for resale. she says the extra income generated as a result of this loan, will allow her to increase her income, hence improving the family’s welfare. in the future, susan plans to open a boutique.

koy’s group lives in a rural village in kandal province in cambodia. koy makes a living cultivating rice and does extra work as tailor and seller to support his family. \r\n\r\nin their village, there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women and men safeguard the health of their families, save money on medical expenses and save the time it takes to collect fuel and boil water.

day by day, increasing expenditures compelled asia to start her own business selling animals. she is 44 years old and is married. she has been doing business with the help of her husband (shown in the photo) for many years. her business has provided her family with a decent life. she is the mother of 4 children and is working very hard to provide her family with the basic necessities of life.\xa0

she has requested a loan of 45,000 pkr. she intends to utilize this loan to purchase more baby goats to cater to more customers. she is confident that she can further expand her business with the help of future loans.

bintihassan is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. she owns a house that has neither electricity, nor piped water.

she has operated a retail shop business for the past six years, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. bintihassan faces a major challenge of competition in her business.

with the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

alice is a smallholder farmer who grows a range of crops to generate income for herself and her two-year-old child. she enjoys farming because for her it is a way to secure the necessities of life. she is seeking a loan to buy modern farm tools to prepare for the coming planting season. when this new season begins, alice will be working longer and harder on her two-acre farm. the tools that kiva lenders finance will be of great importance to her for improving productivity and yields and reducing the time and physical effort it takes to produce her crop.

maría is a member of the “las estrellitas unidas del titicaca” communal bank, located in the pilcuyo district, el collao province, puno department. she is a 45-year-old widow and has 2 independent children. she studied until the fourth grade of elementary school.
for three years she has worked with the movimiento manuela ramos. her first loan was 300 nuevo soles, a loan that expanded her business buying and selling bovine and ovine livestock and pigs.
with this new loan of 2000 nuevos soles, she will purchase a cow and a pig to sell immediately, even though she sometimes fattens animals for three months in order to sell them at a better price. she works alone in her business. her dream is to improve the animals and, above all, to improve her income.
what she likes about her communal bank is the savings and her earnings.

zosima h. is from the village of malugas. she is 66 years old. zosima is married and has 2 adult-aged children. to make a living, zosima owns & operates a business venture in the food sector running a food stall. while not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling rice products in the local community. zosima has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 php a month for these activities.

in 2007, zosima joined pmpc to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. zosima has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 php from pmpc. zosima is requesting a new loan of 7,000 php which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. this loan will be the 5th loan taken out by zosima from pmpc. she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

about pmpc:

paglaum multi-purpose cooperative (pmpc is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern mindanao. it reaches out to the rural poor using the grameen model.

*note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva.  given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

ricardo is a microfinance member of pagluam multi purpose cooperative. he has a piece of agricultural land in tambulig. as a hardworking father of 3 he labors a lot to sufficiently provide the needs of his children. for this cropping season, he availed a loan to purchase fertilizers and chemicals for his farming activities. ricardo wants to see all his children finish their studies.

manuel is 52 years old, married and has two children. as a way of generating income, he has engaged in a variety store business within his community in cavite, philippines for years now. he, together with his wife, works hard to provide for the everyday needs of their family.

in the philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. it is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 phps-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. he earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. his regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. he earns a minimum of 500 php in sales every day.

due to financial insufficiency, manuel wants to make his business more profitable in order to earn a higher income. for this reason, he would like to avail himself of a loan amounting to 11,000 php (philippines pesos) to buy additional grocery items that are needed. he is hoping that he will further improve the business through this financial assistance.

manuel hopes for his business to flourish and dreams for his family to have a well-to-do life. he meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his life and business every week, and this is where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the word of god he studies.

*all cct community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

luzmabel is a 62 year-old married woman with two school-aged children. luzmabel is from cebedo st. ozamis city. luzmabel operates a service-based business, providing transportation services to local community members. luzmabel has been engaged in this business for many year and earns well every month from these activities. in 2010, luzmabel joined gdmpc to gain access to financial services. luzmabel is requesting a new loan of 35,000.00, which will be used to purchase a new set of tires and spare parts in maintenance and repair of her motorcycle. she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve her family's living conditions.

the vista al mar group meets every 15 days in the city of manta.  this city is known for its beautiful beaches that are heavily visited throughout the year.  it is also known for its very diverse cuisine and its many tourist attractions that attract native and foreign tourists.

this is where merlyn, age 23, lives.  she is in a common-law marriage, and they have a four year old son.  this year he starts going to the city kindergarten.  her husband works for the local municipality.

in order to have her own earnings, merlyn sells all types of clothes.  she has display cases at her house where she exhibits her garments.  most of her sales are by order.  she travels to guayaquil to buy what her customers order.  she gives them credit and collects every eight days.  she has had her business for five years, and it allows her to earn something on her own.  this way she feels useful and independent.

she will use this loan to buy pants, shirts, and clothes for women and children.  she has been in the communal bank for four years.  she likes it because the loans help her a lot.  her dream is to have a big place.

justine has been a farmer for a long time and knows what it takes to succeed. he is a hard worker who always says, “i eat from my sweat.” he is based in mokube, a rural village in the rich highlands of kenyenya. he is happily married and has been blessed with two angelic looking children. 

he has been practicing farming for the past five years, and has never looked back. his primary source of income has been milk, eggs and crops. most of the small-holder farmers in mokube village own approximately ¼ acre of land per household, and this has made them work extra hard to fully utilize their farms. he has been able to earn a decent and honest living through milk and egg selling and a personal business. these ventures have enabled him to send his children to school and feed his family. 

justine has planted many trees on his compound and also has napier grass, which has high protein and is used to feed his dairy cow, thereby enhancing his milk-selling profits. because of increased demand, justine is kindly requesting a loan to buy a good quality dairy cow. dairy farming is a very profitable venture, and he wants to take full advantage of the ready market for dairy products. through the loan, justine is sure of satisfying the demand for milk in his area. through increased profits, justine is sure that he will repay the loan on time and also be in a position to comfortably take care of his family. 

justine, with his entrepreneurial spirit, strength and tenacity, would like to continue fighting so that he can achieve his dream of owning his own business and empowering society by being a source of employment. juhudi kilimo, through its training, has helped justine save more effectively, and through his accumulated profits, he plans to add value to his milk through packaging. he also hopes to one day start manufacturing milk products such as yoghurt and cream.

mirley is a single 32-year-old woman who makes a living selling clothing. she started this business out of economic necessity. through it, she hopes to move forward and change a reality, a time when a lack of resources caused her to experience hardships. she is seeking to change that situation through honest work.

she is requesting a loan to stock up on men's and women's clothing and accessories. she is seeking to improve her sales, obtain more resources, and fulfill her dreams, but especially, to give an exemplary life and a good educational foundation to her 10-year-old son.

if you want to know more about the entrepreneurs and the loans from interactuar, you can join the lending team called: “friends of interactuar colombia”: http://www.kiva.org/team/interactuar_colombia

sara is requesting a loan to buy supplies for her business such as rice, greens, beans, corn, drinks, vegetables, meat and other items in order to keep her business well supplied as she serves breakfasts, lunches, and dinners. sara hopes that her children finish school so that she will feel fulfilled as a mother.

srey chim (in the photo) is a garment worker, while her husband, chanthy is a fisherman who also raises pigs at home.  they live in a village about 20 kilometers from phnom penh city and they have one daughter who is in school. 

srey chim wants to stop working as a garment worker and start her own tailoring business.  she will have more time to take care of her house.  so, she is asking for a loan in the amount of $1,000 to buy a sewing machine and fabrics.

wilfredo is a member of the proyección village bank. he is 40 years old and is the single father of a seven-year-old boy. he has been working as a photographer for 20 years and now works independently at different events in the city of ayacucho, peru. most of his business consists of taking photos and filming weddings, baptisms, quinceañeras and bachelor parties. these celebrations are mainly on the weekends, and on a good weekend he earns between 300 and 400 soles.  

wilfredo is requesting a loan of 2000 soles (us$650) to buy a new video camera, since the equipment he currently uses is old and outdated. he will add this loan to his savings to buy the camera (which costs more than 2000 soles).

wilfredo has been working with finca for the past two years, and has been a very reliable client. he says finca helps him pay for his son’s education, for which he is grateful. his dream for the future is to buy a home for himself and his son.

khloak d., 30, is a married woman and mother. she retails both new and used clothes that she orders in bulk from wherever they are sold at a reasonable price. she was busy selling her clothes at the market when the photo was taken, so her husband is pictured instead.

khloak d. is married to koy sarim, age 30, who is a motor taxi driver. they have two minor children who are not enrolled in school. 

khloak d. conducts her investment very smoothly. she has a lot of regular customers who need to buy her clothes because she is skilled in public relations and is very satisfied person.

khloak d. faces a problem with transporting her clothes to the market because she has no vehicle. because of that, she decided to request her second loan to purchase a new motorbike which she will use as transportation. with the remainder of the loan she will buy more clothes to sell.

violence, a 50-year-old business lady, is married to john, a businessman, and they are blessed with five children. violence has been a tailor for the past two years, earning a monthly income of kes 20,000 which she uses to support her family.

\r\n\r\nhaving repaid her previous loan, violence is requesting her second one from kadet to buy cloth materials and a sewing machine. she will put the anticipated additional profits toward the education of her children, and in the future hopes to buy a piece of land and build rental houses.

vuon is 28 years old and married with one child. she lives with her family in the moung russey district of battambang province. for the past five years, vuon has worked as a rice and sesame farmer and is able to earn up to 23,600 khr per day. she has repaid a previous loan with the kiva partner visionfund and keeps gradually improving her living standards. 

vuon is the leader of a three-woman group requesting a 3,400,000 khr loan. she will use her portion of the loan to buy seed and potash, and to pay plowing fees for the upcoming planting season. vuon hopes to harvest her crop in a timely manner and earn a good yield and income so that she can set aside some money to build a new house for her family.

a group of neighbors and friends formed the “patrón san jerónimo ii” communal bank in the city of cusco in cusco province and department of cusco.  this communal bank is composed of people who seek at all times opportunities to get ahead and with their daily efforts provide a better future for their children.  the economic activities of the members are for example: food sales, snack sales, grocery sales, beauty products sales; some work as teachers, public employees and others provide medical services, tourism services and transportation services.

(adela is raising her hand in the picture.)  adela was born in the city of cusco and still lives where she was born.  she’s currently 60 years old and her main economic activity is selling anticuchos [grilled skewered meat] from place to place.  she works from 3pm until 8pm monday through saturday.  
she’s been in this business for 30 years and does very well thanks to the effort she puts into it.  on this occasion, adela needs the loan to buy ingredients like meat, chicken, sausage, oil, potato, dehydrated potato and other things.  adela’s dream is to open a locale where she can sell her anticuchos.
 
the members in general are grateful for the opportunity provided and commit to make their various installment payments in the established time frame.  (the members who appear at the bottom of the photo asked the governing board permission to be absent from the meeting.)

cusco is located in cusco district and province belonging to cusco department in the very heart of the ancient city of the incas.  it’s noted for being a very tourist-oriented zone because of its archaeological sites, for its historic city center, for its scenery and for its history; it is an enchanting city in the country’s southern region.  cusco is known as a very tourist-oriented, commercial zone, for its traditional inti raymi festival and because one of the seven wonders of the world, machupicchu, is located there.

evelyn is a married woman with four children. she is 50 years old and one of her children is in school. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

she has a food vending business in the philippines and has been in this business for 6 years.

evelyn requested a php 11,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy ingredients and raw products for her business.

 in the future, she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

holger is 50-years old, married and lives with his wife and their children in the city of chimbo, bolivar province.

holger works in agriculture.  he grows corn on land that is nearby his house.  he is requesting the loan to purchase seeds, compost, and fertilizer for his crops.  the loan will help him to get the things he needs for his crops.  the challenges he faces are variations in the weather and crop disease. 

holger's dream is to have enough money to take a trip on a plane.  in his free time, he likes to walk through the country-side and reminisce about his childhood.

lourdes is married with five children. she is 33 years old and lives in san carlos, tukuran. for five years lourdes has farmed rice. each month, she earns 10,000 php. she has requested a loan of 10,000 php to purchase fertilizer and seedlings for the next crop. recently, lourdes joined gdmpc. in the future, she wants to make improvements on her house and improve the general living conditions of her family.\r\n

lilian is a 29 years old, married and hard working lady who operates a tailoring shop. she is a mother of three children aged seven, three and one respectively.

she learnt about kadet from posters distributed in her area of work. she has acquired her first loan of kes 20000 which will facilitate her in the purchase of fabrics for dress making. she will use the proceeds to expand to dealing with cultural outfit in the quest of expanding the business.

she hopes to attain financial stability.

noor raises goats. she is able to benefit from selling their wool and milk. she sells the wool and makes cheese from the milk. she does everything to see her children become good people. she is in need of a loan to buy food for the goats.

caroline lives in likoni area of coast province, kenya. she is married and has one school-going child. she owns a grocery shop, a business which has been running for two years. in the business, she sells foodstuffs, household goods etc. she also runs a transport business, owning a motor cycle.

she learnt about milango through friends who invited her to the group and she joined with the aim of accessing credit to improve her business operations. her main challenges are inflation and bad debts. 

caroline is applying for a loan of 21,050 kenya shillings to buy a stock of groceries including maize, beans, rice and cooking fat. the extra income from the loan will be added to her savings to improve on the living standards of her family and pay school fees for her child. she aspires to open a mini-wholesale shop.

miss. phalla p., age 26, is single and lives with her father and her sisters who are a garment factory workers. the family lives in a small village across mekong river about 20 kilometers from phnom penh, the capital city of cambodia.

phalla has been a silk weaver for five years. she sells her finished products to the middle man in the village, who then takes it to sell in phnom penh. phalla is requesting a loan of 550 to purchase silk material for her weaving business and to buy rice for food.

this group is called al-hadil and consists of four members. they live in hodeidah, yemen. they are working hard so that they can achieve their goals. 

khadra is 37 years old and is the leader of the group. she sells sweets and ice cream. she has been doing this for 13 years. she says that she began this business when she felt her husband wasn't able to cover all the expenses of his family. she is hardworking, and through effort and dedication, has managed to overcome adversity and get ahead. 

she is asking for a loan of 70,000 yer (yemeni rials) from amb to buy sweets and ice cream in order to be able to continue her business. she is working toward increasing her income.

parbati is a 41-year-old woman. many years ago, she established her tailoring business. working six days a week and eight hours a day, she supports her family. she has already received, and successfully repaid, four loans from patan bpw. she used her most recent loan to buy raw materials for her business. in the future, she plans to uplift the economic conditions of her family. she thanks you for your support.

juanita is 58 years old and has eight children, four of whom are in school. juanita is in the agricultural business, raising pigs, in the philippines. juanita requested a php 5,000 loan through nwtf to buy feed, vitamins and other supplies to raise her livestock. juanita has been in this business for 10 years now and has borrowed 1 time in the past from nwtf to sustain it.

in the future, juanita would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

luz went to school up to the seventh grade. she is in a relationship, and her husband works as a policeman. her child is small and doesn’t yet go to school. luz works selling enchiladas and corn pastries in the area. she now has several years performing this work, and she learned it from her mother. previously, luz dedicated herself strictly to the domestic chores.

she needs the loan to purchase corn, potatoes, oil, and condiments among other ingredients for selling enchiladas and corn pastries. luz has always dreamed of opening a food stall in front of a school so that the students could buy her products.

alma is an enterprising woman of 59 years. she is single and has two children. her business is selling furniture and handicrafts. she has been selling her products in managua for 30 years. she has belonged to adim for 4 years. the loan alma is requesting will be used to buy inventory like shelves, hammocks, chairs, corner cabinets etc.

as a married parent of two children, liezel works hard to support her family.

she has a fish vending business in the philippines, and also earns additional income from buy and sell dried fish. liezel is borrowing php 28000 through nwtf to buy additional boxes of  fish to sell for her fish vending business.

she successfully paid back her previous loan, and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business.

liezel has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

saeeda is a 46-year-old woman living in rawalpindi, pakistan with her five children. her husband is responsible to fulfill the needs of the family. saeeda is also providing sewing services and earns income to contribute with her husband to manage the household.

she needs different kinds of goods such as needles, threads, pieces of cloth, machine oil, etc. for her business purposes, but due to insufficient financial means she is unable to purchase these accessories. therefore she has applied for a kiva loan from its field partner brac pakistan. this loan will enable her to purchase these accessories and also help her to increase her monthly sales and profit by providing better sewing services. saeeda is very thankful to kiva and brac pakistan.

merlina is a hardworking woman, running a sari-sari or variety store selling various goods to the people in her place. through this business, she is able to provide the basic needs of the family like food and others. merlina is asking for a loan to buy more stocks to sell like canned goods, noodles, rice, soda, chips and snack foods among others. merlina is optimistic that this loan could help her improve her income and profit.

as a widowed parent of two children, maxima works hard to support her family.

she has a food vending business in the philippines, and also earns additional income from her general store. maxima is borrowing php 8,000 through nwtf to buy ingredients such as vegetables, fish, meat, and other supplies needed for her food vending business.

maxima has been sustaining her business activities through her past one loan from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

lolita has a wide experience in farming. she has mastered banana farming activities from growing, caring, harvesting and earning income as well. lolita has supported her husband doing this type of work.  as a farmer, lolita has nurtured her membership with pmpc and has maintained a good repayment record. she knows she can always turn to the cooperative for her financial needs. recently, she applied for a loan to purchase fertilizers to have good results in healthier, heavier, and potentially higher-yielding harvest.  someday, lolita hopes to purchase more banana land to cultivate that will potentially add income for the family. \r\n

voeung s., 45, has been an internal staff at a cambodian port for more than four years and currently gets a salary of $160 per month. her husband works with her at the same location. (voeung s. was not available at that time, so her husband is in the picture instead.) she has two teenage children who go to school. since the family's current income is not adequate to meet their need, mrs. voeung s. wants to generate extra income by investing as a grocery seller.  however, she does not yet have money yet to start the new business. therefore, she would like to seek a loan of $1200 which she will build a grocery store and then buy a larger quantity of grocery inventory to begin selling.

the members of group jolidenw are married women having an average age of 33 years and 3 children. they live in big traditional family homes with their husbands and children. they reside in the village of marka counko within the fana prefecture, koulikoro region of the republic of mali. they know each other through family ties and neighborhood relationship. they have been in the business of buying and selling of food ingredients and catering for a little longer. these women work with soro yiriwaso microfinance institution with the aim to making durable their lucrative businesses. they are on their eleventh group loan and all preceding loans have been repaid correctly. with this loan, they expect to buy large quantity of food ingredients and rice for the catering business. the ingredients are bought in bulk in bamako and resold in bits right in marka coumbo and a part is used in catering to serve passengers, comprised of male and female.they expect to make an average monthly profit of 25 000fcfa each. on one hand, the profits are reinvested in the business and in the daily family expenses , on the other hand.

translated from french by cletus kuunifaa, kiva volunteer

jepta is a resident of and a farmer in the rural area of kitale in western kenya. he is aged 45 and has been in farming for five years, with his farm producing and selling milk and eggs to the local market. he works as a tailor as well. he is married with two children aged three and two.

jepta has requested a loan of kes 31,200 from juhudi kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. he says farming has been the main source of income for his family's upkeep and the acquisition of a dairy cow will provide his family with milk for family consumption and sale to provide for other basic needs.

he too concurs with many other farmers that the high cost of treatments for animals remains the daunting challenge.

josphine is married and has been blessed with four children. she owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. she cites paying for food and school fees as her major challenges.

josphine has operated a vegetable and fruit-selling business in which she sells retail to her neighbors and town-dwellers. she faces a major business challenge of the bulkiness of her goods and, hence, the high cost of transportation. 

with the kes 20,000 loan, josphine wants to purchase sacks of vegetables, tomatoes, onions, and fruits for resale. she decided to join yehu microfinance trust to access loans, to boost her business.

from a little bit of heaven, my nicaragua has grown, which is why this land is beautiful, the land where i was born*

the town of el sauce belongs to this small land and it is where yader lives.  yader is a 32-year-old man who earns a living working as an elementary school teacher in a neighboring region.  in order to improve himself, he is studying for a teacher training degree on weekends so that he will have his degree and therefore a better quality of life.

owing to the low salaries that are paid in our country, many people are unable to fulfill their dreams of training to become a professional, doing the same for their children and managing to own a decent home.  however, there are also tenacious people who seek a way to achieve their goals.  this is the case for yader who has requested a loan to pay his university fees so that he won't face any obstacles in obtaining his teaching degree.

yader is grateful to kiva and ceprodel for the support they have given him through these loans which help him to solve personal problems which, owing to the low salaries in our country, he would otherwise be unable to solve.

*(line from a well-known nicaraguan song)

sharbaat is 52 years old, married and has three married daughters and one married son who works as a teacher. she has another daughter living with her who has suffered from a mental disability since birth.

sharbaat has a small poultry business and dreams to afford good living conditions for her daughter.

she is requesting this loan to buy more chickens to expand her business and increase her income for the family.

the mira credit group is made up of seven women who live in the outskirts of the zhidama parish in the gualaceo region.  this region has a moderate climate well-suited to cultivating various types of fruit trees.  it also has a number of places where you can enjoy nature.  its people are very capable and it is where they make the best footwear in the entire country.  the main source of income in the area is trade, animal husbandry, and agriculture.

one of the group members is rosa.  she joined the group two years ago.  she likes this type of credit group because she can share good times with her group mates.  they help each other in times of difficulty and share their joys in the good times.

rosa is 37 years old.  she is married and from her marriage has four children, ages 10, 14, 16, and 21.  her oldest child is working and helps her out financially.  two of her children are studying in secondary school, while the youngest is in the local elementary school.  her husband works as a day laborer.  the house that they live in is their own.

doña rosa works in the fields.  she raises chickens, guinea pigs, pigs, and cattle, from which she sells the milk.  she also gardens, and her harvest is both to sell and to eat in their home.  she also works making guaipe (cleaning rags).  

the money from this loan is to buy cattle and feed for her animals.  her goal is to increase her animal-raising business.

gina is 46 years old and has one child. gina is married and her child is in school.

gina is in the agricultural business raising pigs in the philippines. gina requested a php 10000 loan through nwtf to buy feeds, vitamins, and other supplies to raise her livestock.

gina has been in this business for 4 years now, and has borrowed 4 times in the past from nwtf to sustain it.

in the future, gina would like to save money to expand her business.

meet fatmata.  she is a late-forties-old from the waterloo eastern area in freetown. she is married, with seven children.  

in 2007, fatmata established her charcoal business. she began her business because she wanted to empower herself. she works at the business from 8 a.m. until 7 p.m., 7 days per week. she says the main challenge to her business is insufficient capital to expand.

fatmata requires a loan in order to purchase bags of charcoal to expand her business. she hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her welfare and increase her business. 

in the future, fatmata plans to open a food stand table. she thanks you for your support.

felicité is 34 years old. she has had a stand in the city's grand market for a dozen years. she sells vegetables with her husband. together they manage to meet the family's needs and educate their five children,

félicité joined vahatra to have more financial capital. thus she was able to increase and diversify her vegetable for sale. lately she has been able to ensure the children's educational fees. with this loan she will buy 200 kg of potatoes and 150 kg of tomatoes.

félicité dreams of constructing a house for her family.

epifania is a 59-year-old married woman with four children. her youngest child is 21 and still goes to school.\r\n\r\nepifania runs a fishing business in bien unido, bohol. she earns about 6,000 php per month doing this fishing. this enables to help buy their household needs. epifania works hard to sustain her child's education. she requested a loan to purchase crab traps, nylon and lead weights for fishing. she hopes that someday her family will have a better quality of life.

rubelyn has been a personal collection dealer for almost a year. she is married and has one dependent. her husband earns a living by being a driver.

she earns a living by selling various personal care items ranging from soap, lotion, toothpaste, to house hold items like powdered soap, insect repellent, toilet bowl cleaner and many other items.

as of now, rubelyn is asking for a loan to buy supplies like soap, cologne, toothpaste and lotion. with this, she will be able to sell more items to her customers. in the future, she hopes to make her business a success. moreover, rubelyn wants to save money for her child's schooling.

juliet is a 50-year-old woman who is married and has three children who are now adult. she and her family live a simple life in san dionisio, iloilo. thus, they earn a living through running a family farm, where they grow rice and corn plants.

a few years ago, juliet dreamed of having a water connection, as this would make a difference for her in doing her daily household chores.

she has now applied for a 9,000 php loan through kiva's field partner cevi to buy the needed materials; and that would include pvc pipe, solvent, teflon tape, pvc elbow and other needed items. the rest of the loan will be used to pay for labor.

indeed, this loan could definitely make her dream come true.

salone microfinance trust (smt), a partner of kiva.org based in makeni in northern sierra leone, is very pleased to introduce to you this group of teachers from the eastern city of koidu. they have requested a loan of 24,000,000 sll from smt/kiva lenders in order to solve their immediate financial needs. at the end of each month, they will make payments using their monthly salaries to repay the loan. their school’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the payments and will repay smt/kiva lender on their behalf. 

andrew is the leader of this group of teachers. born in a place called ngardorhun, in eastern sierra leone, andrew, aged 48, has been in the teaching profession for 26 years. he is married and has five children – two in primary school, three in secondary school. andrew has applied for this loan in order to buy construction materials: corrugated iron, cement, etc. to build a house for his family. he will also use part of the loan to pay his children's school fees.

delia works hard to support her family. on november 8, 2013, her business and home were wiped out by super typhoon haiyan.

she has restarted her business and is now requesting a php 10,000 housing loan through nwtf to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor so she could build a house for her family.

with your help delia will be able to rebuild her devastated life sooner.

in the future, delia would like to save enough so she could afford to send her children to school.

rodolfo p. is from the village of sinait. he is 61 years old. rodolfo is married and has 5 adult children. to make a living, rodolfo owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. while not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. rodolfo has been engaged in his business for over 36 years and earns approximately 40,000 php per harvest.

in 2010, rodolfo joined aski to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. rodolfo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 php from aski. this previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. rodolfo is requesting a new loan of 13,000 php which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. this will be the 2nd loan taken out by rodolfo from aski. he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

about aski:

aski is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the philippines. it has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva.  given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

the members belong to the communal bank “apu llallahuani de kallacancha” located in the district and province of paucartambo of the cusco region.

the member dolores is 53 years old, has 3 children and a life partner. she alternates her daily activities with farming. she is a responsible person who hopes to obtain more profits with her business in order to continue supporting her family.

she also works raising small animals. she has had her business for quite a while and it has gone well thanks to the effort that she puts every day. with this business she’s able to get her family ahead.

the member is requesting a loan to buy seeds, fertilizers and other products.

all the members are thankful and happy with the loan that kiva lenders give them.

daniel is 55 years old, married, and lives in the village of upper bayao, tukuran, zamboanga del sur. he is married and has three children, all of whom are already married and live in different houses. daniel has been a farmer since his younger days; he has been working on the farm for 31 years. his income is derived from this livelihood.

daniel joined gdmpc in 2013 to avail a loan. now his loan request is twenty thousand pesos only (php 20,000) to purchase seeds and fertilizer for rice production.

he plans to renovate his house.

jeruto is a married woman with two children. she operates a retail business where she sells clothes and shoes. she has been involved in this business for two years. her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. she describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital.

she will use the 15,000 kes loan to buy more stock of clothes and shoes.

anaam is a 47-year-old married lady. her husband is an electrician. they have three daughters and a son.

with her smile, anaam welcomes her customers at home to buy the clothes and underwear she sells. 

now anaam wants to increase the quantity of clothes she has, and for that she has applied for this loan.

khut c., age 37, is married and resides with her husband and five children in takeo province, cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. she weaves cambodian traditional silk for an income of usd 3 per day. her husband is a teacher at a local high school, earning an income of usd 3 per day. c. is requesting a loan of usd 1200 to purchase a mechanical plow to help plow the rice field. she will use any additional profit to support the education of her children.  this is her first loan from credit, a long-standing kiva partner in cambodia.

larlita is a married woman, 38 years old, with two children. she is a very hard-working entrepreneur.

larlita has a fishing business in the philippines. she requested a php 10,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy additional fishing nets, gasoline for her boat, and pay for maintenance for her business.

larlita has been in this business for three years. she would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

vat t., 45, is married and resides with her husband and two children in kampong chnang province, cambodia, an area known for palm products. t. is a farmer, earning an income of usd 1.50 per day. her husband is employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of usd 3.50 per day.  t. is requesting a loan of usd 800 to purchase a motorbike for the family's use. in the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. this is her first loan from credit, a long-standing kiva partner in cambodia. t. appears in the photograph with her family.

jackline is aged forty and has been in farming for ten years. she currently employs one farmhand, and her farm produces milk. she also runs an agro-veterinary business. 

jackline has requested a loan of 60,000 kes from juhudi kilimo to improve her agrovet business. she says the agrovet business will lower her costs of dairy treatment and improve her income allowing her to give her family better living standards.

jackline is glad her life will be better with access to juhudi kilimo.

desak wiartni recently follows her child's footstep to obtain a loan from dinari foundation. in her first loan, desak wiartni obtained a loan for rp 2,000,000 (translator’s note: 1 us$ fluctuates between rp8,000-9,500.00) that she used to expand her pig farming business. since she only owned a mother pig, desak wiartni bought 4 more piglets for a total price of rp 1,000,000 for fattening. during a 6 month period, usually she could harvest 2 times. feed expenses for 3 months are rp 300,000. profit are about rp 1,0000,000 for 3 months. she hopes for the future that her pig farming business could expand larger, and could increase profit so that her family's living standard could increase.

translated from bahasa indonesia by gwan liong ang, kiva volunteer.

desak wiartni baru mengikuti jejak anaknya yang sudah bergabung mendapat pinjaman dari yayasan dinari. untuk pinjaman pertama ini desak wiratni memperoleh pinjaman sebesar rp. 2.000.000,- yang dipergunakan untuk mengembangkan usaha ternak babinya.berhubung sudah mempunyai satu induk desak wiratni membeli lagi 4 ekor bibit babi dengan total harga rp.1.000.000,- untuk dipelihara secara penggemukan. dalam 1 periode selama 6 bulan biasanya dapat memanen sebanyak dua kali. biaya pengeluaran selama tiga bulan untuk membeli pakan sebesar rp.300.000,-.keuntungan sebesar rp. 1.000.000,- dapat diperoleh selama tiga bulan.harapan untuk kedepannya dari usaha ternak babinya dapat berkembang lebih besar lagi dan mendapat keuntungan lebih meningkat sehingga taraf hidup keluarganya menjadi lebih baik.

liza, from aurora, zamboanga del sur, is 33 years old, married, and has two children. to make a living, she has been planting and harvesting rice for sale for four years, earning 15,000 php a month.

\r\n\r\nin 2011, liza joined gdmpc and is now requesting a loan of 35,000 php to purchase fertilizers and seedlings for her next crop. she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

judy is 45 years old. she is married and has three dependent children. she lives in a town of balasan, iloilo, philippines with her family. she helps her husband run their farm to earn a living. they have been involved in this livelihood for many years. during these years, having insufficient capital to run this business has been their main problem. 

because of this, she and her husband need an amount to buy rice seed. the rest of her requested amount is to buy medicine and fertilizer in order to enhance the growth of their plants and have a bountiful harvest. judy wants to be successful in life; thus, she wants their business to succeed as well.

antonia runs a sari-sari (variety) store, and caters it to local inhabitants in her community. she sells basic commodities like sugar, cooking oil, eggs, assorted canned goods, firewood and toiletries. she is married and has one dependent. aside from running a sari-sari (variety) store, she also engages in food vending.

she would like to boost both her sources of income. that is why she decided to join kiva and requested a loan in the amount of 6,000 php which was used to buy additional supplies like canned goods, noodles and soft drinks.

she is grateful to cevi and kiva for the continued support and she is more determined to work hard for the welfare of her family.

maría is 53 years old. she is a humble woman of good principles. she didn't go to school because the closest school was 8 kilometers from her house, and there was no transportation. currently she is married and has 7 children. only one daughter lives with them. the rest are married and live elsewhere.

maría works taking care of the home. in order to care for their children, she supports her husband in his agricultural work, which is their source of income. her husband also uses his car to make income to support his family. maría needs the loan to repair the vehicle with which her husband works, because it is a source of income for them, and doesn't work. maría's wish is to continue supporting her husband so that they can keep working together, in order to move their family forward and to be able to give them a better quality of life.

rose is engaged in hog raising business in the village of addalam jones, isabela. she is married to antonio jr. who is a farmer. she would like to maintain her hog raising business by providing enough supply of feeds for her hogs.  for this, she is borrowing php4,000 as additional capital to pursue her plans. 

rosie and antonio jr. have two children who are still studying. the eldest is john anthony-14 years old and rex-13 years old. rosie hopes that her two children could finish their schooling. the couple hopes for the support of the kiva lenders to their business

felicia is a 47-year-old hardworking married woman with two children. due to her experience and background, felicia was nominated as the group leader for unity group.

felicia has owned and operated a general retail business for the past 3 years. like many of those in the group, her business is well organized and requires that she work from 6am to 7pm every day. despite the long days, felicia is determined to operate a successful business in order to provide a better life for her family.

she has requested a loan from kiva through id ghana in order to buy ingredients for the production of foods to sell.

with the profits from this loan, she will be able to reinvest in her business, pay school fees for her children, and save for her future.

fishing has been a good business for most people in carles, iloilo in the philippines. this includes lydia, who is a resident of this place. lydia is 54 years old, married, and has 4 children. 3 of her children are already grown, and her youngest is 16 years old. 

for 30 years now, lydia has been engaged in fishing and catching crabs to provide for her children. she is asking for a loan to continue improving her livelihood. lydia will use the loan to buy fishing nets, nylon, rope, and fishing weights. 

lydia finds joy in fishing and helping her husband, who is also a fisherman. in the future, she hopes to have enough savings, be more successful in business, and live a life of abundance.

sakda is 22 years old, a homemaker with a two-year-old child living in the siem reap province of cambodia. her husband is 25 and has been a a construction worker since 2008, earning approximately $7 daily. her husband always goes to work far from home, so she decided to request a loan to buy a motorcycle for her husband to commute to work. this loan will help her husband reduce his traveling expenses. for more future plans in her family, she wants to have a business selling vegetables and fish at the market, have a new house and help her child to finish high school.\r\n

linda is 36 years old and lives in dampalan, la libertad. she is married with 4 children.
linda has a shop that sells vegetables. she has had this business for almost a year. she has requested a loan to purchase assorted vegetables to sell.
linda has been a member of pmpc for almost 2 years.

ms. madjiguene is a 46-year-old married woman.\xa0 she lives in the ngaparou district in yoff.\xa0 she has been a member of the lending group u-imcec since june 2000 and has already benefited from three previous loans.\xa0 madjiguene has four children ranging from 7 to 25 years of age.\xa0 she has been active for thirteen years in the commerce of clothing, shoes, bed sheets, and televisions.\xa0 at the same time, she sells juice and cream.\xa0 she chose this work through her grandmother, who influenced her a lot.\xa0 \r\n\r\nthe most interesting thing to madjiguene is the profits that this business provides. she's requesting a loan of 150,000 francs for buying thioub (a type of dyed cloth).\xa0 her goal is to diversify her merchandise, to increase her profits, and to improve her family's situation.

translated from french by dan kuey, kiva volunteer

marie is 33 years old and married with five children between the ages of 4 and 14. marie makes a living by selling a variety of goods in her shop. these goods include soap, sugar, cooking oil, etc. she has been in this business for about two years. the hours of her business are from 8 am to 7 pm every day.\r\n\r\nmarie needs to request a kiva loan via vision finance company to allow her to start investing in the sale of more foodstuffs (rice, beans, wheat, peas, cassava, sugar, etc.) with the sale of these foodstuffs, marie will hopefully earn more profit which will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability and to start saving for the future of her family as well as her business.

gabriel is a 30-year-old. his life has been marked by limitations and the few opportunities that life has given him. he could not access education due to financial problems at home, so decided to start his own business and set up a shop selling basic household goods. since then, he is the one who pays the household expenses where he lives with his mother.\n\nhe wants his business to be able to offer him a good future and a better quality of life. for this reason he wants a loan that he will invest in the purchase of supplies to increase his volume of sales in the area and improve his family's living conditions.

gulshan is 48 and the mother of four sons and one daughter, living with her spouse and children in the area of rawalpindi, pakistan. her husband is a green grocer by profession and he has been selling fresh fruits at a shop in a nearby town for many years. her husband offers seasonal and fresh fruits to his customers. he has been feeding his family through the generated income from this fruit shop. nowadays, the needs of his family have increased and he does not have other resources to cope with these needs. therefore, he decided to expand his current business. he wants to increase his stock on a daily basis so that he can maximize sales of the fruits. therefore, his wife, gulshan, requested a loan from kiva’s field partner, brac pakistan, so that her husband can buy more fresh seasonal fruits. gulshan thanks kiva and it's field partner, brac pakistan.

santos is 25 years old and his parents supported him in his studies with great effort up until the ninth grade. he is married and his partner has a store in their home. he has two children who are in school and he lives with his wife and two children.

santos works in agriculture, specifically growing coffee, beans, and corn. this job allows him to obtain food for his family. likewise, they have their own business which is the store. santos needs a loan to buy products such as rice, sugar, beans, bread, and drinks, among other products, to satisfy the needs of his customers and therefore offer them better service.

santos dreams of having a bigger business which would provide him with a greater income in order to meet the needs of his family and provide his children with a better quality of life.

julius is a single father of four children and they reside in hoima, uganda. he operates a business selling plastics and home utensils like plates, cups, basins, baskets, trays and so much more and this is his 10th year in this business. he has the responsibility of paying school fees for his children as well as looking after them. he says it is not easy for him to raise children as a single parent and this affects his business growth. he is also challenged by bad debtors as well as limited capital to expand.

julius is requesting a loan to buy more cups, plates, brooms and basins to sell.

peace is 21 years old and lives in the town of njeru, in the njeru region of uganda. for the past year, peace has been working hard to manage her clothing boutique, which sells new ladies clothes.

to help expand her business, peace has requested a loan of 600,000 ugx from brac uganda. the loan will be used to purchase more fashionable dresses to meet demand. and will help peace to generate greater profits, improve her standard of living and also be in position to afford necessities, like sanitary wear. peace hopes that in the future, she will be able to establish a large self-sustaining salon.

peace is a member of brac's empowerment and livelihood for adolescents (ela) program. in addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

simion, 55 years old, supports a family of six members.

he has been practicing tea farming for the last 15 years and earns kes 15,000 per month. he has applied for his first loan of kes 25,000 from visionfund kenya to improve his farming through modern farming to increase production for more income gain.

he plans to use the anticipated profits to expand his farming and to educate his children.

his future hopes and dreams are to be financially stable.

gemma is thirty-one years old and married with three children, two of whom are in school.

gemma is a very hard-working entrepreneur. she has a fishing business in the philippines. she has been in this business for three years.

gemma requested a 6,000 php loan through nwtf to buy fishing nets and other fishing supplies.

in the future, gemma would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

i am farhat and i’m a 44-year-old married woman. i am a citizen of kot radha kishan, which is 24 km from kasur, pakistan. i am an uneducated woman, but i do not hesitate to mention it. but i’ll mention that education is very essential for growing up in life. my husband is also not an educated person. he is a milk-seller with 5 years of experience.

i am the mother of five children: two sons and three daughters. my eldest son manufactures cloth on a power loom machine. my younger son runs a grocery shop. my eldest daughter makes thread and sells it in the market. the other two are getting education in a local school near the house. i help my elder daughter make thread. we both go to the market to sell it.

i successfully repaid my first loan from asasah (a microfinance institute in pakistan). now i am applying again for a loan to buy more milk to expand my husband’s milk selling business. 

i am a group leader of a group of five women. anayat baji wants a loan to buy iron and plastic for her scrap business. shamshad baji wants a loan to buy utensils to resell. suraiya baji wants a loan to by an electric sewing machine to make embroidered dresses. nasreen baji wants a loan to buy rice and wheat to resell. 

this is a group loan. the loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. the members mutually guarantee one another's loans. if one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

note: "baji," which means "older sister," is a term of respect for women in pakistan.

jane is the 42-year-old proud mother of eight children. she is a group leader, often described as a very resourceful person, and represents her group of 12 farmers in webuye district. 

since joining one acre fund in 2013, jane has noticed that she has had a healthier life due to better nutrition. jane described her harvest as excellent last year, but believes she can have a better one this year by continuing to work with one acre fund. 

she is very excited also to be purchasing a solar light, apart from fertilizer and maize.  she will now be able to have light during dark hours for her children to be able to study. 

with the profits from this season’s harvest, she plans to save more money for the future.  with this loan, jane’s group will be able to plant a total of 6 acres of land and purchase a total of 13 solar lights.

phillip is 31 years old and lives in the town of tororo in the mbale region of uganda. he is married and has 3 children, with 2 of them currently in school. for the past 2 years, phillip has been working hard to manage his salon, which does hairdressing. 

to help expand his business, phillip has requested a loan of 300,000 ugandan shillings from brac uganda. the loan will be used to purchase a big screen television and will help phillip to generate greater profits and then pay school fees for his children. phillip hopes that in the future he will be able to educate his children. 

phillip is a member of brac's small enterprise program (sep).  the program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like phillip who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

luis is 61 years old and studied until first grade in school. he is single and he doesn't have children. he lives with an older brother who is independent.

luis has made a living raising poultry since he was 20 years old. he keeps the birds in his home and he works every day from 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 a.m.

he will use the loan to buy chickens to fatten and sell later.

his dream is for his farm to grow, and to be well-known in the community so that his sales grow and he can therefore generate more income.

leonila is a married woman, 52 years old with eight children. she is a very hard working entrepreneur.

leonila has a buy and sell vegetables business in the philippines. leonila requested a php 15000 loan amount through nwtf to buy more vegetables to sell to her local market.

leonila has been in this business for 12 years. she would like to save money to expand her business.

nelva is 60 years old and she is married and lives a simple life in concepcion, iloilo. she and her husband are engaged in a farming business. they have been in this business for many years. nelva wants to make sure that the water they drink every day is good and safe to drink.

with this in mind, she is asking for a loan of 5,000 php through kiva’s field partner cevi to buy a water filter. through this loan, nelva is confident that they will have safe water to drink from now on.

beatrice.is a married woman with one child who attends school. she lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. her greatest monthly expense is rent .

she has operated a butcher shop business for the past three years, selling goat meat. she faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of business.

with the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of goats to slaughter and get meat for resale. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

camila is a 49-year-old married woman and has six children. two of her children are currently in school.  she is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

camila has a motorcycle transport business in the philippines. camila requested a 10,000 php loan amount through nwtf to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

camila has been in this business for 3 years. in the future, camila  would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

ouk s., a 40-year-old mother of two children, lives with her husband in phnom penh, cambodia. she works in a farm with her husband growing and cultivating variety of crops and feeding domestic animals such as pigs, ducks, and chickens. this couple usually makes about $3 per day in revenue. one of her children works at a nearby garment factory, and another is a construction worker. they nomally contribute all their wages to the household every month. s. hopes the loan will help her purchase more seeds for her plantation and to repair her house from leaking during the rainy season.  in the future, savoeu hopes to buy more animals to raise and to make additional income from her plantation.

haya is 23 years old. she is married and has no children. her husband works as a police officer. haya is studying a bachelor of arabic language and literature 4th year. she is one step closer to graduation. haya is planning to work as an arabic teacher in the future. now she is asking for a loan to pay her study fees as her husband's income is not sufficient to pay for them.

mrs. cinthia maría c. is 44 years old and married to juan. they have 1 dependent child. she owns a grocery store and has been in business for more than 4 years. when she started, she had few products and did not offer great variety, but with the little money she saved from her earnings was able to open her business.

the loan she is requesting will be used as working capital to buy basic grains, soaps, detergents and candy. cinthia dreams of diversifying her products and converting her small grocery store into a wholesale outlet.

translated from spanish by ronan reodica, kiva volunteer

teofila is 64 years old, married, and has four children.

teofila is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the philippines. teofila requested a php 13,000 loan through nwtf to buy feeds, other supplies and vitamins to raise her livestock.

teofila has been pig fattening for 12 years now, and has borrowed from nwtf 2 times in the past to sustain it.

teofila would like to save money to expand her business to secure her family's future.

this member continues working in the transport business.  he has a car with which he provides a taxi service.  he works from 8.00am to 6.00pm in different streets in the city of cusco.  through this business, he would like to get ahead in life.  this member's dream is to improve his business as a transport provider.  he is requesting this loan to have maintenance work carried out on his car and to buy spare parts.\r\n\r\nthe member is happy to be receiving his loan and pledges to make his repayments on time.

\r\nsandra l. is a woman known for being a very good shopkeeper who sells clothing and backpacks of all types in her section of the central market in the city of chinandega. her business has been developing in a satisfactory way thanks to her many efforts. she is now looking for support from kiva partner ceprodel in order to purchase backpacks. as it is the beginning of the year her sales will increase because school classes are starting, and it is important to have enough merchandise to offer in order to satisfy her clients.

translated from spanish by emily martyn, kiva volunteer

aurelia is a member of the "sacuyo" communal bank in dos, in the town of sacuyo, district of acora, puno province. she is 43 years old and cares for four children, is married and her primary studies are incomplete (fifth grade). she has worked with mmr for a half year. she works at fattening up and selling livestock at the livestock markets. her first loan was for s/. 500 new soles, which she used to buy feed for her livestock. with this loan for s/. 800 new soles, which will be repaid in 3 installments, she will buy balanced feed for her livestock, medicines and seeds so that they can reach a good weight and she can have good earnings. she is grateful to manuela ramos for their trust in her, which has allowed her to help her children with their education.

translated from spanish by molly puglisi, kiva volunteer

aasma is 31 years old and married. the man shown in the photo is her husband, who is a van driver by profession. he drives in the main city and makes enough income to cover all the expenses of his family.

he wants to change the van's engine, as it is causing a lot of pollution and is consuming too much oil for its work. that is why aasma has requested a murabaha loan of 30,000 pkr for her husband to buy a new engine for the van to provide better customer service. aasma is hopeful that this loan will be a productive one for her husband and will bring positive changes to his business.

our member, eusebia, belongs to the sayhua de chichubamba community bank in urubamba province.  she is 47-years old, single, and the mother of 2 children.  she operates a business selling flowers.  the business is successful, she says, because she has worked hard every day to make it successful.  the business, she adds, is her sole means of supporting her family.\r\neusebia is applying for a loan that she will use to stock her flower sales business.  she is grateful for your help and committed to repaying your loans in the agreed-upon time.\r\n

lis, a young mother of a little kid, is 28 years old and a local farmer residing in kampong cham province. she plants cassava and rice as the main income generating activity to deal with her family’s financial burden. for eight years engagement in the business, she is able to earn up to 20,000 khr. this is lis' third loan with visionfund (kiva’s partner). she has used her previous loans wisely to support her living in a gradual manner. now she is a group leader of three other joint members. for lis, her loan portion will be used on paying for leasing cassava farmland. she highly hopes that she can get more income to better her living.

kholbi is married and has one child. she is a hardworking and dedicated woman, and assured of her own success. her husband is a driver and her son a farmer. she works with feeding and selling livestock. this year she increased her number of animals. she has a pasture for livestock and has enough feed to keep them, so she has decided to buy animals and feed them until late autumn. \r\n

jenny is a 43-year-old, mother of seven children, ages 2 to 18. she lives in carles, iloilo with her family. her husband has been in the fishing business for a long time now. jenny works hard in helping her husband so they can support their children in terms of food and schooling. 

she is asking for a loan of 20,000 php to buy plywood, crude oil, kerosene, rice and fishing nets. she hopes to keep her business for a long time, and to make it more sustainable someday. she dreams of seeing her children be successful in their education in the future.

sandra is a 36 year old mother to 2 young children who are attending school. she lives with her common-law husband in their own home which is currently under construction. she runs her own business while her husband works in the courts. this will be her third loan cycle and, with her previous loans, she successfully invested in the construction of her house, which is now in its final building phase. she plans to use this loan to buy windows, doors, bricks and cement so that she can finish the building work. she dreams of finishing her house and of officially marrying her husband. she would also like to build other houses on a plot of land that she has ready. she is very happy with the loans that she has already received because they have helped her a great deal with managing on her husband's wage; previously they were short of money and didn't have enough to cover their household expenses but now she has taken on these responsibilities, she is able to pay their monthly costs.

mr. duger is 26 years old and lives with his parents in a ger (traditional mongolian housing) in uvs province of mongolia. his parents are retired and stay home. 

duger has been renting a vehicle and running a transportation service in town since 2010. he has gained a lot of experience and networks over the years. 

duger is now starting his own taxi service business in town and requesting 4,700,000 mnt to purchase an eco-friendly car to provide a taxi service in town. he is a hardworking, honest and diligent man.

ma. nancy works hard to support her family. ma. nancy is married and has a fish vending business in the philippines.

ma. nancy requested a php 28,000 loan through nwtf to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell in her fish stall.

ma. nancy has been in this business for 16 years now.

ma. nancy would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

virginia is 43 years old and married with three children.

virginia works hard to provide for her family. she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a loan of 11,000 philippines pesos (php) through nwtf to purchase additional stock of products like diapers, sanitary pads, coffee, detergent soap, shampoo, and fabric conditioner to sell.

virginia has borrowed and repaid 7 loans from nwtf before this loan. she has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from buying and selling firewood.

virginia aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.
