marivic appreciates how center for community transformation (cct) supports every members on their business as it was used by god for the approval of her previous loan request. aside from monetary support, lectures and seminars are part of their program, which is molding her continuously to be a well-equipped entrepreneur.

the prior loan of php20,000 was used to buy necessities for her internet café business. customers became more comfortable since every computer has new and reliable peripherals. the amount made a vast impact and she’s thankful for that. she aims to have a bigger internet café.

marivic wants to add another unit of computer. for this, she’s requesting a loan of php35,000.

she’s looking forward to cct once again granting her loan request.

marivic believes that if you want success to come in, you need god to be your greatest foundation. she is consistent in attending weekly fellowship group for cct partners, which consists of 15 to 30 members, where she gains spiritual strength with the member’s life changing testimony, shares her own experience of god’s love, pays microfinance loans, and hear god’s word that is conveyed to them every week.

antonieta is 46 years old, has two children, and lives in the city of cusco, peru. she has a restaurant called “don coco” where she prepares lunches and à la carte dishes. her business is open from 9am to 4pm. antonieta has been in this business for seventeen years and has done very well as a result of the effort she puts into her work. she needs a loan in order to buy supplies such as rice, sugar, noodles, and other items.\r\n

\r\nantonieta belongs to the communal bank “yahuar maqui”, which is part of asociación arariwa. she is grateful for the opportunity that has been provided and promises to complete her payments on time.

member leticia still belongs to the communal bank mujeres unidas, which is located within the district of cusco, in the province of cusco and the departament of cusco.

member leticia still works at her boarding house business. specifically she offers lunch service every monday through friday in her home. she has been in this business for several years and it is going very well for her, thanks to the effort she puts into her work.
 
member leticia is requesting the loan to perform maintenance on her home, that is, she will purchase doors and other things.

member leticia is happy with the loan and is committed to paying her installments.

fotima is a hospitable woman. she was born in the west-northern part of tajikistan in 1967. she is living in a town, is married and has three children. she has 11 year of experience doing business in agriculture keeping and selling livestock. she is a member of a collective farm and gets forage from her land to feed livestock. she keeps and feeds livestock for 10 -15 days and sells in the animal market. she does a good business and gets enough income to ensure her family's welfare. 

she requested a loan from imon and kiva lenders to buy livestock and continue her business. she awaits kiva lenders kindness and hopes she will have an efficient business to bring a benefit to the budget of her family.

jona works hard to support nine children. she is married and has a business selling vegetables in the philippines.

jona has requested a php 6990 loan through nwtf to invest in a solar lamp. she is getting the lamp because she wants to have backup light in case of emergency.

jona is aware that by using the solar lamp, she will not only be saving money but also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

carmen is married and has two daughters who already formed their own families.
carmen is a farmer and rancher. he has always worked for his family and feels satisfied, because he has been able to form his daughters; even when he had difficult situations he faced them in the best way with god's help.
carmen will use the loan to buy food for the cattle.

adolfa is from malaubang, ozamiz city. she is 49 years old. adolfa is married and has 6 children. 

to make a living, adolfa runs a general store, selling a variety of food and home use products in the local community. adolfa has been in business for 25 years and earns 3,000 php a month for these activities.

adolfa is requesting a loan of 6,000 php, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. in 2008, adolfa joined gdmpc to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

ludivico is encouraged that he previously received and faithfully repaid his loan on time. the proceeds of his loan really helped to render his tricycle service safe and efficient, and thus he has been able to provide for his family. being a tricycle driver at his age is not easy, but he is happy that he is able to send his elementary kids to school.

to help ludivico maintain his service, he is again humbly seeking a php 11,000 to pay for registration, tires and fuel for his tricycle. he values his tricycle as it is his main source of income. he thanks god and you in advance for supporting his livelihood.

ludivico's precious dream is to send his children to college. he aims to acquire one more tricycle to improve his income. he faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week, and to draw strength and inspiration from the word of god he studies.

* all cct community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

phon is 54 years old. she is married and resides with three children in kampong chhnang province, cambodia. to earn a living, her husband runs a taxi service (motor taxi). he earns about $6 every day. three of her children are employed in a garment factory. they earn about $10 per day. due to lack of funds, phon is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase construction materials to fix her house. this money will help her provide better living conditions for the family. in the future, she would like to run a tailoring shop for her daughter. \r\n

sokhom’s group live in a rural village in the prey veng province of cambodia. 

sokhom makes a living cultivating rice.  she also does extra work as a construction worker and seller to support her family. 

in the group's village, there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these members to safeguard the health of their families, save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

gloria is taking out her third loan with the “el cisne” (the swan) communal bank.  she lives around el valle parish in cuenca, a place with a cold climate.  its architecture is a mixture of the old and the modern.  for the most part, agricultural production is for home consumption and they work raising animals.  el valle has grown commercially.   its residents like the members are kind, gracious people who still retain the culture and traditions of its peoples.

gloria’s 25-years-old and a single mother of three children who are 6, 4 and 3 years of age.  her oldest son attends school and the two younger ones are in a day-care center.  she does not have a house of her own; she lives in her mother’s house and shares expenses with her.

gloria works raising and selling pigs, guinea pigs and chickens in her community.  she also works her land and what she grows is for home consumption.  at home, she also works doing embroidery, an activity she learned thanks to a girlfriend. 

she will use this loan to buy animal feed and fabric and also to pay for one of her children’s palate surgery.  her goal is to give her children the best education so that they will become good professionals someday.

nena is 61 years old, from danao, plaride. she is hard working mother. anita is very busy when it comes to her snack vending business. she is happy that she can help her family through her snack vending business. nena is availing a loan to purchase additional materials and ingredients for her business. nena looks forward to paying her obligation to the cooperative.

maria teresa is a member of the communal bank called pautenitas. she lives in paute, a place known for its pleasant climate, flower cultivation, friendly people and local cuisine. maria teresa is 44 years old and has been divorced for 3 years. she has 3 children from her marriage, ages 25, 23 and 17 years old. only the youngest lives with maria teresa. the eldest has moved away to find better work and now helps his mother financially. her daughter has married and lives independently with her family in their own house.

maria teresa has owned a small general store for 25 years where she works on sundays and wednesdays. the other days she works cultivating plants. in her extra time she washes clothes. this additional work has enabled her to improve her quality of life. she has 3 cycles now working with the communcal bank, and the loans have helped her to make necessary repairs to her house. with the new loan, she wil purchase rice, sugar, oil, salt, cleaning supplies and other items to fix up her store. she would like to finish the repairs on her home.

translated from spanish by emily charnes, kiva volunteer

meet fatmata, 45 years old, from waterloo western rural in freetown in sierra leone. she is married with two children.  for the past 20 years, fatmata has had her retail business. she began her business because she wanted to educate her children. she works at the business from 8:00 am until 5:30 pm, 6 days per week. she says that the main challenge to her business is price inflation and proper business location.

fatmata requires a loan in order to purchase cigarettes, drinks and biscuits to expand her business. she hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to change her standard of living and increase her business. in the future, fatmata plans to expand her business more than ever. she thanks you for your support.

mary is a 40-year-old married woman with three children. her children are between the ages of 12 and 20, and they are all attending school at the present time. in addition, mary cares for additional family members. she resides in and rents a two-room house, where she lives with six other people. her family has access to electricity but no running water, and she works in a semi-urban area in the outskirts of kampala.

for ten years, mary has been in the business of selling bananas in the kalerwe market. she notes that she purchases these bananas from delivery trucks, which have been stocked by farmers. she explains that she does not incur any transportation costs to and from shopping areas because she buys the bananas at her place of work. she sells to all categories of people -- both retail and wholesale customers.

mary has been with mcdt for nine years, and she is currently servicing her 22nd loan, working all the while with the same group members. she is now applying for another loan, with the hope that the proceeds from this loan could be used to buy additional bunches of bananas. she aspires to see her business expand further so that she can someday purchase her bananas directly from the farmers.

nelia works hard to support her family. nelia is married and has a fishing business in the philippines.

nelia requested a php 10,000 loan through nwtf in order to buy fishing nets and other fishing equipment.

nelia has been in this business for 30 years now and earns additional income from pig fattening.

in the future, nelia would like to save enough money to expand her business.

josphat is a married man who has three children. he operates a retail business where he sells shoes. he has been involved in this business for 10 years. his business is located in a good area and his primary customers are locals. he describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital.

he will use the kes 80,000 loan to buy more stock of shoes. his business goal is to have a wholesale business within five years. this is his third loan with smep microfinance bank. the previous loans were repaid successfully.

yet s. is 50-year-old and a resident of phnom penh, the capital. to make a living, yet s. always orders traditional silk skirts in bulk from weavers who live near her house and then bring those skirts to sell in retail from home to home around her community. she sells her item to people who need to wear for parties or other ceremonies. in the business, her husband (pictured) helps work with her in ordering and selling produces. this older couple has five children: three are single and two are married and have ready started new homes. yet s. needs extra capital in order to make her business successful. she requested a loan of us$1000 to be used to purchase traditional silk skirt to sell.

adjoa a. processes palm oil for sale at abura.  adjoa has been through junior high school. she is married to a carpenter and lives with her four children. adjoa has been selling palm oil for about three years now. she helps her husband with the general upkeep of the home. her loan will be added to her initial income to buy a palm oil extractor to be able to extract more oil to sell. she hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back into her business.

to prepare her locally made palm oil, she gets her palm nuts from the farmers on the farm. she washes them and boils them for about 40 minutes until they become soft and tender. the cooked fruits are strained, put into a big mortar and gently squeezed with a pestle, avoiding damaging the nut but only to peel the pulp covering the nut. water is then added to it. the juice obtained is strained, separating the nut and taking out the chaff with the hand. (the chaff is sometimes used by the local people to light charcoal fire). the juice is boiled again and as it boils, the fresh oil will be seen floating whilst the water keeps boiling beneath. the scooped oil is left to cool and later bottled or preserved for sale. fresh oil from palm fruits are traditionally used in eating roasted yam or plantain in africa, especially on the farms after a hard days work.

maría is a member of the prod natura community bank. she lives in the parrish of victoria del portete. this place has cold weather. its people are dedicated to livestock and farming. many work in the city of cuenca in different areas of work.

maría is 48 years old. she is married and her married union has resulted in eight children of whom three are married adults, three are college students and two are in school and help her with the housework. her husband works as a bricklayer. the house that they live in is her property, the result of effort and work.

maría is dedicated to selling tiens brandname, natural products (vitamins, slimming products, nutritional supplements, beauty products, etc.) she has done this work for four years. she sells her products from sunday to sunday without fixed hours.

this is her second loan with the community bank and her new loan will be invested in natural products to expand her business. her goal is to grow her business.

iris is a 21-year-old mother of two children, who mean everything to her and are her reason for getting ahead. in the morning, iris sells seasoning at a stand in the bellavista market, while in the evening, she sells cold drinks at home, which is located in a commercial area. her partner, mr. magbis, repairs refrigerators for a living and supports iris in her decisions. they both give their young ones everything that is necessary for their education. iris would like to improve and expand her business, which along with her husband’s job, is the family’s source of income. with your help, ms. iris will obtain her goal very soon. \r\n

translated from spanish by elizabeth casian, kiva volunteer.

\r\niris tiene 21 años y es madre de 2 niños, los que son todo en su vida y su razón de salir adelante. iris se dedica por la mañana a la venta de condimentos en un puesto del mercado bellavista, y por la tarde a la venta de bebidas heladas en su casa, ya que está ubicada en una zona comercial, su pareja, el señor magbis es técnico de refrigeradoras y apoya en todo lo que iris decide, ambos brindan a sus pequeños lo necesario para su educación. el propósito de iris es crecer, mejorar y ampliar su negocio, que junto al oficio de su pareja son el sustento de su hogar. con tu ayuda la señora iris logrará su propósito en corto tiempo.

baguma is a 45-year-old hardworking man with 10 children living in fort portal, uganda. he produces 'waragi', a local brew in his area, and slaughters cows to add more to his income. he is faced with the challenges of inadequate funding for business sustainability and competition. despite his hardships, baguma has future plans of expanding his business to new areas. 

baguma needs a loan to buy cows for slaughtering to sell.

the extra people in the photo are people at the market, and could not be excluded as the market day is always busy.

mavluda is 44 years old. she is married and raising four children. her eldest daughter is an adult, while the other three are not yet adults. 

mavluda works as a loan expert at imon international. she is a smart and hardworking woman and therefore she carries out her work at the highest standard. her husband works with repairing vehicles. her daughter mardjona has successfully finished high school and started at a branch of the national research technological university "misa", specializing in economics. 

mavluda needs to pay her daughter's tuition at the university. she requests a loan in the amount of 750 us dollar. she awaits your kindness.

blanca is 62 years of age and a columbian woman who lives in ecuador. she says that she is happy because eucuador is a peaceful place to live and there are many activities one can do as a living.\r\n\r\nblanca is a lady very devoted to her family, which consists of her 8 children, but only three live with blanca. despite her age, blanca is eager to work. she will invest the loan in the purchase of a cow which she wants to raise on the farm where she works with her children. she says that she really needs the loan, as animal husbandry is her source of income.

as a married parent of three children, helen works hard to support her family.

she has a trucking business in the philippines and also earns additional income from a tricycle taxi. helen is borrowing 29,000 php through nwtf to buy spare parts and new tools for her trucking services.

helen has been sustaining her business activities through her past 20 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

jemimah is a 50-year-old mother living in kyenjojo-uganda. she owns a women's salon where she offers hair dressing, braids and weaves. she started this business to supplement her husband's income to meet the family's needs, including paying school fees for children in high levels of education.

her business is doing well now, after seven years, but it lacks modernization needed to overcome the high competition. such modernization would require a small amount of capital. therefore, jemimah is requesting a loan to buy braids and weaves for hair dressing.

the person raising her hand in the photo and with a black top is hanna, a member of thabina women group. she is 54 years old, married, and has 4 children. she participates in group activities and has been trained by hand in hand eastern africa in savings and resource mobilization, which both enabled her to make some savings and start operating a green grocery shop within her locality.

hanna also supplies surplus products to the other nearby markets. she is applying for a kiva loan so that she can add more stock and access larger markets and thus earn more profits. this will enable her to support her family with their basic needs.

hanna is grateful to kiva and their lenders and promises to repay her loan portion on schedule.

abel is a thirty-nine-year-old married man with ten children living in bundibugyo, uganda. he is a farmer who grows cocoa. from the savings of cocoa he set-up a motorcycle transport business which now he operates to cater for his daily obligations. \r\n\r\nhe hopes to improve on his family's standard of living though price changes, bad weather and bad debtors affect his plans. he intends to use the loan to buy and sell cocoa ahead of the peak season.

hello kiva community. meet irene, who is a crop and animal farmer and a mother eager to provide the very best for her family. she states that with her small income, she hasn’t been able to provide sufficient lighting through the electricity in her home. her family has been using kerosene lamps, despite the toxic fumes that put the family at risk of contracting respiratory diseases.

irene is kindly appealing for a loan to buy a solar lantern to provide adequate lighting, enabling her children to read well while at home. with the lantern’s dual charging capability, her husband will also be able to efficiently charge his phone. kindly consider lending to her.

jhoan is a married woman who lives with her family in getafe, bohol. she makes her living through farming and growing rice. jhoan's husband is a fisherman, and she has two young dependents.

she is bothered by the safety of her drinking water. to combat this problem, jhoan is asking for a loan from cevi to purchase a water filter that will purify their drinking water. by using this water filter, jhoan can keep her family safe from diseases caused by drinking dirty water.

victoria g. lives in the naguru neighborhood of the city of kampala, uganda. she is single and has four children, all of whom are in school. victoria has a business selling second-hand clothes. she has been in this business for six years, and works six days a week. victoria sells her products at the market, by means of wholesale/retail. victoria has requested a loan of 1,000,000 ugandan shillings from mcdt sacco, which she will use to buy more boxes of second-hand clothes.     \r\n\r\nshe also generates additional income through tailoring. the main business challenge(s) for victoria include transportation and the rainy season. her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and also to educate her children up to university. victoria lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity, but not to piped water. her major monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees.

emerita works hard to support her family. she is married and has a business selling dry goods in the philippines.

emerita requested a php 10,000 loan through nwtf to purchase more stock of dry goods, such as pants, curtains, blankets, etc., to sell.

emerita has been in this business for six years now.

she successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

in the future, emerita would like to save money to expand her business.

estrella works hard to support seven children. she is married and has a general store business in the philippines.

she requested a 10,000 php loan through nwtf to build a sanitary toilet for her family.

estrella is aware that by using the sanitary toilet, she is reducing health and hazard risks to her family and neighbors as well as promoting environment protection.

julita is 60 years old and widowed with seven children. 

julita is in the agricultural business, doing pig fattening in the philippines. julita requested a php 29,500 loan through nwtf to buy additional piglets, feed and vitamins for her business.

julita has been in pig fattening for 43 years now, and has borrowed 23 times in the past from nwtf to sustain it.

in the future, julita would like to save enough money to expand her business.

bernaditha is a married woman with eight children. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur. bernaditha is 54 years old and two of her children are in school.

bernaditha has a shell craft business in the philippines. bernaditha requested a php 15,000 loan through nwtf to buy materials needed such as thread, etc.

bernaditha has been in this business for eight years. in the future, bernaditha would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

james is married with four children, and living in bundibugyo uganda. he is a retailer and gets additional income from rentals. 

he started the business 10 years back and continues to see progress despite challenges of inadequate capital, which limits his profits. however, he works hard to expand his business and raise income for the family and school fees.  

james has asked for a loan to  buy merchandise like sugar and cooking oil, among other things, for selling.

hannah is 48 years old. she is a divorced woman with two children: ages 22 and 29 years. they live at home while attending school.

hannah runs a business where she sells charcoal, a business she has been operating for eight years. she describes herself as hardworking business woman. she started to sell with money given to her by her former husband and her mother taught her how to sell.

hannah spends eight hours a day at her business site, monday through saturday. since she started to sell, she has had no problems with her business. she uses a car to transport supplies to the business site. hannah likes her business because it gives her money on every selling day and she is proud of her business because it helps to send her children to school.

to add increase business, hannah requires a loan through brac liberia, a kiva field partner. the loan will be used to buy more charcoal to sell to her regular customers. in the future she would like to have a large business. she wishes to say thanks.

rosmery is 24 years old and is a very happy and hard-working young lady. she lives in the house she inherited from her grandmother together with her husband orestes, 25 and her beloved daughter, ivet, 4, tow hom she wants to give a better quality of life. working very hard together with her husband rosmery has managed to move her household forward. the crops that she has cultivated with such hard work hardly give her the money necessary to cover the costs of her home, and for this reason she also breeds pigs, this being the main activity that she does as it gives her better economic results. what she likes most about her work is feeding her pigs, as the fatter they are the better earnings they give her. she has been doing this activity for 4 years and considers the most difficult thing to be selling her pigs to storekeepers who kill them to sell the meat. in the future she hopes to buy a truck with which she can transport her animals to the city, as she believes she can obtain better prices there. this is rosmery's first loan with mfp. she knows she has to invest money in her business if she wants it to progress. she is a very happy and beloved member of her communal bank and has always demonstrated great responsbility. rosmery will invest half of the money that she is seeking in fumigating her farm and the other half in buying food for her pigs.

translated from spanish by jane mccrory, kiva volunteer

monica is a hard-working woman. she is 16 years old and lives in the town of kaliro in the iganga region of uganda. she has no children. for the past two years, monica has been working hard to manage her hotel (restaurant) business. 

to help expand her business, monica has requested a loan of 200,000 ugandan shillings from brac uganda. the loan will be used to buy saucepans, rice and bananas, and will help monica to generate greater profits and earn extra income. monica hopes that in the future, she will be able to open up a big restaurant. 

monica is a member of brac's empowerment and livelihood for adolescents (ela) program. in addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

ana marie is 36 years old and married with two children.

she earns a living by pig fattening in the philippines. ana marie is borrowing 20,000 php (philippines pesos) through nwtf to purchase additional feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

ana marie has been pig fattening for five years and also earns additional income from tailoring and from motorcycle transport.

she is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

as a married parent of three children, myrna works hard to support her family.

she has a business buying and selling frozen foods in the philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling personal care products. myrna is borrowing php 15,000 through nwtf to buy more frozen foods to sell to her customers.

myrna has been sustaining her business activities through her past 4 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

this group is called al-boary. it consists of three ladies and a man who live in aden, yemen.
samira is 45 years old and married. she has five children. she has worked very hard for many years to get her family ahead and give them everything they deserve. she has been selling cosmetic products, which is her main source of income. 
samira's dream is to see her business flourish. due to the current bad situation in yemen, her enterprise has earned less profit. she took out a loan of 50,000 yer from amb to stock her business with more cosmetic products and perfumes so that her customers can always find what they need.

this is a small loan for a group of four people, all residents of siem reap province in cambodia. mrs. p. has been selected to be the leader by the members. she is a 30-year-old widow who has given birth to two children, both now teenagers attending school.

since early 2007, p. has run a store in front of her house selling snack foods for the neighborhood, earning approximately $4 per day. p. proposes to earn additional income by selling a few groceries; thus, she is looking for a loan to buy grocery inventory to sell.

the other three borrowers are: c., a snack-food seller who asks for a loan for repairing her husband's bicycle; t., a widowed trader who sells fish paste and is applying for a loan to increase her business capital; and p., a widow who sells fish paste in the local market and needs the loan to buy more fish paste in bulk to resell.

husnigul is a hardworking young woman. she was born in 1983 into a working family. she is married and has two children. husnigul is a student at the dangara state university. she is clever and studies well as a fourth-year student extramural.

she cannot afford her tuition, as she must pay her own university tuition every year and feed her two minor children. she is unable to do so alone. so, she is taking a loan of 4,000 tjs and using it to pay her university tuition.

she is asking for a loan from kiva and imon for her university tuition. she awaits your support and sends her great thanks for making her education possible. she is a returning borrower and has positive credit history. she is asking for a loan for the fourth time through kiva’s field partner imon.

charlene is 35 years old.  she is actively participating in the various programs and services that the coop offers.  as a microfinance member of paglaum mpc, she availed a loan to purchase housing materials such as sand, cement and galvanized sheet for house repair.\n\nin the future she plans to begin constructing the fence of her house.

mary is separated from her husband. mary started her food business 3 years ago, but she was formally into selling tomatoes at her home area. mary owns a strategically positioned spot in unit m, near jambanja, which is the heartland of all activities of buying and selling.

mary is a 53 year old mother of three children. mary experienced challenges of little stock which ended up translating into low sales. mary formed a group with ladies from her neighbourhood and they named their group chimwechete a vernacular name which means “oneness and unity” these ladies have known each other from their teenage days till they were married.

mary wants to buy groceries such as mealie-meal, drinks, cooking oil, sugar among other products so that she will not have challenges of turning customers back because of lack of the commodities which they will be looking for.

mary and her group members were happy with their training at thrive, which has made them real business entrepreneurs.they hope to implement whatever they have learnt into their businesses.

gulbakhor m. lives in khujand; she is married and has 3 children.  mrs. m. has been a successful, strongly motivated client of microinvest since 2006. her credit history makes her eleigible for larger loans. she works in the joint-stock company "navbakhor" making winter wear. gulbakhor m. developed her own patterns and used special accessories to make the clothing more individual. she has the a loyal clientele of long standing. she has a lot of ideas on how to make her work more efficient and how to broaden the product line. she would like to modernize her business and requests a loan of $725 to buy a computerized sewing machine. her dream is to open her own shop in the future.

sully m. o. is married and her husband works in trade. their earnings help with household costs. they have one child, age 5. she has sold cosmetics for 2 years; it was thanks to her husband's support that she was able to purchase her business' first merchandise.\r\nshe manages, even though there are months in the year when sales cool off and earnings wane. she hopes that the second half of 2010 will be better, and so she is requesting a loan to buy a better inventory. the requested loan is for the purchase of cosmetics in order to benefit from the day of celebration of nicaragua's mother. this will improve her income for investment in new jobs, and offer her little child better conditions to benefit his personal development.

translated from spanish by christine cooper, kiva volunteer

greetings from magburaka, a community near the small and busy northern area in sierra leone.

this is 26-year-old mabinty, a married mother and businesswoman. mabinty has three children between the age of 2 and 10.

mabinty runs a retail business; she sells cigarettes and batteries at a busy road where many people stop to take transport to other towns and cities. seemingly distinct businesses are often mixed in sierra leone, the idea being that a customer will come to purchase one thing but will leave having purchased another.

mabinty has been a trader for 10 years now and desires to empower her life. mabitny works six days a week and 10 hours per day. this is her only source of income, and she is proud of her young business. she likes the fact that she continues to have new customers and has kept the old ones.

mabinty wants to use this loan to buy cigarettes and batteries to sell to her customers. mabinty would like to open a big shop. she really wants to improve her life and is grateful to brac sierra leone and the kiva community for their financial support.

asuncion is a married woman with ten children. she is a very hard-working entrepreneur. asuncion is 55 years old and has three children who are in school.

asuncion has a buy-and-sell coconut wine business in the philippines. she has requested a php 7,000 loan through negros women for tomorrow foundation, inc. (nwtf) to purchase additional containers of coconut wine to sell.

asuncion has been in this business for four years. in the future, she would like to save enough money, so she could afford to send her children to college.

salima m. works in the trade business. she brings replacement parts in from the city of dushanbe for automobiles and sells them in the local market. this is the only source of income for her family, which is why it is essential for her to grow the business. in order to do that, she wants to take out a loan and increase the assortment of goods she can sell. this way, she will be able to increase her profits. she will repay the loan within 6 months.

translated from russian by dan ostrovsky, kiva volunteer.

мирсаидова салима занимается торговлей . привозит из города душанбе запчасти для легковых автомобилей и продает их на рынке района. это единственный источник доходов его семьи, поэтому ей необходимо развивать бизнес. для этого она хочет получить кредит и увеличить ассортимент товара. таким образом она сможет увеличить прибыльность дела. погасить кредит планирует в течении 6 месяцев.

mr. magnan is 50 years old, married, and the father of five children. he lives with his wife and their children in a nuclear family in the neighborhood of kamalen sirakoro, a working-class neighborhood in the city of sikasso, in the 3rd administrative region of the republic of mali. 

after being unsuccessful at a number of jobs, magnan started buying and selling vegetables and tubers (yams and potatoes). he buys his supplies in cote d’ivoire. 

this is his first individual loan with the microfinance institution, soro yiriwaso. he hopes to better satisfy his ever-growing clientele.

this loan will allow him to buy 15 100-kg bags of yams and 10 50-kg bags of potatoes in bouake in cote d’ivoire. 

he sells for retail prices, for cash and for credit, and in the market to a clientele comprised of men and women. he hopes to earn an average monthly income of 160,000 fcfa. this income will allow him to pay his interest and invest in his business.

the banco comunal los tres ángeles (the three angels communal bank) meets every fortnight in the montecristi canton, a place renowned for its rich pre-colonial culture and for its arts and crafts, celebrated both at national and international level. it is also the homeland of the famous toquilla straw hats.

here we meet paula, aged 38, who is married and has two daughters aged 8 and 3; the eldest goes to school. her husband is a professional driver.

she is a teacher in a public school in montecristi; on top of this she also sells costume jewelry. she is a street vendor selling door to door articles such as rings, necklaces, earrings, bracelets and so on. she runs both activities every day, as she brings her products to her school where she sells them to her colleagues and to the mothers coming there. she buys at wholesale price form a supplier in portoviejo; she told us she has been engaging in this activity for three years and that things have been going well.

she will use this loan to purchase costume jewelry. she has been a member of the communal bank since the beginning, and she likes it because of the reliability both of the institution and of her teammates.

she hopes to be able to offer a better future to her daughters.

ma. luz l. is from the village of nabbotuan, solana, cagayan. she is 38 years old. ma. luz is married and has three school-aged children. to make a living, ma. luz raises pigs for fattening and sale. ma. luz has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 3,000 php a month for these activities.

in 2008, ma. luz joined aski to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. ma. luz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 php from aski. ma. luz is requesting a new loan of 5,000 php, which will be used to purchase baby pigs to raise and sell in the future. this loan will be the fourth loan taken out by ma. luz from aski. she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

about aski:
aski is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the philippines. it has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. its clients are mostly farmers, fishers, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva.  given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

sebazungu g. is among the early clients of vfc. he was born in 1979 in eastern province, bugesera district. he is married and stays with his family in nyamata sector/ nyamata-city.\r\n

\r\nin 2005, g. started a small-scale business trading shoes. his business was conducted in a small house he was renting for three thousand per month (rwf3,000). he was living in the same room with 4 orphans (2 boys and 2 girls) as a child-headed household family. after joining vfc, his business grew, and he started to inject the small loan he obtained to purchase other items. according to g., “i was wondering where to find money in order to increase my capital and inject in other businesses which overlap with the shoes i am selling. it is by that reason that i approached vfc and started with trousers since people who were buying shoes could also be in need of trousers.” this business was initiated in 2006 with 10 men\'s trousers. g. says, "the loan i am going to get from vfc is going to help me to increase my business and hence improve my family welfare."

edward is a 34-year-old married man living in kasese, uganda. he has four children, three of which attend school. he has a retail shop business, and is also in the motorcycle transportation business. with the income he's earned, he has been able to pay school fees for his children and reinvest in his business. competition is his major challenge. 

his dream is to own a wholesale shop, since most of the traders who operate in retail purchase from wholesalers in the city.

edward intends to use the loan to purchase posho, sugar, and rice to sell.

joan is happy to share that her humble store has grown from the faithful support of kiva and cct. the loans granted her were a big help to boost her business and she also drew closer to god amidst the challenges in life.

in order to be more competitive, she needs to offer a wider array of packaged food items. in view of this, she trusts that once again you could loan her to refill her store with various canned goods, instant noodles, eggs, beverage, toiletries. aside from her store she also derives income from her tricycle service. part of the loan she will use for the maintenance of her tricycle.

joan's simple dream is to grow her store and add one more tricycle to complete construction of her house. every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the word of god which she studies.

*all center for community transformation (cct) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

sreu is 55 years old and a mother of 10 children, three of whom are still dependent on her. she and her husband make a living through fishing and working for others for a fee. the current business earns them about 90,000 khr per day and they are able to save about 30,000 khr daily for the future needs.

this is the second loan for sreu with kiva’s partner, visionfund. she is now leading her group to apply for a loan. sreu will use her portion to buy fishing supplies and a boat to support her fishing business. she hopes to catch more fish to sell so she can make her family’s living better.

serah is a married woman. she has 4 children with ages ranging from 2 years to 6 years. she describes herself to be dedicated woman to her work. she operates a tailoring business where she sells clothes. she has been involved in this business for 4 years and employs 1 staff member. her business is located at a local residential area and her primary customers are local residents. \r\n\r\nserah describes her biggest business challenge to be the high cost of clothes materials. she will use the kes 20,000 loan to buy fabric for making clothes, such as men and women suits, blouses, shirts etc. her business goal is to be a supplier of dresses to shopping mall within 5 years. she hopes that in the future, she will run a big clothes fashion and a boutique.

vicent is a well-known farmer, mainly dealing in tea farming in kataremwa village, kibazi parish, busheny district. he started this project in 2005 and has managed to sustain his family of seven children and one wife. vicent was born in 1983. his children are aged 15, 13, 11, 9, 7, 5, and 3 years old.  all of them are in school. his side income is cattle rearing, and this has helped him earn some good money to support his family.

he has applied for a loan of 2,500,000 shillings to buy fertilizers for adding manure to his tea shamba, to increase the yields and help in family sustainability. he is an honest man at work and spends eight hours per day working on his business. he sells to all coffee factories around bushenyi district. he is faced with the challenge of price fluctuations, pests, and diseases that affect the harvest. his vision is to buy a big chunk of land and he is honest.

greetings from zimbabwe! this is 27-year-old sharon from murehwa. she is married with three children, one attends school. she also cares for one other dependent. 

sharon runs a retail business to sell groceries. the business has been in operation for 10 years. she says the main challenge being faced is lack of access to working capital to expand her business. sharon has requested 600 usd to buy groceries. she says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve her family's standard of living. 

in the future, sharon plans to run a successful supermarket.

zaynura is a joyous and responsible woman. she is divorced and has two children. zaynura lives with her family in a rural area. zaynura works as a waitress at a cafe. she really loves her children and tries to teach them wholeheartedly because she wants to see her children get educated well. however, her salary is not enough to cover all of the family's necessities.

at the present time, zaynura wants to repair the house where they live to improve their living conditions, but does not have enough of her own money to do this. this is why zaynura came to arvand to obtain a loan to buy construction materials to repair her house. she hopes for a positive result and thanks arvand for the support in advance.

cecília, 41 years old, was born in boane district, maputo province and attended school until fifth grade. she is a widow with three children, two of whom are minors and are at school. cecília became a widow when she had two children and suffered a lot after the death of her husband. she was kicked out of the house by her late husband's family, but luckily managed to build her own home. she had her third child with another husband, but they have never lived together. her principal source of income is from selling clothes and furniture, brought from the north of mozambique. this provides her an income of 7,000 mt per month, on which she is able to live. she lives in her own home. with a loan of 10,000 mt, she intends to increase the amount of merchandise she can buy which will reduce the number of trips to the north. in the future, she plans to build a small shop in her house in order to avoid constant travelling.

translated from portuguese by heidi petersen, kiva volunteer

seth is a single woman. she operates an m-pesa business where she offers mobile-phone-based money-transfer services. she has been involved in this business for two years. her business is located in an area with potential and her primary customers are loyal. she describes her biggest business challenge to be theft. she will use the kes 40,000 loan to add m-pesa float. her business goal is to open more business outlets within five years. she hopes that in the future she will expand the business. \t\t\t\r\n

rosa, 55, is a very hard-working mother. she lives in her own house with her husband and three children. for the past 5 years she has sold notebooks, stuffed toys and styrofoam items. she is very skilled and makes scale models, stenographic work, figurines and many school projects for students. while tending to her bookstore she produces teaching materials and her contacts with teachers lead to students who need projects done because she’s very keen with them. her daughter helps her to make the decorations for important celebrations because detail work on styrofoam is difficult to do alone. she has been in this line of work for 5 years and she’s happy with her accomplishments so she does not neglect her business. for later on in the future she would like to rearrange the accessories in her bookstore and expand her business. this is her 8th loan with mfp. she realizes that the loan will be very beneficial for her to increase her working capital so she pledges to repay in a timely fashion. she is a very talkative group member and always works toward her group’s wellbeing. she plans to use the funds to increase her stock of office supplies because she wants to be better stocked so that she can fill all her pending orders.

translated from spanish by michael bujazan, kiva volunteer

eva is a divorced woman. she has 4 children. she operates a retail business where she sells clothes. her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. she will use the kes 30,000 loan to buy a water tank to store clean water for domestic use. she hopes that in the future, she will improve her family standards of living. this is her first loan with smep microfinance bank.

kimlean, 34 years old, is a citizen residing in a rural area of dambae district, in cambodia’s kampong cham province. she is married and a mother of four children, all of whom are dependent on her. to make a living, kimlean plants cassava, while her husband works for others as a paid laborer to add more income to the family. kimlean and her husband are able to generate income for their family of around 20,000khr daily.\r\n\r\nkimlean has been with visionfund (kiva’s partner) for two loan cycles already. with her previous loans she succeeded in purchasing pesticide and paying the cost of labor. kimlean is now seeking a new loan with visionfund in the amount of 2,000,000khr, to pay for plowing land and to pay wages to farm laborers. this hard-working mother (kimlean) hopes to send her children to good schools in the future, and to be able to guarantee food security for her beloved family.

james is a kiva borrower. he has 2 children. he describes himself to be confident . he operates a retail business where he sells vegetables, fruits, honey. he has been involved in this business for 10 years. his business is located in a good area and his primary customers are locals. he describes his biggest business challenge to be transport costs.

he will use the kes 80,000 loan to buy more stock of fruits, honey. his business goal is to have more shops within 5 years. he hopes that in the future, he will educate his children to university level. the previous loan was repaid successfully. he will use the anticipated profits to purchase additional stock

31-year old demetria lives with 34-year old mauro and their four lovely children. they live in their own house in pichari district. demetria runs a carpentry workshop with her husband. previously they worked on the land but this did not provide them with the income they wanted.

now demetria makes furniture that has been previously ordered by her customers. she is happy with this work as it allows her to be creative and innovative in accordance with the taste and preferences of her customers. the business is doing well and she is getting good results.

in the future demetria wishes to expand the business and buy innovative tools which will allow her to make more furniture in record time. for this reason she approached kiva partner mfp to ask for a new loan so she can achieve this long-awaited dream. this will be her second loan and she is greatly looking forward to help from donors so that she can develop her business. with the 2,000 soles demetria will buy tools so that she can work more efficiently.

maria is a married woman with four children. she is a very hard-working entrepreneur.

maria has a water dispensing business in the philippines. she requested a php 12,000 loan amount through nwtf to purchase more drinking water to sell retail.

maria has been in this business for ten years. in the future, she would like to to expand her business.

patricia, 42 years old, is a hard-working and honest woman who earns a living from a store. she has been in the business for 16 years, which have gone very well for her. she is partnered and the mother of 2 children, ages 12 and 20.  this is the 2nd time that she is getting a loan from the kiva members, she asks for the money to purchase rice, sugar, beans, and toilet paper and, so, to achieve her goal which is to build an enclosing wall.

catalina, 38, is from chinandega but currently lives in granada.  she’s married and the mother of three children who are still in her care.  she’s a merchant; she has a grocery store.  she completed elementary school.

she started her business two years ago after having a bad experience with he first marriage.  she was left a single mother so she decided to go to costa rica in search of a better life for her and her children. she worked for a time with a family as a domestic employee.  she left that job and started selling ‘buñuelos’ [fried flour tortilla sprinkled with sugar and cinnamon] and fried fast food and saved some of what she earned from that business to return to nicaragua and open her own business.  she left her current husband in costa rica because she met him there because they worked together.  she returned to nicaragua.

shortly after opening her business, catalina saw the need of injecting more products into it due to high customer demand.  she took out loans in financial institutions in order to get working capital.  she’s now been in the grocery store business for two years and she gets support from her husband and her children.

she also gets additional income because her husband travels to costa rica during good work seasons and sends her stipends that she invests in the grocery store.

catalina is taking out the loan to buy basic staple items like bread, cookies, milk, oil, sugar and to buy assorted soft-drinks that she feels will help her satisfy customer demand with products in highest demand and will expand the business.

kebbeh is 49 years old and lives in gardnersville. she is married, her husband is not working, and they have four children. only one is attending school and lives at home. 

she has been selling pepper, coal, palm oil, etc. she started this business with money given to her by her husband, and she learn this way of selling from her mother-in-law. 

she is requesting a loan to purchase more pepper, coal, palm oil, etc. for her business. her plans is to build her shop.

darlin yanet owns a grocery store business.  she has been in this business for more than six years.  she started out with her own funds as she didn't have enough income to support her family (her children are in her care).  every day she gets up early to start serving her customers.  the loan that she is requesting is for buying candies, soft drinks, bread, cookies and basic grains.

mary is a married woman and lives with her husband and two children. she owns a house that has neither electricity or piped water. her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

for the past three years, she has operated a charcoal selling business. she sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. her major challenge is the high cost of transportation. 
with the kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of charcoal for resale. she decided to join to yehu to access loans to boost her business.

alberto is a man who has a keen desire to get ahead in life; from day to day he works as a moto taxi driver, a job in which he works hard every day as he relies on it to earn money to support his family.\r\n\r\nalberto is grateful for the help given by the kiva loan lenders as it is thanks to their help that he will be able to buy a fridge to keep food for longer. this will improve his quality of life and he will continue to fight to make his greatest dream a reality, that of having a car and generating other forms of income.

ngome is a married man and he has been running a business selling clothes. ngome is a father of seven children, all of whom attend school. he is a self-made man and wants to live his life with integrity.

he very carefully selected his business as he wanted to have a profitable business. so he started a business of clothes trading, thinking that he could easily do it in his house. this business really turned out to be a profitable one as men and women from the surrounding community started purchasing clothes from him. with the support of yehu microfinance, he has gradually improved his business.

currently he has requested a loan of kes 30,000 to purchase more variety of clothes in many colors and designs, considering the choice of his customers. he expects a gain in his net income and wishes to utilize part of the profits on the expansion of his business. he is thankful to yehu microfinance for its support.

caroline is a 32-year-old married woman. she has three children. she describes herself to be focused. she operates a retail business where she sells drinks, cooking fat, sugar, wheat flour, bread, washing soap and other household items. she has been involved in this business for four years. her business is located in a vibrant location and her primary customers are of all types. \r\n\r\ncaroline describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of capital to expand the business. she will use the kes 100,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, wheat flour, cooking fat, drinks and other items she sells. her business goal is to own a wholesale business within five years. she hopes that in the future, she will own a pickup to ease delivery of her products. this is her fifth loan with smep dtm. her previous loans were paid successfully. she will use the anticipated profits to expand her shop to wholesale.

\r\nmichelle is a married woman from panglao, bohol.  she has a five year-old daughter. she has been in the hog raising  business for three years. michelle plans to use the loan to purchase additional piglets, feeds and pig supplements. each month, she earns four thousand pesos by doing the hog raising business.  in the future, michelle would like to expand her business to support the schooling of her daughter.

eunice is a widowed woman. she has three children with ages ranging from 3 years to 18 years. she describes herself to be ambitious. 

she operates a tailoring business where she makes clothes. she has been involved in this business for eight years. her business is located in a developing area and her primary customers are daily. she describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of finances. 

she will use the kes 50,000 loan to buy a stock of tailoring materials. her business goal is to have a big tailoring shop that will serve many customers within 5 years. she hopes that in the future, the business will be stable and will sustain her family. 

this is her second loan with smep micro finance bank. her previous loan was repaid successfully. she will use the anticipated profits to repay the loan.

buyan r. is 33 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in mongolia's bayanhongor province. he and his family live together in a ger, a traditional mongolian nomadic tent. his daughter attends a local primary school. buyan operates a clothes trading business out of two different containers in his town with the help of his wife. they began their business in 2006, selling a variety of clothing items in a rented container at the local market, with working capital of 1,500,000 mnt, and over the years they managed to establish a successful business in the local community. after years of stable operation, they have expanded their business, and their earnings have enabled them to purchase two containers which they sell their products from. today their working capital exceeds 6,000,000 mnt. with their business earnings, they were able to not only expand their business but also greatly improve their quality of life. also, with their business success, they have managed to buy a car for their family. for the future, they plan to build a house in their yard. buyan is a talkative and open-minded man and is requesting a 1,500,000 mnt loan in order to purchase more clothing as well as consumer goods to sell from his two containers. \t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\r\n

gulchekhra m. has no education, and was a housewife for many years. in 1994, she started her business with selling perfume.  her last loan was used for adding other kinds of goods. when she goes to buy more goods, her children sell at her workplace. her husband is unemployed, but he helps her with the housework. now they are reconstructing their house. her current loan request will be used to install shelves, as she has expanded the assortment of her goods, and she needs to make her workplace more functional.

juana sell basic food items in her grocery store. she has been doing this for many years and it is the main income and sustenance for her family. juana is requesting a loan to buy merchandise like rice, sugar, oil, pasta, milk, etc. to increase the working capital of her business.

evangeline is 29 years old and married with three children, two of whom are in school, evangeline works very hard to provide for them.

she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 10,000 loan through nwtf to purchase additional stocks like soap, shampoo, sugar, etc. to sell.

evangeline has been in this business for 9 years.

she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

dagvasuren is a 46-year-old married man who lives with his wife and daughter in a ger, a traditional mongolian felt tent, in the ger district of ulaanbaatar city, mongolia. this district lacks basic infrastructure.

he has been working as a minivan driver since 1992. as of 2010, he owns a minivan. currently he operates his business with special help from his wife. they have one daughter and their daughter attends a local institute. 

the family decided to build a new house in their yard. dagvasuren is requesting 1,400,000 mongolian tugriks (mnt) to purchase some construction materials, which he will use for fundamental work for their new house.

ameena baji is the wife of r. a. and lives in a city named lahore, pakistan. lahore city is famous for its historical places and for its punjabi food. she has been living in this city for the last 30 year. she lives with her family in a two -room brick house. she is the mother of three daughters. all of her daughters are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood.

\r\n\r\nameena baji's husband has a business of helmet-selling. her husband chose this work because in pakistan it's compulsory to wear a helmet when riding a motor bike. he has been in this business for the last 20 years. ameena baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. she successfully repaid her first loan from asasah (a microfinance institute in pakistan). now she is applying for a loan to buy more helmets for her husband's business.

ufoma is a 30-year-old single woman. she has sold men's shoes and clothes since 2007. ufoma is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 nigerian naira to purchase more male shoes and clothes to sell. she thanks all kiva lenders.

jade is 52 years old and lives in san vicente bajo, oroquita city, misamis occidental, philippines. he is married with 2 children.

jade works as a fisherman, he and his wife helping each other. jade catches fish and his wife delivers fish to the market. jade has been doing this kind of work for 20 years. he earns php 3,500.00 per month. jade wanted to buy an additional fishing net to double his catch every day. jade requested a loan at gdmpc php 5,000.00 to buy fishing materials.

jade has been a member of gdmpc for  one year. in the future, jade hopes that he will be a member in good standing in gdmpc and that he can buy additional fishing boat.

about gdmpc: gdmpc is one of the most progressive cooperatives in mindanao, philippines. it has seven branches covering the provinces of zamboanga del sur, lanao del norte and misamis occidental. its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

gdmpc people empowering people.

nancy belongs to the maria elena moyano communal bank.

she continues in her work at her grocery store. she's been running this business for a while now, and it's allowed her to continue supporting her family. she continues selling different types of products, such as rice, dried beans, oil, etc. to her clients, who request them of her.

she is a responsible and painstaking person, and it's in this way that she's getting ahead with her family.

she is requesting this loan to buy carbonated beverages, milk, etc.

orbelina is 27 years old. she studied up to the sixth grade in the community school. she married nine years ago. her partner is a hardworking man who works in agriculture. they have two children, aged 8 and 6, who go to school.

orbelina works as a housewife, but she also has a small business: she raises hens. she learned this activity when she was a little girl, because her family worked with that. this is how she now helps her husband, because it has not rained and it is difficult to grow cereals.

orbelina needs this loan to buy hens and animal feed, in order to help her family to overcome this difficult situation.

orbelina dreams of having a better quality of life with his family, and giving her children the opportunity to study and become professionals.

faith is married and has one child. she describes herself to be innovative. for the past ten years, faith has operated a retail business selling maize flour, sugar, bread, soap and other items. her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals.

faith describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate capital. she will use the kes 21,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, flour, bread, milk and other items. she hopes that, in the future, she will own a supermarket.

jasmin is 37 years old and is married with two children who are in school. she and her family survived super typhoon haiyan which swept through the philippines on november 8, 2013, but her business and family home were wiped out. jasmin has been a borrower with nwtf since 2011. 

jasmin is requesting a 7,980 php loan to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor to build a house for her family. she plans to recover from the typhoon through her food vending business. with your help, jasmin can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of super typhoon haiyan. in the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

najma is 27years old, an amazing mother who lives in a small village near multan city. she has two children and she is working hard to ensure a good life for them and ensure that they do not need anything. najma’s husband is responsible to fulfill the needs of the entire family, but he cannot cover all the needs of his family. she wants to help him in any way she can because she is a very productive and hardworking woman, so she decided to open her own tailoring business.

najma started her business 10 years ago. she sews clothes to sell. after she felt that she had a good experience in this business, she decided to expand and develop her work. therefore, she applied for a loan to help her buy a new sewing machine, yarns and fabrics to increase her income.
she needs your support to achieve her dreams.

najma and her family will be thankful to kiva, its lenders and field partner brac pakistan for helping them by funding this loan to improve their living standards.

with one child under her care, makou is a 47-year-old married woman, who lives and works in tokoin. she works selling used clothing.

makou procures her merchandise twice a month from the market and makes her resales from a stall at the market and from her home.

she is seeking this loan to make an order for bales of used clothing, as a way to earn higher profits. this will allow her to cover the daily expenses and provide her child with good living conditions.

aminata f. is married. she will use this loan to buy cloth which she will make into dresses and then sell. she also plans to make traditional incense to sell. in this way she will improve her family's living conditions.

translated from french by laure kwon, kiva volunteer

juana is a member of the dúo pastores group. thanks to god, she continues selling used american clothing (a bale), and she is happy about it. with her son's help, it is going well, which is why she can go to different places around where she lives; she already has her clientele in certain areas. in addition to selling clothing, she also sells fish on the days she doesn't sell clothes.

she has been able to move forward with her business and thus provide a good lifestyle for her family. juana does not have a husband, which is why she is thankful for the support that kiva has given her through the loan.

ferisina is married with four adult children. she has been in active farming for over 15 years. her farm produces mainly bananas which she sells to the local market.

ferisina has requested a loan of 35,000 kenyan shillings from juhudi kilimo to help her buy fertilizer and pay the farmhand working on the farm. she wishes to start an irrigation system in order to expand her acreage for bananas and horticultural farming. ferisina points to poor local markets and inadequate capital as major challenges.

emilia works hard to support her family. she is married and has a business raising livestock in the philippines.

she requested a php 15,000 loan through nwtf to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

she successfully repaid her previous loan, and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

emilia would like to save money to expand her business to secure the future of her family.

at age 31, kpenangni clémentine lives with her husband and is the mother of three children, two of whom go to school. the oldest is nine years old and the youngest is two.\r\nfor years, she has owned a shop in which she sells cookies and candy. she gets her supplies from one of benin’s markets. desirous to increase her sales and to strengthen her business, she requested and obtained a micro-loan from finadev, with the objective to meet consumer demand and to increase her supplemental revenues.\r\nthe additional profit will allow her to participate to paying her children’s school expenses and to help her husband finish building their house, which is currently under construction.

mbaye mactar a. is 45 years old and a family man. for more than ten years he has worked as a furniture maker producing beds, wardrobes and other items of household furniture. his workshop is set up in his house. he has been a member of the credit union for 12 months and has benefitted from several loans to strengthen his business. with this requested loan he will develop his business by increasing his production capability through the purchase of a large quantity of wood.

translated from french by alison dent, kiva volunteer

bassiratou c. was born in 1977 in lomé (golfe prefecture). she is married and the mother of two children with another child in her care. she sells various goods in her district in lomé. the income from her husband does not allow him to entirely support the family. and so, most expenses are taken over by ms. c.. this is possible thanks to the income from her commerce.

but to be effective in this role, she needs more substantial funds for bolstering her commerce. this is why she is requesting a loan as working capital to buy and sell her various goods. strengthening this business is going to enable the family to rise above daily difficulties.

translated from french by daniel kuey, kiva volunteer

madame c. bassiratou est née en 1977 à lomé (préfecture du golfe). elle est mariée et mère de deux (2) enfants avec un enfant à sa charge. elle est revendeuse de divers produits dans son quartier à lomé. le revenu financier de son mari ne permet pas de supporter toutes les charges de la famille. ce qui fait que la majorité de ces charges sont prises en compte par madame c.. ceci est possible grâce aux revenus de son commerce.

mais pour jouer efficacement ce rôle, elle a besoin des moyens financiers plus consistants pour renforcer son commerce. c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite un crédit qui va lui servir de fonds de commerce pour l’achat et la revente de ses divers produits. le renforcement de cette activité va permettre à la famille de sortir des difficultés quotidiennes.

fazirra is a 30-year-old married lady blessed with 2 children living in fort portal, uganda. \r\n\r\nshe has a business of selling clothes and has been in this business for a period of 6 years. she started with capital from the gratuity of her late father. she is challenged with low capital which is a hindrance to her goal of buying land and building her dream house. she has asked for a loan to help her buy more clothes to sell.

adela is 50 years old. she lives in a common law marriage with her husband with whom she has two children. she lives in the area of san pedro sula, cortes. she has 16 years of experience running her own grocery store business where she sells sugar, flour, butter, eggs, bread, coffee, milk, pasta, cleaning products, sodas, candies and other goods. her husband works completing tailoring jobs at the same time.

by now adela has obtained five loans from odef to keep her business active. currently she is seeking another loan of $1,300 to purchase more products in bulk, such as sodas; sacks of sugar, rice and flour; boxes of butter; cleaning products; meats and dairy. with this loan she hopes to obtain more earnings and to be able to help her husband with the expenses of their home. her goal for the future is start another separate business in order to increase her income.

doña ibérica is a 32 year-old single mother from the annex roma, she studied secondary, has a 10 year-old daughter who is in fourth grade, elementary school; she lives in the annex roma, provincia de ascope la libertad – peru. for two years she has been selling groceries at a street corner and meat from the main avenue close to her home. she received her first loan of s/.300 from manuela ramos in 2007 and it was invested in groceries. she is a member of “banco comunal romanas luchadoras ii”. with the loan of s/.800, to be repaid in 4 months, she will invest in implementing her stand. doña ibérica dreams of having her own big business close to her home in order to attend to her daughter and improve her income and living conditions.

translated from spanish by lene struck, kiva volunteer.

\r\n\r\nla señora ibérica esta madre soltera, tiene 32 años, natural del anexo roma, cursó estudios secundarios, tiene 01 hija de 10 años la cual cursa el cuarto grado de primaria; vive en el anexo roma provincia de ascope la libertad – perú. ella se dedica hace dos años a la venta de abarrotes en una esquina y carnes en la avenida principal, cerca de su domicilio. se inició con manuela ramos desde el año 2007 concediéndole un primer préstamo de s/.300.oo, lo invirtió en la compra de abarrotes. pertenece al banco comunal “romanas luchadoras ii”, con el préstamo de s/. 800.oo, el cual será cancelado en 04 meses; lo invertirá en la implementación de su puesto. la señora ibérica sueña tener un local grande y propio cerca de su casa para poder atender a su hija y mejorar sus ingresos y condiciones de vida.

sithav’s group live in a rural village in kandal province in cambodia. sithav makes a living cultivating rice and she also does extra work as factory worker to support her family. in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

naneth is a 45-year-old farmer from trinidad, bohol. she is a married woman with four young children.\r\n\r\nnaneth has been in the rice farming business with her husband for more than six years now. by working on the rice farm, she helps her husband to meet the needs of their family, especially of the schooling of their children.

as parents, donna and her husband, joselito, must be responsible in developing a good family, particularly in terms of their physical, emotional, social and spiritual aspects, said donna tulod. donna is a hard-working mother and entrepreneur in the village of tuao north, bagabag, nueva vizcaya. she has three children: asear, jonna mae and jonna marie, who are all studying. the eldest is in college, while the last two are still in elementary school.

donna works selling barbecue and vegetables in their barangay (village) from a table in front of their house, where she displays her products daily. from her business, donna usually earns an average income of php1,000 weekly, which is utilized for their immediate daily needs and for the allowances of her children. but according to her, this is not enough to finance the school needs of her children since education nowadays is very costly. therefore, she hopes to strengthen her business in order to increase her income for the schooling of her children. due to a lack of financial capital, donna is now asking for financial assistance amounting to php10,000, which she will use for the improvement of her vending business.

marivic is 36 years old and married with three children who are in school. marivic works very hard to provide for them.

she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 15,000 loan through nwtf to buy items to sell like canned goods, personal care products, etc.

marivic has been in this business for three years.

in the future, marivic would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

laxmi is 47 years old. she is married and has four children, ages 29, 26, 23 and 20. 

many years ago, laxmi established her grocery store business. working seven days a week and 12 hours a day, she supports her family. she has already received and successfully repaid seven loans from patan bpw and used her most recent to buy grocery goods for her business.

 in the future, laxmi plans to uplift the economic conditions of her family. she thanks you for your support.
