in the kathmandu valley, small grocery stores called pasals are an important part of the local economy. fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. owners of small grocery stores use kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. by keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. while a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

elvira is 44 years old, widowed, and has four children. as she says, being a single parent is very difficult, but elvira still does her best just to lift her family from poor living. to make a living, elvira owns and operates a food stall. she has been engaged in her business for more than one year and earns approximately 6,000 php a month for these activities. 

now, she is requesting a loan of php 10,000 to purchase meat and vegetables to cook and sell. elvira plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

as a married parent of four children, julieta works hard to support her family.

she has a bakery business in the philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs. julieta is borrowing php 10000 through nwtf to buy additional ingredients like flour, sugar etc. and other supplies needed in her business for her bakery business.

julieta has been sustaining her business activities through her past 8 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

nillecil is 28 years old and lives in danao, plaridel. she is married with 4 children. nillecil works in the fishing industry, catching and selling fish for a living. she has been doing this for 5 years. 

she has requested a loan of 15,000 php to purchase gasoline, hooks, and maintenance for the pump boats. nillecil has been a member of pmpc for 7 years. in the future, she hopes to save more for the education of her children.

lila, who is 39, is separated and has five children, three who are of school age. she now belongs to the group "el esfuerzo es grande" (the effort is great), which consists of 10 hard-working women who work in different commercial activities. lila is a hard-working mother who with much effort has managed to progress. she now works as a seamstress, with the greatest number of her customers being neighbors from her zone. as a second business, she offers fast food (fried snacks) every weekend. her greatest desire is to see her children have careers. the loan that she applied for will be used for the purchase of fabrics, scissors, threads, and needles. to continue improving her sewing business is another great wish. the group "el esfuerzo es grande" is grateful to the people who make this loan possible. lila is seated; she is the first one on the right side and is wearing a pink sweater..

queen sells foodstuffs like rice and other items. she lives in benin city. she is 31 years old and married with 5 children. she hopes for the loan amount of n50000 to purchase more foodstuffs and other items to sell. she thanks all her lenders.

lorna is a 50-year-old widow with three children. she resides at poblacion, lopez jaena, misamis occidental province, the philippines. lorna owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products to earn a living.  she's been 8 years in this business. each month, she earns php 4,000 doing this type of business. she requested a loan of php 5,000 to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps, etc. in 2010, lorna joined gdmpc. in the future, lorna wants to build a house and to complete her children's education. \r\n

jumagul s. lives in the asht region and she is married with three children. she has only been a client of microinvest since 2008 but has showed herself to be a serious client. she is engaged in the family business of livestock. she works also works on a collective farm. mrs. s. dreams of buying a pedigree bull to increase her livestock. so she is applying with kiva with the request of financial support for her business's development with a loan of 2100 stj for 6 months. mrs. s. thanks kiva for its support.

diaselvia is 27 years old and live in badian, cebu. she has two children aged five and seven.

for two years, she has been selling snacks like fruit, candies, biscuits and chips. she is asking for a loan of php 6,000 to buy more stocks of fruit, biscuits, chips and candies.

in the future, she hope to have a big sari-sari (general) store for a better revenue. her income will be utilized for her children's school fees.

maria lives with her 9 children in a humble home which she built with great effort with her husband, who is now deceased. she is a hardworking woman who fights to move her children forward with their education. for more than a year, maria has made a living by selling meat, chicken, and fish in communities far from the river. 

this is her second loan and she would like to purchase a freezer in order to keep her meat products fresh. there is no running potable water in the community, so residents drink water from the river. there are also no health centers; the closest health center is three hours away by motor boat.

she mentions that she is fortunate to receive loans from visionfund because she has been able to grow her business and provide more products to her customers.

maria rosalie is 39 years old and married with four children.  with four children in school, maria rosalie works very hard to provide for them.

maria rosalie runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 15000 loan through nwtf to buy items to sell like beverages, canned goods, home product care.

maria rosalie has been in this business for 6 years and sells a variety of items. 

in the future, maria rosalie would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

this member continues to manage her hardware business where she sells paints, nails, and tools. she works from 8:00 a.m to 6:00 p.m. the member has been in business for 10 years and it has enabled her to help her children get ahead. her dream is to expand her hardware business, so she is requesting a loan to buy nails, paints, and tools.

she is pleased with the loan and promises to complete her payments.

razia is a 39-year-old active borrower of brac pakistan. she lives in rawalpindi, pakistan. she is a mother of five daughters. her husband has been doing a scrap recycling business.

razia's husband needs to buy scrap material in bulk to recycle but due to some financial constraints, he is not in a suitable position to buy the scrap in bulk. therefore, razia has applied for a kiva loan from its field partner brac pakistan. this loan amount will enable her husband to purchase the scrap material in bulk so that her husband can easily adopt the recycling procedure and earn a profitable income derived from his business.

razia is very thankful to kiva and brac pakistan for this financial assistance.

herilyn, a 28-year-old married woman with five children, resides in pangabuan, tangub city, philippines.

herilyn owns a fishpond and operates a business venture selling seafood products, including crabs and shrimp, in the local community to earn a living.

in business for nine years, each month herilyn earns 15,000 philippine pesos (php). a member of gdmpc for one year, she has requested a loan of 15,000 php to buy more shrimp and crabs to sell.

in the future, herilyn wants to build a house and have her children complete their studies.

rachelle is a sari-sari store owner, where she sells a variety of goods. she is 39 years old and a married woman. she has three children, ages 17, 9, and 7 years old, who need her support. they live in a town of concepcion, iloilo. rachelle has been running her store for seven years to earn income. it is the business that helps them sustain themselves every day.

thus, she hopes to improve this business in the future for their sustainability and for her children’s education. she wants them to finish their studies and have better lives in the future. for this, she is requesting a loan for additional capital to buy stock for her store such as canned goods, noodles, eggs, cooking oil, spices, snack foods, mosquito repellent, drinks and other commodities.

karol yaritza: is originally from puerto cabezas, she has miskita ethnicity, she is 23, married with two children. the oldest kid is eight years old and in third grade of elementary school, the little girl is two years old.  she is requesting her first loan to expand her residence of metal and wood.  with the loan she will be able to buy wood, nails and cover labor expenses.  her dream is to provide her family with a safer residence in good conditions.

at the age of 46, razia is a vigorous married lady. she has two children. eight years ago she started a business selling cloth in her locality. she always has a great collection to offer, and by now she has gained a good number of customers by selling good-quality fabric. razia has earned a good income to bear her household expenditures. in order to meet the increasing demands of her customers, she has applied for a loan of 40,000 pkr. with the help of this loan, she will be able to purchase bundles of good-quality fabric. it will allow her to increase her sales to earn a good profit.

nora works hard to support one child. she is married and has a pig-fattening business in the philippines.

nora requested a 5,000 php loan through nwtf to invest in a sanitary toilet.

nora is aware that by using the sanitary toilet, she is not only saving money, but also helping the environment and reducing health risks to her family.

as a married parent of four children, rose works hard to support her family.

she has an e-loading business in the philippines, and she also earns additional income from buying and selling cosmetic products, direct selling and fish vending.

rose is borrowing php 30,000 through nwtf to purchase additional electronic load cards to sell.

she successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

rose has been sustaining her business activities through her past eight loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

mwanamisi is a single woman blessed with three children, all attend school. she lives at her own house that is without electricity and running water. her greatest monthly expense is school fees.
mwanamisi has sold poultry for one year. the business is challenged by diseases which affect the poultry.

she wants to purchase chicks and poultry feed. she joined yehu to access loans to improve her business.

as a married parent of five children, hideliza works hard to support her family.

she has a buy-and-sell dry goods business in the philippines and also earns additional income from a general store. hideliza is borrowing php 15,000 through nwtf to buy more dry goods to sell for her buy-and-sell dry goods business.

hideliza has been sustaining her business activities through her past eight loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so that she could afford to send her children to college.

silvia, age 39, lives in the villa venezuela neighborhood.  she is married, and her husband works as a taxi driver.  they have two children, age 10 and 19, and the children go to school.

she sells used clothes and cosmetics at her house.  at times she goes with her husband to sell in the departments.  she does this in order to manage to balance the expenses with the sales.

this is the first loan that silvia has requested from afodenic.  she will use the loan to invest in her business with a variety of clothes and shoes.  this investment will help her quite well to improve her family’s finances a bit.

this is lerma, wife of maximo. she manages a tailoring shop that has been running for more than 23 years. she makes school and company uniforms and whatever else her customers request, like skirts, blouses, pants, and the like. also, she has an apartment that she rents out for fixed monthly rates.

lerma is very thankful that her previous loan request was granted. that paved way for her to have more orders for her tailoring business. for her business to continue to flourish, she is applying for a loan amounting to 25,000 php. she will use this loan to purchase additional supplies, such as textiles and thread. a portion of this loan will also be used for the maintenance of her apartment, specifically for repairs to the roof and floor in order to prepare for the upcoming rainy season.

lerma’s utmost goal is to be able to provide for the daily needs of her family, especially now that she has grandchildren. she never stops thinking of ways to earn a consistent living. she wants her grandchildren to finish college in their chosen courses to make sure that they have a bright future ahead of them.

* all cct community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 20 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

teresa is a married woman, 59 years old, with ten children. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

teresa has a fish vending business in the philippines. she requested a php 10,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy more fresh fish to sell and other materials needed including plastic bags and boxes for her fish.

teresa has been in this business for 10 years. she would like to save money to expand her business.

nonata s. owns a small sari sari store. why "sari-sari"? because it is the filipino local term for "variety" or "sundry shop". she sells dry goods, soaps, vinegars, rice, shampoo and other products in her village. people come in to buy their needs. nonata is 27 years old and married to julito s.. they have one child. she previously worked as an avon lady, a person who sells avon fashion products.

nonata is requesting a loan of 11,000 pesos from cevi. she will use the loan to buy more goods for her store. in this way, she believes she will attract more customers. her loan will be a big help in her business expansion. her business feeds her family. she needs to sustain it more for the future of her family.

cevi is helping its clients sustain and expand their businesses. all cevi clients receive credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage.

this is mary, 60, a resident of dasmariñas, cavite, philippines. she is married to vicente, a driver, and is a mother to her children. she, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. at this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

mary oversees operations of their jeepney transportation business. 

jeepneys were first used by american soldiers helping the philippines throw off the invading japanese. filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn, and modified the jeep into a 20-seater jeepney, open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy for everyday travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. now, the jeepneys are one of the things that makes the philippines truly philippines. 

mary has one jeepney (14-16 person capacity). her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. she earns a minimum of php 1,000 every day.

to help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a php 8,000 loan. she will be using the loan to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of her jeepney unit.

mary dreams to have a good life with her family. she faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of god she studies. 

* all cct community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

virginia is a 53-year-old widow who has 4 children. she is from campo 4, ramon magsaysay, zamboanga del sur. virginia is engaged in farming on a monggo (mung beans) plantation in her community. she has been doing this for many years to earn a living. she works hard in order to provide for the needs of her children. she is asking for a loan from gdmpc in the amount of 12,000 php to purchase additional fertilizers for her monggo plantation. virginia wishes to uplift her livelihood to have enough money to improve their living conditions and to send her children to school.

plinh is the head of his family, so it is a big responsibility on him to find income to support his family. at present, he is a construction worker in siem reap province. all the people there know that he is very talented and has good creative ideas. he can earn about $4 per day. if we talk about his wife, she isn't a lazy woman. she is a farmer and also a housekeeper. she also earns perhaps $1.50 per day. they would like to borrow $500 to purchase chickens to raise.

omar learned the recycling trade from his parents, who were always engaged in this type of business. he has extensive experience in this line of work, which has allowed him to succeed. omar is separated from the mother of his three children, so he is responsible for maintaining the expenses of his family. for this reason, he works hard in his business. omar's recycling business is a major source of income and he has been able to get ahead due to his great experience. he is eager to purchase some more materials, so omar is taking this opportunity to access a loan for acquiring recyclable products that are being offered at a very low price. \r\n

\r\nby acquiring these products, omar will increase his profit margin because of the low price that he is paying. he also hopes that continued growth and more income will result in his children having a better quality of life.

katherine is one of the members of the “empresarial” group.  she’s single and 20-years-old and is living in her aunt’s house.  katherine works selling vegetables.  she started the business thanks to her aunt who taught her how to be a merchant.  she leases a stand in her local market where she sells all types of vegetables and tubers.  her work is very demanding.  she must rise at dawn every day to buy fresh products at good prices.  her best customers are housewives who buy from her daily.  in the afternoon she studies and her work covers those costs.  katherine wants to have a bigger business and will use the loan towards that end, to buy vegetables at wholesale and earn higher income.  katherine is grateful to all kiva lenders for supporting her business and allowing her to continue to make progress.  in the photo, katherine appears wearing pink pants and a gray shirt. on the right hand side is sr. filiberto wearing jeans and a light blue shirt.

elma is 36 years old and married with seven children. with five children still in school, elma works very hard to provide for them.

elma runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 9,000 loan through nwtf to buy items to sell such as beverages, bread, canned goods, junk foods, home care products, and other groceries.

elma has been in this business for eight years and sells a variety of items such as shampoo, soy sauce, coffee, etc.

in the future, elma would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

for the last 3 years mrs. lelia has been a member of the community bank "manuela ramos” in the santa rosa district, el collao province, state of puno. she is 23 years old, has a partner and one child. she finished high school and is dedicated to the purchase and sale of clothing and blankets.

lelia tells us that with the first loan requested to the manuela ramos group, which was for 300 nuevos soles; she was able to increase her working capital.

she is requesting a loan of $ 700 which she will invest in the purchase of clothing in bulk. her dream is to work better and increase her working capital and profits. what she likes the most about the community bank is the savings.

translated from spanish by adriana pierce, kiva volunteer

abdullo n.  has been an active client of the microinvest since 2007. the business development and profit increases have helped him to return the previous loans and  develop his business significantly. mr. abdullo n.  is 59 years old and he lives in the asht region and has a family of 6 children. he has been engaged in his business for 15 years. he started the business from his household and he now trades from an outlet in furnishings, towels and other items. he has many customers because he is one of the most respected men on the collective farm. abdullo applies to kiva for  help. he requests a loan to increase and improve his business by importing new goods. mr. n. abdullo requires a loan of 2800 tjs for 10 months. he thanks kiva for the support that kiva presents to  small entrepreneurs.

purity is a married woman. she describes herself to be god fearing. she operates a farm where she grows bananas, mangoes, and other crops. she has been involved in this business for four years. her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. she will use the kes 75,000 loan to buy farm inputs to boost production. previous loans were repaid successfully.

mareme s. is a 55 year old woman, married, and responsible for six children, two of whom attend school. she has been a member of the banc villageois of the city of escale for the past seven years. she has been selling beauty products and dyed textiles for the past five years, and has gained good experience in this activity. profits from the sales allows her to improve the living conditions and health of her family and ensure that her children are able to receive an education.\r\n\r\n

translated from french by chloe tuot, kiva volunteer

hemila is 56 years old, married, and has five children. three of these children are already grown up and two of them are still dependents. hemila and her family live in a small town of catigbian, bohol where her husband is a chainsaw operator and hemila does a hog raising business. she has been doing this to help her husband support the needs of their children. with this, she is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy piglets and feed. in the future, she plans to improve their business for sustainability.

maria is 47 years old and is married. she lives with her husband and their three children who are between the ages of 7 and 23, and currently attend school. since she is a good mother she wants to improve her family's living condition. for the past seven years she has owned a stationary store  that has provided necessary income for her household. because of her great service and kindness to her customers she has stood out among the competition. she has been able to grow her customer base, which is why she wants to maintain her business. however, she needs to purchase notebooks, pens, poster boards and erasers in bulk, which are much needed items for her stationary store. her main goal is to educate her children because she knows that it will be the foundation for their success.

adela is 45, married to a driver and they're blessed with two children. she has owned and managed a retail store in their village for almost 14 years and earns a net income of 1,000 php daily. due to insufficient capital in her business, she would like to avail a loan amounting to 50,000 php to purchase fabric and materials needed for her tailoring business. she's hoping that her business will continue to improve and become more profitable.

efrena has been running a piggery for more than three years to supplement her husband's income. she raises pigs and sells them in volume and earns well for her family. efrena successfully repaid a previous loan from gdmpc for her piggery. 

efrena is requesting a loan to purchase pig feed as she has been expanding her business. she hopes that continued success in her business will allow her to care for her family.

mr. d. is a craftsman who is specialized in canvas work and who does business at moussanté, the main market in thiès. in his workshop, he has a few machines that he uses to sew handbags. the finished products are transported for sale to the capital, dakar, and the rest are sent to his brother in gambia. as is the case with all businesses of this type, one must be able to acquire the raw materials necessary to be able to fill all of the orders.

translated from french by kristina jackson, kiva volunteer.

mr d. est un artisan spécialisé dans la tapisserie dans le grand marché de « moussanté » à thiès. il dispose dans son atelier de quelques machines avec lesquelles il coud les sacs à mains. le produit fini est acheminé dans la capitale dakar où une bonne partie est écoulée et le reste est envoyé chez son frère en gambie. comme dans toutes les activités de ce genre, il faut pouvoir assurer l’acquisition de matières premières pour pouvoir honorer les commandes.

eva is a very hard working  married woman charged  with the responsibility of taking care of two children and all attend school in hoima uganda.\r\n\r\nshe ventured into the selling of men's clothes alongside farming,whereby she anticipates to generate a lot of income to support her family. she hopes to expand her business and also educate her children. she is seeking for a loan facility to buy more clothes for sell. sell.

eduardo n. is from the town of banga. he is 48 years old. eduardo is married and has four school-aged children. to make a living, eduardo owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. eduardo works hard to sustain his children's education. he wishes them to finish college someday and be working professionals.

eduardo joined cevi to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. eduardo is requesting a new loan of 6,000 php, which will be used to purchase sacks of seeds and fertilizers. he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for his children's tuition fees.

fouzia is responsible woman with 3 children. she lives in rawalpindi, pakistan. her husband has provided taxi transportation services for 18 years. her husband is responsible to meet the needs of the entire family. he needs to maintain his taxi because it requires more maintenance on a daily basis.

due to insufficient finances, her husband is unable to maintain his taxi. fouzia has applied to kiva for a loan from its field partner brac pakistan. this loan will help fouzia's husband to easily afford the maintenance costs and provide better transportation services.

fouzia also plans to save the profit to meet her family's needs in future.

fouzia is very grateful to kiva and brac pakistan.

margarita isabel m. d. r., 40, lives in soyapango with her husband and two children who are 3 and 6 years of age and go to the local kindergarten. margarita has a stand where she sells spices like: oregano, various types of seeds, dehydrated chilies and all sorts of products used to improve the flavor of foods. her store is insid. soyapango’s market and she has several regular customers. margarita has an enormous wish to increase her sales greatly so that she can provid. more for her home. this is why she’s asking for a loan with which to by larger quantities and varieties of spices to offer at accesible prices thus increasing her income.

translated from spanish by michael bujazan, kiva volunteer

maría is 49 years old. she appears in the picture with her grandchildren. she is married and her husband works as a guard in an evangelical church, which is located near their house.

maría works making and selling tortillas. she has many years of experience doing this activity, which she learned from her mother. she wakes up early in the morning to wash the corn, cook it, take it to the corn mill to obtain the dough and make the tortillas. besides that she sells pupusas (a thick corn tortilla stuffed with cheese, fried pork rind, chicken, or refried beans) on the weekends. her current working schedule is from 5:00 am to 1:00 pm.

thanks to the previous kiva loan she was able to invest in her business. she is a hardworking woman and she has already paid her debt entirely. now she is requesting a new loan to buy corn and gas to continue with her business selling tortillas.

she wishes to see her grandchildren grow and give them all the support that they need. she also hopes to expand her business so she can have greater profits.

ahmad is a young, ambitious guy with willpower. he is 26 years old and lives with his family in a sector of jordan \u200ecalled ajloun. since his childhood ahmad has carried responsibilities of his family, and he used to work to help his \u200efather in the food supplies shop. he has good experience in trade and likes what he does. he did not \u200ecomplete his education, because of the financial situation of his family. when his father saw in him the willpower \u200ethat would lead him to be a good entrepreneur, he sold his shop to ahmad.  the dream became true, and he owns a mini-market for the food supplies.  the second step for ahmad was to apply \u200efor a loan, to help him buy new food supplies and new products, such as soft drinks, candy, and snacks. this will help him to expand \u200eand develop his business, to increase his income.\u200e

isatu is 40 years old and has 6 children.  her husband works as a driver but the income is insufficient for their family expenses.  for this reason, isatu is engaged in a small business to earn income for their children.  she sells basic items such as onions, salt, canned fish, and chicken stock cubes.  her inventory has increased with the loans from smt.  isatu meets her loan obligations on time and she is now requesting another loan of $275 to further expand her business.

mrs. bineta g. is a 52 year old widow who lives in ndeugagne in yoff. she is the mother of two children between 21 and 26 years of age. mrs. g. has more than 40 years experience in business. she chose her business because it was the business of the prophet mohammed psl. she went into the sale of beignets and dried fish and by this means her goal is to make a profit and satisfy her personal needs as well as those of her children. mrs. g. has been a member of the yoff credit union since april of 2009. she already received a previous loan. she is requesting a loan of 150,000 francs which will be used to buy dried fish in mauritania. one part of the financing will be used to bolster her beignet sales. the growth of her earnings will enable her to contribute to the improvement of her family’s living conditions.

translated from french by connie archea, kiva volunteer

the cristo rey communal bank includes the following members: teresa rosibel, amparo del socorro, natividad del sscorro, aracelis del socorro, marcia fatima, alicia del socorro, delbis maria, carlos and petronila. they have demonstrated during the course of time they have worked with leon 2000 that they are responsible, hard-working and solvent with their payments. amparo del socorro is the coordinator of the bank. she buys and sells pigs for preparing typical dishes from the area. \r\n

maricel is a businesswoman who earns money through retailing various items. she is a full-fledged member of pmpc and enjoys the benefits of insurance and financial assistance. recently, she applied for a loan to purchase bags of cement and hollow blocks. she is on her way to renovating her house. she wishes to live comfortably with her family.\r\n

cheam m., 56, is married and resides with her husband and three children in takeo province, cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. she and her husband are employed to operate tractors to plow fields for an income of about $5 each per day.  m. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase tractor parts to change out when they are broken. she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  this is her first loan from credit, a long-standing kiva partner in cambodia. m. appears in the photograph showing her house under construction.

nelson, who is 47 years old, is a driver. he operates a motorcycle for transportation services. his wife helps him with his work. they have children who are gradually becoming involved in their business, since at their age, they won't be able to continue working a lot longer. they need rest. nelson and his wife have been hardworking people who keep working and persevering. nelson requests this loan to repair a transport vehicle used in the business in order to keep working as he has been. he thanks gdmpc for their support and says that one of his dearest wishes is for his business to prosper every day so he can continue supporting his children.\r\n

jhanet is 29 years and lives with her partner, who is the father of their 3 children. she learned how to weave as a child. now that she has her own family and is supported by her husband, jhanet sells basic food necessities out of a cramped space inside of her house.

every morning at 5am, she goes to the bakery to purchase warm bread that her customers enjoy. by 6am she is feverishly cleaning her store and preparing it to open for business. this delights her customers, who appreciate her efforts. jhanet learned early on that her customers are the reason for her business. therefore she tries to keep them happy because they allow her to earn household income.

this is jhanet’s second loan with mfp. she enjoys working with her communal bank. they money she is requesting will be used to purchase more merchandise for her grocery store.

translated from spanish by ronan reodica, kiva volunteer

flora is 59 years old, married with five adult age children from pagadian city. she is engaged in direct reselling business of various cosmetics, fragrances, plastic wares and others for eight years and is making good sales out from it. her business is primarily financed by paglaum mpc where is an active member since 20015. recently, she avails a loan to purchase additional stocks of inventories for direct resell.

habila, a babban gona maize farmer, is married and lives in a modest mud house with his family in tashar bakwake village. habila is a meticulous farmer who has invested time and resources in his farm, and like every parent, hopes to see his four children work twice as hard and become successful in the future.

previously, despite toiling for long hours on his farm, habila was only able to feed his family two meals a day. now that he is a babban gona member, habila can improve his yield, and as a result, feed his family through access to high quality inputs, such as fertilizers, herbicides and better yielding seeds.

luckily, as a babban gona member, habila will be provided with a full suite of the best inputs to optimize his farm and increase his yield up to 3.8 metric tonnes per hectare, two times the national average.

with increased yield and income of up to 2.8 times the national average, habila looks forward to using his additional income to pay his children's school fees.

habila is a happy babban gona farmer and holds when he joined babban gona and became a successful farmer as his best memory as a babban gona member. habila looks forward to a brighter future with babban gona, as he too has joined the fight against poverty.

safia works hard to support her family. she is 50 years of age and married. she has 5 children. 

she assists her husband in running a general store at their house. they have been running this store for the past 5 years. most of their income is spent on the well-being of their children. 

she is in her 5th loan cycle. she has requested a loan of 40,000 pkr. this loan will be used to purchase soaps, shampoo and edible items like buns, tea, packed milk etc. 

she wants to earn more income by expanding the business. she will spend it on providing a better standard of living to her family members.

elizabeth is a thirty five years old lady, married, with two children. she joined hand in hand eastern africa in the year 2015 and has benefited from enterprise development and financial management training.

she does maize, beans and potato farming. she is borrowing a kiva loan to buy certified potato seeds so as to improve her potato production. she hopes this will increase her income which she will use to provide food, clothing and pay school fees for her children.

she is grateful to kiva and their lenders for the financial support and promises to repay promptly.

yamah is 42 years old, married, and has 3 children between the ages 12 and 20. she lives in air port area along with her children and husband. her children are in school. for 20 years now, she has been selling bread. she learned how to sell from her mother. she enjoys her business because the business gives her money every day. yamah requested a loan to buy more flour, sugar, butter, and other item for her business. in the future, she wants to build a house.

luzviminda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy and sell of rice business in the philippines. 

she is borrowing php 12,000 through nwtf to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell for her buy and sell of rice business.

luzviminda has been in this business for four years. luzviminda earns more income from buy and sell of rice grains.

she has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from nwtf. she dreams of saving enough to build a house for her family in the future.

rosalie owns and operates a jeepney unit. she has been successful in this business for seventeen years, and she repaid her previous loan used for the business. she also finds ways to improve her income by collecting metal scraps and other fragments to be sold to junk shops.

relative to this, she would like to take a new loan to buy spare parts and accessories for their vehicle. she is requesting an amount of php 25,000 for the maintenance of the jeepney unit to continue operations of her business.

in the future, rosalie hopes to be able to purchase a permit for her trading business, so that she could continually support her children in their studies.

she meets every week with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and to also draw strength and inspiration from the word of god she studies.

* all cct community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

lis is 22 years old. she is single and resides with her mother in takeo province, cambodia. she has been working in a garment factory for more than two years, earning approximately $3 per day. her mother is a rice farmer who makes an income of $1 daily. 

to improve her family’s finances, lis is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a tuk tuk (a motorcycle-based taxi) for her brother to run public transportation service. this purchase will help him generate more income for the family. in the future, she would like to run a grocery store and build a new house, if possible.

carlos is 49 years old and he works for an agro company. he is married with 4 children who attend grade school and he supports 2 of his siblings who live with him in a house that he owns.
he will use this loan to buy cement, stone, sand and metal rods to continue building his home.
his dream is to finish the works and furnish the home and build a store where to sell basic products. he began building his home with his previous loans.
he has some financial difficulties, so he's been working to overcome them and with the help of his wife, who is also an agro factory worker he would like to ask for more loans until they reach their dreams.

jackline is a married woman. she has 3 children with ages ranging from 13 years to 17 years. she describes herself as honest. she operates a restaurant where she sells tea, cooked maize, beans, and other foods. she has been involved in this business for 7 years. her business is located in a relatively good area. she describes her biggest business challenge to be the high cost of food. she will use the 20,000 kes loan to add stock of milk, cooking oil, flour, and other ingredients for making food. her business goal is to have more branches within 5 years.

dinah is 50 years old and married with six children.

dinah works hard to provide for her family. she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a 11,000 php loan through nwtf to buy items like canned goods, personal care products, etc. to sell in her store.

dinah has borrowed and repaid 30 loans from nwtf before. she has been running the general store for 10 years, and she also earns an income from pig-fattening.

dinah aspires to save money to expand her business.

kaitano is 33 years old and lives in the midlands province of zimbabwe. he is married and has one child aged 1. 

kaitano has been in the poultry business for three years. his challenges are the scarcity of feeds and a lack of funds to buy stock in bulk when they are available.

he has applied for us$400 to buy feeds and chicks. with the additional income obtained from his business, kaitano will pay school fees for his three brothers he is looking after.

kaitano plans to own a farm in the near future.

rowena d. is 28 years old and a very good member of kiva partner, ashi. she is also a very responsible mother to her two children, aged six and seven, both of whom are in primary school. rowena’s husband is a hired company driver. he is sweet and loving to her and the children. despite facing poverty and the many adversities it causes, a good relationship with her husband and children is rowena's inspiration and motivation to pursue her dream of giving her children an improved kind of life worth living for.
somehow, rowena wanted to help her husband earn money for their children's future educational expenses until they receive their own bachelor degrees. she joined ashi in 2008 and has been able to set up a hog-fattening business. she fattens hogs in four months and then sells them, either slaughtered or alive, at the market or in her village. after one year, rowena realized that her business profits were quite good and therefore she is requesting a loan to grow her hog-fattening business into a piggery in her backyard.

lenny's smile shows how happy he is to take a step forward in terms of the good hygiene of his home. he's a well operator of 29 years of age and the father of a one year old son. he wants to invest in the sanitation of his home.
to have a better hygiene to keep his wife, child, and himself free of any diseases, lenny is requesting a loan to build a waste water drainage system. this will enable him to achieve his goal of protecting his family. part of his plans is to build his own home since he still lives with his mother.

wilma is 60 years old, married, and a resident of upper bunawan, tudela, philippines. her husband is a tricycle driver. they have two children, both of whom are in school. starting with capitalization of 3,000 php, she opened a sari-sari (general store) and was able to expand it with the help of paglaum cooperative. aside from financial assistance, she was able to generate savings and enjoys the benefit given by the co-op. she became a member in april 2012 and has taken out three loans. now she is applying for 10,000  php to buy additional stocks for her sari-sari store, particularly basic commodities. in the future, she wants to own a mini-mart someday, and will be fully satisfied if she sees her children finish their studies.

rajambo a. lives in the city of qurgan-tube. she is 43 years old, married and has four children. rajambo has finished nursing school and currently works as a nurse at the local hospital. on the side she also manages a small business - a sale stand at the local market, where she sells children's clothes. rajambo wants to purchase school supplies in time for the beginning of the local school year. however, in order to have sufficient funds for the purchase she needs to take out this loan. this loan will enable rajambo to earn money during the back to school sale season. she will use the income to support her family and will also invest in her business. rajambo is planning to pay back the loan in 12 months.

translated from russian by anya lyuksyutova, kiva volunteer.

алназарова раджабмо жительница города курган-тюбе. возраст 43 года . замужем и имеет четверых детей. закончила медицинское училище. работает медсестрой в поликлинике. кроме того занимается мелким бизнесом. работает на базаре. имеет торговую точку , где продает детскую одежду. хочет привезти школьный товар к школьной ярмарке. но для этого сначала она должна получить кредит, который даст ей возможность заработать в сезон школьной продажи. прибыль полученную от торговли использует в хозяйстве , а часть для увеличения бизнеса. погасить кредит планирует в течение 12 месяцев.

flordeliza is 50 years old and married with six children, one of whom is in school. she is a very hard working entrepreneur.   

flordeliza has a business selling ready-to-wear clothing in the philippines. flordeliza requested a php 15,000 loan amount through nwtf in order to buy more curtains, towels, pants, blouses and other ready-to-wear clothing.

flordeliza has been in this business for 13 years. in the future, flordeliza would like to save enough money to expand her business.

alma is a 42-year-old, married woman living at poblacion 3, clarin, misamis occidental in the philippines. she and her husband have eight children.

to earn a living, alma owns and operates a general store, where she sells a variety of different products. she explains that she has been running this business for three years. each month, she earns approximately 5,000 php from her business.

she requested a loan in the amount of 15,000 php to purchase more products for resale purposes. alma became a member of gdmpc in 2011. in the future, alma hopes to help her children finish their studies.

charlita b. is a 55-year-old entrepreneur who runs a business buying and selling slippers. she is a resident of barangay malibabag over peñablanca, cagayan. she wasn’t able to pursue her studies because of their family’s poor living conditions. when she got married she and her husband decided to invest their little capital into her current business. aside from slippers, charlita also sells bags, wallets, and purses to generate income daily.

with her desire to expand the business, she has decided to request a loan of php 6,000. she wishes to utilize the loan wisely so that her business can grow and expand. she hopes to use any extra income to support their children’s education and also hopes to employ others in her business someday.

“with god’s help, we were able to fight the challenges of life and now we can already, at least, sustain the needs of our family with the minimal income of our shop,” ended charlita.

elizabeth is 51 years old and married. she has three children. she works very hard to provide for them.

she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 17,000 loan through nwtf to purchase additional stocks to sell like soap, milk, sugar, noodles, etc.

she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

gemma is a 49-year-old married woman with three children, one of whom is still in school. gemma works very hard to provide for them.

gemma runs a general store in the philippines, and requested a 25,000 php loan through nwtf to purchase additional stock such as coffee, cereal, chocolate drinks, soft-drinks, noodles, shampoo, sanitary pads, etc. to sell.

gemma has been in this business for 4 years, and sells a variety of items. 

gemma would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

bushra is 51 years old and a married mother of four children. her husband is a driver by profession and provides transportation services using his three-wheeled rickshaw. bushra's husband has been driving a rickshaw for many years to meet the family expenses, but now it requires proper maintenance to keep it functional. for this reason, bushra has applied for a loan of 35,000 pkr for her husband. he wants to buy new tires for his rickshaw vehicle.this will help him drive more smoothly and provide better transport service to his passengers. bushra is hopeful that this loan will be a productive one for her husband and will bring positive changes to his business. \r\n\r\n

un is a married mother who is blessed with two dependent children, one of whom is too small for school while the other one is a student. she is 28 years old. she is living in kampong cham province. her daily business is rice and cassava planting which she has been involved in for 10 years. she is also raising pigs behind her house to earn extra income. her rice crop has produced very low yield in this year so that is her main challenge. this is her second time as a client with visionfund. after she paid back the past loan on time, she decided to apply for a new loan to buy fertilizer to support her rice plantation. in the future, she hopes that her rice crop will produce more yield and gain her more income.

james is a married man. he has one child. he describes himself to be committed. he operates a transport business where he transports customers using his motorcycle. he has been involved in this business for three years. his business is located in an area with potential. he describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of enough capital. 

he will use the 40,000 kenyan shillings loan to buy a motorcycle. his business goal is to buy a public service vehicle within five years. he hopes that in the future, he will run a transport company. this is his second loan with smep microfinance bank. the previous loan was repaid successfully.

juanita landed at a right place for her needed capital when she joined pmpc. she knew this would be her last chance to get back on her feet when she went broke after her first business went bad. 

pmpc came to juanita's rescue by lending her money when she needed it the most. now she availed herself of another loan for the next cropping season. she borrowed an amount for land and seedbed preparation.  

juanita perseveres and always believes she can reach her goals to continuously provide for her family.

brenda is a 59-year-old married woman from talibon, bohol. she has four grown children. she provides tailoring services. she makes dresses and does dress alterations. she has been doing this for almost 10 years. she requested a loan of 6,000 php to buy spare parts for her sewing machine, to pay the labor fees for repairing her sewing machine, and to buy food for the family. this will help brenda improve her services and provide capital to continue operating her business. in the future, brenda hopes to accommodate all her customers' needs and to save for old age.

emelita is 32 years old and married with three children. with two children currently in school, emelita works very hard to provide for them.

emelita runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 10,000 loan through nwtf to purchase more groceries to sell.

emelita has been in this business for 12 years and sells a variety of items such as detergent, soap, shampoo, cereals, coffee, milk, soft drinks, etc. 

in the future emelita would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

jimmy is 40 years old. he is married and has three children. he runs his mobile money transfer and auto spare parts businesses in his hometown of lundazi, a town in eastern zambia near the border with malawi.

jimmy has been selling car spare parts for five years now. he added mobile money transfers to his line of business two years ago.  being a zoona mobile money transfer agent means that jimmy offers the service of sending and receiving money to his community. he gets his profit every time a customer uses the service at his shop. he says being a zoona mobile money transfers agent has helped him grow as a businessman in his town. when asked what his biggest challenge is, he sites the lack of working capital. he says the saddest part is that, when he runs out of cash at his shop, he has to make his customers wait, while he goes out to look for money and in some cases ends business..

he is grateful for the opportunity to get a kiva loan, as it will help boost his working capital and he will earn more profit. he thanks the kiva lenders.

in this video, a representative from zoona interviews jimmy.

joshua is a maize farmer from makwala village. as a babban gona member, joshua is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times higher than the average nigerian farmer. 

before joining babban gona, joshua would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at it’s lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. as a babban gona member joshua can to store the maize he harvests and delay it’s sale until a period later on in the season when he can obtain the best price for his maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

thanks to the support from babban gona’s marketing services, joshua no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. with the opportunity to earn up to $2000 per hectare of land, joshua hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

ry h., born in 1954, resells fish that she purchases from the local fishermen near the docks in siem reap where she lives with her husband, ry nghit. she typically makes us$4 each day while her husband works in construction and provides us$3 each day to help support their four children. two of their children are also employed—one in construction and one in the fishing industry. they help to provide additional income for the family. the family's typical daily expenses are $2 for food, $0.35 for utilities, $1 for education, and $1.25 for transportation needs. ry h. would like to expand her business and increase her customer base so she can increase her income, allowing her to provide more for her family. she has asked credit for a loan of us$200 to purchase more fish from the fishermen and increase her inventory so that she can sell more to her customers. in the future, ry h., would like to expand her business through the purchase of a stand in the local market where she could have a more permanent location and reach more customers.

mr. nantiebe k. is 34 years old and works in lome, his hometown. he has a store called "kisi techno" where he sells electronics such as cellphones, laptops, irons, vacuums, and other goods. he\'s been in business since 2007. he\'s married to a cleaning woman and they have two children. he\'s in the process of taking his third loan from wages in order to purchase laptops and portable irons. he has requested 400,000 cfa.

madina k. is a young woman who has been occupied with the selling of mens’ clothes since 2004. despite of her young age, she is very smart and a very quick businesswoman. she has a stable business and her assets are increasing every month. she reimburses her loans in time without any problem. now, she wants to enlarge her business and is hoping for another loan. madina thanks you in advance.

jhonna g., 33 years of age, has operated a junk shop for almost one year. her weekly net income is 2,200 php. she plans to avail of a loan from kiva lenders in the amount of 4,000 php for her additional requirements, and she hopes to become productive in due time to support her family in their needs. 

she is married to mr. renato g., a farmer, and has been blessed with 3 children: jonathan, 10 years old and in grade 5; followed by renato jr., 8 years old and in grade 3; and their youngest, john rey, 5 years old. they are residing at baranggay san francisco, isabela. their house is located near the rice farm and fish ponds. she hopes that her loan will be granted as soon as possible. she believes that "prayer changes everything; just have faith in him."

votha’s group lives in a rural village in takeo province in cambodia. votha does work as a farmer to support his family.

in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women and this man to safeguard the health of their families, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

christopher is a 36 year old married man with four children and a permanent resident of katabi. his main source of income is a bar though he has a side business of a piggery project at his home, where his wife helps him with the project.

this is the second time hehas applied for a loan facility of 2000000/= to help him boost his piggery project. he will buy baby pigs and feed them for sale at a higher price. he is so greatful to ugafode microfinance ltd for the facility rendered to him and has promised to remain a good client of ugafode microfinance ltd.

mercy is a smallholder farmer who has been farming for eight years. over this time, she has gathered a lot of experience and is considered among the best farmers in her village. her primary sources of income have been milk, eggs, and horticulture crops. mercy is very passionate about farming and loves cultivating her farm. she is an honest, hardworking, loyal person who is dedicated to her farm because it allows her to support her family's needs.

although she makes a profit from farming, mercy's standard of living is not comfortable. she has always wanted to increase her income by buying quality seeds and other farm inputs. therefore, she has requested this loan in order to make these investments and improve her horticulture farming.

kenya's litein area, one of the country's most populated regions, has a high demand for food. this means that mercy is poised to increase her profits and satisfy the existing demand for horticultural products. mercy is grateful that juhudi kilimo is partnering with kiva lenders to help hardworking and honest women farmers like herself turn their farming dreams into reality through training and loan financing. mercy is confident that this loan will help her and that she will be able to improve her standard of living through satisfying local demand for horticultural products.

mercy is a special person and is grateful for the help and support of her kiva lenders.

jessica is a 28 year old married woman with three young children. the oldest child is 7 years old. jessica's husband works as a fisherman.

jessica has had a sari-sari store business for 6 years. she sells items like canned goods, rice, noodles, coffee and sugar. jessica earns about 5000 php per month with her store. jessica also helps her husband sell fresh fish and crabs int the market. jessica works hard to support her family.

jessica has requested this loan to buy fishing nets and more items to sell such as canned goods and rice. jessica hopes for her businesses to grow.

emigeline is 36 years old and married. she has five children, three of whom are in school.

she is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the philippines, and requested a php 7,000 loan through nwtf in order to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs.

emigeline has been raising pigs for two years. she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

as a married parent of three children, maurecia works hard to support her family. she has a business of buying and selling dry goods in the philippines, but she also earns additional income from food vending. maurecia is borrowing 10,000 php from nwtf to purchase more inventory of dry goods to sell at her business.

she has been sustaining her business activities with her past 16 loans from nwtf. maurecia hopes that her hard work will help her to attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

residing in baek chak village, akphivoadth commune, tuek phos district, kampong chhnang province, and nul is 43 years old, and he is a father of two dependent children. to support his family, he has been farming rice. his wife is just raise some pigs at home to add more income. nul has been involved in this businesses for around 10 years after he got married, and he is able to save about usd 6.5 each day to feed his family.

the lack of fertilizer and seeds for his rice farming are the main challenges for his business. his crop is not growing well, so he gets a low income for this season. at the same time, he would like to improve his family living standards by helping his family members get a light to use at night.

his income is not enough for him to reach his goal yet. so the last option will be for him to apply for a loan from kiva through hkl to buy a solar panel, which he expects will light his house at night.

he hopes that this loan will enable him to improve his family's standard of living. he is waiting for your help now, and he would like to say thanks to all lenders for your financial support for poor people like him.

mwanamisi is a married mother of two children, one of whom attends school. she owns a house that has electricity and piped water. her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and household consumables.

for over one year, she has operated an open air food selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. she faces a major challenge of competition in her business.

with the kes 10,000, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour and cooking fat. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

lucita is 37 years old, married with three children and a resident of lower lamac in oroquieta city in the philippines. she earns a living by tending in her small sari-sari business.

lucita has been  a member of the paglaum multi-purpose cooperative (pmpc) for two years and enjoys the privileges of being a member. now, she is applying for a loan of 10,000 philippine pesos to restock her store with basic commodities.

lucita deeply wishes to maintain her position as a member in good standing with pmpc.

matia is 26 years old and is married with two children living in kasese, uganda. he runs a retail shop with general merchandise. he has been in this business since 2010 and also practices commercial farming, growing crops such as beans and maize to get additional income. he began the business to improve his family's standards of living. \r\n\r\nmatia is a hardworking man dreaming of a wholesale business. he wants money to buy rice, soap, sugar, salt and other general merchandise to sell. high transport costs are a hindrance to his operations.

matilde a. works with much effort in her mini-market business, which is located in her home in the city of managua in the municipality of san rafael del sur. since she began her business she has be able to get ahead and has supported her home providing better living conditions for her two little ones.

today, conscious of the need to invest in her business, she is seeking the support of ceprodel to get a loan with which to obtain the products to sell. it is important to point out that through this loan she will be able to stock the mini-market and support her household in her community.

translated from spanish by aimee sostowski, kiva volunteer

carlos is a young student who lives with his parents and siblings. he decided to study the career of technical maintenance engineering mechanics, because he is fascinated by the mechanisms inside a machine, while also maintaining the machinery. it is a career that will greatly benefit both him personally as well as his family and community, because once he receives his degree he can provide services in his community and also develop new machines.

carlos is doing very well in school, and every day is learning more new things that increase his interest in the subject. he has completed one year of school, and has two more years until he completes his career. when he graduates from senati, he would like to work as a supervisor in a large company. his biggest dream is to become a working professional, so he can give back to his parents for all they have done for him.

the biggest obstacle in his life is a financial one, due to the difficult economic situation of having a member of his family in very delicate health. for this reason, carlos is asking kiva to provide him much-needed support so he can finish the career he loves so much. with this loan, him and his parents would feel much better knowing that carlos could finish his schooling within the proper timeline, and that he would not have to leave school.

carlos would like to express a few words: "i am very grateful for kiva as my dreams will continue forward and will not be affected by financial problems. i thank you because without knowing me, you are betting on me, and god bless you for ensuring that our goals and dreams are met thanks to your kind support."

bernadita works hard to support her family.

she has a business buying and selling dried coconut meat in the philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs and farming coconut. bernadita is borrowing 10,000 php through nwtf to buy more sacks of dried coconut meat to sell for her buying and selling dried coconut meat business.

she successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

bernadita has been sustaining her business activities through her past 5 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

francisca works hard to support six children. she is married and has a food vending business in the philippines.

francisca requested a php 5,900 loan through nwtf to build a sanitary toilet for her family.

francisca is aware that by using the sanitary toilet, she is reducing health and hazard risks to her family and neighbors, as well as promoting environmental protection.

good day, lenders! now it’s time for you to meet one of ruma’s agents, hoiriah. hoiriah lives in south tangerang, located about an hour's drive from jakarta, the capital city. she lives there with her husband and her three children (one daughter and two sons).  hoiriah owns a stall where she provides photocopy service and mobile payment service for her community.  she joined ruma in 2013. as a woman, she wanted to join ruma because she wants to learn about how to improve her business, as well as make more contributions to her community. 

as the business grows, hoiriah is hoping to get a working capital loan from kiva. she will use the capital to provide more mobile payment services to her community, especially on weekends. having known about the importance, your loan will be very useful to help hoiriah improve her business and accordingly, her community which needs access to such services. as seen in the photo, hoiriah is the one who is standing and smiling. she will be thankful for your support.

carillo is a married woman with four children. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur. she is 41 years old and has two children who are still in school. she has a fishing business in the philippines. 

carillo has requested a php 15,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy fishing net, gasoline for her boat, bamboo and other materials for her business. she has been in this business for 20 years. she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

the group leader of this small group is irene t.. she is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add stock. irene is 27 years old and is married. her husband is a social worker. she has 1 child aged 2.5. each week, irene makes approximately ugx 28000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re-invest in her business. irene has taken a loan from brac uganda before in the amount of ugx 200000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

irene is joined in her small group by josephine b., gladys nakibuule, carol n., and annet n.. josephine b. has a business selling tie and dye clothes and wants to buy tie and dye material. gladys nakibuule is currently operating a restaurant business and wants a loan to purchase more furniture and utensils. carol n. operates a business of charcoal sales and wants to purchase in bulk. annet n. is currently in the business of selling fresh food and is requesting a loan to invest in the business.

olga is 25 years old and has a young daughter who is in school. she has lived in an urban area of the city of pacasmayo for several years. olga has many good personal references.

she has a small establishment in her home where she offers her customers and neighbors basic necessities and various grocery products. her business has received very good publicity since it is located in a central area. olga has been in business for three years and is well-known in her trade. her business has plenty of activity and the revenue she generates helps to move her family forward.

olga wants to expand her business by purchasing more products because demand has increased this season. for this reason, she is requesting a loan from edpyme alternativa in the amount of 2000 pen.

olga has many good references from the people who know her. they describe her as a peaceful and hardworking person.

emmanuel, 60, is married with 10 children and lives in kasese, uganda. he has been in the bar business for seven years and the business is very profitable as he is assured of daily income. his hardships are price fluctuations and inflation. his personal goal is to build a permanent home. his business goal is to diversify his business. emmanuel wants a loan to buy beer to sell.\r\n

josé is 40 years old. he lives with his common-law partner, and has two children who are in school.  they live in their own home, and he works in agriculture, which is the only source of income for his humble household.  the loan will be used to invest in a potato crop, so that he can increase his production and improve his earnings to pay for his children's education.

gina is 32 years old and has five children. four of her children are in school.

gina is in the agricultural business in the philippines.

gina is requesting a loan in the amount of 9,000 php through nwtf to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. gina has been a member of nwtf for one year now, and has borrowed two loans from nwtf in the past to sustain her business. in the future, gina would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

betty is a married woman. she has three children. she operates a retail business where she sells tea leaves. she has been involved in this business for six years. her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals.

she describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. she will use the 60,000 kes loan to buy more stock of tea leaves to sell at her business. this is her third loan with smep microfinance bank. previous loans were repaid successfully.

rosa b. is a widow and mother of two children. on is 15 and the other 5 years old. she was born in xai-xai in the gaza province on novemeber 30th, 1968. she is 39 years old. she was raised by her parents. her family had limited economic means and her father immigrated to south africa in search of work. she studied until the 7th grade, and worked as a seamstress to help the family. she married in 1985 and lived with her husband for 14 years. her husband did not allow her to work outside the home. in 1999 her husband passed away. rosa experienced many difficulties. she then found a job in the móbil. she saved from the small income for 4 years in order to build a home. with help from a partner rosa had a space in ndlavela where she sells different products including drinks.

she was introduced to hluvuku credit program by her aunt. she then requested a loan of 15.000mt in order to buy different products and increase her inventory. rosa’s work has a positive impact in her community because it provides employment for rosa, and brings goods closer to her community. in the future, rosa plans to expand her business to include selling food, chickens and meats.

translated from portuguese by mariana fraga, kiva volunteer.

localização: bairro ndlavela - maputo cliente: rosa b. actividade:comércio valor de empréstimo: 15.000,00 mt (600.00us$) aplicacao: compra de produtos de 1ª necessidade e refrigerantes início: 27/08/07 fim: 18/11/08 rosa b., é viúva e mae de 2 filhos o primogénito de 15 anos e 5 anos respectivamente, nasceu em xai-xai na província de gaza a 30 de novembro de 1968, tem 39 anos de idade, cresceu e viveu com os pais, numa família com poucos recursos financeiros, o pai emigrou para áfrica do sul para trabalhar com pasteleireiro porque não conseguia arranjar emprego no país. estudou e concluiu a 7ª classe, trabalhou como costureira para a ajudar na renda familiar. casou-se em 1985 e viveu com o marido durante 14 anos e este nunca aceitou que fizesse alguma coisa como forma de ocupar-se e ajudar na renda familiar. em 1999 perdeu o marido, tendo atravessado momentos conturbados e no ano 2000 consegue uma vaga na móbil como servente da take away durante 4 anos e com magro salárioconsegui poupar até construir uma casa e comprar diversos bens e ainda poupou mais algum que veio usar para a compra de um contentor em 2004. com ajuda do seu parceiro em 2007 compra um espaço em ndlavela onde coloca o contentor e apetrecha com diversos produtos de mercearia incluindo bebidas.

teve conhecimento da hluvuku através da tia, tendo decidido a proximar e pedir auxílio no valor de 15.000 mt , para incrementar o volume do seu negocio adquirindo diversificados produtos de mercearia incluindo bebidas. actualmente emprega um trabalhador e a sua actividade tem um impacto positivo na comunidade pois para além de constituir uma fonte de emprego, reduz as distâncias em cerca de 50% das que eram percorrida em busca destes serviços, constitiundo deste modo uma alternativa segura para os clientes. com os rendimentos do negócio garante o sustento familiar e dar respostas as diversas necessidades pontuais que possam surgir. no futuro planeja reguer uma esplanada no quintal para venda de comidas, frangos e carnes assadas e melhorar cada vez mais seu negócio para atrair mais clientes.

adwoa a. is fifty years old and is married with five children who are all in school. she is married to mr. a. who is a farmer in the community where they live together with the children.

adwoa works very hard to provide food for her family. she sells used women’s shoes and slippers and sells through hawking: that is, house to house to house selling. she obtains her stock of goods from kumasi and retails to her customers through hawking.

adwoa treks to kumasi every week for her stock and her reason is that she doesn’t have enough money to buy in bulk. adwoa is therefore requesting your loan support to avoid frequent traveling to kumasi. with the loan she wants to buy more slippers and shoes to increase her stock. she belongs to the village called ‘gyedie mu aba’.

phan s., a 47-year-old woman, has four children and lives with her husband in phnom penh, cambodia. one of her children is a garment worker, another one is a chef in a small nearby restaurant, and the rest are students. phan makes her living by growing a wide range of crops and raising animals in the field. she and her husband normally earn around $5 per day by selling crops and animals. in order to make additional income and to satisfy greater demand from the market, this couple must grow more crops and raise more animals on their farm. phan hopes to use the loan to purchase a piece of land to grow more crops and to raise more pigs. in the future, if she has enough money, she would like to buy a car for her husband to run a taxi business and to build a concrete house for her family.

mohamed is a hardworking 30-year-old business gentleman. he sells bread at retail, a business he has been doing for the last three years. 

he had previously acquired a loan from yehu that helped him to grow his business. he understands how to manage his business because he has been trained in business management. he needs a loan of 50,000 kes to add stock of bread for sale.

mohamed is divorced and without any child, but he tells us that he plans to marry another wife very soon. he therefore hopes to have a family. he dreams of expanding his business and opening a bakery in the future.

\r\nfanny was born in the city of quillabamba but currently lives in the city of cusco.  she’s 28-years-old and single.  fanny works independently as a legal advisor; she’s been in business six months and does very well.  on this occasion she needs a loan to buy office supplies like paper, ink, pencils, etc. that she needs for her office.  fanny is a member of asociación arariwa’s “los andes” communal bank in the city of cusco.\r\n

ekua sells fried fish and kenkey at abura. she is divorced and has 7 children. in the photo, the wooden container has the fried fish stored in it to prevent flies from coming into contact with the fish. the blue net is fly-proof. on her left is the fante kenkey. \r\n\r\nher loan will be used to buy more fish and maize to make kenkey for sale. she hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a better eating place.

jeremiah is a 48-year-old father with four children who is married to lucy. for the past 17 years, jeremiah’s primary business has been running a dairy and crop farming. jeremiah lives in kiambu, which is a relatively productive area that receives a good amount of rainfall every season making it favorable for agricultural activities.

jeremiah got to know about kadet through a friend who was already a member. this is his second loan with kadet and he has also previously borrowed from other institutions. with this loan, jeremiah plans to buy a water pump and irrigation pipes. he also plans to have electricity installed in his farm.

carolyne is a married woman who has 5 children. she describes herself as ambitious. she operates a retail business where she sells fish. she has been involved in this business for 6 years. her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals.

carolyne will use this kes 30,000 loan to buy more fish to sell. she hopes that in the future, she will educate her children to university level. this is her first loan with smep microfinance bank. she will use the anticipated profits to expand her business.
