this lady, jeerling, lives in the municipality of ticuantepe with her family. her husband is self-employed and works to contribute to the household expenses, as they have a ten year old son who is studying at primary school. jeerling has been working for a private company for many years, and her plan for her family is to improve their living conditions. \r\n\r\njeerling requires this loan because she wants to change the roof of their house, as it has deteriorated a lot and in wet weather it acts like a strainer which damages the few electrical appliances that she painstakingly managed to buy. this loan will be invested in the purchase of zinc, beams and cement, among other items.

as a married parent of two children, jean works hard to support her family.

she has a farming rootcrops business in the philippines, and also earns additional income from general store. jean is borrowing php 13000 through nwtf to  purchase additional sacks of fertilizers for her farming root crops business.

jean has been sustaining her business activities through her past 3 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

dolores is a 60-year-old widow with four children. she works very hard to provide for them by running a general store in the philippines. she is requesting a loan for php 15,000 from nwtf to buy more items to sell, including shampoo and groceries. dolores has been in this business for 30 years and her goal for the future is to continue expanding her business.\r\n

mehwish is a women entrepreneur and struggling to bring prosperity to her family along with her husband. she is 25 years old, and lives in a small house with 6 family members. she is a skilled woman who has adopted cloth stitching as a source of livelihood. she has around 2 years of experience in cloth designing and stitching.



at the moment she is lacking finances to purchase raw material including cloth, colorful threads, needles, buttons and laces for cloth stitching. she therefore has requested loan from jws pakistan, field partner of kiva to finance raw material for her business.



she is hopeful that the loan will be productive for her business and family.



she is grateful to kiva & jws pakistan for the kind help.

margie is a dealer of boardwalk products for men, women and kids. in order to purchase more products to sell, she would like to request a loan of php6,000 that she will use as a down payment for her merchandise. she also hopes to expand her business and sell avon, natasha and mse products to further develop her direct selling skills and to support the education of her children and graduate from college.  

margie is married to marcelino jr. and they have two children: princes erika – 6 years old, pre-school student; and michaela – 2 years old.

toshbibi is very glad that you helped her. thanks to you, she is advancing her business. her sons help her with sowing and harvesting. toshbibi has decided to plant melons and watermelons. she is requesting a loan in order to obtain mineral fertilisers and seeds. toshbibi believes in you and your support.

allen is 61 years old and married with six children.

allen works hard to provide for her family.  she runs an ambulant store of grocery items in the philippines and requested a php 19500 loan through nwtf to purchase more stocks of groceries to sell.

allen has borrowed and paid 22 loans from nwtf before this loan.  she has been running the ambulant store of grocery items for 15 years and also earns an income from raising livestock.

allen aspires to save money in order to expand her business.

lutfiyamo was born in 1977 in the city of kulob. she is married and the mother of a boy and a girl, whom she loves deeply. she feels very happy with her family life and the fact that she has given birth to such beautiful children, as her son and daughter are now her source of support in life.

lutfiyamo is a very peaceful woman with a pleasant personality. she has been sewing women's clothes for the past four years and she has a good number of customers who only turn to her when they need to have a dress made. at the moment, she would like to expand her activity. in addition to the orders that she gets from her customers, she also sews dresses for resale. for this reason, she needs to buy a computerized sewing machine. she is taking a loan to make this purchase. with a good quality sewing machine, she will be able to improve the quality of her work. this loan means a lot to luftiyamo and she is turning to you for support.

judith is 36 years old and has 6 children. she is a group leader and is representing her group formed by 14 farmers in kimilili district, kenya.

judith has been farming with one acre fund for years now, having joined the program for the first time in 2012. this decision was largely a result of her desire to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods. although she described her last harvest as very good, she believes she could have a better one this year by continuing to work alongside one acre fund. judith also decided to purchase a solar light as part of her loan, which she is very excited about, as it will allow her to reduce the consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore save more money.

obtaining this loan means that judith's group will be able to receive a total of 5 solar lights, as well as farming inputs to plant a total of 11.75 acres.

good day, lenders! now it’s time for you to meet one of the ruma agents, achmad. 

achmad lives in semarang, capital of central java, 9 hours drive from jakarta, the capital city of indonesia. achmad is happily married. together with his wife, they have two children. he owns a stall that sells mobile airtime credits  for his community. he already joined ruma for a year. he knew ruma from ruma’s sales executive that came to his stall. he decided to join ruma because he is interested in ruma’s system; the sales executive will be coming to his stall to collect the money. moreover, his community sees him as a friendly and trustworthy mobile provider.

as the business grows, achmad is hoping to get a working capital loan from kiva. he will use the capital to process more mobile airtime credits and bill payment services to his communities. having known about the importance, your loan will be very useful to help achmad improves his business and accordingly, his community who needs access to such services. as seen in the photo, achmad is the one who is standing. he will be very thankful for your kind support.

norah is a 34-year-old, proud mother of five children. she is a group leader, often described as a very hardworking individual, and is representing her group of eight farmers in webuye district. since joining one acre fund in 2015, norah has noticed that she has had a healthier life due to better nutrition.

norah described her harvest as good last year, but believes she can have a better one this year by continuing to work with one acre fund. she is very excited to also be purchasing two solar lights, apart from fertilizer and maize, because she will now be able to reduce the consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore save more money. with the profits from this season’s harvest, she plans to send her children to school.

with this loan, norah’s group will be able to plant a total of 2.5 acres of land and purchase a total of eight solar lights.

faten sells home products from home. she wants to take care of herself and, although married, finds that financial independence is the best thing that could happen to her. so, she is working hard toward it but she is limited by those who can visit her at home. the passersby and customers who haven't heard of her are eliminated because she works at home. therefore, she wants to open a store but the capital she has at the moment is not sufficient. she wants to buy more home products to increase her sales to use toward opening a store.

romela is a married woman with nine children. she is a very hard working entrepreneur. romela is 50 years old and has three children who are still in school.

romela has a food vending business in the philippines. romela requested a php 15000 loan amount through nwtf to buy ingredients for her food vending business such as, vegetable, fish, meat, and other supplies needed in her buisness.

romela has been in this business for 23 years. in the future, romela would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

taing r. is 26 years old, married, and has two children. both of her children are young and go to primary school. her husband, bin say, 29, is a fisherman. she and her family live in kompong tom province.

\r\n\r\n

she is a local farmer who specializes in growing both rice and vegetables. she has been widely known in the business for over seven years, earning approximately $1.50 per day. r. is requesting a loan to purchase two cows to help her with the farming.

milagring is a married woman with six children. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur. milagring is 49 years old and her six children are in school.

milagring has a vegetable vending business in the philippines. she requested a 12,000 php loan through nwtf to buy different kinds of vegetables to sell at her stall. milagring has been in this business for 10 years.

in the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

tati is 49 years old and lives in gilimanuk, west bali.  she is married and has three children, and they are all still in school.   her husband is a goverment officer.   she has a textile business (embroidery business).   she has been in this business for five years. 
 
with this effort she was able to provide jobs for women in her neighborhood. she makes bags, clothes and other types of ladies' accessories sold to denpasar. she needs this loan to buy yarn and needles. she receives an order in large enough quantities. she hopes these efforts will be more advanced, could provide jobs for many women and certainly provide welfare for her family.

omar is originally from matiguas, matagalpa. he has lived here his whole life. he says that with much support and effort from his parents, he was able to study only through the first grade of primary school, in the rectory of the small church that was in his community. he says he has been learning to do the field work, such as sowing basic grains, picking coffee, raising cattle and more, since he was very young. today, that helps him a lot. 

he lived with his parents until age 24. following that, he got married and formed his family - a wife and three children - with whom he lives happily. his children are studying. he motivates them to be prepared, and become professional people in the future. his wife is a housewife, and he makes a living cultivating and selling the crops he harvests. 

in the community, they do not have electric energy. it is very sad not to be able to have electricity, he says, because if they did they would stop contaminating with the smoke of the candles that they use now. he wants to apply for a loan and buy solar energy kits for his home.

anabelle l. is 39 years old, married and supports her family by operating two businesses: fishing and fish vending. she lives in purok 1 in the barangay of culipapa, hinobaan municipality in negros occidental province on the mindanao islands. she has been a member of nwtf-project dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from nwtf and through her own efforts. by working hard in her fishing and fish vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. she now earns an average monthly income of php 6000.

anabelle is now borrowing php 17,000, her seventh loan from nwtf-project dungganon, to purchase fishing gear and equipment. her previous loan of php 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. anabelle aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure its future well-being by following the dungganon way.

about nwtf:

in a world full of challenges, negros women for tomorrow foundation (nwtf), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through project dungganon (a hiligaynon word that means honorable). through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. they are on a life path that will ultimately make them dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

help nwtf continue its mission to help the poorest in the philippines by clicking the link to the nwtf kiva lending team on kiva.org to join our team.

this group is made up of ten dynamic women who work in various businesses, as evident from the photo.

bernadette, the member highlighted today, sells beverages. her business is profitable, as she manages to pay for her expenses and to turn a profit. she is married and a mother of seven. six of the children go to school, and one of her daughters is married.

with this loan, she will purchase beverages to stock up and retail. as for paying back, the group has always met deadlines. profits made possible by this loan will allow bernadette to carry on business and to help her husband pay for the family’s expenses.

sophie apiyo o. is a 28-year-old mother of two children, aged 5 and 3. both are in school. she lives in the manyatta slum where she sells food purchased wholesale from kibuye market in downtown kisumu. she is asking for a loan of 20,000 ksh and hopes to use it to open a depot for soda and chips. because she has been selling food for so long, she wanted a change of pace. she wants kiva lenders to know that she loves the work that k-met does and hopes they continue to assist women who want to open businesses. she says one of the great benefits is that they send their children to school.

pedro is an excellent worker, friendly, and very serious. pedro is 46 years old, and says that, thanks to the loan that was previously granted to him, he was able to give his crop good care and got the best harvests.

pedro has great dreams of improving himself and improving his living conditions. for this reason, he has come to ask for another new loan which he will invest in the purchase of seeds and agricultural supplies for his potato crop. pedro's greatest dream is to improve his family's income.

beverly is married with four children. she is 40 years old and lives in dansalan, labason, zamboanga del norte. beverly sells clothes to earn a living and has had this business for three years. each month, she earns 3,000 philippine pesos (php) doing this type of work. she has requested a loan for 13,000 php to purchase more clothes to sell. beverly has been a member of pmpc for more than a year. in the future, beverly hopes to expand her business.\r\n

norma is a hardworking entrepreneur who operates a general store business in the philippines.  she is borrowing 17,000 php through nwtf to buy items like canned goods, eggs, noodles, soap, and shampoo to sell in her general store business.  norma has been in this business for 4 years but also earns additional income from pig fattening.

she successfully paid back her previous loan and has now requested a new loan to further build her business.  norma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from nwtf.  she dreams of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

nazma is 37 years old, a married woman and mother of six children.

her husband is a driver by profession and provides transportation services using his three-wheeled rickshaw. he has been driving a rickshaw for many years to meet the family's expenses, but now it requires proper maintenance to keep it in its functional routine. 

for this reason, nazma has applied for a loan from kiva’s field partner brac pakistan for her husband. he wants to buy new tires and do a little bit of engine maintenance on his vehicle. this will help him drive more smoothly and provide a better transport service to his passengers. she is hopeful that this loan will be a productive one for her husband and will bring positive changes to his business.

nazma gives thanks to kiva and to its field partner brac pakistan.

analie is a married woman with two children. she is a very hard-working entrepreneur. analie is 34 years old and both children are attending school.

analie has a general store business in the philippines. she requested a php 14,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy more groceries to sell.

analie has been in this business for five years. in the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

fatuma is a married woman with two children, one of whom attends school and the other is still too young to attend school. she owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. her greatest monthly expense is food.

for the past two years, she has operated a coconut-selling business, selling to local neighbors. she faces a major challenge of seasonality and high cost of transportation. she dreams of expanding to improve her living standards.

with the kes 20,000, she wants to purchase sacks of coconuts for resale. she decided to join yehu to access loans to boost her business.

in the resort of san clemente del cantón sucre, the first of december community bank meets every 15 days. this place is known for its beautiful beaches that are visited by many local and foreign tourists. it offers a diversity of beautiful places and a rich variety of typical dishes of the region.

in this place lives lida. she is 60 years old. she is married and, fruit of this relationship, are three children who are adults. one of them still lives at home in her house. her husband is dedicated to fish and also farming.

she has a small shop in her house. there she works every day but the days when she sells most are weekends since many tourists arrive in this beautiful resort town. she sells sandals, clothing, costume jewelry and many more products but almost all with beach themes, which are requested by her customers who arrive daily in her shop. she has more than 8 years experience with her business and it's going quite well.

this loan is going to be used to stock her shop. she is going to buy sandals, costume jewelry, clothing, etc. she has been in her community bank for more than ten years and she likes it because she started her business with one of the loans and with the subsequent ones she has been improving it day by day. 

her goal is to continue improving her shop.

this is 35-year-old fatmata. she is married and has four children aged 16, 14, 13 and 9 years old, all of whom are school going children. in 2004, fatmata established her clothing business. she began her business because her parents were traders. education is less considered for a girl child in their family. she started trading as a teenager until she was able to stand on her own. working 7 days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about sll 550,000 every month from this business. she would like a loan in the amount of sll 3,000,000. fatmata requires a loan in order to purchase clothing (skirts, dresses, baby wear) and jewelry. in the future, fatmata plans to give her children a good education and improve the business. the rainy season causes low sales. the loan will help her a lot as it will improve her business. it is a privilege for her to get funds from ard because it is the only source she now relies on. she thanks you for your support.

eva is married and has one daughter. her husband works as a baker, and eva began work 17 years ago making suits for men and women. her mother sent her to an arts college, and when she left ms. t. was given a sewing machine. from a very young age, she loved to sew, so eva decided that she would continue with this line of work when she got older. her customers come to her because they can count on quality and low prices. eva as well as her husband take turns going to wholesalers so they can purchase things like fabric, thread, utensils. with this $600 loan, eva is hoping to buy another sewing machine and new fabrics that are popular. rather than 20% per month, eva is now able to afford a loan and build her business so that she can improve her family’s standard of living.

\r\n\r\n

mifex offers its clients microinsurance and access to business training and educational programs. for more information about microfinance, ecuador, and our services, please visit www.mifex.org.

shoira is a loving mother. she brought up her daughter by herself, as her husband died a long time ago. five years ago she opened a beauty salon, providing services such as haircuts, hair designs, manicures, pedicures, makeup, etc. she knows her business well and performs high quality work. she recently made repairs at the salon and now she wants to buy some equipment. this is why she is asking for a loan of $1,000 (usd). she awaits your kindness and hopes for your support.

astrude's restaurant, amical bar resto, is one of the oldest restaurants in the heart of port-au-prince. under the leadership of astrude, the business has financially supported its employees despite the rough period after the earthquake. a major part of the restaurant building collapsed during the earthquake of january 2010. as a trained cook, astrude took the initiative to reopen the only restaurant in the community providing her own talent in the kitchen. however, the lack of equipment prevents the business from satisfying higher demand. a loan from zafen will help astrude to buy the equipment needed (freezer, oven, generator, chairs, water cooler and fans) to attract and serve more customers.

"i am a group leader and my name is parween k.. i am married and live with my husband in a small town, chichawatni, pakistan. my brother is a rickshaw driver and he needs to replace his older rickshaw. i help him because he gives me a reasonable rate of profit out of his business.

last year, i bought a sewing machine to start my stitching business with my share of his profits.

my group members are: rukhsana b. who requires a loan for her flower business; manzoora b. who will invest her share of our loan in her family’s envelope business; shaheen zulfiqar who wants a loan to improve their restaurant; and rubina b. who will use the loan to expand their ready-made garment business.

donitila is a member of the 'mujeres productivas' community bank which is based in calleria district, in ucayali department.  she is 43 years old, married, and has five children.

donitila has been working with manuela ramos loans for three loan cycles.  she invested her loans in her family business.  her son is the one who looks after the business when she has other business to attend to.  she has an auto repair shop and her son helps her with the work.

with this new loan for 1,000 soles, donitila will buy spare parts with which to stock her business a little more: one box of spark plugs, one bucket of grease, half a dozen inner tubes, a clutch cable, one box of oil and fifty bolts.

donitila's husband is an independent salesman who buys and sells wood.  he is a wood dealer.  his work is doing well and so he also contributes money to stock the businesses.  they are both very grateful to manuela ramos because they have had a lot of help in starting up their family businesses.

hernane is 56 years old and widowed with three children.

she earns a living by raising pigs in the philippines. hernane is borrowing 15,000 php through nwtf to buy feed and other supplies to raise her pigs.

hernane has been raising pigs for 20 years and also earns additional income from a general store.

she is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

joseph is a 47-year-old married man. he has four children with ages ranging from 7 years to 18 years. he describes himself to be an aggressive man. 

he operates a retail stall where he sells clothes such as jackets. he has been involved in this business for five years. his business is located at a busy area and his primary customers are employees of institutions. he describes his biggest business challenge to be frequent disruptions by city council asking for payment. 

he will use the kes 20,000 loan to buy twenty jackets for selling. his business goal is to build a permanent business premises within five years. he hopes that in the future he will have expanded his business.

jonathan is 30 years old and married to jane. they have three children and they support four people within the family.

he has been a shopkeeper for the last 4 years, selling sugar, cooking oil, bread, maize flour and wheat flour, from which he earns a monthly income of about kes 12,000. he is applying for his first loan of kes 25,000. he was introduced to kadet ltd by a credit officer.

he hopes to use the profits to save for his children's education and to open up another business to provide basic family needs.

barbra is 32 years old and lives in the town of kyengera in the kampala central region of uganda.  she is married and has three children.  all of her children are currently in school.  barbra has a business of a bridal care center, which she has had for six years.         

to help expand her business, barbra has requested a loan of 2,500,000 ugandan shillings from brac uganda.  the loan will be used to purchase bridal dresses for resale.  with the help of the loan from brac, barbra hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children.  

in the future, barbra hopes to expand her business.  barbra is a member of brac’s small enterprise (sep) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

dom’s group lives in a rural village in kampong thom province in cambodia. dom makes a living cultivating rice  to support his family. in his village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help dom safeguard the health of his family, save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

marlyn is 45 years old and married with two children.

marlyn works hard to provide for her family. she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 30,000 loan through nwtf to purchase more items to sell in her general store.

marlyn has borrowed and repaid four loans from nwtf before this loan. she has been running the general store for four years and also earns an income from selling school supplies.

marlyn aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

jane is a hardworking smallholder livestock farmer in mugwe village who is turning 59 this year. she lives together with her husband of 33 years. the couple is blessed with four children aged between 20 and 33 years. \r\n\r\njane is seeking a loan investment from kiva lenders to construct animal housing on her farm. she has 2 cows, 2 pigs and 10 heads of poultry. the housing will offer protection and a clean and conducive environment for her animals to be comfortable and productive.  she will use the income from this investment to help her husband settle monthly bills and their child's university education fees.

manthatisi is a 49 year old widow with three children, aged between 29 and 23. she lives in a multi-roomed house without electricity. for lighting she uses paraffin lamps and lpg for cooking. she says she spends around lsl 200 every month on fuel alone.

that is why she decided to buy the ace1 cook-stove. with this stove her fuel costs are bound to decrease and she will use the led lamp for light. she will also cook using wood without any smoke. she will save lsl 80 on fuel as she will pay lsl 120 for the stove.

'manthatisi and the other women in the group have kindly requested a loan from kiva lenders to pay for the stove.

visit www.africancleanenergy.com or @africancleanenergy on facebook to know more about the stove.

maría was only able to study up to grade 4 in school. her life companion makes a living in agriculture. only her youngest son and two grandchildren live with them.
\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
maría has made a living with her store for over three years. she decided to open the business because it seemed that it could be profitable. besides that she could take care of her children. her partner helps her in the store in his spare time.
\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
she needs the funds to buy more fruits and vegetables like avocados, carrots, beets, cabbage, bananas, etc. for her business. doing this she hopes to improve her income so her family can live better.
\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
maría dreams of her business continuing to grow and having more customers.

nary, 19 and married, lives in a rural area of the moung russey district of battambang province, cambodia. she has one dependent son who is too young for school. to make a living, she has been farming rice on one hectare of farmland and also planting pineapple to earn extra income. she is able to earn about 26,000 cambodian riels (khr) per day and manages to save about 2,000 khr per day after daily expenses. drought is the main challenge for her business.\r\n\r\nnary’s group consists of two members who have been with visionfund for one cycle. nary completely repaid her prior loan, which has provided her family sufficient food. now she is leading her group to apply for a new loan. nary is going to use her portion of the loan to buy fertilizer for her rice and pineapple plantation. she hopes her crop yield will be more profitable and sell for a good price. she also hopes to improve her standard of living.

mrs. meong d., 31, has a business with her husband selling groceries, gas, and ice at their house, earning around $20 a day in revenue. they have two children, one of whom just recently started school. she would like to request a loan from kiva to purchase groceries in bulk to lower the cost of purchase, as now she has many customers.

michael is a married man. he has four children ranging in age from 4 to 11 years old. he describes himself as courageous and caring. \r\n\r\nmichael operates a retail shop where he sells household items such as sugar, tea leaves, rice, sweets, soda, etc. he has been involved in this business for seven years. his business is located within a potential business area and his primary customers are the general public. he describes his biggest business challenge as insufficient funds for improving his business. he will use the kes 20,000 loan to buy household items to resell. his business goal is to expand his business within five years. this is his first loan with smep dtm. he is also a small-scale farmer and he sells farm products .

kiriana’s business is raising animals.  she raises guinea pigs and chickens; she fattens them and makes them grow.  she later sells them at different markets.  she works from 8:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m.  she has had this business for six years, and it is going very well for her.

it is through this business that she wants to get ahead.  her dream is to have a place where she is able to sell the animals.  she is requesting the loan to buy guinea pigs, chickens, and feed for the animals.  she is happy about the loan that was granted, and she pledges to make her payments.

kennedy is 49 years old, and married with two children aged 23 and 17 years old. he runs a grocery shop and a mobile money transfer (m-pesa) business in nairobi town. his wife also provides additional income which they use to support their family and parents. he has been in the business for 7 years. 

he plans to use the loan to add more vegetables, tomatoes, onions and cereals to his greengrocery. he also plans to add more money float to his m-pesa business. this will be his 3rd loan term with kadet limited. he will use the generated profits to acquire a permanent asset such as land. 

kennedy hopes to open more grocery shops and mobile money transfer businesses in other places, make more income and provide a good education for his children.

peter is 35 years old. he is married to catherine wanjiku and they are blessed with 3 children. he has had an agrivet business for 15 years.

he has borrowed kes 65,000 from visionfund kenya and will be using the loan to purchase and add a stock of veterinary medicines to his business.

with the anticipated profits, he will be able to buy food for his family, pay school fees for his kids, cater for medical care, expand his current business and repay his loan too.

his hopes and dreams for the future are to enjoy an improved life with his wife and kids.

cristina is 54 years old and married, and she works very hard to provide for them.

she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 30,000 loan through nwtf to buy items to sell like shampoo, soap, milk, coffee, eggs, etc.

cristina has been in this business for eight years.

in the future she would like to save money to expand her business.

nicanora is 60 years old and married with five children.

she works hard to provide for her family. she runs a buy and sell charcoal in the philippines and requested a php 24000 loan through nwtf to purchase more sacks of charcoal to sell.

nicanora has borrowed and paid 29 loans from nwtf before this loan. she has been running the buy and sell charcoal business for 13 years and also earns an income from general store.

nicanora aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

victor is an auto body repair technician who lives in the country's capital. thanks to the experiences obtained in his previous jobs in auto body repair and restoration garages, he has gotten to master his art and offer better service. his main clients are in fontibón and take their vehicles to his garage in the hours between 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. any day of the week, and pay off advance payments at the beginning of the work and the rest upon its completion, as agreed.

victor is very committed to his business. he says that this is his profit-making project and that is why he wants to apply to his first kiva loan, which he is negotiating with the mario santo domingo foundation, to buy specialized tools for the repair of bumpers, and raw materials such as plates, rivets, and others. this investment will help him to be successful and his service of better quality.

support him with your loan!

as a widow, aida works hard to support her family.

she has a business selling ready-to-wear clothing in the philippines, and she also earns additional income from raising pigs.  aida is borrowing php 10000 through nwtf to buy additional stocks of clothing for her business.

aida has been sustaining her business activities through her past 3 loans from nwtf. she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

jeniffer is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school. she lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. her greatest monthly expense is food.

she has had a motorcycle transport business for more than two years now. she is a very self-sacrificing woman, and she operates from door to door. she mentioned seasonality as a major challenge in her business.
she is requesting the loan for the purchase of a second-hand motorcycle, so she can meet her customers' needs.

kawthar is 23, single, has 4 siblings and lives with her parents. her father is a farmer and he is the only breadwinner of the family. however the income from farming is very low.

she decided to start a small grocery store project to help her father with cover the family's basic needs. she is requesting a 5000 egp loan to buy grocery products such as oil, cheese and pasta to expand her business.

jairo is a 22-year-old farmer who works primarily in the production of coffee, which is his main source of income. jairo has a son under his responsibility. he has been growing coffee since he was 16 years old. jairo sells coffee with the help of cocafcal, of which he is a member. with the profits from his coffee he meets the needs of his family. he wants to be able to build a small legacy for his son\'s future.

jairo has a great deal of passion for growing quality coffee, and linked to this passion he has already obtained several certification seals for his coffee plantations, such as fair trade, rainforest and utz. now he is interested in entering the program of organic management and production, primarily because in this way, he ensures a better market for his coffee, and also makes his coffee plantation more sustainable and environmentally friendly.

jairo is requesting a loan to be able to carry out the work necessary to be able to carry out the work necessary to convert his coffee plantation to organic. the new quality certification will make his coffee more marketable, which will increase his income and as he says, "the most important thing isn\'t the price of the coffee, but rather that we protect the land that is the inheritance of our children."

a loan will help jairo to have better markets for his coffee, and therefore obtain better profits, which will allow him and his family to have a better quality of life, and enable him to offer his son a quality education.

this group of six men is represented by adouna. adouna is 45 years old, married to one wife, and is the father of six children.

adouna needs this loan to buy seeds and 10 bags of fertilizer to farm his field. he has been farming corn for 35 years, work he learned from his father. he works his field alone, and also sometimes with some of his children.

he has improved his farming by using a tractor to plant seeds and to harvest, in order to produce more to his customers' satisfaction. his customers demand a lot.

after his sales, his profits allow him to take care of his family and also continue farming.

he is on his first loan with acfime and will work to make his repayments on time.

nelore yii/niessan has just finished its first kiva loan.  the repayment terms were respected.  souleymane, the representative member, thanks all of the staff and the lenders at kiva for their support.  with the loan, souleymane was able to pay for bags of seed and of manure for his agricultural production.  the harvest was good and he was able to sell his grain.  he had a profit which enabled him to expand his business and to make several expenditures for his family.  souleymane still needs some loans to continue his business.  he has a project of buying a tractor to increase his agricultural production and to flourish even more.

naume is a 42 year old married woman with seven children. she owns a house in kasese, uganda. she has been in the grocery and clothing business for eighteen years, after having acquired her initial capital by selling cooking oil and coffee. her hardships include debtors, high transportation costs, and price fluctuations. her vision is to run a wholesale business and have an educated family. naume needs this loan to buy soda and mineral water to sell.

a villager from the kampong cham province’s koh district, ny is 32 years old and married. she has two dependent children who are still small. the main source of her family’s income is from growing wax gourd and jicama to make a living. having been in this business for 12 years, she is able to earn daily income of 34,000 khr to support her family and she can save about 14,000 khr per day for the future needs. 

this is the first loan for ny with kiva’s partner, visionfund. she is leading her group to seek a loan. as the leader, she is going to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland. she hopes to increase her crop yields so as to make a better living and have a bigger house for living in.

carlos is a youth who looks out for the needs of his family. he is 23 years old and lives together with his parents in a community of sololá. carlos is a very dedicated, hard-working and responsible man. carlos in spite of the economic situation of his parents has not stop studying.

he has been working for 2 years now for the municipality of his community and with the income he generates he helps his parents with the sustenance of the family. carlos is a good student and he loves to prepare day by day to become a great professional serving his community.

but in order to continue to do this carlos has a problem that he does not have a computer. facing this he decided to request a loan which he will use to buy a computer so he can continue to prepare to become a professional. carlos's dream is to get this loan as soon as possible and become a good professional and one day be able to construct his own house.

modeline is the coordinator of the lamentation de philibert group. she lives in the trou-du-nord region of haiti, where electricity is rare and water is very limited. she has three children. 

modeline has been running a restaurant business for the last seven years. she would like to use this loan to invest in this restaurant by buying food.

the other group members need a loan for their businesses which sell food products, cosmetics, clothes, shoes, and coal.

modeline says that her main challenge is increasing sales, since the economic crisis in haiti has not recovered much.

flordeliza is 40 years old, married, and has three children.

flordeliza is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the philippines. she requested a php 20,000 loan through nwtf to buy feed and other supplies to raise her pigs.

flordeliza has been pig fattening for two years now, and has borrowed three times in the past from nwtf to sustain her business.

in the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

bader, 21 years old, is one of six brothers and sisters. he is studying to become a nurse in the applied university and he is now in his third year. he has applied for a loan to pay for his upcoming semester so he can graduate as soon as possible and get a job to help support his family.\r\n

yasmeen is a resident of borewala, which is a small city in pakistan known for its shrines. she is a housewife, stays at home and does her household responsibilities. she has proven herself a very good wife and a very good mother who is raising her children very well. her husband's name is m. a.. he is involved in a timber-selling business. he sells timber through his shop, which he has in the market.  

yasmeen loves animals and loves to take care for them as well. she has young goats at her home and she takes care of them by giving them food and water on time. yasmeen has applied for a loan from kiva partner, asasah, for her husband’s business. with the loan amount, her husband will buy timber and improve the success of his business.  

yasmeen is hopeful that the loan amount will help her husband in increasing his income by selling to the maximum number of customers. 
note: “in the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is yasmeen”.

vilma, is 44, married to a farmer and blessed with one child. she has owned and operated a retail store in their village for almost 20 years and earns a net income of php 500 daily. her net income from her business is usually spent on the school allowances for their child. due to insufficient funds for her business, she would like a loan of php 25,000 to purchase coffee, sugar, and beverages to sell. she's hoping that her business will continue to improve and become more profitable.

adwoa sells traditionally made soaps and pampers.  she is married and has 7 children.  her husband is a carpenter. \r\n\r\nshe uses her income to support her partner in the general upkeep of the home.  she will use the loan to purchase more ingredients to prepare soap to sell.  with the new profits from her expanded business, adwoa plans to reinvest for further growth.

sr. norberto donato is married and has no dependents because all of his children are grown. his main business activity is producing and selling bread. he has a bakery and has been in this line of work for more than 16 years. only in the last two years did he have his own facilities and equipment. norberto had always worked for other bakeries, which allowed him to acquire good experience before making the decision to start his own bakery. with the financing he received from other institutions, he was able to build his facilities and buy machinery. these loans were repaid using the income generated by his bakery.

sr. norberto will use this loan to buy supplies for making bread so that he can increase production. he wants to take advantage of this season when more sales are generated in the area.

narin’s group live in a rural village in kampot province in cambodia. narin makes a living cultivating rice and she also does extra work as a construction worker to support her family.

in their village, there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women and men to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

sarah has been selling clothes in olkalou town for the last nine years.  she is 44 years old, married to benson k., and they have two children.

she was introduced to kadet ltd  by her friend and this will be her third loan.  she repaid both her previous loans well and in good time.  she plans to use the loan amount to buy school uniforms and women's clothing for resale.

in future, sarah hopes to grow her clothing business into a big boutique.

khetam is a 41-year-old married woman from al nasser, amman, jordan and a mother of four children.\r\n\r\nkhetam is a tailor and she is requesting a loan of 400 jd to purchase fabrics with an aspiration of opening a shop.

nat’s group lives in a rural village in kandal province in cambodia. nat makes a living cultivating rice and she also does extra work as factory worker and farmer to support her family.

in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women safeguard the health of their families, save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

hello kiva lenders. get to know caroline! she is a hardworking small-holder farmer with around 10 years of experience. thanks to her tireless nature, she has a farm where she grows crops and raises livestock. she also earns some income from a personal business. caroline never had a formal education and is content with the farming lifestyle.

the kapsowar area is a favorable for farming, so she is seeking a 40,000 kes loan through kiva's field partner juhudi kilimo to buy farm inputs, such as fertilizer and seeds, to enable her to grow more vegetables, reap maximum profits, and increase her business.

being a woman and accessing funds in kenya, especially around kapsowar, is very challenging. however, caroline feels relieved knowing there are institutions such as kiva that help enterprising women like her. she is always working to improve her family’s living conditions, but her biggest dreams are to become independent, support her family by herself, secure her children’s future, and buy a home.

she needs lenders' trust and understanding.

greetings from uganda! this is ramzy. he is the head teacher of kasubi modern islamic primary school, a mixed school in the peri-urban area of kasubi in kampala district with 385 students. kasubi modern islamic primary school has requested a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining a uv water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students. the school does not currently have access to consistent clean drinking water and therefore has to spend a considerable portion of its budget on firewood, which is used to boil water for the children. installing a water filtration system will therefore save the school money in the long-term as the cost of firewood will be reduced. the loan will enable the school to purchase a uv water treatment system with a 450 litre tank, which will be big enough to store clean drinking water for the students every day. 

kasubi modern school will repay their loan from their school fees, which they collect each term. ramzy ultimately hopes that having access to safe drinking water will improve his student’s concentration and attendance by reducing the number of children that fall sick from water-borne diseases as well as increase the number of students coming to the school.

tha, 33, is a married woman and has three children who are her responsibility. the family is residing in the prey chhor district of kampong cham province with a daily income is usd 2.50. tha and her husband are farmers in a cassava field, which is located not so far from their house.

tha has been a customer of hattha kaksekar for two loan cycles. recently, she would like one more loan to buy some farming materials and hire some laborers to help her with her farming. she hopes that this loan will have a great effect on her farming and help her to improve her living standard.

doris manages a business selling used clothing in her community to make living. she is married and has two children. doris successfully repaid her previous loan used for her business. \r\n\r\ndoris took a new loan recently to purchase bundles of used shoes and bags to sell. she is hopeful she will gain more profit from her investments and plans to save a portion of it for the future education of her children.

ms. hermelinda belongs to the corazón d. jesús [heart of jesus] communal bank, located in the district of san jose d. sisa, province of el dorado, department of san martin. she is thirty-six years old, married, and a mother of three children, all of whom are dependents and studying.

her drive and desire to see her children become professionals motivated her to start her own business selling groceries. her business is located in her house, which is very well equipped for attending to her customers.

her earnings contribute towards her family’s income. nowadays, she is greatly loved by her regular customers, who frequent her shop daily because they can count on her to have all of the products that a housewife needs and for her captivating character and charisma.

with this loan of s/.1,000.00, she will be able to purchase sacks of rice and sugar , packets of noodles, milk, and a variety of different brands of boxes of fish preserves, "javas" of eggs, and personal hygiene products in order to continue to provid. the best service to her customers.

hermelinda is enthusiastic about continuing her work. every day she is thankful for her life for giving her the amazing opportunity to move forward as a woman, and likewise for the manuela ramos movement (“movimiento manuela ramos”) that pushed her to become a business woman.

translated from spanish by tracy quan, kiva volunteer

jalyn works hard to support her family. she is married and has a 'buy and sell' banana business in the philippines. she requested a php 10,000 loan through nwtf to buy additional stocks of bananas to sell.

jalyn has been in this business for 15 years now,.

in the future, jalyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

patricia i. is a young and beautiful woman who is 54 years of age. she is married with two (2) children and has been an lapo client for 6 years. she is experienced in her line of business and worthy of a loan from lapo. she will use the money ($400) to expand her business.

maría virginia continues to sell beauty products including cosmetics and perfume. she sells them face to face and by order form to her customers who are mainly female. \r\n\r\nat the moment maría virginia is applying for a loan to buy goods such as cosmetics and perfume. she is very grateful to the investors for helping her to continue working and she promises to make her repayments on time.

florida is sixty years old and married with seven children.

florida works hard to provide for her family. she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 17,000 loan through nwtf to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. in her sari-sari store.

florida has borrowed and paid for twenty-one loans from nwtf before this loan. she has been running the general store for seven years and also earns an income from food-vending.

florida aspires to save money to expand her business.

bauirjan h. is 26 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in the bayan-ulgii province of mongolia. he and his family live together in their own house and fence. bauirjan owns a transportation service where he transports people using his own jeep between local sub-provinces. he started his transportation business in 2004 and has been successful enough to buy a car, which enabled him to start his second business driving a taxi to supplement his earnings. he has built a successful and stable operation and his earnings have enabled him to build a house and live on his own with his family. he makes 2-3 trips in one week between local towns and operates a taxi service during his free time within his town. his daily business income is between 15,000 and 25,000 mnt and his monthly average income has reached a level of 350,000 mnt. bauirjan is a very honest and hardworking man and says, " i want to start saving my business profits in order to invest money for my children\'s future. " he is requesting a 1,500,000 mnt loan in order to purchase necessary spare parts for both of vehicles.\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\r\n

brigida was born in the city of challabamba and has resided in the city of salvación for many years. (salvación is located in the district of manu, in the province of manu, within the region of madre de dios, peru.)

brigida is 40 years old and is in a common-law marriage from which she has two children. she has a lodging house, a grocery store, and a restaurant. she has already been working in these businesses for 13 years, and they are going very well thanks to the effort she puts into her work. she is an entrepreneurial and hardworking woman who supports her family. she belongs to the communal bank "del futuro del manu" ["the future of manu"].

she needs this loan to buy merchandise like, for example, bags of rice, bags of sugar, mineral water, soft drinks and soda pop, noodles, cans of milk, and other things. she appreciates and values the loan and promises to meet the monthly payments.

linda is 44 years old and has five children. linda is married and has three children who are currently in school.

linda is in the agricultural pig fattening business in the philippines. linda requested a php 10000 loan through nwtf to purchase additional piglets, feed, vitamins, etc. for her business.

linda has been in pig fattening for 8 years now, and has borrowed 7 times in the past from nwtf to sustain it.

in the future, linda would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

41-year-old walter lives with his family in his own home.  the only basic service his house receives is electricity.  it is located in the rural part of pitipo district, in lambayeque department.  the people in this area farm and raise livestock.

walter is a farmer.  he owns his own farmland where he grows cassava and beans.  he has been in this business for several years.  the crops he grows are very popular.  once he harvests his crops, he sells them in markets in his local area and in other areas.  he uses the income that he makes to provide his family with a better quality of life.

noting that his business was growing, walter decided that he needed to request a loan for 2,300 soles from edpyme alternativa to buy fertilizers with which to improve his land and his crops.  he will use the profits that he makes to repay his loan and cover his family's daily needs.  through his hard work and commitment, walter provides his family with the best, offering them other opportunities in life.

rodolfo alejandrino is 52 years old and married.  he lives with his wife and his two children who are 20 and 17 years old.  he lives in montalvo, in los ríos province. 

this community bank is called pita and is located in san pablo de pita, in caluma canton, 45 minutes from montalvo.  the members of this bank work in agriculture, growing oranges, bananas, 'orito' (a small, sweet variety of banana), cacao and coffee.

rodolfo works looking after his cacao, oranges, 'orito', bananas and coffee as these are long-cycle crops.  he makes his purchases in san rafael shopping center in caluma and makes his sales in montalvo.

rodolfo is requesting this loan to buy supplies such as fertilizers, urea and fungicides for weeds.  he will also buy ranger to deal with diseases among his crops.  the loan will help him to increase the quality of his produce and avoid losing crops.  his dream is to buy a plot of land so that he can continue sowing his crops as he enjoys his work.

in his free time, rodolfo enjoys carrying out social work such as helping his neighbors clean the streets.

romeo c. is from the village of jasaan, misamis oriental. he is 46 years old. romeo is married and has four adult children. to make a living, romeo operates a specialized retail store. the main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. romeo has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 8,000 philippine pesos a month for these activities. in 2009, romeo joined hspfi to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. romeo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 php from hspfi, a kiva partner. this previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. romeo is requesting a new loan of 10,000 php, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. this will be the third loan taken out by romeo from hspfi. he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. about hspfi: hspfi is one of the accredited partners of opportunity international in the philippines. it is based in cagayan de oro city and is reaching out to the poor households of northern mindanao. *note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva. given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

fati is an active woman of 41 years old from tamalgu in the northern part of ghana. fati is married and has 7 children. she is the woman seated third in front from right to left in the group photo. 

fati is a member of shea nuts and butter processing group who have been doing the business over the last 4 years. their group is named ‘suglo nbori buni - tamalgu’ women group. she enjoys and makes good profits from the business since she and every member of her group have been trained by grameen ghana and partners on how to process high quality premium shea nuts and butter for local buyers and exporters.

fati and the group have asked for their next cycle of loan of ghc 12,900.00 after having paid off a previous loan of ghc 8,800.00. fati’s share of this loan is ghc 500.00 which would help her to pay for the cost of 2 more bags of shea nuts meant for production of shea butter. with this, fati would increase productivity and payback the loan. she also intends to support her children by providing for their educational and health needs. fati is highly appreciative of her lenders’ support.

josé luis is a 30-year-old father who lives with his wife and two school-aged children in a family member's home, located in one of the hamlets that make up the rural area of the district of cayalti, a district dedicated to commerce, crop farming and animal husbandry. 

he earns a living preparing food and drink to sell to workers in the farming enterprises in the area. this business is quite well-attended since the majority of workers in those enterprises are not from the area and cannot return home to consume their meals during break times. at the same time he raises poultry and sheep in the area where he resides. 

josé luis wishes to venture into the commercialization of the excrement produced by the animals he raises for agricultural uses (it is used as fertilizer in the region). for this purpose he has requested a loan of 2,000 peruvian soles that he plans to invest in the purchase of containers and the hiring of workers to gather up the excrement from his animal pens and package it prior to sale. 

josé luis hopes that, with this business, he is able to increase his earnings and so get his family ahead. he appreciates in advance the persons who support him in reaching his goal.

johnrey is 20 years old and is the fourth of six children in the family. his mother, joemima, is a member of negros women for tomorrow foundation, inc. and supports the family through her rice retailing business in the philippines.

johnrey is studying for a bachelor's of science in information technology and is currently in the second of this four-year course.

joemima is borrowing php 6,500 to pay for tuition fees of her son, johnrey, for the first semester of the school year 2015-16.

johnrey plans to graduate and be gainfully employed in the future.

ignacia yemileth is a member of the “desarrollo” (development) communal bank.  she’s married and has four daughters.  her husband works building houses.  her daughters are students.  she is a responsible, hardworking woman who very much wants to get ahead; she lives in colon.

for the last ten years ignacia has been working selling snacks and natural beverages.  her work schedule is 9am to 3:30pm.  one of her advantages is that she has many customers because they like the product she offers.

ignacia needs the loan she’s requesting to buy raw materials to make her snacks and natural beverages like: flour, lard, bananas, chicken, tamarinds and melon, among others.  with support from this loan ignacia will be able to stock her business so that sales will be greater and her living conditions will be better.  

her goals are to make her business grow and to raise her children.  her greatest challenge is being able to have her business at home because she doesn’t have a stable place to sell her snacks.  ignacia has been a fama client for three cycles and she’s made all her installment payments punctually.

oscar omar is 35, single, and lives with his children in recinto rancho grande, which is part of ventanas canton. he has children ages 14, 6 and 2.

the "bendición de dios" communal bank is located in recinto rancho grande, in puerto pechiche parish, 45 minutes from the program office. it is made up of 11 members.

oscar omar is a farmer, and grows corn. he is applying for the loan in order to buy urea, manure, and insecticides to improve his crops. he does his purchasing and sales in ventanas on a weekly basis. his dream is to acquire his own piece of land. the challenges he faces are pest infestations that affect the crops, such as locusts.

in his free time he likes to rest, and enjoy pleasant times with his children.

juan manuel, 29 years old, is single and has one son who depends on him.  he lives with his siblings in a community of san lorenzo, a valley in southern honduras.

juan manuel does not have his own house and for two years, has been making a living selling groceries, soft drinks and detergents.  his customers prefer him for his good service and the accessibility of his business.  juan is an entrepreneur with desires to get ahead and improve his living conditions.  

he is applying for this loan to buy cement, bricks, bars, gravel, etc. to improve his housing since he is finishing construction of a sink and bathroom, and needs the money for the construction of the sink, bathroom and roof.

with the support of this loan, juan hopes to fulfill his need to construct his bathroom, that he so needs.  he is happy for the support to his business and now for the improvement to his housing.  his dream is to have his own home.

carlos is 21 years old, single and lives with his parents in the mocache canton, de los ríos province. he is a member of the communal bank “los luchadores” [the fighters], in recinto la guayas, mocache canton. the members of this communal bank work in agriculture.

carlos works in agriculture; he has been growing corn and rice for some years now. he buys the supplies in ventanas and sells them at the local marketplace and in cantón.

carlos is requesting a loan to buy compost and fertilizers to grow corn and rice. the loan has helped him to support the family’s economy. his dream is to study and become an engineer, so that he can improve his plantations. he likes to play sports and to study.

raymundo is a 52-year-old farmer from the town of garcia-hernandez, bohol. he is a married man and has two grown-up children. raymundo needs a loan for his farm. he is asking for a loan to buy seedlings, fertilizer and pesticides for the farm . with this, raymundo can produce more crops and vegetables which he can then sell at the market. \r\n\r\nin the future, raymundo has hopes of making his business a success.

judy is 50 years old and married. she has seven children, three of whom are enrolled in school.

judy is in the agricultural business, duck raising in the philippines. she has requested a php 10,000 loan through nwtf in order to buy feeds and vitamins for her ducks.

judy has been raising ducks for four years now and has borrowed from nwtf six times in the past to sustain her business.

in the future, judy would like to save enough money to continue sending her children to school.

meet eunice, a lady in eldoret who has been practicing agriculture for the last four years. to make ends meet, she sells milk, eggs, fruits and vegetables from her farm. as a mother of three, she also holds a job to get extra income for her family. of all her activities though, she is very passionate about horticulture. the only problem is that she does not have enough capital.

eunice is seeking financial support through a loan to be fully dedicated to horticulture. she is very good at horticulture and she believes it is her way out. she learned about kiva in a juhudi kilimo training and was impressed by the interest and repayment period terms. with your support, eunice will be able to expand her operations and increase her family's income.

rina is 34 years old and has four children. rina is a woman and has four children who are in school.

rina is in the agricultural business raising pigs in the philippines. rina requested a php 8,000 loan through nwtf to buy feeds, vitamins, and other supplies to raise her livestock.

rina has been in this business for 3 years now, and has borrowed 4 times in the past from nwtf to sustain it.

in the future, rina would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

mrs sri is the mother of 4 children and lives in sukun, malang regency on java, indonesia's largest island in terms of population.

in indonesia, like in many other developing nations, you need to treat water before you can drink it. unsurprisingly, most indonesians boil the water before they drink it. some people also buy water from refill stations which is not always safe.

mrs sri heard of a new option for disinfecting water when the promotion crew from nazava water filters held a safe water training in her vicinity. nazava water filters filter well, rain, and city water so it becomes safe to drink without boiling, without using fuel or electricity.

mrs sri, who is also a health worker, took the opportunity and became the reseller of nazava water filters in her community. this is the third time mrs sri applies for a loan. she has an excellent record in repaying her loans.

this loan will allow mrs sri to buy 10 filters and sell them on credit to her community making safe drinking water available to 50 people.

ligia, 27 years old and single, has worked as an account manager for two and a half years. in addition to this, she sells gold and silver-plated jewelry to earn extra income and support her mother because right now she does not have her own family. she is requesting her third loan to invest in her small business, buying items so she will be able to offer more to her customers and satisfy their demands. her dream for the future is to have her own business that will allow her to giver her family a better quality of life.

kousar is a 27-year-old widow. she is an active and talented lady who excels in the work of stitching. she has gained years of experience in this field and has gotten a lot of appreciation from the people of her community. she didn’t lose hope after the death of her husband and continued her stitching work to support the needs of her two children. for meeting the requirements of her customers she needs to purchase more spools of thread and packs of lace, buttons and needles. she applied for a loan of pkr 30000 to kashf foundation. she is in her 2nd loan cycle and is very much thankful to kashf for its support. she dreams of expanding her business in the future.\r\n\r\n

rose a. is a 50 year old widow with six children. one of the kids is currently in school, while the others have completed their schooling. rose enjoys selling and has a great deal of experience in customer care. she has been selling maize and gari for thirty years to support her family.

she treks to farming communities to buy her stock from the farmers. this saves her from middlemen who buy from the farmers and resell to her at higher price. she wants to use this loan to buy maize and bags of gari in bulk to meet the daily demands of her customers. she hopes to use part of her profit to support her kids who are ready to enter university this year.

rose is a member of a community group called first kings trust group. in this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans.

the group named bokk jom was created 2 and a half years ago, at the same time when the communal bank to which they belong was created. it is made up of 28 women who live in the same quarter. their principal activity is a small business. 

mrs. codou s., pictured above the crow, is the leader of the group. she is 48 years old. she is a widow and she lives with her 7 children. 

she has a business selling fresh and candied fish. she manages her business very well, following 5 years of experience. 

her new loan is in the amount of 500.000 francs and she will increase the quantity of merchandise she purchases. 

since the passing of her husband, the income generated from this small business has permitted her to support her children, purchasing every month their food and paying the water and hydro bills, etc.

flora is a widowed woman with three children. she is a very hard working entrepreneur; she has a meat vending business in the philippines. flora is 55 years old.

flora requested a php 30,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy more meat to sell, and other supplies needed in her business.

flora has been in this business for four years.

in the future, she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

salen’s group lives in a rural village in banteay menachey province in cambodia. salen makes a living cultivating rice, and she also does extra work as a farmer to support her family. in her village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help salen safeguard the health of her family, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

neliza is a married woman with eight children. she is 57 years old and two of her children are still in school.

neliza is a very hardworking entrepreneur. she has a buy-and-sell tobacco business in the philippines. she requested a 7,000 php loan through nwtf to buy more tobacco to sell to her customers.

neliza has been in this business for 30 years. in the future, she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

nelia is a married woman with six children. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur. nelia is 55 years old and has one child still in school.

nelia has a fishing business in the philippines. nelia requested a php 14,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy materials like a fish net, gasoline for her boat, and other materials for her business.

nelia has been in this business for 15 years. she would like to save money to expand her business.

rono is a 29-year-old farmer in litein, south rift, kenya. he is married with one child aged one. he has been in farming for 11 years and currently produces milk and tea for the local market.

rono has requested a loan of 31,200 kes from juhudi kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow to boost his dairy business. he says he will use the income to improve the living standards of his family by providing them with the basic needs they currently lack.

he points at lack of finances as the major challenge for smallholder farmers.

maría isabel is 52 years old, married and lives together with her husband, mother-in-law and children in cayaltí. she is from a close-knit family, and they live in a community in which trading, farming and animal husbandry are common. cayaltí is a district located in the province of chiclayo, lambayeque region, on the north coast of perú. \r\n\r\nmaría isabel makes a living raising and selling guinea pigs and ducks. she also receives an income from her husband who is a teacher in two educational institutions. the loan is destined to be used to make improvements to their home. this will result in an improvement in the layout of their home, which will improve their quality of life.

sorn’s group lives in a rural village in takeo province in cambodia. sorn makes a living cultivating rice and also does extra work as a factory worker to support his family.

in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these group members safeguard the health of their families, save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

leili went to school through ninth grade. her husband works in agriculture and masonry, and they have three children who are already adults.

leili works in agriculture, since she produces her own crops with the help of her husband and children. in addition to this, she works as a seamstress on weekends, and she learned this from her mother. another of her activities is raising cattle.

thanks to five loans that she has received previously, she has been able to improve her life. she has already paid off four, and she only needs to complete [paying off] the most recent. she needs a new loan to buy compost and pay to rent the land where she plants basic grains.

she dreams of having abundant crops and setting up a formal business of selling basic grains.

her name is jocelyn, a hardworking woman from buhangin, davao city who raises two children with her husband archie, a taxi driver. since her husband’s income is unstable and it usually cannot suffice for their everyday expenses and children’s education, jocelyn decided to embark on direct selling of home and personal care products. she chose this business because it typically requires low capital to begin with. then she enhances it by expanding her network of target consumers. not only this, she started to build a pigpen just recently because she has a plan to buy piglets that she can raise very soon. she tries her best to enhance her family’s financial resources in order to support the needs of her children and push through their college education until its completion.

now jocelyn aspires to improve her business with the aid of additional capital amounting to php 18,000. she will use it to buy more personal and home care products that she can sell to her friends, neighbors and other network. she will also start her hog-raising venture with one to two piglets and a few sacks of feed. she’s positive that this additional capital will boost her income and savings.

her dream is to have a stable business so she can buy a four-wheel vehicle someday. she also desires a good future for her children and harmonious relationship among her family. she meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the word of god. *all cct community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

this group is comprised of 5 women who are in different kinds of business such as selling of second hand clothes, kitchen ware, rearing of poultry and selling of building materials. the group leader is 52 yrs old  has 5 children aged between 22yrs and 28 months. the women live in komarock area within nairobi and they have been using the traditional cook stove for cooking. with traditional cook stoves, there is a lot of indoor air pollution (iap)which leads to respiratory diseases and also there is a lot of charcoal consumption by the traditional stoves.

currently on average each member spends usd1.3 on charcoal everyday. the loan will enable them purchase high efficient cook stoves- eco zoom that will save them up to 50% of their daily consumption on charcoal. these cook stoves also reduce smoke and carbon emissions from the charcoal thus creating a better and cleaner environment for their families.

the families will be able to save usd 0.65 daily from the reduced consumption on charcoal.  this translates to usd234 every year for at least 5 years (lifetime of the cook stove).  this money will be saved and used for other needs like paying for their children's school fees, paying rent and making their lives better.

meet the members of the “women of progress” group from waterloo, a small town in western sierra leone. they are all local entrepreneurs who have come to smt, a partner of kiva.org, to apply for a loan of 500,000 sll apiece. with the help of this loan they hope to expand their respective businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. \r\n\r\nwendy is the featured leader of this group. the 39-year-old is married to an “okada driver” (motorbike taxi driver) and they have 3 children together. wendy has been a businesswoman for many years now; she sells “achekeh” (food made from cassava roots). with her share of this loan, she will buy a large quantity of ingredients in order to cook a larger amount of achekeh to sell.

lourdes arambuloo, who lives in the island village in the town of binangonan, rizal province in the philippines, is a woman of courage who maintains hope in her ability to rise above poverty. happily married to felix, a 37-year-old fisherman and her business partner, she is a mother to three boys and a girl.
