lourdes joined ashi (ahon sa hirap, inc.), an mfi and kiva partner in the philippines, in 1999, and during her ten years as a member of ashi, she has been noted for her exemplary performance in meeting her obligations in the organization. her previous loans were carefully used as rolling capital for her fishing business. because fishing allows her to earn just enough income for her family needs, she recently ventured into raising pigs, an enterprise that will bring her enough profit to save for the future of her children. fishing will now become her secondary business.

she is now requesting her ninth loan, 45,000 pesos to pay for 10 piglets, 26 sacks of assorted feeds, vitamins and transportation expenses. lourdes is hopeful that the trust and opportunity given by ashi and kiva, coupled with hard work, will allow her to reach her dreams of expanding her business, sending her children to school, and building a new and more spacious house.

voeun, 58, is a widowed mother of two garment factory children who resides in the village in svay reang province, cambodia. she is a rice farmer and has been working on her rice farm for over 20 years to earn income to support their living expenses.

in order to increase her crop yields and family profits, she is now asking for a loan with a group of four members. as the group leader, she would like to use her loan share to cover the plowing expenses and to purchase natural compost for cultivating rice in dry season. with the profits from this season’s harvesting, she is going to enlarge her farmland and to build a new house.

analisa is 34 years old and married. she has two children who are both in school. analisa works very hard to provide for them.

analisa runs a general store in the philippines. she has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items.

analisa requested a php 10,000 loan through nwtf to buy items to sell like canned goods, beverages, home care products, and other groceries.

in the future, analisa would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

margaret, 45, is happily married. she practices dairy cow farming with her husband, and they support the family together. she has done this business for many years and enjoys feeding the community with milk. the quality of her milk is outstanding, and she is getting many orders.

she will buy another hybrid dairy cow to boost her daily milk collection and offer better services. this is her second loan cycle, and she has a good repayment history. her dream is to be a great dairy farmer.

gemma is 32 years old and married with one child.   she works hard to provide for her family.   

gemma runs a sari sari (variety) store in the philippines.  she has been running the store for 10 years and also earns an income from food vending.  

gemma requested a php 20500 loan through nwtf to buy more items to sell.  she has borrowed and paid 6 loans from nwtf before this loan.   gemma aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future for her family.

"i only have a small rice farm until it grows. my husband and i have been tilling our farm since the start of our marriage. all we want is to have an abundant harvest to be able to provide for the needs of our two dear children," says mrs. joan d., a 31-year-old farmer from agusan del sur, mindanao. she would like to ask for a loan of php 14,000 from cevi. she will use the loan to purchase seven sacks of fertilizer and pesticides as well. she thinks that by doing so, she can improve their harvest. cevi is reaching out to a lot of poor families. it gives not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

marilyn, who is 37 years old, is married, with six children, four of whom are currently in school. she is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

marilyn has a business selling food in the philippines.  she has requested a php 11,000 loan amount through nwtf to buy ingredients and materials for preparing her food.

marilyn has been in this business for one year. in the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

furaha is 29 years old, married, and the father of one child. for the last five years, he has earned a living by supplying water in malindi. he earns a monthly profit of 10,000 kes. furaha was introduced to kadet by a credit officer and he is applying for his fourth loan now. this loan, of 20,000 kes, will help him to purchase the additional water tank that he needs for his business. he will use the profits made possible by the loan to pay school fees for his child as well as to expand his business. furaha's goal for the future is to own a well-established water distribution depot in the area, so as to improve his family's living standards.

bunnaley’s group lives in a rural village in preah vihear province in cambodia. bunnaley makes a living cultivating rice and he also does extra work as farmer to support his family. in his village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water.

bunnaley is requesting a loan to buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for his family. having a water filter at home will help each of these group members safeguard the health of their families, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

josephine is 49 years old and married with four children.

she works hard to provide for her family. she runs a general store in the philippines, and requested a php 6000 loan through nwtf to purchase additional stock to sell, like soap, milk, sugar, etc.

josephine has borrowed and paid six loans from nwtf before this loan. she has been running the general store for 11 years and also earns an income from farming vegetables.

she aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

lydia ailo o. is a 43-year-old skilled and experienced businesswoman who has a longstanding relationship with her school. she operates her own private school where she earns a living. she is married to kaloli wandera. they have five children aged 25 years, 21 years, 17 years, 16 years and 8 years, respectively. they live in kabiyemit eldoret, kenya

lydia started her business in 2005 with ksh. 25,000 startup capital. she has been in this business for the past five years with an income of kshs. 60,000 per month.

she was introduced to kadet ltd by a credit officer and she is applying for her first loan of kshs.25, 000 with kadet ltd. with her loan, she plans to buy stationary and desks.

stella n. is single and the mother of one child. she supports her small family by selling new clothing, and has joined with four of her friends to secure a loan to buy more inventory. with the extra profits made possible by this loan, stella plans to open a retail shop.

linet,35,is happily married and blessed with 5 children.her husband is a teacher by profession and they support one another.she is a dairy cow farmer who sells milk for a living.she is a hardworking honest lady as she is well known who has been doing this business for many years.she will use this loan to buy animal feeds to in crease her daily milk collection and grow her income.her profit will pay her loan in a short period of time so that she can take another loan.her dream is to grow her business and educate her children.

arlen is a young 29-year-old coffee producer. he has done this activity for 5 years. since he was a little kid he has been involved in some kind of agricultural activity.

his dream is to have a productive and sustainable farm. in order to make that happen, he has been working in the execution of the technical recommendations that the technical team of the association to which he is affiliated to has given him. thanks to these recommendations, in the last year he has increased his coffee production in a 20 percent.

with the purpose of continuing with the improvement of his farm productivity, arlen is requesting a loan to buy supplies for his coffee crops and with this have better results in this new cycle. this will help him to give his family better living conditions.

wilfredo went to school until high school. he is married and his children live on their own.

wilfredo has had a store in his house for 1 year and also works as a plumber in the community. his wife helps him attend to the customers that buy in his store.

he needs a loan to buy first need products to sell in his store.

wilfredo dreams of his business being prosperous and having good health to continue working.

cecilia is 44 years old and married to josphat. the couple is blessed with three children, ages six, 14 and 16. for the past nine years, cecilia has run a photocopier, stationery, and m-pesa (cell phone-based payment system) business. she earns a monthly income of about 26,850 kes to take care of her family.

cecilia is requesting her second loan from kadet ltd to purchase more stationery and repair her photocopier machine. this will be her second loan from kadet. cecilia will use her anticipated profit to open another branch in kitengela.

in the future, cecilia hopes to establish a wholesale stationery store in kitengela and open another m-pesa outlet.

carmen t., 47, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. she is married to perigryn t., a driver, and they are blessed with six children. she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. she has been managing her own piggery while overseeing their slipper-making business. she also owns a clothing store and a hot dog / hamburger stand.

carmen has been a regular member of center for community transformation (cct)* for more than a year now. she regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in cct’s cooperative. she is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.

to ensure the success of her business, carmen would like to apply for an 18,000 philippine peso loan. this money will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business to buy more products for her clothing and snack stand. she will also invest some of the loan into buying feed for her swine and raw materials for their slipper business. she dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* all cct community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

sok keang, 37, is married and resides with her husband and four children in kampong cham province, cambodia. 

she and her husband have been cultivating corn, sesame and beans for over 10 years, earning approximately usd 7 per day. two of her children are farm workers who earn approximately usd 5 per day. 

sok keang is asking a loan of usd 500 to rent the farmland where she is planting her crops. this money would enable her to acquire security for this agricultural work. 

in the future, she would like to purchase farmland and help her children get bachelor’s degrees. moreover, she plans to build a new house as soon as possible.

jose is 24 years old; he is single, and he has no children. he lives with his mother and two siblings, but only his mother is dependent on him.

jose works as a farmer, and he has six years of experience at his job. he walks to his job, and he works from 6:00 am to 3:00 pm.

he is requesting a loan to buy farming supplies to grow basic grains and to pay the rent on the land where he farms. he dreams of a future where his crops grow well, he has excellent harvests, and his income increases in order to support his mother.

otgonbayar is 28 years old and the mother of two sons, aged 2 and 8. she lives with her family in the outer ger (tent) district, which lacks the basic infrastructure of ulaanbaatar city, mongolia. otgonbayar supports her family by operating a clothing business. she knits and sews blouses and jackets using camel wool. \r\n\r\npreviously, she was rented a small stall at the largest outdoor market in the city. since the beginning of this year, she knits her products at home and sends them to the suburbs to be sold. she will use the requested loan to buy a variety of yarns.

liliana lives in the village of san isidro with her family. liliana works growing taro, pineapple, and raising pigs. thanks to god, she has her own land with quality water sources which help her to tend her crops in a very good way. for some years, she has worked in agriculture and she says that she began this work with the help of her mother and father who died, but these days she is grateful for their instruction since now she does this work with a lot of love, so it is noted in the way she tends her crops. she has the help of her older brother who is her right hand in her work.

she is asking for the loan to purchase a pump and tools to implement an irrigation system on her plots of land since summer is coming and she wants to be prepared so her crops do not lose quality.

liliana expects the loan to help her a lot since, by implementing the irrigation system, she will be able to cultivate any crop since her dream is to establish a good business in her village where she can offer a variety of products and, so, generate more income.

santa cruz de yojoa, honduras
february 2017

mrs.narantsetseg is 58 years old lives with her husband in a small house in selenge province. her husband donoi stays home and works as a russian to mongolian translator. her 2 children are married and live separately from them.

\r\n\r\nmrs.narantsetseg has been taught by russian agrarian how to grow mushrooms and produce organic products from them. she has started her organic mushroom growing and producing business last year. she is now requesting 1'000'000 mnt to install a heating system to her mushroom growing green house, to extend the period of growing. she is a hardworking, welcoming and modest woman.

jane, age 58, sells fresh food items and firewood to earn a living. her primary challenges are weather changes and inadequate capital for expansion. nevertheless, she would like eventually to build a commercial establishment for her business.

jane has six children and lives in fort portal.

she is requesting a loan in order to buy fresh foods like tomatoes and beans to offer for sale.

mom’s group lives in a rural village in battambang province in cambodia. 

mom works as a farmer to support her family. in the group's village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. 

having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save both money otherwise spent on medical expenses and time spent collecting fuel and boiling water.

luzviminda m. is 43 years old and married with six children, three of whom are in school. luzviminda works very hard to provide for them.

luzviminda buys and sells rice in the philippines and requested a php 25,000 loan through nwtf to buy more stocks of rice to sell.

luzviminda has been in this business for four years. 

in the future luzviminda would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

reach’s group lives in a rural village in prey veng province in cambodia. reach\u200b\u200b makes a living cultivating rice and selling vegetables to support her family. in her village, there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help reach safeguard the health of her family, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

the woman in this photo is dilbar. she was born in 1981 in a workers family. she is married and has three children. she shares responsibility with her husband and take care of her three children.\nshe deals with buying and selling cotton. she has been working more than ten year in this sphere. she has a great experience. she loves her job and does very well. her husband helps her with managing the business. the income of their business is good and they has bought a flat where currently living.\nshe needs money to expand her business. with this aim she is asking for a loan 13 000 somoni to buy more cotton for her retail business. she is returning client and has positive credit history. it is her second loan through kiva’s field partner imon. she promises to pay back her loan on time. she awaits you support and mercy.

hilda cerefina sells fruits and vegetables. this is not first time she has a requested loan. therefore, the experiences she had have been rewarding. for more than 22 years, hilda has been a vendor. she wishes to help her family get ahead. this is her motive for continuing to work hard every day. this loan will be used to purchase melons, watermelons, cabbage, onions, potatoes and other fruits and vegetables.

juan is 28 years old. he is single and lives in the community of san pablo. juan works as a professional driver. he has a taxi. he is requesting the loan to buy new tires. he works every day in the taxi. he lives with his parents. his dream is to have his own taxi, because he now drives his father's taxi. he faces challenges, such as his financial situation. in his free time, he works taking care of bean crops.

safura is a hardworking 57-year-old woman from bimbilla in the northern region of ghana. she is married and has six children. safura is the individual in the middle of the photo with both hands raised among members seated. safura is a member of a shea butter processing group that has been in business for a decade now. the name of the group is 'malititi - masaka bimbilla'. safura earns a good profit from her shea butter business. she sells her products in the local markets and sometimes to exporters.\nsafura and malititi - masaka bimbilla group have asked for a third cycle loan of ghs 12,450.00, after having successfully paid-off a previous loan of same amount. safura’s share of the loan is ghs 500.00, which would be used to buy shea nuts for processing. safura aspires to earn more income and expand her business as well as to repay this loan and support her family. safura thanks kiva lenders for their continuous support.

mahfirat is a repeated client of imon. she has a good credit history. mahfirat used her previous loans for developing her business. she is a hardworking and successful business woman. mahfirat sews and sells men's national clothes ‘chapan’. mahfirat has been busy with this activity for more than 31 years. she sews ‘chapan’ with high quality. that’s why she has her own regular customers. she earns a living this way. mahfirat lives with her husband and 3 children. her husband is a master at car repair. mahfirat is going to buy new washing machine because her washing machine is broken. she is asking for a loan of 3500 somoni to buy a washing machine. she awaits your support.

natividad is a single parent. she lives with her mother and her only son, who divides his time between studying at college and working part time. previously, natividad was selling chickens but it was not going well. now, by her own initiative, she decided to make a radical change and installed a small shop in her home offering everyday items to contribute to her son's income. to better serve her customers, she needs to buy a refrigerator to keep drinks and other products fresh. she is requesting a loan of $450 with the commitment to repay the loan in 6 months. this will enable her to meet her goals while serving her customers. let's support her efforts so that she can realize her goals.

natividad es madre soltera vive con su madre y su único hijo que comparte sus horarios de estudio en la universidad con un trabajo a medio tiempo, anteriormente ella estaba abocada a la venta de pollos al por menor; actualmente por iniciativa propia decidió cambiar radicalmente de rubro y ha instalado en su casa una pequeña bodega en la que oferta artículos de primera necesidad para contribuir con el dinero que genera su hijo con la actividad que desempeña en una institución de su ciudad.para cubrir las necesidades de sus clientes requiere comprar una refrigeradora con el fin de mantener las bebidas y otros productos bien conservados, porque la que tiene se encuentra en sus últimos días de vida útil; motivo por el cual solicita un préstamo de 450 dólares con el compromiso de retornarlos en un período de seis meses, esto le permitirá cumplir sus deseos en beneficio de sus clientes. colaboremos con el esfuerzo de natividad para que siga progresando en la actividad que realiza

translated by kiva volunteer, emily charnes

esperanza is a young woman who has dreamed her whole life of having her own business and helping her parents to get ahead.  through a lot of hard work, she has met her goals.  esperanza now has her own workshop where she makes pre-ordered clothing.  she also makes clothing to sell at a small stall she has at her local market.  with her mother's help, esperanza has learned to connect her jobs; she also works for a private company as a accounting assistant to earn more money.  esperanza is requesting this loan to purchase raw materials, as she has a lot of orders for uniforms for this school session, and she wants to take advantage of the opportunity.  esperanza is grateful for the confidence and help that kiva and afodenic have given her.

mrs. teresa del pilar belongs to the “las abejitas” communal bank, in the district of moyobamba, moyobamba province, department of san martín. she is 38 years old, in a stable relationship, and the mother of 4 daughters who still depend on her. it is for them that she endeavors day after day. teresa del pilar dedicates herself to making hand-sewn artistry and selling toys. her shop is located in her own house, in an ambiance well conditioned for attending to her customers. teresita, as she is lovingly called, is a very hard-working woman who day after day, puts much effort into her work. in this manner, she attempts to achieve her dreams and provide a good education for her daughters and see them become professionals down the road. with this loan of 1,300 new sols she will buy materials to create her designs, including professional patterns, artist's brushes, pencils, and cloth for making her hand-sewn artistry. part of the money will be used to buy plastic toys for boys and girls. teresa del pilar today feels like an accomplished woman, with much desire to continue forward and turn her dreams into reality. she is grateful to the movimiento manuela de ramos for helping her start her business, as well as those of many other women who wished to grow as entrepreneurs.

translated from spanish by harold sims, kiva volunteer

vy is a married mother of three children; one of them is in school. she is 45 years old and living in kampong thom province. growing rice, catching fish, and working as a paid worker have been the sources of her family’s income for many years. these businesses allow her to earn just enough income to cover the family’s living expenses and be able to save only a little income for future needs.

due to lack of working capital, vy is now requesting her first small loan. she intends to use her loan to buy a fishing net to support her current business catching fish. she hopes this loan can help her to earn more income in order to upgrade her family’s living conditions.

deri runs a small stall where he sells stationery and mobile phone airtime credits. he lives in sukabumi, a semi-urban area about 2.5 hours from jakarta. deri is single and lives with four people in the family house.

deri began working with ruma one month ago because he wanted to increase his income. he feels really excited to expand his business in selling mobile phone airtime credits and servicing bill payments. 

as the business continues to run, he hopes to get a kiva loan as working capital in order to do more transactions on weekends.

yang m., age 37, is a good mother to four children, and she always spends most of her time managing daily activities. her daily duties include cooking meals, cleaning house, caring for her children, and controlling other property in and around her house. she has a life partner in her husband who works in the construction industry. she has one daughter who often generates income for yang m. by working as a mobile hairdresser. yang m.’s daughter wants to open a small shop to provide hairdressing services. yang m. really wants to help her daughter but she doesn't have enough money to do so. therefore, yang m. is applying for a loan from kiva to help her daughter open a small beauty salon.

carlos enrique is a member of the communal bank “progresando”. he has a travel agency where he is in the business of selling tour tickets to different people, including foreigners and locals. the tickets he sells are to different places, such as macchu pichu and the sacred valley. carlos enrique works from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. he has been in this business for five years and is doing very well. his dream is to continue managing his travel agency.

he is requesting a loan in order to buy tour tickets to sell. carlos enrique is pleased with the loan and promises to complete his payments.

mirasol is 41 years old and has two children. she is married and both of her children are in school.



mirasol is in the agriculture business raising livestock in the philippines. she requested a php 19000 loan through nwtf to buy feeds, supplies, and vitamins to raise her livestock.



mirasol has been raising livestock for 4 years now, and has borrowed 6 times in the past from nwtf to sustain it.



she would like to save money to expand her business to secure the future of her family.

mideleidy is a law student. she is requesting a loan in order to cover education expenses. this is her story: "my name is mideleidy. i am 21 years old. my mother is currently unemployed and my father is an auto mechanic.

i am currently in my 12th quarter of my legal sciences major at the central university of the east (uce) in san pedro de macorís.

from an early age i learned to argue and fight for the rights of others, it was my god-given duty. that\'s why i enrolled to study law. i started with a payment plan that was provided to me by the department, thanks to my grades in high school. however, in the 4th quarter, that payment plan was taken away from me because i wasn\'t able to pay for the 5th quarter on time. since then, thank god, we have been able to pay for the other quarters, but i have a debt with the university that will not allow me to finish my studies, unless i pay the debt.

without the help of kiva, i won\'t be able to settle this account, or graduate, or get my bachelor\'s degree in law."

yuri is 21 years old and is married with one child.  she works together with her mother selling cold drinks such as soda, beer and juices.  yuri’s husband is an independent businessman.  

yuri has been working with kiva partner manuela ramos for a year and a half and is a member of the communal bank “las colinas” (the hills).  she invested her very first loan of 300 soles in purchasing drinks for her business and will do the same with this loan of 1200 soles.

yuri dedicates herself to her business full-time and is grateful to manuela ramos for showing confidence in her business by giving her loans.  thanks to her loans, yuri is moving forward with her business.  yuri’s goals are to have her own business locale (a soda fountain, for example) and to study cosmetology.

bayarlhagva is 37 years old and lives with his wife and two children in zavhan province, mongolia. his two children, ages 12 and 10, attend a local secondary school. his wife, otgontsetseg, is a salesperson and her monthly salary is 150,000 tugrugs (~ 110 usd). 

during the day, bayarlhagva earns his living by operating a meat and raw material trading business in his town. he has been operating his businesses since 2000, and has steadily expanded both businesses. his meat trading business is seasonal and his profit is high during the summer. bayarlhagva's monthly profit is between 80,000 – 150,000 tugrugs (~  60 – 110 usd).  he sells his products at his rental counter and has a loyal customer base. 

originally he was a herder  between 1990 and 2000 before he has started the meat and raw material trading business. bayarlhagva is a very hardworking person and is focused on the future. he says, “i started saving money for my children's tuition fees to provide a good education for them.” he is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase a plot of land with a house and yard for his family.

matías, 63, is married and has five children. he lives in a community in the town of gracias, lempira. he has worked in agriculture his whole life, growing corn and beans and now coffee. the coffee crop has been his biggest source of income for his family. he sells his crop pulped and dried in the local market.

he has already requested several loans to take care of his crops. he has been able to earn more profit and improve his home. currently he's requesting another loan, for 4,000 lempiras [hnl], to buy soil amendments for his coffee crop to improve his harvest.

matías plans to increase his production by planting more coffee plants so he can improve his family's lifestyle.

fredy is 24 years old.  once he left high school, he began an electrician course at the national learning service (sena) center.  ever since he graduated from this course, he has been growing in his profession as an electrician through projects in different areas of medellín. 

he is a man with a vast knowledge of his trade since he is continuously training and taking new courses.  for this reason, clients seek him out for projects.  however, he is currently stuck because the tools that he owns do not allow him to perform certain types of jobs.  therefore, he is requesting a loan to buy more tools so that he may work in an improved and more efficient manner.

his greatest dream is to be able to create jobs in his field and to train young people to carry out this type of work by sharing his knowledge with them.

charito is 43 years old, married, and has five children, three of whom are still in school. she has been raising pigs in the philippines for 10 years.

charito has borrowed three times in the past from nwtf to sustain her business. she is now requesting a php 10,000 loan to buy feeds, vitamins and other supplies to raise her livestock.

in the future, charito would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

lilibeth works hard to support her family. she is married and has a food vending business in the philippines.

she requested a php 25000 loan through nwtf to purchase spices, cooking oil, can goods, etc.

lilibeth has been in this business for 11 years now.

in the future, lilibeth would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

mathew is a maize farmer from burus village in kaduna. before he became a member of babban gona, mathew would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after the harvest, to meet his immediate cash needs. with this loan and babban gona’s support, mathew can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. mathew, like other members of babban gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and he hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

christegen is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the philippines. she is borrowing 15,000 php through nwtf to purchase more groceries to sell to her customers for her general store business. christegen has been in this business for 8 years. christegen earns additional income from rice retailing.

christegen has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from nwtf. she dreams of saving enough money to expand her business in the future.

mansir is a babban gona maize farmer from pala board mai chidiya
 village and resides with his family in a humble mud house. mansir has a daughter, saratu; whom he hopes would be a great doctor. 

previously, mansir and his family were only able to eat 2 meals a day despite toiling for several hours on the farm. however, as a babban gona member, he now has access to better yielding seeds, fertilisers, herbicides and other essential inputs that will help him to efficiently optimise his farm and attain yield of up to 3.8 metric tonnes per hectare; which translates to 2 times the national average in nigeria. this not only increases his income earnings 2.8 times the national average but also increases mansir’s yield, ensuring that his family will never go hungry again. in his quest to provide enough food for his family and pay his daughter’s school fees, mansir also hopes to secure a bright future for his child. 

this season, he will use the income generated from his maize sales to satisfy these personal income goals. mansir’s greatest memory as a babban gona farmer was when he built a house for his family. mansir is confident that with babban gona his future is secure and that he will have many more great memories and amazing accomplishments together with his family.

hyam is a 37-year-old married woman.  she is the mother of three daughters and two sons. a few years ago, hyam started a beauty salon business at home using one hair dryer and few tools.  she also sells makeup products.  recently, she was able to enlarge her business by adding beauty salon seats and got more hair dryers and a straightener. she still needs some hair tools and wants to add some facial products, for which she has applied for this loan.

mayra is 29 years old. she is married and has three children. evelyn is 11, elizabeth is 10, and britany is 7. mayra decided to start her own business because there were no places to work, and the needs of her home were becoming more critical every day. the desire to move her family forward caused her to put into practice her business idea. for 10 years she has worked raising and selling chickens. with this income she has managed to put bread on the table of her humble home every day.

she aspires to to have a shed for her pigs. she is known as being friendly, collaborative, humble and responsible. her business has benefitted her family as she has been able to share moments of happiness with them. she needs to buy more chickens, ground corn, concentrated feed and small potatoes. this will allow her to improve her production, maintain her business, and continue paying for her household expenses.

alejandra is a married woman with three children. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur. alejandra is 46 years old and all of her children are in school. she has a business selling seafood in the philippines. alejandra requested a php 23,000 loan amount through nwtf in order to buy more seafood to sell. she has been in this business for ten years. in the future, alejandra would like to save enough money so she can continue to send her children to college.\r\n

gumbo, 41, has six children. as group leader, she is representing her group of 10 farmers in matete district, kenya.

gumbo has been farming with one acre fund for years now, having joined the program for the first time in 2012. this decision was largely a result of her desire to have access to quality training and to acquire new farming methods.

although she describes her last harvest as poor due to bad weather conditions, she believes she could have a better one this year by continuing to work alongside one acre fund. gumbo has also decided to purchase a solar light as part of her loan, which she is very excited about. it will allow her to have light during dark hours for her children to study.

obtaining this loan means that gumbo's group will receive 11 solar lights and farming inputs to plant four acres in total.

rosaly is a married woman. she is 47 years old with four children. she is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

rosaly has a food vending business in the philippines. rosaly requested a php 30,000 loan amount through nwtf to purchase meat, vegetables and other ingredients for her business.

rosaly has been in this business for 10 years. she would like to save money to expand her business.

florence is 30 years old and married with 7 children. five of her children are currently attending school.

florence is a farmer from kisii town, in western kenya, where she has been farming for eight years. her farm produces maize, milk, tea, coffee and sugarcane, which she sells locally. she depends mainly on the income from her farm to meet her family’s needs. 

she has requested this loan of 40,000 kes through juhudi kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. the extra income from this loan will help improve her family’s living conditions and pay school fees for her children. in the future, she aspires to increase her number of dairy cows from the current 2 to 5, and to start a posho mill business. however, she faces the challenge of lack of financing to buy farm implements like fertilizers, which affects her production.

vechna is a 31-year-old villager of cheung prey district of kampong cham province. she is married with one young daughter. she has been a rice farmer for 12 years, and she also raises ducks to sell. she manages to save about $7 us per day. \r\n\r\nas a new member and the leader of her group, vechna is applying for a 1,000,000 riel loan to buy rice seed and duck feed. she hopes that she will have enough capital for future investment in her rice farm.

mario is a smiling, charismatic, and simple person who began a business raising birds in 2002, with the objective of improving his living conditions in his home, providing a better quality of life, and supporting his 3 children with opportunities to go to school so that they can become education and aspire to a better future. mario dreams of improving his home's condition, remodeling his kitchen, bathrooms, painting his home, floor, and roof.

mario comes to the kiva community with the intention of seeking a loan to economically support the rotation for raising chickens all year around. he needs a greater quantity of animals in order to achieve this. therefore the loan will be used to buy chickens and feed to raise and fatten them.


if you want to know more about the entrepreneurs and the loans from interactuar, you can join the lending team called: “friends of interactuar colombia”: http://www.kiva.org/team/interactuar_colombia

lucila continues to work raising cattle and farming. she has a plot of land where she grows vegetables such as onions, carrots and pumpkins, which she later sells in different markets, as well as selling cattle. 

with these small businesses lucila strives to get ahead. her dream is to have her own store where she can sell her vegetables. 

lucila has asked for a loan to buy seeds and fertiliser for her land. she is grateful for the loan she has been granted and promises to meet her repayments on time.

chhin a. is a local farmer who has been living in the city of phnom penh.  she can make a profit from this farming business of around $3 per day, and her husband also assists her in the same business. she always cultivates rice crops on her own farmland in both rainy season and dry season. \r\n\r\npresently, she will plant her crop for the dry season rice field but she lacks some farming supplies. chhin a. would like to request a loan to buy necessary farming supplies to start growing her crops. she hopes to use the rest of the loan funds to fix her broken machine. chhin a. is blessed with three children, two of whom are single. one is married and lives independently.

day’s group live in a rural village in prey veng province in cambodia. day makes a living cultivating rice to support his family. in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women and man to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

most of the kenyan people struggle to make their way in the world because of unemployment and lack of capital. this is true for tabitha, 51, who is based in the chuka area of kenya and is a mother of two adorable and lovely children. 

she has been practicing mixed farming for the past five years and managed to earn a decent income. her primary source of income has been milk, eggs, crops, and some personal businesses she engages in to make ends meet. she passionately loves dairy goat farming, and when asked what is most enjoyable about dairy farming, she stated “feeding my goats”. her hobby is milking her dairy goat. 

she sells goat milk to her neighbors and at the local market, but the demand has been overwhelming and she cannot meet the demand. for this reason, she is seeking a loan to buy an extra dairy goat, which will assist in increasing milk productivity. the dairy goat she plans to buy is not just an ordinary goat; it’s a quality breed of dairy goat that will produce between 1 to 2 liters of milk a day. this will immediately translate into more profit and increased income levels. profits from selling milk will be used in repaying back the loan in full, and the extra income will be used to increase her business enterprise. 

tabitha is very ambitious. in the near future, she intends to start adding value to her goat milk business by packaging the milk before selling it. she also plans to start selling dairy products such as yogurt. an improved income level will assure her family a secure future. by joining juhudi kilimo, which assists smallholder farmers, she will also benefit from free extension services and links to markets.

julia belongs to the “mujeres de la colina ii” communal bank, in la banda de shilcayo district, in the province of san martín, in san martín department. 

she is 39, and lives with her partner. she has three children, ages 22, 20, and 8, of whom only the youngest is in her care, and attends primary school. 

with three children to support, and with her husband's salary not being enough to pay the household expenses, she decided 12 years ago to sell beauty products by catalogue. she did this with 600 soles of capital. it went well, because of the effort she put into it. 

she has been part of the communal bank for four years, which helps her obtain working capital, so that she can start selling new products that her customers need. as well, she has a good clientele, as she provides them with friendly service. 

with this loan of 3,000 soles, she will buy natural products, as well as merchandise such as clothing and beauty products for the christmas sales season.  

julia is an enterprising and hard-working woman. her dream is to open a spa, where she can apply the knowledge she has been acquiring about the beauty products she sells. this will enable her to continue generating her own income. 

thus she is very grateful for the support she has been receiving from the movimiento manuela ramos, through the loans and the orientation that she receives.

jocelyn is a hardworking female entrepreneur with five children.

she runs a general store in the philippines and has requested a php 14,000 loan through nwtf to buy items like canned goods, personal care products, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.

she successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business. 

jocelyn dreams that one day she will be able to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

noralyn is a married woman with two children. she is a very hard-working entrepreneur. noralyn is 30 years old and has two children who are in school.

noralyn has a fishing business in the philippines. she has requested a php 13,000 loan through negros women for tomorrow foundation, inc. (nwtf) to buy fish nets, gasoline, and other fishing supplies needed in her business.

noralyn has been in this business for ten years. in the future, she would like to save enough money, so she could afford to send her children to college.

meet dadiri. he is single and lives with his family in bekasi, a satellite city located at the east of jakarta. dadiri works as an employee in a private company, but  he realized he needed to increase his income in order to support his family's living. 

he decided to sell mobile phone airtime credits. he began working with ruma a year ago and he feels really excited to expand his business selling mobile phone airtime credits. as the business runs, he hopes to get a kiva loan as working capital loan in order to do more transactions on weekends. 

dadiri is the one in the photo.

khorn’s group lives in a rural village in battambang province in cambodia. khorn makes a living cultivating rice to support her family.

in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

this gentleman is a mechanic who opened his own automobile repair garage in 2007. the garage is located in the hédzranawoé area of lomé. over time, he has also benefited from the sale of spare automobile parts. he works with 5 apprentice mechanics who help him in his duties. he supplies himself in ghana with low-cost spare parts in order to then re-sell them to customers who need them. this sale allows him to realize a good profit margin. it is to buy new spare parts that he is seeking a loan through wages (one of kiva's field partners). he is unmarried and has no children.

translated from french by vilas menon, kiva volunteer

kheng’s group lives in a rural village in prey veng province in cambodia. kheng makes a living cultivating rice to support her family. 

in their village, there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families, save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

maría studied until the fourth grade in school. she is a single mother, since her children's father abandoned the family. 

maría has made a living selling fish for many years, and it was her mother who prompted her into this type of business. thanks to her work, she manages to provide for her children. she goes to another city to buy the fish and she travels by bus. she then sells them from 5:00am until 3:30pm.

maría needs this loan to buy fish to be able to continue her sales. she dreams that her children, who live with her, will finish their studies and have better employment opportunities.

lionel kentenich grew up in bujumbura, burundi, where he was raised by both his parents in a family of nine children. at 21 years of age he is a first-year student at kepler. he was able to complete his primary and secondary education with the support of his family. he chose to undertake university studies to increase his knowledge and broaden his perspective, making him suitable to get a well-paying job.

communications, with a concentration in business for the next three years, is to be his field of study, earning a bachelor’s degree at the end of the course. after graduating, lionel would like to have a job as a communications manager in a company, where he will be able to put his skills into practice. it will come with monetary benefits, enabling him to succour his family. lionel kentenich's long-term goal is to create his own enterprise, making him independent and able to provide jobs for some people in the community.

lauben is a 49 year old hard working man who resides in kamwenge uganda. he deals in cattle buying and selling to earn a living. 10 years in this business, he has been able to carry out some personal developments from the proceeds and his plan is to own more cows.

he also supplements his income with crop production though he is challenged by inadequate capital as well as price changes for agricultural produce in the market.

he is requesting a loan to buy more bulls for resale.

asma is a jordanian woman who is struggling. her husband was a soldier but is retired now. she is applying for a loan to pay her son abdullah's tuition fees.

this ambitious student wants to raise his family and help his neighbors. all this blessing is from god, his parents and your support. abdullah is an economics major. he is a special student who is facing a tight situation where he is expected to pay all his fees and his graduation expenses at once.

abdullah is in the photo instead of asma as she is a conservative woman.

the madoma group consists of three hardworking, determined, and enterprising women. one of them is sra. maría r.. she is 55 years old and has an eatery that has been operation for more than ten years. maría started out selling vegetables, meat, ice cream, ice, and sodas. within time, she decided to invest in food preparation. her goal is to open a restaurant as soon as possible since it is currently under construction.\r\n

\r\nthe other members of the group are mayra garcía alegría (age 58) and hiondra isabel s.. these two lively and creative women operate a workshop where they specialize in manufacturing intimate apparel.

duch is 43 years old and happily lives with her family in kompong cham province. duch earns a living by managing one hectare and a half of land for growing rice. she has her husband's help in the maintenance of the rice field to ensure a good output each harvest season. also, some of her teenage children help in the farm work when they are available from school. \r\n\r\nduch would like to improve her business and maintain healthy crops, so she is borrowing a loan of 2,500,000 khr to buy seeds and farm inputs such as fertilizers, insecticides and pesticides used for their rice fields. in the next few years, duch plans to purchase extra land to expand her rice production.

moun’s group live in a rural village in prey veng province in cambodia. moun makes a living cultivating rice to support her family.

in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

cecilia is a lovely lady from rural kenya. she has been doing mixed farming for 12 years to take care of her four children. her main income is from milk and crops grown on her farm. she stated that she loves what she does because it is sustainable for the environment and profitable as well. however, lack of funds is her biggest challenge.
 
cecilia is seeking a loan to purchase a chaff cutter. she has plans of expanding her dairy farm by growing her milk production volume. a chaff cutter is going to help her achieve the objective by shredding fodder into little evenly cut pieces that the stock can quickly and easily ingest and digest. feed in this form is also easily mixable to come up with a ration good for the stock.

with your lending, cecilia's stock will grow healthy and productive. this will boost the amount of milk she takes to the market. returns from the investment will enable her to repay the debt and afford education fees for her children.

sr. rosendo vicente g. a. provides transportation services using his own motorcycle taxi. he lives at home with his family, which consists of his wife and young children. his wife sells beauty products to help meet the family needs. \r\n

\r\nthe loan he is requesting will be used for maintenance of his motorcycle taxi. this loan is being granted to rosendo because he has good personal references and a good credit history.

shown in the photo are the members of the “top-up” group. they are small-scale businesspeople based in makeni city in northern sierra leone. they have come to smt, a kiva partner, to apply for a loan of sll 1,000,000 each in order to expand their businesses. with this loan, they will be able to make more profit and consequently improve on their standard of living.

the leader of this group is unisa k., pictured on the left. he is age 38 and was born in port loko, in northern sierra leone. he now lives in makeni, where he owns a kiosk and sells mobile phone accessories, top-up cards for all four mobile phone companies, and recharges mobile phone batteries for a fee of sll 1,000.

with his share of this loan, unisa will buy more top-up cards and mobile phone accessories to add to his business.

josenta atieno e. is 23-year-old mother of two children aged 6 and 3. a widow, josenta supports her family and sends the kids to school by selling "mandazi" in the morning and vegetables in the evening. she cooks the mandazyi herself and told us that all it takes is baking flour, sugar, a little salt and some milk to make the dough. then she fries it.

\r\n\r\njosente buys her vegetables from kibuye market in downtown kisumu and brings them back to the nyamasaria slum. she hopes to use the loan to purchase more inventory for her business and the rest for poultry or livestock as extra food security. she is asking for 20,000 ksh and would like kiva lenders to know that the profit will go to pay for school fees for her children.

hasanah. a is a 32 year-old married woman with one son and two daughters. hasanah. a has been weaving hats scout and her husband is a labor for fifteen years.

she has asked for a loan of idr 7.000,000 from kopsyah bmi. this loan will be used to build water sources at their home to improve access to sanitation and water sources for their family. her family income is insufficient to build toilets and water sources but hasanah. a will be able to repay the loan received.

she and her family want to live a healthy life with healthy sanitation and clean water. she is very grateful for the opportunity and wants to thank to all lenders.

maria is a businesswoman who has been involved in business activities since 2012.  she started with her own working capital of $300.00. 

she has a kiosk in her house and she is now requesting a loan of $800.00 from kiva partner tuba rai metin in order to improve her business in the future. she will buy additional supplies with the loan such as candies, detergent, noodles, biscuits, wheat, perfume, aqua, cooking oils, milk, salt. and other things to sell including hard drinks. 

she is happy, because with the loan from tuba rai metin, she will increase her income and her management can be strong.

rosa is 55 years old and a very hard working entrepreneur.

rosa has a food vending business in the philippines. she requested a php 25,000 loan through nwtf to purchase ingredients like meat, fish, vegetables, spices, etc. for her food vending business.

rosa has been in this business for two years. in the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

daraty, 28, is a resident at kampong chhnang province of cambodia. she is a mother of two children, aged 1 to 2 years. her family has been supported by her husband who is a sugarcane juice seller.

to gain more profits, she is now asking for a loan to purchase cows to fatten and sell. with the profits from the business, she is going to enlarge her farm, to renovate her house, and help her children to attend school.

sra. valentina m. f. is 52 years old and lives in the fatima subdivision of the city of tegucigalpa. she sells dairy products, such as cheeses (in different sizes) and butter. in addition, she manages a small grocery store. her dairy product sales are strong. valentina previously made chorizo sausages, but the cost of her ingredients and supplies kept increasing, and she did not have enough capital to keep making them. at the moment, valentina is requesting a loan to buy more dairy products. this type of product generates good sales because many people enjoy it for its flavor and hygienic preparation.\r\n

\r\nvalentina is married and has four grown children who have their own families. she says she is very happy that her business continues to grow each day.

translated from spanish by ronan reodica, kiva volunteer

josé anastaco is 50 years old, and he comes from the community of posoltega. he engages in buying, selling and slaughtering pigs. he has 6 children whom he is responsible for, and he teaches them to earn their living in a very honorable way. he has requested a loan to buy 3 pigs. in the future he wants to improve the purchase and the selling of pigs; he also wants his children to study but also to keep on working in the activity he has carried out with much effort.

elsie is a 50-year-old married woman and a mother of six children from carles, iloilo. she has been engaged in the fishing business for more than 27 years now. it is the source of her income.\r\n\r\nelsie is asking for a loan to buy fish net and engine. with this loan, her fishing business will improve thus generating more income. elsie dreams of making her business more productive and sustainable.

talatu is a maize farmer from gwani village. as a babban gona member, talatu is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give her the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times higher than the average nigerian farmer.

before joining babban gona, talatu would have had to sell her maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at its lowest, to meet her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. as a babban gona member talatu can to store the maize she harvests and delay its sale until a period later on in the season when she can obtain the best price for her maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

thanks to the support from babban gona’s marketing services, talatu no longer feels the pressure to sell her maize at low harvest prices. with the opportunity to earn up to $2000 per hectare of land, talatu hopes to realize better yields and plans on using her additional income to acquire more land to put into the babban gona program.

the dúo mariposa monarca
miriam is 33 years old. she started her business 4 years ago when she invested 500 gtq buying diapers and baby creams and her business has been growing. now she has a small store. her main wish is to one day be able to have a large store with the help of god and her family who help her a lot. she is grateful to god and to her husband for the help they have given her. at this time she is requesting a loan to by food products to sell.

shahnaz akhtar baji is a 52-year-old married lady and a citizen of lahore, pakistan for the last 21 years. shahnaz baji is the wife of r. h. who is a carpenter by profession. shahanz baji is the mother of four kids: two daughters and two sons. her sons are painters and paint houses and windows. her elder daughter works in a factory for a monthly wage. her younger daughter reads in the 10th standard. shahnaz baji operates a decorative embroidery business. she prepares embroidered dresses and sells them in the cloth markets to earn an income. she successfully repaid her prior three loans from asasah (a microfinance institute of pakistan). now she is applying again for a loan to buy material (beads, colored thread and sketches) for her decorative embroidery business. 

shahnaz baji is the group leader of another four women from her locality. jamila baji wants a loan to buy sanitary supplies (pipes, taps) to sell. riffat naz baji wants a loan to buy nimko and chips for her canteen. shakeela bano baji wants a loan to buy vehicle spare parts to sell. suraiya baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics and a hair dryer for her parlor. 

this is a group loan. the loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. the members mutually guarantee one another's loans. if one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

shagufta is a 34-year-old woman, married, with 2 children. her husband is a farmer. she lives in the small village of sialkot, pakistan.

to help her husband, she takes care of buffaloes for milking. she finds this activity profitable but lacks money to bring it to a scale where it can pay back reasonable profits. therefore, she has requested for a loan from jws pakistan to purchase an additional milking animal.

she is very thankful to kiva and jws pakistan.

martha r. is 37 years old, she lives on the outskirts of managua. she married young and has a 14 year old son, who is in school. she started a small mobile business selling fruits and vegetables, and with her husband's help, she was able to set up a small shop, which she has been running for 3 years. she also sells firewood, which her husband cuts down on their land. he is a farmer and rents land to cultivate. he grows beans and tomatoes and with this he supports and helps his family with their needs. because of a lack of capital, they have not been able to increase their inventory. this loan will be used to purchase the basic goods customers purchase day to day, including rice, beans, oil, soap, cheese, cream, chicken, cleaning products, and the sale of firewood, in order to generate more sales and increase their savings, so they can improve their home. martha thanks afodenic for the opportunity to improve her business.

translated from spanish by kristen jancuk beck, kiva volunteer

rosita is a 35-year-old married woman with four children, all of whom are in school. she is a very hard-working entrepreneur. rosita has a seafood vending business in the philippines. she has been in this business for six years.

rosita requested a php 5,000 loan through nwtf to buy additional seafood to sell. in the future, she would like to save enough money that she can afford to send her children to college.

helen is 27 years old. she lives with her partner in a common law marriage. she has a son, and lives with her spouse and son in the town of cofradía, cortés.

she has had a business selling food for one year. she is established in another area of the city, where she offers her customers a variety of foods and also sells sodas.

she seeks a loan of 10,000 lempiras to buy staple goods to make and sell food. this will help her sell more plates of food to improve her earnings. her goal is to improve her sales in order to have greater income that will allow her to remodel and improve her locale. she also wants to build her own house.

candelaria is 41 years old. she lives with her husband, josé luis, who is 43 and a driver, and her children jeaneth 19, mariela 16 and karen 7 years old. josé luis and candelaria are a real team. while candelaria makes the meals that they offer, josé luis attends to the diners, making their small business very attractive to the public who prefer candelaria´s cooking. the business is going well and growing in clientele. they have always like cooking and think that this line of work, which they have been in for 7 years, will be their window to success. candelaria is now in her second loan with microfinanzas prisma. with this money she will buy chairs, some tables and accesories to improve the business as well as ingredients to prepare her delicious meals.

translated from spanish by molly puglisi, kiva volunteer

anecita joined paglaum multi-purpose cooperative in the year 2008 and she appreciates the programs, services, and continuous education of the co-op. she is a member in good standing and very active in attending the various programs and services that the cooperative offers.

she is requesting a loan in the amount of php 5,000. this loan is intended to buy additional supplies, such as cement, roof, nail, hallow block, round bar, wood and hardiflex, for house repair.

anecita dreams of nothing more than to have a happy, healthy life and a safe home.

illuminada works hard to help support her six children. she is married and has a sari sari, or general store in the philippines.

illuminada has applied for a 4,600 php loan through nwtf to buy a solar-powered lamp. she is getting it because she wants to save money by minimizing her kerosene expenses. she is aware that by using it, she is not only saving money but is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

blanca is a 24 year old young woman, who lives in the post-conflict zone of sincelejo. she works making her own line of clothing. she also makes special requests, like, for example, the fuchsia dress pictured, ordered specifically by a client. she is the mother of two children. the oldest is three years old, and the youngest is only 3 months old. her two babies are in the growth stage.

to improve her job, increase her work and optimize her production times, blanca wants to seek economic support to invest in the purchase of an embroidery machine and raw material, primarily fabric. her dream is to have a stable and profitable business to pay for the education of her children.

this is gul, whose name means "flower". she is 51 and married and lives in the sarband region with her family. she has three growing children whose needs are growing, too. it was getting hard for her husband to provide for the children on his own, so gul started to work as well. for the past two years she has been selling bread products at the local market, an occupation she enjoys. she goes to work in all weather and in the future hopes to have her own space or booth.\r\n\r\nthe reason gul is looking for a loan is to purchase building materials to renovate her house. she doesn\'t have the money to finish the renovations. she hopes that she will receive this loan so she will be able to complete her renovations.

mrs. benita is a member of the communal bank "villa turística d. catac ii". she sells groceries and candy for a living; her business is located at the catac market, in the district of catac, recuay province, department of ancash. with the loan of $750 usd, which will be paid in 8 installments, she will purchase: 2 sacks of sugar, 2 sacks of rice, 1 box of oil, 1 pack of salt, 1 bag of semolina, 4 packs of 1.5 liter sodas, 4 bags of noodles, 3 large packs of yogurt, 3 small packs of yogurt, 3 boxes of shampoo, 2 bags of detergent, and 4 packs of toilet paper. she is 48 years old; she is married and has 6 children who are adults and are independent. her husband picks up occasional jobs.

translated from spanish by natalie kane, kiva volunteer.

la señora benita, pertenece al banco comunal villa turística d. catac ii, se dedica a la venta d. abarrotes y golosinas, su negocio esta ubicado en el mercado d. catac del distrito catac y provincia d. recuay, departamento d. ancash. con el préstamo d. s/. 2,000.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 8 cuotas, comprará 2 sacos d. azúcar, 2 sacos d. arroz, 1 caja d. aceite, 1 paquete d. sal, 1 bolsa d. sémola, 4 paquetes d. gaseosa d. 1 ½ litro, 4 bolsas d. fideos, 3 paquetes d. yogur grand., 3 paquetes d. yogur chico, 3 cajas d. shampoo, 2 bolsas d. detergente, 4 paquetes d. papel higiénico. ella tiene 48 años d. edad, es casada y tiene 6 hijos ya son mayores e independientes, su esposo tiene trabajos eventuales.

nieves is 52 years old and married with six children. she works very hard to provide for them.

she runs a general store in the philippines and requested a php 20,000 loan through nwtf to purchase additional stocks to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, sugar, etc.

nieves has been in this business for 10 years.

in the future, nieves would like to save money to expand her business.

this time, for her sixth loan cycle, gaudencia is borrowing 14,000 php (philippines pesos) to buy more fish to sell in her food stall. her fish vending business that she previously funded through kiva partner nwtf continues to provide gaudencia and her family with income that is improving their quality of life.

luzmila es socia del banco comunal lila.
luzmila es casada, tiene 41 años y 4 hijos, luzmila junto a su esposo se dedican a la elaboración de bellos tejidos en telares, actividad que realiza con el apoyo de 9 personas, sus productos los comercializa en la ciudad de lima y también una feria en ee.uu.
luzmila necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de hilos.
los sueños de luzmila son que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener mas capital y exportar mas sus productos.

meet alfred! he is a farmer full of positive attitude and passion towards farming. he has been into agriculture since early childhood. despite his age, alfred is very, very hardworking. he is happily married, and together with his wife, is blessed with two children

alfred has identified free space on his farm and wants to fully utilize this space by keeping a good, quality dairy cow. dairy farming in kenya is a very profitable venture and milk prices in the recent past have been going up, so alfred, being a visionary and entrepreneurial man, wants to take full advantage of this. he has chosen the breed of cow that he will keep, and he knows that he will not only get milk from the cow, but also manure, and this will boost the fertility of his farm. selling his milk will never be a problem, because there is a ready market and he will also be selling to big dairy processing firms.

alfred said he chose juhudi kilimo for this loan because they offer agricultural-based loans, and their interest rate is low, and is on a reducing basis. this loan will change his life and will secure the future of his school-going children.

alfred is so thankful for your attention and appreciates you checking his profile.

the person raising her hand in the photo is ruth, 47 years of age and a mother of five children. ruth joined hand in hand in 2013 under a group by the name wabepa farmers and was inducted through business management skills and record keeping by hand in hand east africa, (hih ea).

her main economic activity is goat keeping. she applied for her first loan with hih ea which she used to buy more goats. she now has fifteen goats and has applied for a second loan from kiva which she intends to use to expand the goat pens. 

ruth is grateful to kiva and its lenders for the financial support and  pomises to repay her loan with no default.

edisa mariana, 50, is single living with her 16-year-old daughter in chillanes canton, bolívar province.

the “nueva unión” (new union) communal bank is located in san josé del tambo parish belonging to chillanes canton.  the members of this communal bank are farmers, especially of corn, cocoa beans, rice, oranges, bananas and coffee.

edisa mariana grows cocoa beans, corn and rice.  she also raises chickens to sell later.  she makes her purchases and her sales at the san josé del tambo market every weekend.

she requests the loan to buy farming supplies: fertilizers and manure, for her crops and chicken feed.  the loan will help her meet her economic needs and improve her farming activities.  she faces challenges like the drop in price of the products she sells as well as dealing with middlemen.  

her dream is to have a house of her own and she enjoys going on outings with her daughter and chatting with her neighbors.

chantha’s group live in a rural village in kandal province in cambodia. chantha  work as factory worker and tailor  to support her family. in their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

janet, pictured above, is a group leader and is here representing her group, formed by five farmers in webuye district, kenya. she joined one acre fund for the first time in 2011. she decided to represent her group, because she wanted to be more active in her community. she is married and has four children.

with a portion of this loan, janet will purchase not only maize seed and fertilizer for the coming planting season, but also a solar light. receiving a solar light as part of her loan means that in future, she will be able to reduce the consumption of paraffin fuel, and therefore, to save more money. janet plans to use the profits she gains this year to send her children to school.

in total, janet’s group will use the inputs received from this loan to plant a total of 1.25 acres of land. they will also receive a total of 5 solar lights.

josephine's group members thank kiva lenders for their previous loan. the members used the loan to buy good quality inputs, fertilizers and paid casual laborers to plough their gardens. their harvest doubled from the previous farming seasons.

josephine, the group chairperson, used part of her crop sales to buy three pigs and paid school fees for her children. 

josephine's group request for a new loan to start ploughing new gardens and expand their farms. they will use this new loan to pay casual labours, buy good quality seeds and fertilizers for their new gardens.

angeline c. is a 26-year-old married woman. she has one child who is only five years old. she invested in rice farming and shared that her business is going well. she works hard at her farm because she wants to provide for her family and save up for her child’s future. being a member of cev, an mfi in the philippines and a kiva partner, she can avail of its financial service. she is applying for a loan of php12,000, which she will use to purchase seeds and fertilizers and pay for the laborers who help at the farm.

hashmat is 37 years old. she lives in rawalpindi, pakistan with her six children. her husband is responsible to fulfill the needs of the family. one of her sons is also providing sewing services and earns an income to contribute with the father to manage the house hold. 
hashmat's son needs different kinds of goods, e.g., needles, thread, pieces of clothes, machine oil, etc. for his business, but due to insufficient financial means he is unable to purchase these items. therefore, hashmat has applied for kiva loan from its field partner brac pakistan. this loan will enable her son to purchase these supplies and will be helpful for his increasing his monthly sales and profit by providing better sewing services.
hashmat is very thankful to kiva and brac pakistan.

helen g., from the village of tigdok, tudela, misamis occidental.she is 44 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. to make a living, helen owns and operates a bakery business in the local community. engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 10000 php a month.


in 2009, helen joined pmpc to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. having repaid her previous loan of 10000 php from pmpc that was used to purchase additional raw ingredients for her bakery, she is requesting her seventh loan of 25000 php to expand the business. helen plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.



about pmpc:



paglaum multi-purpose cooperative (pmpc) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern mindanao. it reaches out to the rural poor using the grameen model.



*note: to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by kiva. given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in english while providing quality and accurate information to kiva lenders.

subscribe to updates from this loan

lydia is 42 years old and lives in the town of bungokho in the mbale region of uganda. she is married and has 6 children, who are all currently in school. for the past 5 years, lydia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, where she sells sugar, soap and salt. to help expand her business, lydia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 ugandan shillings from brac uganda. the loan will be used to purchase more food items for sale in her shop, thus helping lydia to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. lydia hopes that in the future she will be able to increase her shop's business. lydia is a member of brac's small enterprise program (sep). the program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like lydia, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

mrs. léa g. was born in cotonou and comes from zè (atlantique department). she lost her husband, colonel jean-pierre batchéoumba, nine years ago and has eight children. mrs. léa g. resells various staples : soap, perfumes, liquor, pasta, canned food, etc. in the beginning, she used to sell shoes and pagnes (colorful african cloth) in the grand market dantokpa in cotonou. following her husband's death, she stopped her business. three years ago, she started her new business. the third loan she's seeking now aims at bolstering her inventory to better meet customer demand.

translated from french by patrick stadelmann, kiva volunteer

osa’s o. is 24 years old, is still single, and lives in benin city. she is a professional hair dresser who studied the business for a year and six months, after which she started her own salon in 2006. the loan amount of $250 will go a long way to improve her business; she will be able to buy more weavons, hair creams, relaxers, and drinks for sale, as well as an additional dryer. she thanks you.

john is a hardworking married man who lives in kamwenge, uganda. he deals in produce, selling rice, coffee and maize as his main source of income though he also practices farming where he earns an extra income. he started this business to have a better standard of living. he faces challenges of competition, price fluctuations and weather changes that affect his produce business. he has a vision of owning a big store and to have educated children.\r\n\r\njohn is requesting for a loan to buy more rice, coffee and maize to sell.

clarita is 50 years old, married, and has four children. she raises pigs in the philippines, which she has been doing for 10 years. 

clarita requested her twentieth third loan from nwtf for 26,000 php, which she will use to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs. in the future, clarita would like to save money to expand her business.

mary is 20 years old, single and supports her parents. she has been running a restaurant for the last two years earning a monthly income of kes 8,000. 

with her first loan of kes 20,000 from kadet ltd, she intends to purchase service items, foodstuffs and other food supplies. the anticipated profits will be used to support running the restaurant's business.

her future dreams are to grow her business and to be financially stable in the future.

paul is a 39-year-old male. he is married with six children, aged 20, 18, 17, 15, 13 and 10 years old, whom he supports. this is his seventh loan of kes 100,000.

he was introduced to visionfund kenya by the visionfund officer. he does bicycle repairs and services. he has been in this business for seven years, and he earns a monthly income of kes 20,000.
