this is a group loan with five members from battambang province. mrs. roeut y., a 35 year old fish seller, is the leader of the group loan. she owns and runs a small store in the beung chok market. she sells fish, dried fish and fish paste and earns a profit of approximately $3 per day. mrs. y.'s husband is oun chomnan who is a 34 year old motorcycle taxi driver. they have three children who are currently attending school. mrs.y. is requesting a loan to purchase fish for her business. 

there are four other borrowers in this group loan including sen p. (age 35), sen l. (age 20), ly p. (age 28) and bil s. (age 27). they all require loans to buy more fish for their fish businesses.

sari-sari stores are seen everywhere in the philippines. sari-sari means "variety". since then, they provide the people with products mostly needed for everyday survival - from products for personal hygiene such as shampoo, toothpaste, and powder to condiments, food, canned goods and other stuffs at a low cost. this is why many of those who want to go into business often start by being a sari-sari vendor because with just a small capital, you can automatically operate a store and earn.

it\'s just like salve, 55 years old, from pasay city, metro manila. she began being involved in this kind of business five years ago. and through all those years, she was able to provide her children a living through the income she gets from the store. what she does is basically buy stuffs in a large quantity and then display them at her store and sell them at retail, often at a price that is very affordable for people but is larger than the original price so she can have a profit.

however, you cannot expect a regular and stable income from this since sales vary from time to time. for this reason, salve wants to ask you for a php 15,000 loan that she will use to buy more supplies of products to display in her store. certainly, this will really help her improve her business and attract more customers.

she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the word of god she studies.

*all cct community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

meet margarita. she is the mother of a child. she has been in the nursing aide program for one year. she is happy and feels that she made the best choice of programs. she wants to finish her studies as she wants a good future for her and her daughter. 

she likes this career and feels more and more attached to it. from the beginning she has been attracted to all the subjects they have studied and she wants to continue in the field. she would like to be a head nurse. if she can continue to progress and things go well in her career she would like to study pediatrics at university.

she would like a loan from kiva as she is a single mother who is still a minor who has not had the chance to work yet. she lives with her mother who is a salesperson who makes a minimum wage. her mother is the person responsible for her and her child and for her own expenses. the truth is margarita doesn't want to abandon her dream. she hopes people can help her and she is sincerely grateful.

luis lives in a common-law relationship with his partner and children in the achin community, chillanes canton, in bolívar province. he is engaged in raising and selling livestock.  he says that he will invest the loan in the purchase of breeding beef cattle, dairy cows, fertilizer, and vaccines for care.  luis’ dream is to increase his livestock. he spends his free time with his family, and he enjoys the carnival

in this time of high unemployment, susiati feels tremendous economic pressure in her poor family. susiati started a small convenience store that sells daily household goods, like rice, vegetables, spices. each day she needs $20 capital to buy goods to be sold. she usually earns $5 daily profit. she uses earnings from her store to pay for daily expenses totaling $2, including school fees for her children who is in 3rd grade and to feed her 1 year 8 months infant child. susiati and her family lives in their own home. susiati hopes that her business will grow to be able to sustain her family's economy, and support her children to higher education levels.

translated from indonesian by kresna hartandi, kiva volunteer

tekanan ekonomi bagi keluarga kurang mampu sangat terasa akibatnya sekarang ini, pekerjaan yang sulit, apalagi bagi kehidupan susiati, meskipun begitu susiati membuka usaha warung di rumahnya dengan menjual berbagai macam jenis barang dagangan mulai dari sembako sampai keperluan sehari –hari. modal usaha yang dibutuhkan per hari rp 200.000,- dan dari modal tersebut bisa mendatangkan keuntungan rp 50.000 dari hasil berjualan itu ia gunakan untuk biaya hidupnya rp. 20.000,- perhari termasuk biaya sekolah anaknya yang baru kelas 3 sekolah dasar dan yang seorang lagi baru berumur 1 th 8 bln. susiati dan keluarganya tinggal di sebuah rumah milik mereka sendiri. susiati berharap usahanya kelak akan berkembang untuk menunjang perekonomian keluarganya serta menunjang akan cita-cita anaknya dapat sekolah sampai ke tingkat yang lebih tinggi.

ms. naseem is a 35-year-old married woman; her husband has been doing a business of wristwatch sales for many years. the man shown in the photo is naseem’s husband; he offers various types of watches in different designs and colors and earns a sufficient amount of income to contribute to the family income. 

in order to purchase more variety of watches in different sizes and designs, considering the choice of his customers, naseem contacted kashf foundation and applied for a loan of rs. 20,000. it will help him to grow his sales which ultimately helps in generating more cash. naseem is in her 2nd loan cycle with a good repayment history and hopes to have a good experience with the new loan.

\r\n\r\npatricia, 47, lives with her husband and their two children who help out with her business. they happily live together in their own home. three years ago patricia felt it would be profitable to start selling prepared meals. she is a native of the peruvian jungle region and known for preparing the tasty dishes of that region. she works based on prior orders because she doesn't have space to serve customers. she prepares food for those who request it and they pay according to their weekly consumption. patricia is happy because her work makes her happy. she takes care of her customers in the morning and in the afternoons she shops in preparation for the next day. for the future, she would like to improve her business by having a space to set up her restaurant. she is a long-standing client of mfp. however, this is her first individual loan; before, she was part of a communal bank and known for being very responsible with respect to repayments. with the funds requested she will buy larger amounts of ingredients to prepare her delicious dishes in order to meet her goals little by little.

translated from spanish by michael bujazan, kiva volunteer

this is aida, 57, a resident of batasan, quezon city, philippines. she has children and they manage their own household while operating the business. at this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

aida operates a rug-making business. she mainly offers rugs, from round palm-sized ones to much larger doormats and other crafts that most rug makers come up every day. as rugs are a major part of filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. aida's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  she earns a minimum of php 500 in sales every day.

to help her continue operations of her business, aida is requesting a php 50,000 loan. she will use the loan to buy more raw materials like fabric, thread, and other items for her business.

aida dreams of having another place for her business and hopes to support her children financially. she meets with her co-fellowship members every week to share stories of her life and business and also to draw strength and inspiration from the word of god, which she studies.

* all cct community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. a fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. the fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

edison, 22, is a young entrepreneur living with his parents.  he completed secondary school and lives in san rafael la capilla that belongs to otavalo in imbabura province.  this is a place with much tourism.  most people living around him work as craftsmen making and selling reed mats.  edison sells these mats in the city of napo.

he’s been doing this since the age of 15 having learned from his parents who also sell mats.  he stopped going to school in order to go into this business because the lack of economic resources made staying in school impossible and now with the business he’s been able to learn much and also help at home with basic household expenses and utility costs.

he works from 5 in the morning until 6 in the evening going through the streets in the city to sell from street market to street market.  moving about has always been difficult because he must carry his merchandise on his back; he sells mats of various sizes.

the mats are made from ‘totora’ [texture of sedge, flags, or rushes] and depending on their size can take up to two hours to weave but they are very attractive to tourists.

now edison is asking for a loan to increase his merchandise for the christmas season in which sales tend to improve to increase business and meet household needs and also to pay debts he has.  edison is very grateful to fundación alternativa and to kiva for giving him the opportunity of continuing to increase his merchandise and to increase sales thus improving his life style.

raymond is 61 years old and lives in the suburbs of antsirabe. he is the father of four children and is devoted to his family. for eleven years, he has been selling chickens. this business covers the day-to-day needs of his family and enables him to build up a savings account. he must cover a very long distance to reach the big market where he makes his sales. for this loan, he is going to purchase 50 chickens, which he will sell at the big market. his goal has to do with his family’s well-being.

azra is a 48-year-old married woman living in the area of lahore, pakistan. she is pictured with her husband.

he is a chef by profession; he provides cooking services for marriage ceremonies, parties, and funfairs. he cooks delicious pakistani food such as biryani, qorma, roast chicken and fish, and in sweet dishes he prepares firni and kheer. he is a very famous chef in his town, and most of the people like the cooked food from him. sometimes he has to cook many dishes at a time. recently, he faced the problem due to a shortage of a cauldron.

therefore, azra has requested a loan from kiva's field partner brac pakistan, so that her husband can be able to buy a new cauldron, spices, and fire wood for cooking food.

azra is the mother of five children; she is very thankful to kiva and field partner brac pakistan for this honourable support.

justus is 21 years old. he is not married and still does not have children yet. 

he has had a retail shop business for one year and has requested for a loan which he will use to purchase maize, beans, sugar, salt, milk, tea leaves and soaps, and hopes this will help him to expand his retail shop.

this is his second loan with visionfund kenya of kes. 25,000.

his hopes and dreams for the future are to build a house and get married.

mercedes is 72 years old and he studied until fifth grade. he lives with his partner; his children are already of age and they all have their own family.

mercedes has been working to provide for himself since he was very young. his father taught him traditional fishery. he has been working selling essential goods and sweets for few years. in this way he has acquired experience in the business and this is the reason why he continues to sell in his shop.

he is requesting this loan to buy more essential products such as sugar, coffee, bread, eggs, spices, sweets, drinks, etc, to stock his shop.

he hopes to continue having the strength to take care of himself and to cover his household's needs.

mercedes del carmen a. p. is 22, and she lives in the la borgoña neighborhood. this is a neighborhood where the inhabitants have scant resources. she has devoted herself to farming for 11 years. one of the main problems that she has encountered has been the drought that threatens the crops. she started working in this field thanks to her father, who supported her economically. she now feels capable of asking for a loan to buy fertilizers and seeds to diversify the production. she also wants to open the door to new working businesses such as opening a clothing store.

translated from spanish by ginny kalish, kiva volunteer

sajida  is 34 years old, married woman. she is been involved in the business of cloth trade. she purchases variety of cloth at low prices from city market and sells them in her own town. she has a strong customer base. sajida  has requested for a loan of 50000 pkr. she wants  to buy greater variety of cloth in different colors for her business to get boost in her earnings with her loan
